HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mixed Showing for the Dollar As Early Selloff Is Overcome

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar overcame a selloff caused by negative comments from top German central bank officials yesterday, rebounding on a Commerce Department report that showed a healthy United States economy with benign inflation.
The currency finished the day mixed against most major currencies, as it completed one of its strongest monthly advances against the yen and mark. Traders said the underlying upward trend for the dollar had not changed. 
 "The market was like a yo-yo today," said Elena Shperling, chief currency trader for the Banco di Sicilia's New York branch.
In New York, the dollar settled at 121.38 yen, down from 121.79 yen late Thursday, but still up 5.45 yen, or 4.7 percent, compared with the end of December. The dollar was at 1.6383 marks, up from 1.6368 Thursday. For the month, the dollar rose nearly 6.3 percent against the mark.
The pound declined broadly on diminished expectations that interest rates would rise in Britain anytime soon. In New York, a pound cost $1.6007, down from $1.6213 Thursday and the lowest level in more than three months.
The dollar began the day rebounding against Asian currencies on diminished fears that the Bank of Japan might intervene to sell dollars to defend the yen.
But the dollar dropped later when two senior members of the Bundesbank made comments that were interpreted as signals to sell the dollar.
One of the German officials, Guntram Palm, head of the Bundesbank regional bank in Stuttgart, said that Germany's exports were already benefiting from the mark's depreciation and that a further weakness in Germany's currency would not necessarily help.
The dollar's declines were limited, reflecting a prevailing view in the market that influential finance officials were simply trying to control the dollar's ascent by making occasional comments.
The dollar rebounded later when the Commerce Department reported that the economy grew at a 4.7 percent annualized rate in the final three months of 1996, far stronger than the 3.8 percent that many economists had expected. But a measure of inflation in the report was much weaker than had been expected.

HEADLINE: C. E. Inniss, 61; Was a Leader In Many Causes

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Charles E. Inniss, a retired vice president of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and the chairman of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, died on Thursday at Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. Mr. Inniss, who lived in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, was 61.
The cause was cancer, said his wife, Marjorie. 
 Mr. Inniss devoted his life to community, social and educational concerns. A partial list of his titles at his death included trustee of the City University of New York, chairman of the university's Construction Corporation, trustee and past chairman of the Studio Museum in Harlem and a director of the Brooklyn Children's Museum, the Catholic Interracial Council, the Marcus Garvey Nursing Home in Brooklyn and the Staten Island Zoological Society.
At the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, a nonprofit community development group in Brooklyn where he became a director in 1983 and was elected chairman in 1994, Mr. Inniss helped establish and develop the Bedford-Stuyvesant Family Health Center, the Billie Holiday Theater and the corporation's Center for Art and Culture. He first served the corporation as its director of area development from 1969 to 1973.
At various times and in various capacities he also helped the Brooklyn Arts Council, the Mayor's New York City Advisory Cultural Commission, the American Gas Foundation and the Black Officer's Association. He was a retired captain of the 369th Artillery Battalion of the Army National Guard.
Mr. Inniss joined Brooklyn Union Gas in 1979 as an assistant manager in public relations and communications. He retired in 1995 as vice president for community affairs.
"Responsibility was taught in the home," Mr. Inniss's brother, Wilbur, said. "Caring for people was taught in the home, and my brother loved people."
Mr. Inniss was born in Harlem and spent the formative years of his childhood in the East Bronx. His parents, Edna and Stanley Inniss, had come to the United States from Barbados and Canada.
He graduated from Evander Childs High School and in 1968 earned a Bachelor of Science degree in economics from New York University. He began his career as an assistant district service manager for Dun & Bradstreet Corporation.
In 1980, Mr. Inniss received a master's degree in public information from N.Y.U. His honors included a Doctor of Laws degree from St. Joseph's College in Brooklyn.
In addition to his wife, the former Marjorie Thomas, and his brother, Wilbur, who lives on Staten Island, Mr. Inniss is survived by two sisters, Norma and Frances, both of the Bronx.

HEADLINE: Nissan Motor Cutting Jobs in U.S. Marketing Unit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Faced with stagnant sales and worried about what the consolidation of car dealerships will mean for auto makers, the Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. is eliminating several hundred jobs in its 2,500-member marketing staff through early retirements, incentives to leave and dismissals.
Nissan executives said today that the cutbacks reflected purely a strategic decision to combine many management functions and reduce costs. "We had accumulated a bureaucracy over 35 years that was really working against our intentions to be a small, nimble company," said Robert S. Thomas, the American unit's president. 
 But Wall Street analysts and even some people close to the company said that the steps were a sign of trouble at Nissan, which suffered a 2.7 percent drop in American sales last year.
For example, in the hot market for sport utility vehicles, Toyota has already introduced the small RAV-4 and Honda will come out with its slightly larger CRV in mid-February, but Nissan's offering is still a year and a half away from introduction.
Also, Nissan's latest advertising campaign, aimed at building long-term brand recognition, has actually coincided with a drop in sales in the last several months. And Nissan's mainstay cars, the Sentra and the Altima, face heavy competition.
While Nissan contends that the job cuts are a response to the steady consolidation among dealerships, auto analysts suspect that that element is only part of the story. "I would take it as kind of a confirmation that the news has been bad, they're probably overstaffed and they're not expected to get any better," said Jay N. Woodworth, an auto industry consultant in Summit, N.J.
Nissan has offered early retirement to 280 eligible employees and asked that 200 more volunteer for severance packages, and has warned of possible layoffs ahead. The company reduced the number of vice presidents last year to six from nine. Last week, Nissan forced out 4 of its 24 directors, the management tier just below vice president; Mr. Thomas said those positions would not be filled.
Nissan's American marketing operations have been criticized in recent years as bloated, and the company has little opportunity to expand sales because its main American factory, in Smyrna, Tenn., is already operating at full capacity. But with most of its offerings in the car market, and few in the lucrative markets for sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and full-size pickup trucks, Nissan has been forced to offer generous incentives to buyers, a step that tends to erode profit margins.
Mr. Thomas is one of the auto industry's most outspoken advocates of reducing marketing and distribution costs, which include not only car dealers' costs and profits but also rebates, lease subsidies and advertising campaigns. These costs run as much as 30 percent of the cost of a new car.
At a time when the Ford Motor Company, for example, has decided to save a dime on each Ford Explorer by no longer painting the inside of the ashtrays, big auto makers still have a dozen or more dealerships in each big city. That means that car prices have to be high enough to support the salaries of a dozen dealership general managers, finance managers and other dealership staff positions, as well as a sizable staff at each auto maker to stay in touch with all of the dealerships.
A labyrinth of state laws, often written by lobbyists for dealership groups, prevents auto makers from shutting down excess dealerships. But the recent wave of dealership purchases by publicly traded companies like Republic Industries has begun to produce some consolidation in dealerships.
Mr. Thomas said that he welcomed this consolidation, while warning auto makers in a recent speech at the Automotive News World Congress here that more needed to be done.
"Your entire wholesale and retail distribution, logistics and retailer support networks need thrifting," he said. "You have huge, unnecessary expenses in those areas, as well as in Government-mandated emission and regulatory areas, which could be shared and consolidated as an industry without interfering with brand marketing differentiation concerns."
Christopher Cedergren, the managing director of Nextrend Inc., a consulting firm in Thousand Oaks, Calif., said that while Nissan might have a few difficulties, particularly in the short term, the company's decision to cut marketing staff was likely to be followed at some point by other auto makers. The room for further economies in the manufacturing of cars is shrinking after years of aggressive cost reductions by all big auto makers.
"The next frontier is the marketing side," he said.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Rally as Inflation Stays Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices gained yesterday as a flurry of economic reports failed to persuade bond investors that inflation had become a problem.
Investors were confident that Federal Reserve policy makers, who start a two-day meeting on Tuesday, would not raise short-term interest rates. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond surged 31/32 , to 9612/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.78 percent from 6.86 percent. A week ago the yield was 6.88 percent.
Prices received a strong early push as short-sellers bought securities to cover potential losses after a report on the fourth-quarter gross domestic product showed little inflationary pressure.
Short-sellers are speculators who sell borrowed Treasury securities on the premise that if the market declines they can later buy back the securities at an even lower price, pocketing the difference as profit. But if prices rise, they can incur big losses.
While the G.D.P. rise was higher than expected, at 4.7 percent, investors were heartened by the weak gains in the report's price indexes. The chain-weighted price index rose 1.8 percent, compared with 2 percent in the third quarter. And the implicit price deflator -- a measure of inflation -- gained 1.4 percent, after rising 1.7 percent in the third quarter.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said the G.D.P. provided convincing evidence that inflation was not yet a problem.
"It's obvious that many investors continue to be favorably surprised by an economy that can generate two quarters of 4.7 percent growth in a given year while still generating a G.D.P. price deflator that remains will within the zone of acceptability for the U.S. central bank," he said.
The market's momentum increased after a survey by the Chicago Purchasing Management Association came in weaker than expected. The managers' index fell to 55.9 in January from 57.1 in December.
The tame price components within the report on G.D.P. helped to ease investor fears generated by the large 4.7 percent increase.
One piece of data not released yesterday was December's sale of new homes. The Commerce Department said it was delaying the release until at least Tuesday because of a processing error in its statistics.
Next week most investors will be focusing on the National Association of Purchasing Management survey on Monday and the employment report on Friday.
Mr. Chan of Banc One Investments said that if next Friday's employment report was surprising on the wage front, it would be difficult for investors to maintain the positive sentiment of yesterday's market.
Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York, said what strength was reported in some of the G.D.P. components was probably not sustainable, like the jump in exports.
"There is no chance of a rate hike next week," he said, "which will help the markets to do better into February, but looking further ahead, I think both the markets and the Fed will have to deal with evidence of brisk growth, with this weighing on the bond market. And the Fed will probably tighten if this growth is accompanied by lower unemployment or higher inflation."

HEADLINE: Congress Is Asked to Speed Money for Family Planning Overseas

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
President Clinton formally asked Congress today to speed its financing of overseas family-planning programs, setting up what abortion opponents call the first abortion-related vote in the new Congress. The vote must be held by Feb. 28.
In a report to Congress, the Agency for International Development said a delay in financing would result in a serious shortage of contraceptives in at least 60 countries, including 50 million condoms, 500,000 intrauterine devices and 4.8 million cycles of birth-control pills. It could also mean shutting down 17 of 95 overseas programs. 
 Congress decided last year to delay the spending for another four months. But the consequences of doing so, the report said, "would be increased unintended pregnancies, more abortions, higher numbers of maternal and infant deaths and, of course, more births."
Abortion opponents on Capitol Hill have said the family-planning money was being used to promote and perform abortions, and the report repeatedly addressed that concern.
"As a matter of longstanding law and policy of this and previous Administrations," it said, "U.S.A.I.D. funds may not be used either to fund abortions or as a method of family planning or to motivate any person to have an abortion."
The Administration is seeking to move up to March, from July, the monthly installments of $385 million that Congress allocated in 1996 for overseas family planning.
The agreement said that if the Administration could make a case by Feb. 1 that withholding the money until July was damaging family-planning programs, Congress would vote by Feb. 28 on whether to allow the money to be released by March 1. Today's report was the Administration's effort to show that those programs were being damaged.
Citing the successes of the 30 years of United States involvement in family planning overseas, the report said the world had 500 million fewer people than it would have had without contraception. The average woman in the developing world now gives birth to four children instead of six.
It also said family planning had reduced abortions worldwide, especially in the former Soviet Union, where abortions were the primary form of birth control and the average woman had nearly three of them.

HEADLINE: Suit Says 'Cats' Character Was Much Too Frisky

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Bill Maher, the host of the ABC talk show "Politically Incorrect," says crime may be down in New York, but nobody can do anything about "Cats." Well, someone is trying.
"Cats," the Broadway musical that played its 5,988th performance at the Winter Garden Theater last night, apparently on its way to eclipsing the Broadway record of 6,137 held by "A Chorus Line," is being sued over No. 5,561. 
 On the night of that performance, Jan. 30, 1996, Evelyn Amato, an unemployed office worker who lives in Manhattan, was sitting in a fourth-row orchestra seat with her fiance, Dennis Melendez, and several members of his family.
In the lawsuit that Ms. Amato, who is in her early 30's, filed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, she contends that just before intermission, an actor, David Hibbard, dressed as the feline character Rum Tum Tugger, came off the stage and as a packed house watched, attacked her as part of the show.
The suit -- for assault, battery, invasion of privacy, violation of civil rights, negligence, intentional infliction of emotional distress and false imprisonment -- asks for $6 million in punitive and compensatory damages. It names as defendants Mr. Hibbard, who is no longer in the show; the Shubert Organization, which owns the theater; the director, Trevor Nunn; the producer, Cameron Mackintosh, and the composer, Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber.
It does not name T. S. Eliot, whose poems supplied the show with its lyrics.
The suit was filed a year to the day after the alleged assault, the last day allowed under the statute of limitations.
No one connected with the musical had any comment yesterday. Mr. Hibbard did not respond to a message left at his home.
"Cats," with its saccharine melodies and elaborate, whiskered costumery, was never a critical favorite, but it has been immensely popular. In a part of the show, several of its characters, dressed like, well, cats, roam out into the audience and behave in character, purring and snuggling and so on.
But last Jan. 30, Ms. Amato contends, Mr. Hibbard did far more than that. She said in an interview that Mr. Hibbard yanked her handbag from her and twice pulled her to her feet to try to get her to dance with him. Both times, she said, she shouted, "No."
"I didn't want to be a part of whatever he was going to do to me," she said. "I was afraid after he'd pulled me up so hard. I was petrified, as a matter of fact."
When she sat down for the second time, she said, Mr. Hibbard leapt onto the arms of her seat.
"He crouched down and started moving his hips back and forth, saying, 'Boom, boom, boom,' " Ms. Amato said. "He was moving his groin back and forth. If I hadn't turned my head he would have rubbed it in my face."
After that, she said, Mr. Hibbard grabbed her head and shook it from side to side, mussing her hair.
"The audience was laughing at me," she said. "I was totally humiliated."
She said she was unaware that yesterday was the final day she could legally file her suit. Her lawyer, Michael G. O'Neill, whom Ms. Amato said she found in the Yellow Pages, called the date a coincidence.
Mr. O'Neill said his client sent a letter to the show's general manager, Nina Lannan, and two months later received an apology with an offer of tickets to see the show again.
"That's like offering someone another ticket on the Titanic," Mr. O'Neill said, dismissing the suggestion that the suit might be frivolous.
"She didn't consent to this," he said. "She wasn't warned that someone might sit in front of her and thrust his pelvis in her face. She doesn't find public, simulated sex acts enjoyable or entertaining."

HEADLINE: Unocal Signs Burmese Gas Deal; U.S. May Ban Such Accords

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration weighs whether to impose a ban on new American investment in Myanmar because of its human rights abuses, the Unocal Corporation has signed a deal with the Burmese Government to greatly expand its rights to explore and develop gas fields off the coast.
The agreement was announced by Unocal on Thursday, the same day the State Department, in its annual human rights review, condemned the killing and torture of dissidents and ethnic minorities in Myanmar, formerly Burma. Though Unocal's statement made no mention of it, company officials confirmed today that the Burmese Government was paid a signing bonus of several million dollars. 
 In recent weeks, Administration officials say, there has been growing discussion in the White House and at the State Department about banning new investment in Myanmar by American companies; a new law empowers President Clinton to impose sanctions if repression there worsens or if Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel peace laureate and opposition leader, is detained again.
The State Department report notes that in recent months, Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi "has been severely restricted in her ability to receive visitors," and that at least 147 members of her party have been arrested.
Unocal would be a major target of that ban, because it is already the largest American investor in Myanmar. Another major American company that once operated there, Pepsico Inc., announced earlier this week that it would join a growing list of companies that are pulling out, partly because of protests by rights groups.
Unocal denied today that it had acted quickly to strike the deal before any investment ban.
"We do not believe that the sanctions are about to be implemented, and we hope they won't be," Barry Lane, a spokesman for the company, said today. "We believe sanctions are not good policy, and the best policy is engagement."
Mr. Lane added: "We would never enter into a contract in haste. We have been negotiating the terms of this contract for six or nine months, and the Ministry of Energy in Myanmar set the date for the signing ceremony."
Unocal's decision puts the Administration in much the same position it found itself in early 1995, when the Conoco Corporation announced a major deal with Iran. President Clinton ultimately ordered the company to void the contract and barred American companies from investing in Iran. Conoco's deal was picked up by the French oil company Total, Unocal's partner in Myanmar.
But some in the Administration, including in the National Economic Council, have argued that a similar ban on investment in Myanmar would be useless because other nations are eager to trade there. This week Japan protested to the State Department about a Massachusetts law that prohibits the state from doing business with any company that does business in Myanmar; those companies include Sony and many of Japan's automakers.
Others in the Administration fear that a ban on doing business with Myanmar in the name of human rights would open the White House to more criticism of its China policy. That policy, reiterated by President Clinton just a few days ago, holds that continued trade and investment in China will ultimately bring freedom to the country.
"There's a struggle on to come up with a way to differentiate China policy from Burma policy," one of Mr. Clinton's top economic aides said recently. "And here's what it comes down to: China's too rich to mess with, and Burma isn't."
Unocal and Total are already partners in developing the Yadana gas field, a $1.2 billion project that includes a pipeline to pump gas to Thailand. The new contract calls for the exploration of an adjacent field that covers more than 4,200 square miles.
The Yadana project has been a constant source of lawsuits, protests and problems for Unocal.
The International Labor Organization has accused Myanmar of using forced labor to guard the pipeline, and State Department officials say there is credible evidence that the Burmese military has leveled towns in the path of the pipeline construction. Villagers either are told to go elsewhere or are pressed into work for the military, the officials say.
Unocal says it does not have evidence of any such abuses, and notes that all of the Burmese it employs are well paid. The State Department report confirmed that, saying, "The preponderance of evidence indicates that the pipeline project has paid its workers at least a market wage."

HEADLINE: U.S. ECONOMY RISES BY A STRONG 4.7% AS INFLATION DIPS

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Powered by a surge in exports, the economy grew at a surprisingly vigorous 4.7 percent pace during the final 1996 quarter, more than twice as fast as during the summer, the Government reported today.
Despite this latest surge, coming after nearly five years of steady growth that has kept factories humming and unemployment at low levels, the economy showed almost no signs of strain. Indeed, inflation by one important measure shriveled to the lowest point in 30 years. 
 The upbeat economic figures -- instead of frightening the securities market as they have so often in the past -- were so well balanced that they were greeted unusually warmly on Wall Street. Convinced that the Federal Reserve will find no reason to raise interest rates at its policy meeting next week, traders pushed interest rates down and the stock market up. The Dow Jones industrial average fell slightly at the end of the day, but all the broad market indicators gained ground. [Page 37.]
For the full year, the Commerce Department reported, the nation's real gross domestic product -- the broadest measure of the total output of goods and services by the American economy after adjustments to eliminate the effects of inflation -- advanced 2.5 percent.
With the most recent recession having ended in March 1991, the current expansion is now approaching its sixth anniversary. Since World War II, only two expansions have been longer -- from 1961 to 1969 and from 1982 to 1990.
At the White House, Vice President Al Gore hailed the report as part of "a galaxy" of favorable economic data and "another resounding affirmation" of Administration policy. "The American economy is growing and a land of new promise is emerging," he said.
Because of the low rate of inflation and the absence of any signals that the domestic economy might be on the verge of overheating, private economists agreed that the Federal Reserve did not need to tighten monetary policy soon. Indeed, analysts said the economy might well have already started to slow down as it entered the new year, pushing a possible rate increase by the Federal Reserve even further off. into the future.
Several analysts lowered their estimates for the first-quarter growth because it appeared that many companies had little need to increase output an extra amount to replenish shelves and rebuild other inventories.
David Hensley, a senior economist at Salomon Brothers, said he now expected the economy to grow at a rate of about 2 percent from January through March instead of 2.5 percent.
That slow but steady pace is widely regarded as fast enough to provide enough new jobs for an expanding work force but not so fast as to risk driving up inflation. And some economists said that the combination of low unemployment and low inflation that the economy has enjoyed for many months may well continue.
"The economy's more productive," said John O. Wilson, chief economist at the Bank of America. So while the jobless rate, now 5.3 percent, is "way below" the point where in the past inflation would already have started to rise at a more rapid pace, "we're just aren't seeing it," he said.
The blistering rise in exports -- which accounted for nearly half the growth estimated for the quarter compared with their normal 11 percent share of the economy -- was a central factor in the strong pace of growth. But export growth is expected to slow this year because the stronger dollar and weak growth among the nation's major trading partners will make it harder for American companies to sell abroad.
And while consumer spending revived during the fourth quarter on all counts -- big-ticket items, nondurables and services -- it too was expected to slow.
The 4.7 percent growth rate matched the pace of last spring and has not been surpassed since the spring of 1994.
"This is not the kind of strength that's likely to continue," said Paul W. Boltz, economist at T. Rowe Price in Baltimore.
The report also confirmed earlier indications that the housing market had softened -- this sector has now been a drag on G.D.P. for two consecutive quarters -- and showed that investment by business in new equipment fell for the first time in five years.
A Commerce Department report on sales of new homes in December that was scheduled to be published today was postponed until Tuesday. The department said it found in a final review that it had "misprocessed" the data.
Changes in the level of inventories, which are often a key force in sudden surges and quick drops in the economy, had almost no effect on the rate of growth in the fourth quarter. While expectations that the economy will slow on its own contributed to the sense that there is little risk that prices are likely to rise soon, analysts also took comfort in the fact that important inflation figures themselves have remained remarkably low. The implicit price deflator rose just 1.4 percent in the final 1996 quarter, the skimpiest rise since the beginning of 1967.
This "just jumped right out," said Deborah Johnson, senior economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in New York.
A different gauge of price pressure that measures domestic prices only climbed 2.5 percent compared with 1.9 percent but would have edged lower had it not been for a surge in energy prices that reversed a third-quarter decline.
From the fourth quarter of 1995 to the fourth quarter of 1996, the increase in G.D.P. was 3.4 percent compared with 1.3 percent a year earlier.
Data included in the gross domestic product for the third quarter of 1996 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: Debt Crisis Adds to Woes Of Car Lender

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 31

 BODY:
A bookkeeping scandal at the Mercury Finance Company pushed the used-auto-loan giant further into financial straits today as banks balked at providing new short-term financing to cover $17 million in the company's debt that is coming due.
Shares of Mercury, which had not traded since Tuesday, before the accounting irregularities were disclosed, plunged 86 percent today. 
 Mercury has been struggling to line up new financing not just for the debt due today but also for approximately $75 million in borrowing due next week.
The company, which is based in Lake Forest, Ill., a Chicago suburb, disclosed the irregularities on Wednesday, attributing them to unauthorizied entries by its longtime controller, James A. Doyle. The company said that its earnings had been overstated by $90 million during four years and that earnings had declined since 1994, instead of rising sharply, as previously reported.
Analysts said today that they expected Mercury to seek bankruptcy protection if it could not obtain funds.
A spokesman for Mercury said that the company's focus had been on trying to resolve its liquidity problem. The spokesman, Joseph Kopec of the Dilenschneider Group, a public relations firm hired to deal with the crisis, declined to comment further on the debt situation.
Mr. Kopec did say that the law firm of Kirkland & Ellis, which the company's board had hired as investigators, had been unable to reach either Mr. Doyle or his lawyer, Joseph Duffy. Mercury dismissed Mr. Doyle on Wednesday after saying that he had disappeared,
Mr. Duffy told the Dow Jones News Service on Thursday that Mr. Doyle was cooperating with Federal authorities in an investigation of what Mr. Duffy said was an accounting "charade" that involved other Mercury employees as well.
The Wall Street Journal, citing an unidentified person, reported today that the Securities and Exchange Commission was looking into Mercury's accounting.
Mr. Duffy also said that Mr. Doyle looked forward to cooperating with an independent investigation by Mercury's outside directors.
Mr. Duffy did not return telephone calls and Mr. Doyle could not be reached.
Wall Street's concerns about Mercury peaked shortly after 2 P.M., when the company's shares resumed trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Faced with a growing likelihood that the company would file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, investors raced to sell. The initial plunge of 88 percent, to $1.625, wiped more than $2.3 billion off the company's value.
The shares later moved up slightly to end at $2.125, down $12.75. Mercury led the Big Board in trading volume, with 42 million shares changing hands.
Mercury is "very close to some reorganization, bankruptcy filing, probably a voluntary reorganization," Thomas Kmiotek, an analyst with the Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company, told Reuters.
Analysts said that the value of the company's loans to auto buyers appeared to far exceed its debts. The financial problem, in essence, is that the cash from the auto loans will flow too slowly to make scheduled payments on the company's debt. Normally such a shortfall is covered by revolving credit lines from banks, but they are now reluctant to provide such credit.
"I think it's oversold, but I don't know what it's worth," said Joseph Jolson, who follows Mercury and other consumer loan companies for Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "It's obvious they are not insolvent in the normal business sense, but we just don't have enough information."
A number of lawsuits, meanwhile, have been filed against Mercury, its executives and others involved in Mercury's accounting.
The lawsuits contend that company executives received higher salaries and bonuses because of the inflated growth figures and were able to sell stock at inflated prices.
"We would expect our class action to proceed against the auditors and the company's executives even if Mercury itself gets protection in bankruptcy," said Steven Schulman, a New York lawyer handling a suit filed late Thursday in the United States District Court here.
KPMG Peat Marwick, Mercury's auditor, is named as a defendant in some of the suits. If those suits go forward, they could lead to a test of recent protections for auditors in such class-action securities lawsuits.
Executives of Mercury did not return calls requesting comments about the lawsuits. KPMG said it had not seen any lawsuit naming it as a defendant and could not comment.

HEADLINE: Mayor Rebuts Criticism Of Budget Plan

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani staunchly defended his new preliminary budget yesterday against criticism that he had not done enough to address New York City's long-term financial ills, maintaining that he had devoted a significant portion of a $1.2 billion windfall in tax revenues to whittling down future deficits.
The Mayor acknowledged that he had ordered some new spending, particularly at the Board of Education, but he maintained that the increase was judicious because it was only one half of 1 percent. 
 He noted that he had apportioned 42 percent, or 500 million, of the new money to help reduce projected shortfalls over the next few years. He allocated the other 58 percent, or $700 million, for tax cuts and new spending.
"The fact is that we have reduced the deficits that New York City faces by more than has been done in any recent year, more than has been done actually in any one of the last 10 years," the Mayor said on his weekly radio show.
Mr. Giuliani's comments stoked a debate over how the city should handle its new-found good fortune, which stems largely from surging profits on Wall Street.
Some experts who analyze the city's finances contend that the Mayor should have essentially applied most or all of the unexpected revenue to reduce future deficits.
They questioned whether Mr. Giuliani had loosened up a bit as he begins his re-election campaign in an effort to move beyond his reputation as a fiscal conservative who repeatedly tried to cut or hold spending steady in his first three years in office. These experts said Mr. Giuliani had made some progress in dealing with the city's chronic budget problems, yet they added that the long-term prognosis was still troublesome. By the Mayor's own projections, for example, the city still faces a gap of $2.54 billion in the year 2001. The budget that year, including money raised from city, state and Federal sources, is projected to be $36 billion.
"I think that the jury is mixed here, frankly," said Martin Arrick, a director at Standard & Poor's, the bond rating firm. "The real issue is that there are still large persistent gaps."
While the arguments about deficits and spending levels may appear arcane, they have an important impact on everyday lives. Future deficits are an important indicator of the stability of the municipal government's finances. If the gaps continue to loom, officials usually have to cut services, raise taxes or employ fiscal gimmicks to balance the budget. The Mayor, for example, ordered $550 million in cuts in his preliminary spending plan.
In addition, when bond rating agencies see governments repeatedly struggling to close gaps, it often leads them to lower the governments' credit ratings, which increases their borrowing costs. That in turn siphons away money that could otherwise be used for services.
Mr. Giuliani suggested in an interview that the fiscal monitors approached the budget as a sheet of numbers, caring little about its ultimate effect on the citizenry. He said that if he reduced spending or scaled backed his tax cuts in favor of deficit reduction, it would have hurt people.
"You can't do much less than a one half of 1 percent increase in spending and maintain a city," Mr. Giuliani said. He added that in a year when the economy was rebounding, he would have run into great difficulty persuading the City Council to approve a budget with hefty cuts.
"It would have been inconceivable that you could have presented a budget that decreased spending," he said. "It would have been a political joke. We could never have gotten it through the City Council."
Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, also emphasized that when the new plan is weighed against election-year budgets in recent decades, the Mayor is calling for smaller increases in spending. It is an election-year tradition that politicians raise spending to curry favor with voters.
The independent budget analysts issued their own comparisons. Responding to the Mayor's assertion on his radio show, they pointed out that Mr. Giuliani had made great strides in reducing future deficits only when his new preliminary budget is measured against the one he presented last year, which was so lambasted that he revamped it a few months later.
When compared with his preliminary budget for the 1995 fiscal year, the first of his tenure, the difference is more modest. In that budget, the projected deficits averaged 14.4 percent of revenues from city sources. In the Mayor's new preliminary plan, they average 10.3 percent.
Richard J. Raphael, executive managing director at Fitch Investors Service, another bond rating firm, said that while the projected deficits may have shrunk, they could easily balloon if Wall Street has a bad year and tax revenues drop.
"Yes, there has been some reduction" in the future deficits, Mr. Raphael said. "Do I think that they are still large? Yes, I do. We certainly would like to see more reduction of those gaps, given their magnitude, and given the vulnerabilities in the city's revenue structure."

HEADLINE: Just Girls, and That's Fine With Them;
At a New School, No Boys, Less Fussing, and a Freer Spirit

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
They have been together for only five months, but the students in the pioneering seventh-grade class at the all-girls public school in East Harlem have already begun to leave their marks on their surroundings.
First, the girls complained that their blue polyester uniforms were too itchy, and got the principal to commit to switching to cotton and wool. 
 Then they persuaded school officials to admit boys next month -- but only for a night, for a Valentine's Day social. And soon there will be tryouts for the first school basketball team, created at the girls' insistence.
They are also learning that school does not end with the final bell: those who have kept quiet in class have been startled to see their parents receive a letter from school, urging them to speak out.
This is the way that the founders of the Young Women's Leadership School had hoped it would be when, in a hotly debated decision last September, they moved to revive the city's long tradition of single-sex education -- a tradition that faded away so quietly 10 years ago that many New Yorkers did not even realize that an era had ended.
The founders hope that the absence of boys will help girls build self-esteem, become more assertive and take on new leadership roles. And in a sense, they are trailblazers: there are only two other all-girls public schools in the country, in Philadelphia and Baltimore, and the research on the subject is extremely limited.
The birth of the third school, on a commercial strip in East Harlem, was not easy. The New York Civil Liberties Union immediately derided the school's "no boys allowed" admissions policy as unfair. And some feminist groups, including the New York chapter of the National Organization for Women, suggested that the school would set the girls back in preparing for a coeducational environment.
The outcry has yet to die down.
The United States Education Department is continuing to investigate whether the school is discriminatory to boys. New York Law School devoted an all-day conference on Thursday to the legal issues raised by the school's very existence. And civil liberties advocates are still hoping to shut it down, or at least force the acceptance of a boy. But while the outside world continues to be preoccupied with the novelty of it all, the 55 girls have quietly settled into a learning environment that they say feels, in places, like a genteel prep school -- albeit one grafted onto the top three floors of a 12-story commercial building on East 106th Street.
Walk down the school's mauve hallways and you're likely to hear Mozart wafting from a portable stereo. All of the 11- and 12-year-old girls wear the school colors, blue and ivory, a requirement, although they have the option to wear skirts or pants, or sometimes even sweatpants. And the classrooms are cozily furnished with rocking chairs and Oriental rugs, most of them supplied by the teachers themselves.
"It feels like home," said Iris Giboyeaux, 12, who transferred to the school over the summer from the nearby Central Park East Secondary School. "You can be more open."
Indeed, particularly when it comes to talking about sex.
"Last year, if I would have brought up a question about masturbation, the boys would have laughed," said Albeliza Perez, 13, of the Bronx. "This year, I brought it up in class and the girls were like, 'Thanks, Abby.' "
Although the legal questions remain unresolved, school administrators are continuing to move ahead undaunted. The school is accepting applications from girls for next year (no boy has applied, and they say they are not sure what they would do if one did). And when this year's class moves on to the eighth grade next fall, they will be joined by 55 new seventh graders and another 55 ninth graders.
Eventually, there are plans to have 330 students, in grades 7 through 12.
It will take several years of testing to determine if the girls have raised their achievement in science and mathematics, the two subjects where boys traditionally outpace girls nationally.
But for now, every effort is being made by the teachers to compensate for what girls lack in coed classrooms, at least according to the limited research that has been done.
Since some studies have shown that girls have a harder time picturing images of abstract mathematical concepts, the school's math teacher, Linda Metnetsky, has used props -- a six-pack of Diet Coke or the sections of a cantaloupe, for example -- to illustrate a discussion of fractions. Ms. Metnetsky says that some girls who used to rely exclusively on paper and pencil to multiply two fractions can now do so, using such pictures, in their heads.
To help the girls find role models they might have lacked in coed schools, the humanities teacher, Madelene Geswaldo, has introduced them to the stories of girls who lived in medieval Europe. Many of the students -- who are overwhelmingly poor and come from the surrounding neighborhood -- identified with the story of a 12th-century homeless girl who apprenticed as a midwife, Ms. Geswaldo said.
Some researchers have found that getting girls to talk about what they are learning is difficult in a coed environment, where the boys often dominate. So at the Young Women's Leadership School, class sizes have been kept intentionally low -- no more than 18 in a room.
Albeliza, who has personalized her uniform by complementing it with rainbow sneakers and neon-green barrettes, received a letter from the school recently about her reticence in earth science class. The difference the letter made was readily apparent the other day, during a discussion of mica, copper and other minerals.
The teacher, Suzanne Kerho, who addresses the girls as "ladies" but insists that they use her first name, was urging them to devise their own categories to classify the minerals' qualities.
One girl shouted out "smooth and rough." Another said, "shiny and dull." Then Albeliza's hand shot up. "Chappy and nonchappy," she said, explaining that some of the minerals peeled away like "chapped lips."
Ms. Kerho directed that the new category be added to the blackboard, and Albeliza beamed.
"Last year, I would have thought, 'I'll take whatever life brings me,' " said Albeliza, who dreams of becoming a marine biologist. "Now I say to myself, 'I can be absolutely anything I want to be.' "
The easiest way to gauge what's on the girls' minds is to visit the powder-blue dining hall. What's immediately clear is that boys may be absent, but they are ever-present in spirit.
Recently, a girl discussed a spat she had had with a boy she met on America Online. ("You should see the poem I wrote yesterday," she said with a sigh. "It's called 'Dying.' ") Meanwhile, two other girls disagreed over who was cuter -- Billy Corgan, the lead singer of Smashing Pumpkins, or Gavin Rossdale from Bush. And a few swooned from afar over the first male to infiltrate the faculty, Ben Lewis, a 26-year-old student-teacher from Bank Street College who has a reddish goatee and is teaching math.
While the girls concede that they are interested in boys, they quickly add that they are not pushing to introduce boys into their ranks anytime soon. They have plenty of time with boys after school, they say, and besides, each is entitled to bring a date or friend to the Valentine's Day dance. During the day, they would prefer to do without the distraction.
"The teacher doesn't have to spend the whole time disciplining them," said Dominique St. Amand, 12, of the Bronx. Then, quickly remembering that her interviewer was a "he," she added, "No offense."
There is another advantage, Iris said. "I get dressed in eight minutes in the morning," she said, visibly relieved that there were no longer any boys she had to impress. "Before it took me a half-hour just to decide what to wear. And then there was the hair. . ."
This summer promises to bring new adventures. School officials say that Smith College is taking the girls under its wing and is planning a two-week science program for them on its campus in Northampton, Mass.
All this has left Cynthia Lopez, 12, to admit that she may have been wrong about the place.
Like many of the girls, Cynthia arrived at the school under duress, at the behest of a mother who was concerned that her daughter was too "boy crazy."
Well, to her surprise, Cynthia said she liked the friends she has made and the information she has learned.
"My mother made a good choice," she said. "Next year, I'll be back."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 33; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1772 words

HEADLINE: Subsidizing Competition In Utilities;
Has a State Tried Too Hard to Deregulate?

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

DATELINE: PETERBOROUGH, N.H.

 BODY:
With its white-clapboard houses set against pine-covered hills, this New England village of 5,300 might seem a piddling conquest for a $13.2 billion energy company trying to make a name for itself as a national supplier of low-cost gas and electricity to homes and businesses.
But Peterborough is part of New Hampshire's pilot program to open the state's electricity market to full competition in 1998 and a forerunner of national deregulation, and the Enron Corporation, based in Houston, was determined to make a splash here. So it set up an office last April with 30 salespeople, spent $25,000 to help revitalize the downtown and even threw a picnic for residents. Most of all, it promised cheaper electricity. 
 As a result, it beat out 30 competitors to gain Peterborough's endorsement as the "marketer of choice" for local customers, then signed up 700 of them, including the town itself -- far more than any of its rivals. [Last Sunday, it announced its victory in Super Bowl commercials beamed to 128.9 million viewers.]
"It's nice to have a choice," said Daniel L. Keaveny, owner of the Jellison Funeral Homes, who says his electricity bill has fallen by 15 percent, or nearly $20 a month, since he switched to Enron from the area's traditional utility, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire. "They had a monopoly," he said of the utility in a dismissive tone. "I hadn't heard from them in years."
Other residents say they have experienced similar savings, and Enron plans to spend $30 million in a nationwide publicity campaign featuring their appreciative comments.
There is only one problem with all this talk of lower rates, a problem that many of the townspeople are not aware of. Most of the savings are not a result of free-market competition or any economies of scale that an energy giant like Enron might bring to bear on a regional market. Rather, they stem from state-mandated subsidies and from the willingness of Enron and the other marketers to shave their profit margins to near zero to get a piece of the action.
And while the deregulation of the national market for electricity might ultimately bring about lower prices in some parts of the country, the monthly bills of the 17,000 New Hampshire residents taking part in the current pilot program could bounce back up if the subsidies are phased out and if Enron and other winners of the marketing battle reward themselves by taking a profit.
"There is a danger we have raised expectations," George R. McCluskey, head of the electric restructuring division of the New Hampshire Public Utilities Commission, said in an interview in his office in Concord.
In a sense, the state felt it had to raise those expectations; without the 10 percent subsidies as an inducement, officials feared, too few people would join the pilot program to get the deregulation ball rolling.
That is partly because most consumers did not understand what deregulation was all about and were loath to switch to an unknown new marketer for a few dollars a month in savings that might never materialize.
Their confusion was understandable. After all, the same wires would continue to deliver electricity to their homes no matter who their marketer was, and the same local utility would continue to bill them. The potential gold mine in the new freedom is for the marketers. They can now shop around for cheaper power outside a local utility's power grid and deliver it into that grid. In the old days, the utilities did not have to open their lines to outside providers; now they do.
Industry regulators like Mr. McCluskey, as well as executives at utility companies and even some marketing companies, worry that the ballyhoo over New Hampshire's program will raise similar expectations in other states that are deregulating their utility industries. Twenty states are well on the way to opening their electrical utilities to competition.
But Jeffrey K. Skilling, Enron's president, brushed aside concerns that lower rates might be short-lived. Once his company is able to compete for all the customers in the state and build up a large base of customers, it will be able to recover its marketing costs, make a profit and still keep the cost of power at the current low levels, Mr. Skilling asserted.
And if Enron eventually gains the right to compete for other services like billing and meter reading, it could drive those costs down, too, for further savings to customers, he added. "To the extent we've been given a chance to compete, we've had a huge impact," Mr. Skilling said.
If New Hampshire is any guide, consumers elsewhere are apt to be overwhelmed by a flood of freebies and complicated offers in the early stages of electricity deregulation. Aside from Enron, 30 other marketing companies inundated Peterborough residents and other participants of the state's pilot programs with mail and phone solicitations.
One marketer, Green Mountain Energy Partners of Vermont, sent out brochures with tree seedlings attached and promised $10 in "Eco Credits" against future bills to any electricity users who signed up by May 28. "Then, if you plant this tree, we'll give you $2 more in Eco Credits, plus an additional $1 Eco Credit if you send in a photo of your planted tree," the mailing read. Another company sent free birdhouses to new customers. Enron offered a choice of one low rate plus a $50 sign-up bonus or an even lower rate without the bonus.
The blitz confused and even frightened some people, said Paul E. Ramsey, the division manager of customer service at Public Service. Some elderly people, misconstruing the pitches they got as threats to cut off their power, pleaded with his company to strike their names from the mailing lists provided to marketers, Mr. Ramsey said. "Some were in tears," he said.
Other potential customers, skeptical of the claims, simply threw away the literature, passing up savings that for some businesses could have run into hundreds of dollars a month.
Only 12 of the 31 companies survived the marketing frenzy, and only because they could absorb the costs of setting their prices for power so low -- between 2 cents and 3 cents a kilowatt-hour and in some cases below 2 cents, the wholesale cost most marketers pay to the New England Power Pool, according to Mr. McCluskey.
By contrast, rates previously averaged about 3.5 cents for residential customers for the power portion of their bill. (The total cost to New Hampshire consumers of electricity, including transmission, overhead, service and other charges averaged about 15 cents a kilowatt-hour. By comparison, New Yorkers pay an average of about 13 cents to the Consolidated Edison Company.)
"The prices that have resulted mean that they are not making any profits," Mr. McCluskey said. "They are at rock bottom."
If the marketers bump their rates back up to traditional levels, their customers' average 15 percent saving would be reduced by nearly one- third, Mr. McCluskey said. Even more troubling to some, state-mandated subsidies account for most of the rest of the price differential, meaning that if they are ended -- a real possibility -- much of the gains consumers now enjoy will evaporate.
The pilot program expires on June 30, 1998, by which time the entire state will be deregulated.
"In New Hampshire, the savings are artificial to make sure you got participants," said Gary Long, vice president of economic development and customer service at Public Service. "My concern is that people are getting used to 15 to 20 percent savings. People will expect to get 15 to 20 percent under real-world conditions."
Another doubter is Edward Harms, an assistant operator at the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant. Mr. Harms went about choosing a marketer scientifically, collecting all the mailings he got, not only from New Hampshire but also from companies in Vermont, Connecticut, Massachusetts and even California. He then put all the prices, incentives and other data in his computer and ran comparisons.
"It's very hard to sort out from the information they send you," he said. He settled on the Granite State Electric Company, a small New Hampshire utility owned by the New England Electric System, adding, "The marketers are going with such low numbers that they are not going to be able to continue that way."
The subsidies are actually paid by the traditional utilities, which agreed to dip into their reserves to help entice people into the pilot program. They have accepted deregulation as a fait accompli and want a close-up look at how the new energy setup will look. Many proved to be quick on their feet, and won many customers through their own intense marketing efforts.
What will happen to the state's utilities in the coming deregulation is still uncertain. Some are weighed down by huge debts -- "stranded costs" in industry parlance -- from investments in nuclear power and other projects that never panned out. Until now, the state has bailed them out by authorizing special levies on customers' bills.
The state must decide whether to expose these financially vulnerable companies to the full brunt of outside competition, or continue to support them with surcharges and deprive consumers of the lower rates that they are coming to expect. Currently, Public Service levies 5.2 cents.
"It's going to be very difficult to meet customer expectations with competition alone," Mr. McCluskey said. "The only alternative will be to deny a substantial amount of the stranded costs. Such denial, however, may result in financial difficulty for the utilities."
That may be an understatement, Public Service, for example, is still recovering from a bankruptcy filing made in 1988 mostly because of cost overruns and problems from the construction of the Seabrook nuclear plant.
And John H. Forsgren, the chief financial officer of Northeast Utilities, its parent company, warned New Hampshire regulators recently that the New Hampshire utility could be forced to seek bankruptcy protection if the stranded costs were not recovered.
The local utility's loss could become Enron's gain. While the company has signed up only 1,400 people, and has yet to make a penny from its involvement in the pilot project, it thinks the investment will pay off.
"Are we creating value for our shareholders? Yes," said Steven L. Lawrence, manager of the company's Peterborough office. Referring to the tens of millions of homes and businesses in the United States that Enron believes will one day be open to competition from outside electricity suppliers, he added, "We're learning about the biggest marketplace in the country."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Residents of Peterborough, New Hampshire, above, chose the Enron Corporation as their electricity supplier. The company is using the town's decision as part of a national advertising campaign, left. (Kathy Seward for The New York Times)
 
Charts: "An Open Market"
In what may be a harbinger for other states that deregulate their electric utility industries, more than 30 companies in a pilot program have flooded New Hampshire with solicitaions for business.
 
"Real Savings or Illusion?"
A pilot program in New Hampshire that allows people to choose their electricity supplier has reduced the electric bill of many participants by an average of 15 percent But the savings come mostly from a rebate from the state's utilities and lower than usual prices from companies' tring to entice people to sign with them. Here is sample bill prepared by one of the state's utilites.
 
UNBUNDLED CHARGES: The state regulatory commission told the utilities to list the component charges of each electric bill so that consumers could see what they are paying for. Under the current deregulation plan, utilites will still be responsible for everything but the actual cost of the electricity.
 
STRANDED COSTS: What to do about costs from power plants and other projects that have not been paid for remains to be decided. The utilites say the costs must continue to be passed along to consumers or they will be pushed into bankruptcy.
 
REBATE: To entice people to join the pilot program, the utilities agreed to reimburse customers for about 10 percent of their bills. This rebate may disappear when deregulation is statewide.
 
COST OF ELECTRICITY: Many companies in the pilot are selling electricity only slightly above cost, in this case 3.1 cents per kilowatt hour. No one knows where prices will settle. (pg. 34)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Parcells Seeking New Kitchen

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
WHILE poor unemployed Bill Parcells shuffles home to New Jersey to sit by the phone and see if he has a future, he should know he has the philosophical blessing of many chefs around the world.
In his departure from the New England Patriots yesterday, Parcells tried to explain his drive for creative freedom, which forced the split with the owner, Robert K. Kraft: 
 "It's just like a friend of mine told me," Parcells said. " 'If they want you to cook the dinner, at least they ought to let you shop for some of the groceries.' "
Now Parcells must wait to see if the New York Jets will pay a high price for him -- the very first choice in the next draft of college players. But he made it clear that next time around he wants to be in charge of going to market as well as supervising the kitchen.
Football owners seem legitimately divided about the wisdom of giving shopping and cooking power to one person, but Parcells's friend is onto something when he cites the tradition of chefs who go poking at the trays of seafood.
"If the eyes are not bright, it's not going to be great fish," rasped Elaine Kaufman, the legendary proprietor of Elaine's in Manhattan.
Kaufman has seen customers like George Steinbrenner and Pat Riley and other sports executives with a lust for power. She understood exactly what Parcells was saying, and said she wants her own chef, Barry Wildman, out at the markets at dawn.
"You've got to see it and sniff it," she said, "just like you would with a player."
Parcells wants to travel the extra 100,000 miles to acquire new players for the same reason chefs make the long haul -- to keep everybody honest.
"Let's face it, produce people will try to push things on you," said Daniel LeBron, the chef at Josephine's, a delightful French restaurant in Marietta, Pa., along the banks of the Susquehanna River, between York and Harrisburg.
"You get 10 times the quality if you go there yourself," said LeBron, who used to make the hour-and-40-minute haul each way to Philadelphia Market, until the French-born proprietor, Jean-Luc Sandillon, began to spell him.
"I know what Parcells means," said the American-born LeBron. "I'm also a Patriots fan and I'm sorry they lost."
Parcells announced he was leaving the Patriots' kitchen two days after Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner of the league, ruled that the Patriots had legal rights to Parcells for the 1997 season. Yesterday Kraft said he could not give Parcells the authority he wanted because "you can't have the business dependent on just one person." "It's just common sense," he said. "What happens when that person isn't there?"
Many owners agree with Kraft. No sooner had 32-year-old John Spano bought the New York Islanders than he forced Mike Milbury to give up coaching and concentrate on being general manager.
As of last night, the Jets seemed willing to give Parcells the power he wants, but Leon Hess might not be as eager to give away the top draft choice, which could produce Peyton Manning, the quarterback from the University of Tennessee. Many football fans think no coach is worth a first draft choice, but my feeling is that some coaches are always going to be better than most of their peers, and Parcells is clearly one of the best.
Parcells put on a suit and tie and tried to hide his normal bluster yesterday at a press conference in Massachusetts, where he and Kraft parted ways. He said he had no problem with Tagliabue's decision that he was bound to the Patriots next season.
"I'm a league guy; whatever the commissioner says, I'll abide by," Parcells said, but it could not have been easy.
He chafed at the family-style layers of authority when he won two Super Bowls with the Giants. He rebelled against Kraft's involvement en route to the Super Bowl this season. He is at his best with unchecked powers, bullying his own players, stonewalling his bosses, showing contempt for the press. It must have been very hard for him to be civil yesterday as New England reporters questioned his veracity.
Until that moment, there had been no known link between haute cuisine and football coaching. Coaches remain sequestered in their grim bunkers for weeks at a time, watching film and eating ghastly takeout food, which may explain their lumpy shapes and sour expressions. Parcells looks like a cheeseburger kind of guy, always suffering from dyspepsia, but at least he has friends who explain the mystique of the master chef.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Spotlight on Public Liaison Office

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
When President Clinton's re-election campaign needed suggestions for political and civic leaders to invite to coffees with him, it called members of a small White House office charged with building public support for his policies.
And when top Administration aides wanted to woo ethnic voters last year, they asked the head of that office, Alexis M. Herman, and her assistants to meet -- in off-duty hours -- with Democratic Party officials and fund-raisers to plot detailed strategies. 
 These and other of Ms. Herman's activities revealed over the past week have raised questions on Capital Hill about whether she blended her official and political roles, and have put her nomination to be Secretary of Labor in jeopardy.
The White House has said that Ms. Herman, who has run its Office of Public Liaison since 1993, did nothing wrong. Today she visited the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, to try to smooth things over.
Senator Lott said earlier in the week that he was concerned that some of Ms. Herman's activities might have come "awfully close to the edge" of Federal laws that limit the partisan activities of Government workers. After meeting with Ms. Herman today, the Senator said: "It was a good meeting. She answered a number of questions I had concerns about."
But he added, "I still think there is a lot of explanation needed."
The most controversial issue has been the role of Ms. Herman's aides in inviting a Federal bank regulator to meet with Mr. Clinton and some of the nation's most powerful bankers at a coffee meeting sponsored by the Democratic Party last May. White House spokesmen have said that Ms. Herman's office was involved only because of a miscommunication about the nature of the event, and that Ms. Herman decided not to go to the coffee after she learned it was being sponsored by party officials.
But the controversy has also focused a broader spotlight on the public liaison office, which promotes grass-roots support for the President's social and economic policies among ethnic, business and civic groups, and how the Administration has used it.
Several people who worked in that office in previous Administrations, both Democratic and Republican, said in interviews that officials of the liasion office have historically not had an extensive involvement with party operatives, especially during election campaigns.
Anne Wexler, who ran the liaison office under President Jimmy Carter and whose son works for Ms. Herman now, said she occasionally asked the Democratic National Committee if there were any donors it would like her to include in large groups -- usually of 200 or more people -- invited to White House briefings. But she said Mr. Carter rarely met with small groups, and her office was "never connected in any way with fund raising."
Bobbie G. Kilberg, who was the liaison director under President George Bush, said people in her office "were not permitted to even talk to anybody in the campaign" to avoid any possible ethics concerns. She said all communications with campaign or party officials were routed through the White House political office.
Others who worked in the liaison office said it appeared that high-level Clinton Administration officials had prodded Ms. Herman and her aides to get more closely involved with campaign strategy than had been the case in the past.
Frank J. Donatelli, who was a deputy in the liaison office when President Ronald Reagan ran for re-election in 1984, said this "is a sensitive area." He added: "If there is criticism, it shouldn't be just Alexis Herman that is singled out. You can't ignore the larger picture of what the White House was doing."
Indeed, the questions about Ms. Herman and her aides stem from the furor over Democratic efforts to raise huge sums of money by granting donors and other prominent people access to Mr. Clinton and by tapping new sources of money in ethnic communities, particularly among Asian-Americans.
The meeting with the bankers was one of more than 100 such coffees at which Mr. Clinton or Vice President Al Gore served as host in 1995 and 1996. And while many who attended the coffees did not make contributions, those who did gave a total of more than $27 million to Democratic candidates or organizations.
Ms. Herman, 49, has declined to grant any interviews while her nomination as Secretary of Labor is pending.
But Lanny J. Davis, a White House special counsel, said that any links that Ms. Herman or her aides had to the re-election campaign were "in substance neither inappropriate nor unusual nor in any way that we can determine illegal under the Hatch Act," the law that limits the political activities of Federal workers.
Mr. Davis also contended that some White House documents describing the work of the ethnic strategy groups contain "less that meets the eye." And he said that while Ms. Herman and her deputies discussed general political strategy during their off-hours with party fund-raisers, they never had anything to do with soliciting donations.
The White House has acknowledged that Ms. Herman attended a handful of the coffees with Mr. Clinton that included Democratic Party officials, although it said her office was not involved in arranging any others than the one with the bankers.
Documents made public by the White House also show that Ms. Herman led an informal group of Administration officials and party activists that was assigned to draft "a comprehensive blueprint for mobilizing the African-American community in 1996 to assure the re-election of President Clinton."
One of Ms. Herman's deputies, Doris O. Matsui, led a similar group focused on Asian-Americans that included John Huang, the former Democratic Party official who is now under Federal investigation for his fund-raising practices. The group's report contained a section on fund-raising goals, but a White House spokesmen said today that it was inserted by Mr. Huang with virtual no involvement from Ms. Matsui.
White House officials also said today that in response to requests from campaign officials, people in Ms. Herman's office also suggested the names of political, business and community leaders for possible invitations to about 15 of the coffees with the President.
One question in Congress is whether Ms. Herman or any of her staff members did anything improper in coordinating the strategy groups or suggesting who might be invited to the 15 coffees.
An Administration spokesman said the Clinton campaign recently paid the White House $917 to cover the use of Office of Public Liaison computers by two people who worked on plans to reach out to ethnic groups.
But Mr. Davis, the special White House counsel, said White House employees were free to get involved in some political activities as long as they worked 40 hours in a week on official duties and did not use Government resources.
Joseph Lockhart, a White House spokesman, said that when Ms. Herman's aides made the suggestions of people who might be invited to the coffees, they faxed them on special machines in the White House that were paid for by the campaign.

HEADLINE: News Summary

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL 2-5
 
Palestinian in U.S. Cell Says He May Prefer Israel
By suddenly accepting his extradition to Israel, Mousa Mohammed Abu Marzook, the political leader of the Islamic militant group Hamas has called Israel's bluff and returned to the political spotlight. His move has prompted veiled threats and generated anxiety about what effect his deportation could have on peace in the Mideast. 1
 
Myanmar Deal for Unocal
As the Clinton Administration deliberates whether to impose a ban on new American investment in Myanmar, the Unocal Corporation signed an agreement with the Government in Rangoon, expanding the company's rights to develop offshore gas fields. The company announced the deal on Thursday, the same day that the State Department issued its annual human rights report documenting the killing and torture of dissidents and ethnic minorities in Myanmar, formerly known as Burma. 4
 
Mandela Courts Zulu Rival
President Nelson Mandela appointed Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, his archrival and leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party, to act as President during Mr. Mandela's trip abroad this weekend. The move, a surprise, was seen as a canny tactic indicating that jockeying for position for elections, still two years away, has begun in earnest. Chief Buthelezi's party has been engaged in a bloody political war with Mr. Mandela's African National Congress Party in the KwaZulu Natal province for years. 5
 
Plot Twists in Mexico
The celebrated case surrounding a body unearthed on a ranch belonging to the brother of Mexico's former President took a new turn. Authorities in Mexico arrested Raul Salinas de Gortari's former mistress, accusing her and others of planting the body in an attempt to frame Mr. Salinas. Officials said they were also investigating whether the baroque plot may have included the top prosecutor in the case, Pablo Chapa Bezanilla, who was dismissed when tests proved that the corpse was not the politician Mr. Salinas was reported to have killed. 3
 
Germany Shrugs at U.S. Report
German officials brushed aside criticism from the State Department about Germany's attitude toward the Scientology movement. They said they would continue their inquiries to see whether the organization should be placed under surveillance or outlawed. The Scientology movement, which claims to have 30,000 members in Germany, has compared its treatment by the state to the persecution of Jews in Nazi Germany. 5
 
Death Sentences in Vietnam
Vietnam sentenced four people to death at the end of a showcase corruption trial. The four, convicted of siphoning off millions of dollars in state funds, included three officials of a trading company closely affiliated with the Communist Party and one state official. Defense lawyers argued that the system let corruption flourish. (Reuters)

Group Adopts Measures For Apparel Industry
In an effort to set industrywide standards for apparel factories, a Presidential task force has agreed on measures to fight harassment and child labor. But the group, whose standards will be voluntary, is divided on other important issues, including wages and hours. 1
 
Simpson Juror Is Dismissed
The only black woman on the jury considering the wrongful death suit against O. J. Simpson was taken off the panel. She failed to tell the court that a daughter had worked for the prosecutors who tried the criminal case against Mr. Simpson. A new juror was selected and deliberations began again. 1
 
Vitamin B12 and AIDS
Men who have a deficiency of vitamin B-12 are likely to develop AIDS much more quickly than those with adequate levels of the vitamin if they are infected by the virus that causes the disease. 7
 
Law Against Gangs Is Endorsed
The California Supreme Court has ruled that cities may prohibit suspected gang members from doing things ordinary citizens may legally do. Law-enforcement officials said the decision gives them another tool to prevent crime. 6
 
Researcher Pockets a Profit
A researcher whose studies found zinc lozenges may be an effective cold treatment says he made $145,000 by buying shares in a company making the lozenges before the research became public. The researcher disclosed his investment when the results were published, and there was no sign he had violated any ethical rules. 6
 
Welfare Guidelines Issued
The Clinton Administration advised the states on how to spend state money under the new Federal welfare law. The main rule, the Administration said, was not to circumvent requirements that welfare recipients find work. 8
 
Hard Line by Defense Chief
In his first news conference, the new Secretary of Defense, William S. Cohen, said he would not tolerate any degree of hazing, sexual harassment or racism and that officers would be held responsible for such incidents. 8
 
Atheist's Son Ends Case
William Murray, the Christian son of the atheist Madalyn Murray O'Hair, is giving up his effort in Texas courts to become guardian of her estate. He cited the cost of an investigation into the disappearance of his mother, another son and a granddaughter, all of whom have been missing since September 1995. (AP)
 
Ruling on Assisted Suicide
In the first ruling by a state judge supporting doctor-assisted suicide, a Florida judge ruled that a man dying of AIDS had the right to commit suicide with the help of a doctor. The judge said, however, that his ruling applied only to 35-year-old man involved in the lawsuit. (AP)

Governor Pataki announced plans to strengthen New York State's enforcement of environmental laws, particularly limits on air pollution from factories and power plants. Federal officials said the changes could end a long period of decline in environmental enforcement in the state. 1

The two 18-year-olds from New Jersey who are charged with killing their newborn son returned home. They are to go on trial later this year. They are free to come and go without wearing the equipment during the day. 22
