HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Economy Grows Rapidly, Paced By Strong Exports
Powered by a surge in exports, the economy grew at a surprisingly vigorous 4.7 percent pace during the final 1996 quarter, more than twice as fast as during the summer, the Government reported.
Despite this latest surge, coming after nearly five years of steady growth that has kept factories humming and pushed unemployment down to low levels, the economy showed almost no signs of strain. Indeed, inflation by one important measure shriveled to the lowest point in 30 years. For the full year, the nation's real gross domestic product advanced 2.5 percent, the best performance of any of the world's advanced industrialized countries. [Page 1.]

Unocal Signs Burmese Deal
The Unocal Corporation has signed a deal with the Government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, to expand its rights to explore and develop gas fields off the country's coast. The signing came as the Clinton Administration weighed whether to impose a ban on new American investment in Myanmar because of its human rights abuses. [4.]

Group Split on Factory Standards
A Presidential task force created to set voluntary minimum standards at apparel factories in the United States and abroad has agreed on child-labor and anti-harassment practices but remains badly split over wages and hours. The group includes representatives of labor unions, human rights groups and industry powerhouses like Liz Claiborne, L. L. Bean and Nike [1.]

Hilton Makes Formal Bid for ITT
As promised, Hilton Hotels formally made a $6.5 billion hostile takeover bid for 50.1 percent of ITT. Even though the price of ITT's stock has traded consistently above the bid price of $55 a share since Monday, when Hilton announced it would pursue ITT, Marc Grossman, a Hilton spokesman, characterized the offer as "strong." [35.]

Stock Market Falls Slightly
The stock market ended a volatile month with a volatile day as the Dow Jones industrial average, after once again threatening to top 6,900, ran out of steam, dropping 10.77 points, to close at 6,813.09. The day, which closed with a series of late-afternoon computer-guided program trades, seemed a fitting end to a month of ups and downs, one in which traders were preoccupied with balancing news of strong economic growth with concerns about inflation. [37.]
 
Bonds Rally on Economic News
Treasury prices gained yesterday as a flurry of economic reports failed to convince bond investors that inflation had become a problem. Investors are confident that Federal Reserve policy makers, who start a two-day meeting on Tuesday, would not raise short-term interest rates. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.78 percent, from 6.86 percent. A week ago the yield was 6.88 percent. [36.]

Coca-Cola Has Strong Earnings
Coca-Cola said that its profits soared 18 percent during the fourth quarter, buoyed by growth in international soft-drink shipments and by an increase in market share throughout most of the world. Net income rose to $762 million, or 31 cents a share, from $648 million, or 26 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1996, meeting Wall Street analysts' estimates. [35.]

Sentence in Internet Stock Fraud
The former chairman of Systems of Excellence was sentenced to 46 months in prison for his role in a multimillion-dollar stock fraud that used the Internet to promote his company's shares. Charles O. Huttoe pleaded guilty to one count of fraud and one count of money laundering in November but that plea was kept under seal while he cooperated with Federal prosecutors. [34.]
 
Dollar Is Mixed
The dollar finished mixed after falling on negative comments from top German central bank officials and then rising on a Commerce Department report that showed a healthy American economy with benign inflation. [32.]

HEADLINE: The Roar of Cold Cash on Snowy Maine Trails

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: MOOSEHEAD LAKE, Me., Jan. 26

 BODY:
Snow draped the evergreen boughs of the spruce and balsam fir trees in fresh white. Here in the Great North Woods, hundreds and hundreds of square miles of remote forest, home to moose, beaver, lynx and the wily, rarely seen fisher cat, the only sound you can hear is---- vroooom.
Vroom, vrooom, varoooooom. Vrooom. Vrom, vrom. Vrooooom. 
 Here they come on their Ski-Doos and Arctic Cats: the Devil's Sledders, Moosehead Riders, Readfield Blizzard Busters, Hungry Hollow '76ers, Smokey's Angels and the rest of the snowmobilers, blasting through the woods at highway speeds and pumping tens of millions of dollars into tiny hardscrabble villages where people used to piece together a bare living cutting down trees and guiding hunters and fishermen.
The trail is broad and smooth as a road, and many of the snowmobilers will roar along for a hundred miles or more in a day, waving at the riders coming in the opposite direction and pausing sometimes in big clumps at trail intersections.
Encased in black leather and a helmet, Jim Lecuyer lounged with a group by his machine and took in the view. During the week, he drives a truck in Boston.
"Down there, it's a zoo," Mr. Lecuyer said. "Here, you could hear a snowflake fall."
Vroooom. He swung back on his snowmobile and the group was off, with the distinctive snarl and metallic smell of a two-stroke engine. Vrooom, vrooom.
Once a blue-collar pastime -- actually, red plaid in northern New England, where the locals favor wool hunting garb -- snowmobiling is now a major industry. So big, in fact, that a study just released by economists at the University of Maine found that snowmobiling had brought $226 million into the state's economy last year, more than twice as much as the ski slopes, which generated $110 million.
"Snowmobiling turns the wheels here in the wintertime -- we'd be lost without it," said David Costa, the town manager of Greenville, which had a population of 1,040 in the 1990 census. "This is big business, make no mistake. It's saved us the last few years."
The sleds are so important that Greenville, like Jackman and other nearby towns, invested big money this year for huge snow-grooming machines -- $100,000 for two for Greenville -- to smooth the trails in the hope of attracting more riders. And this winter, the various towns, snowmobile clubs and resort owners in the area got together to groom connecting sections of the Moosehead Trail, which runs all around the lake, which, at 40 miles long and 20 miles wide, is the largest lake in the East. It is lovely here, but it is so isolated and empty that mapmakers tend to cut out the region and stick it in the Atlantic Ocean so they can get all of Maine on a page.
"This was a poor man's sport in the 70's," Mr. Costa said. "No more.
"There's some serious money being spent on this sport. Six sleds in a family is not uncommon. And expectations have grown. People expect excellent groomed trails. That's why we bought this expensive equipment."
Paul Fichtner 3d, the Arctic Cat dealer in Greenville, president of the Moosehead Riders snowmobile club and, not uncoincidentally, the operator of the new grooming equipment, could not agree more. Along with Kevin McDonough over at Kelly's Landing restaurant and other business people, he pushed for the groomers and helped raise the money.
"Everybody else around was buying this equipment," Mr. Fichtner said, "and this stuff makes a big difference" in the competition for the snowmobile trade.
"This has become an affluent people's sport," said Mr. Fichtner, who is known as Arno. "The business is almost all downstate or out of state. A lot of local people can't afford to participate."
"Flatlanders are my bread and butter," he added, using the northern New Englander's term for people from the cities and suburbs to the south. "I don't mean 'flatlanders' in a derogatory way."
Twenty years ago, a snowmobile cost around $650 and was likely to be used by a farmer zooming around his pasture to relieve winter's boredom. They are more sophisticated now, with heated handgrips and powerful engines that make them go 100 miles an hour, and they cost $3,000 to $10,000, with a typical purchase about $5,500. There is even a tiny snowmobile for children 6 to 9 years old, called a Kitty Cat.
The snowmobile enthusiast, Mr. Fichtner noted, also needs a trailer to haul the sled; the enclosed boxes now becoming popular are running from around $1,200 to $2,500. (The sports utility wagon or suburban minivan hauling the trailer can mean an additional $35,000 or so, but it can be used year around, husbands point out.) The cold weather clothing with sled manufacturer's logos -- snowmobilers are fiercely loyal to their brand -- go for about $230 for a jacket and $180 for a bib overall. In leather, they are $479.95 and $439, respectively, Mr. Fichtner said. A helmet is $250, and boots, mittens and other odds and ends go another $250 or so.
"Then there's the trinkets: helmet clocks you can put on your desk, Arctic Cat notepads," he added. "We're not in an area that affluent, but I've been in stores downstate where they can't keep that stuff on the shelves."
The University of Maine's report found that the state's income from snowmobiling had gone up 74 percent since the last survey, in the early 1980's, when the sport was in the doldrums because of high gasoline prices and a recession. Snowmobile registrations had fallen to a low of 53,415 then; now they are now up to 76,477.
Nationwide, snowmobiling is a nearly $4 billion industry, with some 1.3 million machines registered, and the pattern has been similar, said Chris Jourdain, executive director of the American Council of Snowmobile Associations. Manufacturers' surveys show that most snowmobiling families nationwide have incomes of about $60,000, Ms. Jourdain said, "with more and more tending toward $80,000."
The survey here found that out-of-state sledders averaged family incomes of $68,213, while Maine snowmobile families averaged $47,492.
"This is a huge sport," said Bob Meyers, editor of the newspaper of the Maine Snowmobile Association. "And it's all built on volunteer labor."
Indeed, the snowmobile infrastructure that has been developed in recent years accounts for much of the success, said Stephen Reiling, a University of Maine economist (and sometime snowmobiler) who is the principal author of the report. Snowmobile clubs and volunteers have built and maintained an elaborate 12,000-mile interstate trail system stretching into Canada and New Hampshire. In this area, the clubs, Chambers of Commerce and town officials cooperate to buy the grooming machines -- municipalities get lower interest rates on loans and are exempt from sales taxes -- and they are eventually repaid by state grants coming from snowmobile registration fees and a tiny share of gasoline taxes.
There is even a state snowmobile czar, Scott Ramsey of the Bureau of Parks and Lands, who last year took care of about 200 miles of state trails and distributed $902,000 in grants to towns and $344,000 to clubs to maintain club trails. Part of the $20 snowmobile registration fee goes to the Fish and Wildlife Service, whose game wardens are the state's most powerful police agency. The wardens set up roadblocks along the trails to nab drunken snowmobilers.
"Last year, we had 12 fatalities," said Sgt. Tom Ward, who was stopping passing snowmobilers with four other wardens the other day and handing out safety leaflets warning of the dangers of speed and alcohol. "We're trying to stop that. One guy was drunk -- ran into a fishing shack at 100 miles an hour."
Farther along the trail, it was standing room only for the all-day buffet at an inn called Pittston Farm, 30 miles into the woods and a long way from anywhere. Once, the Great Northern timber company stabled horses here who would drag the logs out of the woods in winter. The logs would be piled on the river ice 25 or 30 feet high, chained into booms and floated to the mills in the spring. But the last river drive was two decades ago. On this weekend, the farm was surrounded by a constantly changing parking lot with scores of snowmobiles.
True to the university study, the crowd was largely made up of men in their early 40's, although there were families, too. The study, however, said nothing about size. Impressive girths made it clear that this is not an aerobic sport. These people can eat.
Ken Twitchell, the owner, figures that on a good day, he can dispense 250 pounds of mashed potatoes, along with, among many other rich dishes, 20 gallons of chili and 90 pounds of pot roast. He can also sell 1,800 gallons of gasoline.
"Wasn't no business, winters," Mr. Twitchell said, until the snowmobile trails were connected a few years ago and he groomed his section.
"I was trying to groom with a homemade drag on a snow sled," he remembered, musing that people might someday hang old trail-grooming gear over lodge fireplaces the way they do wooden skis. "Just thinking about spending $53,000 for the new machine was scary. But I figured either you've got to go the whole hog or nothing."
Mr. Fichtner, the Arctic Cat dealer and snowmobile club president, tried to put his finger on the appeal that led to the boom.
"There's unparalleled peace and quiet," he explained. "If you shut your machine off."

A network of snowmobile trails has brought Maine prosperity. SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1560 words

HEADLINE: VOLUNTARY RULES ON APPAREL LABOR PROVE HARD TO SET

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
In a groundbreaking effort to set minimum standards at apparel factories both in the United States and abroad, a Presidential task force that includes representatives of labor unions, human rights groups and industry powerhouses like Liz Claiborne, L. L. Bean and Nike has agreed on child-labor and anti-harassment practices but remains badly split over wages and hours.
The task force hopes that if it can agree on the voluntary standards, they will be embraced by the entire American apparel industry. It would look for bully-pulpit help from President Clinton, to whom it hopes to send its report by late February. 
 But the panel is by no means united on what the standards should be.
The apparel companies in the task force, which want to set standards in order to dispel any notion that they themselves use sweatshops, say factories, whether in New York or New Delhi, should not be considered sweatshops if they pay the local minimum or prevailing wage.
The unions and the human rights groups, on the other hand, maintain that such a wage is often too meager to support a family. They say factories should be considered sweatshops unless they pay wages high enough to meet basic needs.
The members of the task force have pledged to keep their deliberations confidential. But several participants disclosed in interviews that in addition to the pay dispute, there was a split over hours.
The unions and the rights groups contend that factories should generally be considered sweatshops if employees are required to work more than 48 hours a week. The apparel companies say factories should be free to require a 60-hour week.
Any standards adopted would presumably have great potential to influence factory conditions in Haiti, Honduras, Indonesia, Sri Lanka and dozens of other countries on which American clothing and footwear makers rely for production.
For one thing, the task force is leaning toward setting up a monitoring organization to insure compliance at factories that are under contract to companies that accept the standards. Further, it is discussing a proposal under which all such companies would be entitled to place "no sweat" labels on their clothes.
While the task force hopes that all major American apparel companies will adopt the standards, some members fear that if those standards are too strict, many companies will not sign on.
"It's not going to be helpful just to keep these standards to a small number of participants," said Roberta Karp, a co-chairwoman of the panel, who is general counsel of Liz Claiborne. "We really hope to galvanize the industry to go further."
Despite their differences on some issues, the business, labor and human rights participants have been able to reach agreement on others.
On child labor, the task force has agreed that factories should generally not use workers under 15, although in some countries they would be allowed to employ 14-year-olds.
Further, for an industry where workers often complain of being smacked, groped or shouted at, the group has adopted anti-harassment standards that some independent human rights advocates praise. The participants have agreed that "every employee shall be treated with respect and dignity" and that "no employee shall be subject to any physical, sexual, psychological or verbal harassment or abuse."
The task force, the White House Apparel Industry Partnership, was created last August. Its membership is made up of representatives from 18 organizations, among them Reebok, Nicole Miller, Patagonia, the National Consumers League, the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility, the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, and the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union.
When the task force meets on Monday in Washington, the members will focus on methods of monitoring compliance with whatever standards are adopted, and on narrowing their differences over wages and hours.
One member, Jay Mazur, president of the textile employees union, declined to discuss the deliberations, but said: "On the question of wages generally, of course workers should be paid enough to meet their basic needs -- and then some. Most minimum wages are not adequate to do this."
But apparel companies and retailers say they fear that a "living wage," one that meets "basic needs," could prove too expensive and too hard to define.
"When you cross the line into what is a living wage, you get into this incredibly murky area," said Robin Lanier, senior vice president for government affairs at the International Mass Retail Association. "You don't have a concrete standard, and you wind up having to fend off charges that you're not supplying a basic wage."
Advocates of a basic-needs standard say it would not be hard for the task force or independent economists to come up with one, employing local indexes that gauge the cost of goods, housing, transportation and so forth.
Indeed, one task force member who objects to the apparel industry's stance on wages suggested that if agreement could not be reached on this issue, the panel's entire effort might collapse. "If we are not able to inject into the wage standard something meaningful about its meeting basic needs," this member said, "this whole thing is going to go down."
The adoption of standards would provide benefits to each of the effort's principals:
*The apparel makers in the task force hope that they can once and for all rid themselves of embarrassing accusations that the factories they use are sweatshops. These companies hope to avoid the kind of negative publicity that Kathie Lee Gifford and the Gap encountered for using Central American factories that were widely viewed that way.
*For labor, the standards might not only improve the lives of apparel workers around the world but also protect jobs at home, by raising the cost of production overseas. In a concession to labor, the task force has agreed that "employers shall recognize and respect the right of employees to freedom of association and collective bargaining."
*For President Clinton, the task force, though formally independent of the Administration, might burnish his image with unions by demonstrating that he is fighting sweatshops.
*And for consumer groups, the standards would be important because many shoppers want assurances that the clothes they buy are not made in sweatshops.
"We are committed to working with business, unions and human rights groups to insure better working conditions," said Linda Golodner, a task force co-chairwoman who is president of the National Consumers League, founded in 1899 to fight sweatshops. "There should be a way that the industry works together to establish something that consumers can rely on to be sure that goods are sweatshop-free."
Industry and union officials agree that whatever standards are adopted will probably push up production costs, but they say it is too early to estimate whether costs would rise several pennies or several dimes a garment. Ms. Golodner noted a recent poll of Americans in which 84 percent of respondents said they would be willing to pay $1 more for a $20 garment if they knew that it was not made in a sweatshop.
"The companies and retailers see that consumers care about this issue, and are feeling public pressure," said Maria Echaveste, administrator of the Labor Department's wage and hour division. "By tackling international standards and by making commitments to eliminate abuses abroad and not just in this country, they are taking extremely significant steps."
In one recent case of the kind at which the standards would be aimed, labor advocates accused the Walt Disney Company of allowing its Pocahontas and 101 Dalmatians apparel to be manufactured at factories in Haiti that pay 27 cents an hour -- that country's minimum wage but, these advocates say, far too little to support a family. Disney disputes the accusation, saying the factories pay at least twice the Haitian minimum.
"Many third-world countries set minimum wages below subsistence because they are trapped in a competition with each other to attract jobs," said Charles Kernaghan, executive director of the National Labor Committee, a workers' advocacy group. "We've unleashed a race to the bottom as countries offer cheap, compliant labor. The basic-needs proposal seeks to set a floor high enough for people to live on."
But Steven Pfister, the National Retail Federation's vice president for political affairs, said a basic-needs standard was unnecessary.
"The fact that companies are investing in countries, notwithstanding the charge that they are seeking cheap labor, is enhancing the ability of these people to meet their basic needs," Mr. Pfister said.
Even on an issue resolved by the task force, child labor, the accord was struck only after a long dispute, participants say. Unions and human rights groups initially proposed that no one under 15 be hired. But the industry argued that such a demand was unrealistic, because in many impoverished countries families put
 12- , 13- and 14-year-olds to work, to make ends meet.
Given that, the unions and the human rights groups agreed to a standard that would allow apparel factories to hire 14-year-olds in those countries that permit children under 15 to do factory work.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1037 words

HEADLINE: THE BIG CITY;
The Matatu Conjecture

BYLINE: By John Tierney 

 BODY:
THE OUT-OF-TOWNERS PRESENTED THE challenge shortly before Christmas: Could I possibly get them tickets to "Chicago" for an upcoming Friday night? I wasn't optimistic. The musical had just opened to phenomenal reviews, selling $1 million in tickets the first weekend. Broadway insiders accustomed to snagging house seats were complaining they couldn't get tickets before spring. Ticket brokers were being shut out; the first several I called wouldn't even bother looking for tickets. Eventually I found a broker who was offering $70 orchestra seats -- for $175. I was about to call the out-of-towners and confess that I had no better Broadway connections than they did.
Then a wild idea occurred to me. I looked up the "Chicago" ad in the paper and dialed the number for Ticketmaster. A minute later I had four seats in the center of the eighth row of the mezzanine, at $57.50 each. Now my only quandary was what to tell the out-of-towners. Should I revel in triumph ("Well, I don't want to get my connection in trouble, but let's say just I knew who to call") or admit the truth? Aside from enabling me to pose as a savvy New Yorker, wouldn't the lie also be good for my guests? Wouldn't they enjoy the show more if they thought the tickets were impossible to get? 
 I decided to be honest, which goes to show why I will never be a successful promoter, especially in New York. The city's trend-conscious industries and arbiters -- its theaters, restaurants, nightclubs, its fashion designers, art dealers, real-estate brokers -- traffic in illusions of scarcity. Manhattan, an island crowded with people who came here because it's crowded, is the mecca for those who don't want a seat unless they have to fight someone else to get it.
Economists explain this longing as a complicated consequence of the "snob effect" (we want something because it's available only to an elite) as well as the "bandwagon effect" (we want something because everyone else is buying it). It may seem frivolous, a lemminglike pursuit of fashion and status, but choosing something for its popularity can be a sensible form of decision-making. I call it the Matatu Conjecture, in honor of the strategy used by commuters in Kenya who ride in vans called matatus.
When choosing between competing vans waiting to depart from a depot, Kenyans typically get into the most crowded one -- for two reasons. A commuter sees the crowd as a useful bit of information about the quality of service; presumably all these people wouldn't have chosen a terrible driver or van. And because the first matatu to fill up will be the first to leave, a commuter knows that the crowd itself creates better service. Similarly, the popularity of a restaurant or play would seem to tell you something about its quality, and for many events the crowd itself creates a better experience, since you'll probably enjoy a concert or a play or a restaurant more if you're surrounded by an enthusiastic throng.
The problem, though, is that New York promoters have figured out the same counterstrategy as the matatu operators. When you spot a crowded van in Nairobi and take the last spot, another passenger may promptly get off, a ringer having been hired by the driver only to make his van look full. New York club owners sometimes hire people at hourly wages to stand outside in a line, but generally the city's promoters rely on more subtle variations. Restaurants keep window tables occupied and use partitions to hide empty tables in the back; theaters and restaurants quietly paper the house with people getting discounts or freebies.
"If a press photographer is coming to a restaurant, the smart owner does everything he can to fill the seats with warm bodies," says Ken Frydman, a restaurant consultant in Manhattan. "He calls his friends. He has some of his employees dress up and be customers for the evening. Some inexperienced owners want the photographer to shoot empty tables to show off the decor, but I tell them, 'People don't eat decor.' They go to a restaurant because they see other people there."
To create lines, promoters routinely offer some tickets well below the market price. By selling a few front-row seats for $20 shortly before each performance, the producers of "Rent" have induced people to camp out all day on the sidewalk, serving as a splendid advertisement to entice other customers to pay full price. And once they've attracted a crowd, promoters know that it's risky to tamper with popularity by raising prices. They appreciate the danger demonstrated by Gary Becker, a Nobel laureate economist at the University of Chicago. His paper, "A Note on Restaurant Pricing and Other Examples of Social Influences on Price," presents price-demand graphs showing how a popular restaurant can suddenly be ruined if people don't see a line at the door.
But no matter how much scheming promoters do, no matter how many lines they manufacture, there is ultimately a limit to consumer demand: all the seats cannot be filled all the time. My experience with "Chicago" wasn't particularly unusual. Broadway seats are easier to come by than the public realizes -- most shows still have tickets to sell the day of the performance. The hottest restaurants in town are often stuck with empty tables at the last minute. The media ritualistically report on scalpers demanding thousands of dollars for Super Bowl tickets, but some scalpers always get stuck at game time selling tickets for face value or less.
New Yorkers' illusions of scarcity could be devastated this year, because some legislators are trying to eliminate the state law that restricts the reselling of tickets. If we had an open market with lots of competing brokers, tickets would be readily available for much less than what black-market brokers now charge for the seats they obtain clandestinely. Promoters couldn't fool us any longer with artificial lines and baseless buzz. We'd know exactly how popular any show or a concert is by looking at the price of the tickets in the open market. We wouldn't need inside connections (or be so tempted to lie about having them). We could see any show we wanted without standing in line. The question is: Would we still want to go?

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
ALTERED STATES, by Anita Brookner. (Random House, $23.) Condemned to the mines of despair, the prisoner of Ms. Brookner's latest novel -- a man this time -- seeks surcease from a ruinous obsessive love in a cold and misty solitude.
 
THE CREATION OF DR. B: A Biography of Bruno Bettelheim, by Richard Pollak. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) Mr. Pollak's rendition of Bettelheim's life is startling: he was a liar, a fraud, an anti-Semite and a rat. What psychic good accrued to him thereby, the author doesn't say.
 
DO THE WINDOWS OPEN? by Julie Hecht. (Random House, $21.) A first collection of short stories by a brilliant comic writer whose single narrator links all the stories, sharing her daily harvest of terror, pessimism and misadventure.
 
EVERYTHING FOR SALE: The Virtues and Limits of Markets, by Robert Kuttner. (20th Century Fund/Knopf, $27.50.) A contrarian argument by a well-armed economics journalist who longs to demolish the view that government can do nothing right and markets nothing wrong.
 
FLYING HOME AND OTHER STORIES, by Ralph Ellison. Edited by John F. Callahan. (Random House, $23.) A slim but shining collection, some of its contents showing apprentice connections to "Invisible Man," all of it distinctively Ellison's.
 
GIRLS ONLY, by Alex Witchel. (Random House, $23.) Accounts of many all-woman excursions and expeditions by a style reporter for The Times with a gift for the joys and perils of female bonding.
 
GUIDED TOURS OF HELL: Novellas, by Francine Prose. (Metropolitan/Holt, $23.) Two irresistible tales about Americans abroad in pressurized environments that both speed and aggravate the purgation of their inner problems.
 
HINTS OF HIS MORTALITY, by David Borofka. (University of Iowa, $22.95.) An impressive short-story collection, chiefly inhabited by men who have somehow failed to make the grade.
 
THE ISLAND OF THE COLORBLIND: And Cycad Island, by Oliver Sacks. (Knopf, $24.) Once more in search of ingenious adaptations to bizarre conditions, the neurological explorer visits the Pacific in search of populations with runaway frequencies of color-blindness and parkinsonism.
 
PATCHES OF FIRE: A Story of War and Redemption, by Albert French. (Anchor/ Doubleday, $22.95.) An unflinching examination of his own service in Vietnam and failure in business by a black novelist whose grim past, he believes, has driven his creative present.
 
THE SPEARS OF TWILIGHT: Life and Death in the Amazon Jungle, by Philippe Descola. (New Press, $25.) Classic (but unclassically self-aware) fieldwork with a close-to-untouched culture in one of the last places on earth such things are found.

PUB-DATE: February 2, 1997

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1365 words

HEADLINE: Running Mates

BYLINE: By Robin Toner; Robin Toner is a national correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:

Affairs of State
 The Rise and Rejection of the
 Presidential Couple Since World War II.
 By Gil Troy.
 Illustrated. 486 pp. New York:
 The Free Press. $27.50. 
 It is hard to read "Affairs of State" without coming to the conclusion that the modern First Lady simply can't win.
She is expected to advance a serious project of her own -- like mental health or drug abuse or health care reform -- but also to avoid the slightest hint of seeking power and influence in her own right. She has to humanize and support her husband, without making him look dependent or needy. She has to satisfy the millions in the heartland who want to believe in the traditional marriage, and see it reflected in the White House, but also to appease the more liberal elites who expect a First Lady to be an issue-oriented partner.
She also has to manage -- and endure -- a press corps that plays to the public's almost unconscious fear of a dangerous, devouring, unelected co-President. Most First Ladies try, at one point or another, to carve out what Hillary Rodham Clinton once called a "zone of privacy." Bess Truman protested to a press corps going through Eleanor withdrawal: "You don't need to know me; I'm only the President's wife and the mother of his daughter!" Most of the First Ladies also chafe, at one time or another, at being pushed into the role of household saint. "I think we've had enough of this kitchen thing, don't you?" Pat Nixon said to photographers who wanted her posing in an apron one more time (a remark that would have got Mrs. Clinton all but burned at the stake 30 years later). And most of them, sooner or later, feel whipsawed by all the competing expectations. "I could stay here and pour tea and entertain the guests all day and I would be criticized," Rosalynn Carter said toward the end of her stint in the White House.
But no matter how these women rail against their fates, Gil Troy's portrait of modern First Couples, beginning with Eleanor and Franklin Roosevelt, suggests that these tensions are all but unavoidable. To begin with, contemporary First Ladies have the bad luck to be serving at a time when the definition of a "good marriage" is a matter of bitter dispute, indeed one of the issues at the heart of the culture wars. Nancy Reagan's adoring gaze at Ronnie was as offensive to some Americans as Mrs. Clinton's firm control over her husband's biggest domestic initiative was to others.
The days are probably long gone when most Americans could accept Mamie Eisenhower's blithe division of labor: "Ike runs the country and I turn the lamb chops." A lot of people simply wouldn't believe it; the women who survive and thrive as political spouses today are, by and large, not the lamb-chop-turning type. But a truly equal marriage in the White House, an out-in-the-open "two-for-the-price-of-one" deal, as the Clintons put it, leads inexorably to questions about "the unappointed, unimpeachable status of the First Lady," Mr. Troy, who teaches history at McGill University in Montreal, argues. One of the central themes of "Affairs of State" is that most Americans, with their abiding suspicion of government and the psychological baggage they still carry about powerful women, are simply not ready for anything like a co-Presidency.
"Who elected them?" is, of course, a question that could just as easily be asked about Cabinet officers, but rarely is. Still, it is not entirely a reflection of neurotic fears about women. The intimacy of marriage does not easily coexist with the coldblooded trade-offs necessary to get a legislative program passed; it can, in fact, cloud a President's judgment. The Clintons' health care debacle is one example. Mr. Troy writes about another in the Johnson Administration, when Lady Bird Johnson's beautification campaign was mired on Capitol Hill because Congress was resisting legislation to restrict billboards on Federal highways. "Even when Lady Bird was willing to compromise," Mr. Troy writes, "Lyndon refused, thundering, 'Ain't nobody going to be able to write a headline saying that Congress administers defeat to Lady Bird!' "
Still, there are strong historical forces that keep pushing First Ladies to the forefront of politics. Mr. Troy argues that the rise of the First Couple is not simply a function of the women's movement but reflects a mixture of factors, including the weakening of parties, the rise of personality politics, the increasing power of the Presidency and the Federal Government and, perhaps most important of all, "the rise of the mass media and the new political culture it spawned."
Presidents, their wives and their advisers were often eager participants in creating this phenomenon. They recognized the potential political payoff from a popular First Lady or an endearing White House marriage. Charles Colson wrote to President Nixon at one point, "The image of the First Family as it has recently emerged -- warm and appealing -- may well be one of the most important political developments of your Presidency." The Kennedys, of course, were masters at the game, granting unprecedented access to home and hearth to a press corps that was all too willing to suspend disbelief: "Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy will bring youth, beauty and babies to the White House," U.S. News & World Report declared during the transition.
The Kennedy Administration, though, was the last time the occupants of the White House had so much control in shaping the story of the First Couple. Mr. Troy's book goes on to detail the struggle between the press corps and each ensuing Administration over the image of the Presidential marriage. Was Mrs. Carter a supportive, loyal helpmate, or a steel magnolia sitting in on Cabinet meetings to buttress a weak husband? Was Mrs. Reagan the happy exemplar of a traditional wife, occasionally trying to protect her husband's interests behind the scenes, or, as William Safire put it in 1987, "an incipient Edith Wilson, unelected and unaccountable, presuming to control the actions and appointments of the executive branch" and making her husband look "wimpish and helpless"?
After a while, there's a certain depressing familiarity in these story lines that creeps into the political culture: the stronger the woman appears to be, the weaker the man must be. Mr. Troy, perhaps in an excess of Realpolitik, urges future First Couples essentially to resign themselves to these attitudes. He offers a series of recommendations in an appendix, ranging from "Don't Forget Who's Boss" (hint: it's not the First Lady) to "When in Doubt, Go Retro" to "Don't Be Yourselves; Be Who They Want You to Be." He makes the case again and again that the more traditional First Ladies, like Barbara Bush, are often the most popular -- with the masses, if not with the reporters who cover them. "First Couples should give the American people the love story they desire," he writes. "The Presidential spouse needs to symbolize the warm, traditional marriage she and the President have established -- despite working around the clock to get elected -- and give a warm-hearted facade to a welfare state that has grown increasingly complex, bureaucratic and impersonal."
At times, the author seems to have a striking lack of sympathy for the women caught in this hall of mirrors. Nowhere is that more clear than in his disdainful treatment of Betty Ford. As "an outspoken feminist activist," he argues, she embraced the new values sweeping the nation and "in so doing, she may have cost her husband the White House in 1976 and the historical respect his Administration is now often denied." (This is an exceedingly hard case to make, given the other factors at work in the 1976 election, including Watergate, Mr. Ford's pardon of Mr. Nixon and the turbulent economy.)
In the end, Mr. Troy clearly comes down on the side of stiff upper lips and maintaining appearances. He notes approvingly that Mrs. Bush had a firm grasp of an old truism: "The less power you seem to want, the more you'll get and the more popular you shall be." That is, of course, the advice given to women since the dawn of time. It would be nice to see it tested someday by a First Husband.
