PUB-DATE: February 2, 1997

SECTION: Section 6; Page 40; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 7952 words

HEADLINE: Trent Lott and His Fierce Freshmen

BYLINE: By Richard L. Berke; Richard L. Berke is the national political correspondent for The Times.

 BODY:
YOU'D THINK THE MAJORITY LEADER OF THE UNITED States Senate would have better things to do. But Trent Lott likes order so much that he often irons his cotton shirts after they have come back from the cleaners to remove any remaining wrinkles. "He criticized the way I ironed shirts one day," recalls Patricia Lott, his wife of 32 years. "I said, 'Fine, you do it.' So when the shirts come home from the cleaners and he doesn't like the way they're ironed, he does it. I don't."
Even in a world of blow-dried politicians, Lott is known for never having a hair out of place. ("I just spray it once and it stays," he says proudly.) Indeed, starched and sprayed, he seems as if he has always been preparing for more public inspection. Now he's getting it. With House Speaker Newt Gingrich engulfed in a storm over ethics, Lott has emerged as the nation's pre-eminent Republican. His conduct, perhaps more than any other factor, could determine the success of President Clinton's second term. 
 But Lott, who confesses to liking everything just so, could stumble, well-shined shoes and all. And the biggest obstacle for this Mississippi Senator may arise in his own caucus as he tries to tame the most rambunctious, conservative and independent-minded group of Senators in nearly 70 years. With the retirement of a flock of moderates on both sides, the institution's center has all but collapsed. Now the Senate is flush with nine new Republicans, eight of whom are conservative -- firebrands, even.
At first, Lott seems the ideal leader for this restive new class. He was a partisan soul mate of Gingrich from the time the two were backbenchers in the House Republican minority during the 1980's. As the Republican whip for nearly a decade, Lott was a fixture on the House floor, helping lead insurgent conservatives who opposed the Democratic majority at every turn. Lott had such a reputation as an unswerving conservative that when he was elected to succeed Bob Dole as majority leader last June, even moderate Republicans shuddered.
But fears of his radicalism may be overstated. A close look at his style and record shows that Lott is no ideologue. Throughout his career he has been driven much more by pragmatism and ambition. If Lott burns for anything, it is to keep the legislative trains running on time and to build a record of accomplishment.
Yet the danger for Lott, and for the Republican agenda in Congress, is that the very qualities that propelled his extraordinary rise to Senate leadership -- affability and a passion for order and achievement -- may also impede him now that he is there. Lott is confronted by a challenge that even the most adept legislator would find daunting: he must somehow satisfy the deep conservatism at the core of the new Senate without sacrificing the bipartisan coalitions needed to make laws.
Lott has confided to friends that he would like to be President someday. But if he is to pursue that ambition, he knows he cannot alienate the conservatives who are the foundation of his party. At the same time, he also must be viewed by the broader electorate as a leader who can steer Congress out of gridlock.
Even as the House whip, Lott did not have the stomach for partisan bomb-throwing that many of his comrades did. Unlike Gingrich, who for years had a tense relationship with Bob Michel, the House Republican leader who prided himself on working closely with Democrats, Lott always maintained a solicitous respect for his leader. He is that rare politician who, while content to work within the system, has somehow been able to project the image of true believer. Lott has so deftly played down his enthusiasm for compromise that he stunned many Republicans last fall when he embarked on a deal-cutting frenzy. He joined with Democrats to pass welfare and health-insurance reforms, raise the minimum wage and enact a safe-drinking-water measure. His deals prompted even the moderate Mark Hatfield of Oregon, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, to warn his new leader in one closed-door session, "Trent, you're giving away too much."
A prominent Republican Senator says of Lott: "What bothers me is his possible abandonment of principle and philosophy. He doesn't have the same kind of ideological drive that, frankly, Bob Dole had. In the end of the last session it just began to resemble an Arabian bazaar -- just giving the Administration whatever they wanted. That was disturbing to some of us."
The Senator, fearful of crossing his leader, spoke on the condition of anonymity. But if such sentiments come to be widely held and conservatives are not placated, Lott's control over the Senate could be undermined. In an institution where one member can gum up the works for hours, the new Senators are not likely to stand by and watch a leader who forsakes his conservative principles.
Lott presides over a different institution than he did just a few months ago. The new Senate more resembles the rebellious House of 1994. Forty-three Senators, including 25 Republicans, are alumni of the House, the largest proportion in modern history. During their long years in the minority many of those Republicans were schooled in partisan guerrilla tactics. Republicans are still short of what Lott calls "that magic 60" -- the 60-vote majority necessary to break efforts to block legislation through filibuster. But with a comfortable majority of 55 Republicans, the largest since 1929, this Senate may produce the first anti-abortion majority since the Supreme Court permitted abortion a quarter century ago. Lott could be saddled with an institution ready for confrontation and reluctant to compromise.
George Washington is said to have explained to Thomas Jefferson that the reason for creating the Senate was to have one house that is more thoughtful and deliberative. "We pour legislation into the senatorial saucer to cool it," Washington said.
In the new 105th Congress, the Senate threatens to boil over with a reprise of issues that exploded in the last session in the House, like flag burning, late-term abortion and term limits. Many Republican Senators say they will not be content merely to join with the Democrats to pass the balanced-budget amendment, which failed in the last Senate by one vote. They hope its passage will embolden Republicans to push through other initiatives like tax cuts. Republicans also expect to bring about a sweeping review of regulations governing public health, safety and the environment; only last year, a more moderate Senate rejected as too radical a similar measure that had passed the House.
It is something of a role reversal only two years after Gingrich and the Republicans seized control of the House. Their rightward revolution left the more moderate Senate uncomfortably out of the limelight. But last November, House Republicans saw their numbers diminish to the slimmest majority of either party in four decades, while Senate Republicans picked up two seats.
"I'm not up here to be a potted plant," says Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama. He replaced Howell Heflin, a Democrat who in 1986 cast the pivotal vote to deny Sessions a Federal judgeship and who accused him of racial insensitivity. This new Senator intends to press for allowing prayer in public places, saying, "There's a feeling that the Government has been hostile and disrespectful to people of faith."
Even in states where one Republican replaced another, there is movement to the right, as in Oregon, where Gordon Smith, a frozen-food executive, succeeded Hatfield. In Kansas alone, the replacements for Senators Dole and Nancy Landon Kassebaum are two hard-driving conservatives, Sam Brownback and Pat Roberts. Brownback, a member of the rebellious class of 1994 in the House, moved even further to the right during his Senate campaign last year, calling for cuts in education, fewer environmental regulations and restrictions on abortion -- as well as the elimination of no fewer than four Cabinet agencies. "The country is moving more conservative and the Senate reflects that," Brownback says. "If the President puts forward 10 new programs he wants us to start, you're not going to see that happen."
When Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania, went from the House to the Senate in 1995, he was considered something of a misfit, impatient with the more deliberate pace. Now, he hardly stands out. "We're willing to negotiate," Santorum warns, "but we'll negotiate on our turf. In the past, we've negotiated on the other guys' turf."
Indeed, many Democrats say Lott will preside over a Senate that is ruled by ideologues. Senator Tim Johnson, a freshman Democrat from South Dakota and a 10-year House veteran, says: "Some of the partisan mean-spiritedness that has overtaken the House appears to be contagious and may be gaining ground in the Senate. There are forces that would like to move Lott into a combative right-wing mode."
Already, many conservatives are furious at Lott for one of his first moves this year: agreeing to seat Senator Mary Landrieu, a Democrat from Louisiana, even as an investigation continues into accusations that voter fraud gave her an edge over her Republican opponent, Woody Jenkins. Lott followed past practice of dispatching the Rules Committee to conduct an inquiry, but some conservatives say he should have picked a more committed partisan than the committee's chairman, Senator John Warner of Virginia. "It upsets me terribly," says William W. Pascoe 3d, political director of the American Conservative Union. "He was caught up in all this balderdash about the spirit of bipartisanship."
Lott should take notice of such talk. So should other Republicans with designs on the White House, like Senators John McCain of Arizona, Phil Gramm of Texas and even Fred Thompson of Tennessee, who is soon to preside over the hearings on White House fund-raising. Even without threatening Lott's post as majority leader, those Senators would be only too eager to grab the mantle of conservative leader -- and the allegiance of conservative freshmen -- for themselves.
Asked if he, like some other conservatives, thinks Lott was too accommodating to the Democrats last year, Vin Weber, a former House member and a close friend of the Senator, chooses his words carefully: "I withhold judgment on that. Trent was not really leader in the true sense of the word. He sort of completed Dole's tenure as leader." Weber is one of many conservatives who find themselves explaining away Lott's behavior. It is hardly encouraging for Lott that rather than praise the Senator, the best his longtime ally can do is withhold judgment.
 CHARACTERISTICALLY, LOTT PLAYS TO BOTH SIDES WHEN he explains his actions last year. In what sounds like a bone for the conservatives, he says the compromises "could have been a result of the circumstances and the timing" and were not "necessarily a model for how we'll operate." He explains that part of the impetus last year was "the fact that I was new and that I was trying to force action to conclusions on legislation" in an effort "to get the approval ratings up of the Senate."
But then Lott could not help but betray his enthusiasm for making law: "There was a moment where if we didn't do those things, they weren't going to be done -- maybe not then, and maybe never. I have very strong principles and philosophies that I believe in. But what good is a 100 percent pure position if you don't produce any results for the people you care about and your country?"
This artful weighing of principle and product has been a tenet of Lott's professional life. But the new Republicans, not nearly as focused as Lott on building a record, may not accept Lott's balancing act. Sessions, for one, says getting a law passed is not always the goal. Even if he fails, he says, he's determined to press for aggressive efforts to cut waste and fraud in Government. "There are things I'm going to try that I wouldn't have had the energy to try if I had been here 18 years," he says. "And some of those will succeed."
Wayne Allard, a freshman from Colorado, says he plans to co-sponsor a constitutional amendment to prohibit flag burning, a cause he pushed when he was in the House. "We need to recognize there was a lot of blood shed behind that flag."
But Lott is not big on symbolic causes, so do not expect him to champion a flag-burning measure. He has no interest in bringing up an issue for a vote unless he is certain it will pass. This longtime legislative whip, the man whose job is to marshal votes, still views success in terms of passing laws: product, not polemics. When asked what he wants to accomplish this session, Lott does not list goals. He lists bills -- and the list is long. Lott will try to satisfy conservatives with other issues he thinks may have better prospects, like prohibiting late-term abortions. "The social and cultural decay in this country is a major problem and a major concern," he says, "and I think that late-term abortion is a horrible procedure."
Even so, as much as the freshmen talk passionately about eroding morals, Lott has no intention of letting grandstanding on social values preoccupy the Senate. "These issues will be voted on again and they will play out this year," he says. "But they're not going to be things that I just pound home repeatedly. What I prefer to do is bring it up, have a good debate, have a vote -- and win it and move on."
Will that be good enough for the hard-edged conservatives? Lott certainly seems to think so. He pleads ignorance of the notion of an obstreperous class of agitators, citing first Susan Collins of Maine, the only moderate (and only woman) among the nine new Republicans. "Oh?" he asked, bounding down a hotel corridor in Grand Rapids, Mich., shortly after the election. "I didn't notice that. Susan Collins? Who are you talking about? Wayne Allard? These are all very mild-mannered people."
As majority leader, Lott is quite comfortable asserting control by making rules. He recently backed efforts to make sure pedestrians do not stray from designated crosswalks on the Capitol plaza. But his most basic impulse is to control by making friends. The political solar system Lott has created around himself operates upon personal attractions and loyalties. The strategy has worked well for Lott. It is no accident that he is the only person to have ever served as Republican whip in both the House and the Senate, responsible for rounding up votes on both sides of the aisle.
Yet some conservatives wonder if Lott is too friendly to Democrats. Consider the scene on the Senate floor the first Tuesday in January, when members were sworn in. The Senate leader roamed the deep-blue-carpeted floor of the chamber as if attending a garden party, offering bear hugs to Senators like the two liberals from Massachusetts, Edward Kennedy and John Kerry. At that moment on the other side of the Capitol, there were no hardy embraces between Gingrich and the Democrats.
It does not reassure conservatives that Lott seems to get on well with Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader. Eyeing an oil portrait of a smiling Dole on the wall of Lott's outer office, Daschle allows as to how there is a comfort level that did not exist with Dole. It is in part because he and Lott are closer in age. Lott is 55; Daschle is 49.
Moments later, when Daschle is ushered into Lott's office, the majority leader, characteristically, is all hospitality. "Y'all pull up a chair and have a seat," Lott says. Both Senators shed their jackets as Lott seeks Daschle's guidance in working out the Senate schedule. "I wanted you to look over that, go over it and make sure that you understand what we've got there," he says.
And while Lott warns that the Senate might not sign off easily on Clinton's appointments, particularly to the Federal judiciary, so far he has mostly played the accommodator. Hours after Madeleine K. Albright was selected Secretary of State, he assured her that "you'll do fine -- we look forward to working with you." Asked when he hung up the phone why he seemed so soft, he quickly dispensed with the sweet talk, saying Albright would be asked a lot of "very critical" questions. That never happened. The Albright nomination sailed through unanimously.
If it is Southern civility that he lavishes on Democrats, Lott is positively solicitous of his freshmen. One of his first outreach efforts was to hold formal orientation sessions at which the new members and their families could learn the ways of the Senate. In the past, such gatherings were more haphazard. And Lott won praise from junior members when he supported new rules that limit Senators in most cases to one committee or subcommittee chairmanship, a move that spreads influence among more members.
Smith of Oregon, for one, says he is indebted to Lott for a spot on the Budget Committee, "which I prize." He boasts, "I'm the only freshman." Asked if this means he will be more willing to go along with the majority leader, Smith says, "Of course it does." But Smith leaves himself an escape. "I'm certainly going to be deferential to him," he says, "to listen to him, to follow him when I can follow him, when I think he's right."
Lott courts the veterans just as aggressively, praising his leadership team at every turn. To smooth relations with Don Nickles of Oklahoma, his second-in-command, over whom he leapfrogged on the leadership ladder, Lott gave him a larger office and a bigger staff. And he saw to it that instead of being called whip, Nickles is referred to by the more impressive title "assistant majority leader."
In the world's most exclusive club, these gestures mean a lot. "Trent has been putting more responsibility to me as assistant majority leader -- and a better office," Nickles says. "I appreciate that."
But it is the moderates who speak most effusively about Lott. That is because time and again, he has demonstrated that he believes partisan cohesion is more important than conservative dogma. In the House, Lott won the allegiance of Olympia Snowe, who was then a Representative of Maine, when he appointed her as deputy whip, even though her moderate views were at odds with the Republican leadership. Snowe, now a Senator, is one of his most vigorous loyalists. "He does have a more conservative agenda, but he doesn't drive an ideological agenda," she says. "Trent's not going to force us to walk a political plank when it's totally unnecessary."
This year, Lott discouraged efforts by some conservatives who threatened to challenge the chairmanships of perhaps the two most moderate Republicans, Senators John Chafee of Rhode Island and James Jeffords of Vermont. His support might make it less likely that Chafee or Jeffords will stray from the majority on close votes. "He's an excellent person to work with as long as you're square with him," says Jeffords. He and Lott are particularly congenial because they perform regularly in a quartet called the Singing Senators.
Lott has a booming bass and a style that is more open and affable than that of his predecessor, Dole, who was less gregarious -- and less likely to involve many Senators in decision-making. But Dole was also far less controlling. Lott injects himself into the nuts and bolts of committee assignments, concerns that Dole often relegated to Sheila Burke, his chief of staff.
Lott is a master at using charm to get things done his way. Consider how events unfolded after McCain stepped down as chairman of the Indian Affairs Committee. American Indian groups inundated the Senate with faxes and phone calls, imploring Lott not to give the post to the next Republican in line, Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, who is viewed as an opponent of tribal self-government. Their pick was Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell of Colorado, who is part American Indian. With Gorton holding on the other line, Lott, speaking from his office in December, assures Campbell he could convince Gorton to pass up the job. But Lott first has to make sure Campbell wants it.
"If we could work it out where you could be chairman of Indian Affairs, would you be interested in that?" Lott asks Campbell. "I think we've got it worked out with Slade. But I just want to make sure you were interested. And if you are, I'll try to wrap that up tomorrow. O.K.? All right, sir! O.K.! That would be great! Thanks a lot, Ben!"
Lott adds a cautionary note: "Hey, Ben. That's not official yet. I've got to do a couple other things. O.K.? Thanks, buddy."
Then he grabs the line where Gorton is holding. He talks about options for Gorton, but does not tell him that he has just assured Campbell he would get Indian Affairs. "I'm sorry I didn't get back to you quicker," he says. "But I've been just swamped here." Everything went smoothly when Campbell's ascension was announced weeks later; Gorton ended up taking the chairmanship of an aviation subcommittee instead of Indian Affairs.
It is a telling demonstration of Lott's need for order, and his yearning for legislative accomplishment, that his one public outburst as leader was not directed solely at Democrats. Barely three weeks after he took over from Dole, Lott stunned official Washington by upbraiding his Democratic and Republican colleagues for gridlock, asserting that the Senate had become "all balled up here -- and it's not my fault." In Trent Lott's Senate, there is little patience for partisan posturing. He wants results, even if it means consorting with the other side.
 LOTT'S NEED FOR CONTROL, TO BRING order to legislative chaos and, most of all, to satisfy both sides, may stem from his upbringing as an only child in Pascagoula, on the Gulf Coast of Mississippi. He often found himself as the intermediary between his feuding parents; his mother, Iona, now 83, was a schoolteacher, and his father was a shipyard worker who died in a car wreck in 1969 that Lott says was linked to a drinking problem.
Determined, as ever, to manage his image, Lott is reluctant to talk about his father's drinking. "I just don't like to get into personal things," he says. But after some prodding, he discusses his childhood, if only to prove that he is "not ashamed" of his past: "My mother was an educator, a very religious person. Very opinionated. Very blunt, a disciplinarian, a great lady. My dad was a little bit of a happy-go-lucky fellow and he liked to have a good time. He was a hard worker, very proud of his family. Had a drinking problem. He had problems with it all his life. And that sort of problem does affect you. You are forced into problems between your mother and your father. It makes you maybe grow up maybe a little early.
"But it wasn't a dysfunctional family or a cruel family. After I was 4 or 5 years old, I don't think my father ever laid a hand on me. It's not a sad story of oppression or depression or meanness. It's not something that I go home and brood about or cry about."
Lott's early friends say he never revealed any problems at home. He was voted Most Likely to Succeed by his Pascagoula High School class of 1959. "There were the goody-goodies and there were the hoods," says Jerry Dossett, a high-school classmate who runs a pawn shop in Gautier, Miss. "I'm sorry to say that I fit in with the latter group. But that Trent -- he could adapt himself to either group when he wanted to."
Even at the rowdy Sigma Nu fraternity at the University of Mississippi, Lott's passion for control was on display. "Trent was a meticulously neat fellow," recalls Roy Williams, a lawyer in Pascagoula who went to high school with Lott and roomed with him in college. "He had all the tools to be a hell raiser: a good talker, good looking and well liked by all the girls. But he never did raise hell. We never talked about politics in those days, but I recall him as always doing things in moderation, always being in control."
Lott, of course, has not lost the Southern sociability that he displayed in high school and as head cheerleader at the University of Mississippi. Combined with his driving ambition, his charm helped him leap over more senior colleagues to claim the job of Republican whip, then majority leader of the Senate.
His overriding pragmatism has also served Lott well, and it was obvious from the start of his political career. In fact, he was once a Democrat, albeit a conservative one. Lott had barely begun his law practice on Mississippi's Gulf Coast when Representative William M. Colmer, a Democratic segregationist and chairman of the Rules Committee, summoned him to Washington in 1968 to be his top aide. When Colmer retired in 1972, Lott, feeling increasingly alienated from liberals and anticipating the rise of conservatism in the South, announced that he was seeking Colmer's seat as a Republican. He vowed to fight "the ever-increasing efforts of the so-called liberals to concentrate more power in the Government in Washington."
But putting votes over partisanship, Lott insisted on restraint in advertising his new-found Republicanism. "He said, 'I'm running as a candidate for Congress in an area that is not very Republican, and so I don't want the word "Republican" on the headquarters,' " recalls Evelyn McPhail, who until recently was the co-chairwoman of the Republican National Committee and was one of Lott's first volunteers. "We wanted to argue with him: 'You'll be the first Republican we've ever elected down here. We want that on our headquarters.' He said, 'No, you're going to do 'Trent Lott, Congress.' That was the first indication I had that Trent was the boss."
Indeed, one of Lott's most impressive achievements is that he has managed to maintain his conservative credentials while pursuing deals. He has always won near-perfect ratings on social and economic matters from right-wing groups like the American Conservative Union. As late as 1983, Lott opposed the creation of a national holiday to honor Martin Luther King Jr. Lott's discomfort with taxes and big government made him a champion of supply-side economics and deregulation in the late 1970's and 1980's. In fact, he was so opposed to taxes that in 1985, in a rare move, he abandoned Ronald Reagan on his top priority, a tax overhaul; five years later, he opposed George Bush's agreement with Congress to raise taxes. Even Lott admits that there have been moments of weakness. Most notably, he regrets supporting the 1986 tax-reform conference report because it didn't go far enough. "I didn't want to vote for that," Lott says. "I let the President talk me into it. If I could go back, I'd take that vote back."
Long a hawk on military issues, Lott was chairman of the Armed Services subcommittee on strategic forces. He now sits on the Finance, Rules and Commerce Committees. He is vigilant in protecting Mississippi interests, especially the state's military-related concerns. But unlike many long-serving lawmakers who develop an interest and expertise in specific legislative areas, Lott is not usually identified with a particular issue. Instead, he channeled his energy into cutting deals and cultivating his colleagues so he could rise in the leadership. From 1981 to 1989, Lott served as minority whip under Michel, the minority leader. In that post, he sought to show fealty to Michel, who liked to work with Democrats, while also working closely with impatient conservatives like Gingrich.
John McCain says Lott was known as a hard-charging partisan because that was his role. "In the House, when he was whip of a minority his job was to be the adversary, the obstructionist," he says. "In the 80's, being in the minority, the only option you had was guerrilla warfare. You play the hand you're dealt."
But Lott felt stuck after 16 years in the House. He did not want to take on Michel, and unlike Gingrich, he had no master plan for breaking out of the minority. "I'd been in the leadership eight years," he says. "I didn't see Bob Michel leaving any time soon."
Senator Thad Cochran, the senior Republican Senator from Mississippi, a rival of his for years, says Lott moved on when he was threatened by others like Gingrich and Dick Cheney. (Cheney succeeded Lott as whip, Gingrich succeeded Cheney, and six years after Lott's departure, Gingrich became Speaker.) "When Dick Cheney and Newt Gingrich came in, he started to get crowded from behind," Cochran says. "He was beginning to lose his chance. Cheney was an unusually gifted person who had a lot of friends in the House. The word was, if Trent doesn't hurry up and run for leader, they might turn to somebody else."
So Lott gambled in 1988, giving up a safe House seat to take on a popular Democrat, Representative Wayne Dowdy, in a state that was still considered Democratic. Not surprisingly, he rose faster in the Senate, an institution that puts a premium on Lott's propensities toward civility and accommodation; he was elected secretary of the Republican Conference, the No. 4 leadership post, after the 1992 election. His biggest coup was in ousting Senator Alan Simpson of Wyoming as whip after the 1994 election. With help from his Senate colleagues who had also served with him in the House, he won by a single vote. Capitalizing on the Republican takeover of Congress, Lott pitched himself as a conservative complement to the newly Republican-controlled House. That put him in line for majority leader. And in what was seen as another unseemly breach of Senate custom, last June, Lott took on and defeated his state's senior Senator, Cochran, who also sought the post.
Many of Lott's peers expected him to be far more partisan than Dole. But Lott's politics prove to be nearly as flexible as Clinton's. In fact, for years, one of his closest advisers was Dick Morris, who while advising Clinton in 1995 was meeting weekly with Lott. In his new book, "Behind the Oval Office," Morris says Lott spoke with derision about wayward House freshmen who refused to go along with the Republican budget plan. "He began to refer to the House freshmen Republicans, the radical purists, as the ayatollahs," writes Morris. "While in basic agreement with their conservative views, he had a professional politician's contempt for their naivete."
After he defeated Simpson for the whip post, Lott says Simpson urged him not to try to relive the partisan battles that scarred the House. "He said, 'Look, I know you came from a horribly mistreated, oppressed minority in the House where every day you had to battle for your very existence,' " Lott recalls. " 'It was partisan. It was mean. It was hard. Forget that. The Senate is not the same. You're not going to ever get anything done if you don't have some partisan cooperation." Simpson, who retired this year and was regarded as the moderate when he lost the whip's race to Lott, says he nows considers Lott "a moderate, thoughtful leader." In fact, the Senate is known for softening the hard edges of its members, even if newcomers are not always ready for mellow moderation.
 CLINTON AND LOTT, on opposite ends of Pennsylvania Avenue, at times seem like bookends. "We both live next to the same river," the Mississippi, says Lott. "We both came from blue-collar families. We're about the same age. We're the same religion -- Baptist." Lott goes on, sounding as though he might be describing himself. "He's very capable, very intelligent, very smooth -- and he's a very worthy adversary."
Clinton agrees that "we have some similarities in our upbringing and, obviously, in the culture in which we grew up."
Lott declares himself to be an optimist and insists that Congress can be productive if it keeps separate its legislative duties and the inquiries into the Clinton and Gingrich ethical allegations. But many Democrats fully expect Senate Republicans to keep the heat on Clinton in retaliation for the Democrats' ethics campaign against Gingrich.
Lott's role model as majority leader is not Dole but Dole's predecessor, George Mitchell, the Democrat from Maine who was known for masking relentless partisanship with a judicial demeanor. "He was an intelligent leader and an effective one," Lott says. "He had a way of being very gentle and soft, in the way he appeared. He appeared moderate, but he was very tough. So I think there's something to be said for that."
He is already exhibiting traits that Mitchell put to good use. In the same language that Mitchell used with Bush, Lott has called on Clinton to go first, show leadership and come up with the first budget proposal. Declaring, "I want the President to lead," Lott says it is up to Clinton to put forward the first proposals on such volatile measures as wringing savings from Medicare.
Lott calls his approach to the White House, and to the Senate, not revolution but "regular order" -- the phrase Senators shout on the floor when rules are not being followed. It is a fitting choice of words for a majority leader obsessed with control. But he is essentially setting a challenge for the President: You hammered us relentlessly during the campaign about Medicare, and you promised to balance the budget. Let's see how you do it.
At times, Lott, still bitter over the Democrats' successful drive last year to portray Republicans as willing to sacrifice Medicare, sounds as if he is spoiling for battle. "I thought what the Democrats did, what the President did on Medicare was irresponsible," he says. "I thought it was demagoguery. They have not leveled with the American people. They have misled the American people. There is no question about that. They know it. We know it. You know it."
Further friction is inevitable. Clinton, the day after his second inauguration, called for a broad rewrite of campaign-finance laws, and Daschle says it is his top priority. But Lott argues that the problem may be more with the Democrats' fund-raising practices; the most he is willing to do for now is hold hearings. And Senate Republicans say they have no intention of "fixing" the welfare bill that was passed last year, as the President has suggested. Another area of tension may be over Clinton's use of the new Presidential line-item veto. "There are concerns that the President might use it in some ways that were not intended -- or could be interpreted as being political," Lott says.
Clinton might also find Lott to be less deferential than Dole if a foreign policy crisis erupts. "Bob Dole was a person who had a reverence for the office of the Presidency," McCain says. "He supported the constitutional authority of the President as Commander in Chief. That's an area where we may have trouble. Suppose another Bosnia arises? Lott just doesn't have the broad years of experience that Bob Dole has."
But for now, it is the freshmen, not Lott, who are more willing to register doubts about Clinton. "I've gotten a sense that you have to be pretty careful when you make a deal with this guy," says Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, who joins the Senate after a career as an investment bank executive. "I will do all I can to work with the President. But when I think the President needs to be challenged and he's off track and off base, you'll hear from this Senator from Nebraska."
Since it is too soon to proclaim the end of gridlock, these are anxious days in Washington for both conservatives and liberals as they watch their standard bearers to make sure that their penchant for accommodation does not get the best of them. Clinton and Lott have spent much time on the phone with each other in recent weeks; often their staffs do not know of the conversations. The two have also been spotted chatting in the White House residence. Just as William Pascoe of the American Conservative Union complains that Lott did not use his power to try to deny Mary Landrieu her Senate seat, a Clinton aide gripes that the President does not marshal his influence to act tougher in his dealings with Lott. "It's amazing," says this aide, sitting only steps away from the Oval Office. "It's as if he doesn't know he's won and is afraid to use the power. He could go up there and [expletive] on Trent Lott's shoes if he chose to."
 AS LOTT AND GINGRICH stood before a roomful of reporters at a conference of the Republican Governors Association in Grand Rapids, Mich., late last November, one questioner asked what was on everyone's mind: Which politician is now the true superstar of the Republican Party? Gingrich, conceding the obvious with good humor, immediately pointed to Lott. Lott did his best to play down his role, saying he and Gingrich and the Republican Governors would all speak out on issues. "It's not going to be a majority of personalities," he assured the gathering. "This is going to be a majority of ideas."
Lott was speaking as much out of pragmatism as out of modesty. After witnessing a two-year case study on how not to run a revolution, Lott knows from Gingrich's experience that he must be careful not to appear too headstrong or unwilling to work with Democrats. While much of the partisan fervor that marked the House two years ago exists in the Senate today, Lott and his freshmen will express it in subtler, smarter ways.
One of his biggest worries is that he not repeat Gingrich's missteps of appearing to bask in his new-found power. "I will do my share of the Sunday talk shows," he says, "but I will not do it every weekend. We've learned some important lessons over the last two years. How we do things, and how we talk about what we're doing, makes a big difference."
Lott's point is that too often the House Republicans were outwitted by the White House, allowing Democrats to unfairly paint them as intolerant, extremist and unfeeling on issues like Medicare. "If you talk about things in military terms, it may not be well received," he says. "If you talk about what it means to an elderly person or a teen-age girl or for families, then they see that closer to home. Bill Clinton vetoed our budget bill and shut down the Government. He shut it down. But he got away with convincing the American people that Congress did it. That won't happen again."
As Senator Connie Mack of Florida, a member of the leadership and one of Lott's closest friends, puts it, "He is very sensitive to make sure he's not overplaying the situation." Mack says that reflects not only Lott's concern that he not repeat Gingrich's mistakes but also a more participatory approach. "It's generational in the sense that those in Trent's generation, we learned a different type of management, much more participatory than Bob's management, which was very hierarchical." He adds in a chest-thumping baritone, 'I am the leader.' "
But no matter how participatory Trent Lott is, no matter how much he tries to control, his colleagues are monitoring him closely for signs of movement to the middle. Even Gramm, who backed Lott for majority leader, is not prepared to classify him as die-hard a conservative as he is. "No one," Gramm says, "is as committed a conservative as I am."
Lott knows he had better watch out for such wary skeptics if he is to tame the new Senate. He says that was the only parting advice from Dole, who often scrapped with Gramm. "He cautioned me about a couple people to keep an eye on," Lott says. "People who'd give me trouble."
 
THUNDER ON THE RIGHT
 
Senator Alan Simpson, now retired, advises successors: "Relax. You're not here to be a firebrand; you're here to be a legislator." But several new Senators, and some veterans, are very likely to make work, or trouble, for the Republican leader.
 
SAM BROWNBACK, KANSAS
Elected in 1996.
Succeeds: Sheila Frahm, the interim replacement for Bob Dole.
Previous job: U.S. House of Representatives.
 A leader of the House class of 1994, Brownback derided "the imperial Congress" and pledged not to stay in the House long. He did not. Now, just two years later, he stands out in the Senate class of 1996 as perhaps the most prone to revolution. He is less seasoned but more of a troublemaker than the other freshman Republican Senator from Kansas, Pat Roberts, a 16-year House veteran. But Brownback has an outlet for his impatience: he has been named to head a Governmental Affairs subcommittee that deals with Government restructuring.
 Agenda: Brownback says he is most passionate about balancing the budget and fears that President Clinton is not as committed. "It's like what Ronald Reagan said, 'Trust but verify.' " he says. "I trust that he wants to balance the budget, but I want to verify that he actually does."

GORDON SMITH, OREGON
Elected in 1996.
Succeeds: Mark Hatfield, Republican.
Previous job: Frozen-food company executive.
 Smith, who campaigned as a staunch conservative, narrowly lost a special election early last year for a Senate seat from Oregon. When he ran for the other seat months later, he recast himself as a moderate in the Hatfield mold. While Smith does not have the persona of an aggressive conservative, some Republicans expect him to take the right-wing positions that marked his original run for Senate and his service in the state Senate. During his first U.S. Senate race, for example, he said landlords "should not be forced to rent to homosexuals" and emphasized his opposition to abortion and his support for rewriting environmental laws.
 Agenda: Smith says that the parties need to work together but that he fears the ethics clouds over Clinton and Gingrich will make that difficult. "My biggest fear is that it will all break down in recriminations and acrimony and that we'll never rise to the mandate of the electorate, which is to figure things out."

JEFF SESSIONS, ALABAMA
Elected in 1996.
Succeeds: Howell Heflin, Democrat.
Previous job: Alabama Attorney General.
Sessions's past experience with the Senate could not have left a good taste. His nomination to be a Federal judge was scuttled in 1986 after Judiciary Committee members (including Heflin) objected to sworn statements in which Sessions attacked the N.A.A.C.P. and the A.C.L.U. as "un-American" and "Communist inspired." Of the Ku Klux Klan he once said, "I used to think they're O.K." until he learned that some members were "pot smokers." In the campaign, Sessions promoted himself as an authentic conservative and won vigorous backing from religious conservatives.
 Agenda: Sessions says he intends to work to undo many regulations that unduly burden businesses. He says he also will press his views on social issues like opposing gay rights. "Government institutions seem to be quite hostile to anybody who makes a moral choice that gay activity is not acceptable and shouldn't be approved," he says.

TIM HUTCHINSON, ARKANSAS
Elected in 1996.
Succeeds: David Pryor, Democrat.
Previous job: U.S. House of Representatives.
 The Whitewater controversy has been a boon to Hutchinson. When Gov. Jim Guy Tucker, a Democrat, resigned after being convicted in a Whitewater-related case, the Republican Lieutenant Governor, Mike Huckabee, moved up to Governor. That created an opening for Hutchinson, who had served in the House since 1993 and who was closely linked with Newt Gingrich by Hutchinson's Democratic opponent. Hutchinson, a former Baptist minister, is closer to religious conservatives than any other freshman and may push hard to ban late-term abortions.
 Agenda: Hutchinson says he is determined that taxes be cut for American families. "The things that came out of the House that were dead on arrival when they came to the Senate -- some of those we'll now take a second look at," he says.

CHUCK HAGEL, NEBRASKA
Elected in 1996.
Succeeds: Jim Exon, a Democrat.
Previous job: Investment bank executive.
 In one of the big upsets of 1996, Hagel, a political unknown, won the Senate seat over Gov. Ben Nelson. Hagel is so fervent about cutting taxes to spur growth that he went beyond embracing Bob Dole's plan for a 15 percent tax cut; his other ideas include eliminating the capital gains tax as well as estate and gift taxes.
 Agenda: Hagel says he will press for cutting taxes and reining in entitlement programs. "If we continue going along the path we're going now," he says, "we will certainly ruin our country. I think we've asked Government to do too much in the last 30 years." Saying he is not in a great mood to compromise and cut deals, Hagel adds, "I did not run for the United States Senate because I need a job."

RICK SANTORUM, PENNSYLVANIA
Elected in 1994.
Previous job: U.S. House of Representatives.
 At 38, he is the youngest Senator and brash at that, some say to the point of arrogance. Ready to take on anyone who does not hew to his conservative views, Santorum has been impatient with the traditions of the Senate. He was the leader of the movement to oust Mark Hatfield as chairman of the Appropriations Committee for opposing a balanced budget amendment.
 Agenda: He will probably press for constitutional amendments on issues like late-term abortion and flag burning and to jab at moderate Republicans like Senator Jim Jeffords of Vermont. "If the Democrats are still going to be in denial that they're not in the majority," he says, "and continue to be obstructionist and slow the process down, if they continue these tactics, we very well could have some pretty tough times."

JOHN McCAIN, ARIZONA
Elected in 1986.
 He has newfound power as chairman of the Commerce Committee and may differ with Lott about being too accommodating of Democrats. But McCain is not always predictably conservative; his views can be eclectic. He already clashes sharply with Lott on a major issue that is not at all ideological: McCain is championing a bipartisan drive to overhaul campaign-finance laws and limit the amount of money spent on campaigns. Lott has raised objections.
 Agenda: He says campaign-finance reform is crucial. "I have differences with Trent Lott and will continue to," he says. "I'm sure in many ways he regards me as a thorn in his side. But frankly, he's got to handle this campaign-finance reform issue."

JESSE HELMS, NORTH CAROLINA
Elected in 1972.
 The Senate's best-known mischief maker, Helms kept an unusually low profile in the last session, perhaps because he was up for re-election. A favorite pastime has been provoking secretaries of state and holding hostage nominees for ambassadorships. Madeleine Albright, the new Secretary of State, has worked patiently to build a relationship with Helms, which paid off with his courteous treatment of her at her recent nomination hearing. But at some point, contention is likely between Helms and the White House over Clinton's decision not to enforce aspects of the Helms-Burton Act, which punishes some foreign companies that do business with Cuba. Another possible area of contention: relations with China.
 Agenda: After years as something of a lone wolf, Helms is also sure to find more support among his colleagues for hard-right positions on social issues like opposing civil rights for homosexuals.

PHIL GRAMM, TEXAS
Elected in 1984.
 He ran unsuccessfully in the Republican Presidential primaries but was re-elected to the Senate in November -- and remains as outspoken as ever. His Presidential ambitions are still burning, and he has a new platform as chairman of the Finance subcommittee that oversees Medicare and Medicaid. Gramm could spoil efforts by Senate Republicans and the White House to reach bipartisan consensus. As one Congressional Democrat observes about Gramm's new post, "Can you be chairman of something you oppose?"
 Agenda: Gramm vows to make sure Senate Republicans do not waver in their conservatism. "I don't intend to be accommodating," he says. "We won the election."

HEADLINE: SAILINGS WORLDWIDE;
Not Just Cruise Ships Anymore

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL; EDWIN McDOWELL is a business reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
HEAVY bookings for millennium cruises, including cruises whose price and itinerary are not yet established, promise to jump-start the cruise business for the year 2000. But right now the industry is perplexed about 1996, worried about 1997, and wondering whether any of those heady projections about the growing popularity of cruising will be realized before the next century.
To insure that popularity, the biggest ships (whose number -- and size -- are growing rapidly) have virtually become floating destinations, competing with resorts for vacationers' dollars. Elaborate spas, entertainment complexes, boutiques, children's programs, wedding services and sports facilities are to be found on such modern ships as the Carnival Destiny, the Century and the Galaxy. 
 More shorter cruises are being offered, as well as more eco-tourism itineraries and more unusual ports of call.
When 1996 year-end statistics are released in about a month they are expected to show a slight gain over the 4.4 million cruise passengers in 1995 and the 4.5 million in 1994. But deep discounting bedeviled the industry again last year, notably for Caribbean cruises. And industry projections of at least 8 million passengers by the end of the decade (down from 10 million a few years ago) were quietly lowered last year to 7 million.
Nevertheless, many analysts envision a better showing in 1997. The economy is expected to be stronger, there are no Summer Olympics vying for discretionary travel dollars and it is unlikely that spring and summer will be unusually cool and rainy, as they were in 1996.
"The industry was too optimistic last year," said Victoria L. Hallstrom, the cruise analyst for Lehman Brothers. "And some of the ad campaigns seemed more concerned with image than addressing the public's concerns." Those concerns included several well publicized shipboard incidents in 1996 and 1995, including fires, groundings, the abrupt shutdown of Regency Cruises and exploding toilets on the QE2.
This year, with seven new ships scheduled for delivery, most early signs are favorable.
Reservations are strong into early summer. Recent surveys report that people who have cruised are generally well satisfied, while many others who have not cruised expect to do so in the near future. The average age of cruisers has fallen to 49 from 52 in 1986, according to the Cruise Lines International Association. And the fastest growing cruise population is the 25-to-39 age group.
Even the advertisements currently touting the 1998 introduction of the Disney Cruise Line are expected to pay dividends this year. The assumption is that the entire industry will benefit from Disney, the most famous name in vacations, which has put its stamp of approval on cruising and associated it with such words as "magical," "fantasy" and "fun."
The Disney name is also expected to help in another way. While cruising has been the fastest-growing segment of the travel business for about a decade, it still attracts only a fraction of the millions of people who take vacations each year. Cruising's potential remains huge -- especially if it succeeds in selling itself as a less expensive alternative to land-based vacations, in particular resort vacations, or if it can combine both elements in a single package.
The Disney Cruise Line is already promoting weeklong packages that will include three or four days at sea and the remaining days at the Walt Disney World Resort in Orlando.
Other cruise lines will provide competition. Through May, Royal Caribbean's Nordic Empress will combine three- and four-night sailings from San Juan to the Virgin Islands, with remaining nights at any of five resort hotels in Puerto Rico and one in the Dominican Republic. American Hawaii's three- and four-day cruise segments can be combined with stays at any of 15 hotels on Oahu, Kauai, Maui and the Big Island.
Positioning cruise ships as floating resorts is a prime motivation for the many new plush spas and high-tech fitness centers, the Broadway-sized revues in Broadway-sized theaters, bigger and more attractive casinos, upscale shops and boutiques, miniature golf courses and, in 1999, an ice skating rink aboard a new Royal Caribbean ship.
Two months ago Tom Cruise attended the world premiere of his movie "Jerry Maguire" aboard the Celebrity Galaxy during her visit to New York. And last month the Crystal Symphony became the first cruise ship to perform a licensed show of Rodgers and Hammerstein songs; the Crystal Harmony will repeat the show next month on cruises through the Panama Canal.
In the case of spas, shops, on-board art auctions and casinos, a parallel motivation is, of course, additional revenue. During her recent refurbishment the Norway added 36 slot machines for a total of 239, and relocated the library and card room from a high-traffic area to make way for revenue-producing perfume and jewelry shops. The new Celebrity Galaxy's big, ultra-modern spa offers three levels of treatment from $200 to $699, the last of which includes a treatment with a seaweed soap shower, medicinal mud pack, herbal steam bath and massage.
Holland America is using an unusual approach to combining the vacation experience with additional revenue: Last month it bought an uninhabited, 2,400-acre island in the Bahamas, which it renamed Half Moon Cay. When its ships begin calling there late this year, on Caribbean and Panama Canal cruises, passengers will find not only paddle boats, a children's play area and other recreational activities, but also a shopping center complete with an art gallery. Similarly, Royal Caribbean has a fine arts and crafts shop on its private island, Labadee, in Haiti.
Twenty-one cruise lines offer honeymoon, anniversary or vow renewal packages, while nine offer wedding packages and four others plan to do so. Dolphin Cruise Lines' wedding packages, for example, cost $275 to $750, although options like wedding cakes, photographs, flowers, catering and music can easily triple that amount.
Shore excursions are also a growing source of options for passengers and revenue for cruise lines. While shore trips range from the predictable to the plush, many now include nature walks, eco-tours and historical excursions.
Holland America's Statendam recently began offering the first tour by a cruise operator to the land of the Carib Indians on Dominica, while the Windstar plans to have a full-time naturalist aboard when it begins weekly cruises under sail later this year along the coast of Costa Rica. Many of American Hawaii's shore excursions are designed around Hawaiian culture. And Silversea Cruises arranged for its lectures and excursions to be led by photographers and journalists who have traveled on assignment for National Geographic publications.
The industry's reputation as environmentally friendly suffered a possible setback with the December disclosure that a Federal grand jury in Puerto Rico had handed up a 10-count felony indictment against Royal Caribbean charging the line routinely dumped waste oil and falsified log books to cover up the dumping. Last month Royal Caribbean pleaded not guilty to the charges. A spokesman for the line, Richard Steck, said last week that the company planned to meet with the judge and schedule a time for "various filings."
Despite that assertion, the cruise business overall appears to be making a good faith effort to go beyond Federal and international regulations governing the environment, including monitoring the impact of pollution from fuel in buses and other vehicles used by the cruise lines.
This year 130 ships will call at more than 1,800 ports, including such off-the-beaten-sea-lane destinations as Casablanca (Windstar), Tasmania (Orient Lines), Dubrovnik, Croatia (Costa) and Chiloe Island, Chile (Seabourn), which Darwin visited on his way to the Galapagos Islands.
On May 27, the refurbished Norwegian Star will begin seven-day "Texaribbean" cruises to the western Caribbean from Houston. The cruises, the first ever year-round cruises from the Port of Houston, will call at Cozumel and Calica in Mexico and Roatan in the Bay Islands, Honduras. The main reason, officials of Norwegian Cruise Line said, is that the Southwest has the highest concentration of 45- to 75-year-olds in the United States, a prime target group for the cruise industry.
The American Canadian Caribbean Line, whose three 100-passenger ships range between Labrador and the Amazon, will offer two new 12-day cruises in each direction this summer between Massena, N.Y., and Rocky Harbor, Newfoundland. The Carnival Inspiration will call for the first time at St. Lucia and Santo Domingo, on its seven-day southern Caribbean cruises beginning May 11. And the QE2, recently reconfigured to accommodate 1,500 passengers instead of the previous 1,750, is currently at sea on its 75th world cruise, a 103-day round trip that will call for the first time at Dubai, United Arab Emirates and Muscat, Oman.
Any of its eight remaining segments, ranging from 10 days (Yokohama to Bombay or Haifa to Southampton) to 32 days (Hong Kong to Lisbon), can still be booked.
Around-the-world cruises fell to four this year from eight in 1996, and even the number of Alaskan cruises will drop in 1997 -- to 362 from 432 last year. But that statistic masks the fact that since the introduction of large ships into the Alaska market, the number of cruise visitors there has grown almost 150 percent in the past decade to about 450,000.
BECAUSE of Americans' preference for more and shorter vacations, the fastest growing cruises are those of two to five days, a segment that has increased 325 percent in the last 15 years. So while Premier, Majesty and Dolphin ships continue their extensive three- and four-night itineraries, primarily between Florida and the Bahamas, Mexico or Bermuda, many other cruise lines are adding similar short cruises. Twelve percent of Royal Caribbean's 68 itineraries in 1997 are three- or four-day cruises from Miami, San Juan and Los Angeles.
In their appeal to families, cruise lines are adding amenities for children: menus, playrooms, 24-hour pizzerias, supervised activities and, on the Carnival Destiny, a 214-foot spiral water slide.
Older "kids" will find a major change on Carnival. Since Feb. 6, the line has required that passengers on all its ships must be at least 21 unless accompanied by someone 25 or older occupying the same cabin. But married passengers under 21 can rest easy. Not only are they exempt from the regulation, but Carnival, as well as at least a dozen other cruise lines, will be happy to sell them a honeymoon package.

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 17; Column 5; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 721 words

HEADLINE: Railroads Should Play Bigger Role in Future

 BODY:
Your article ["County's Rails Tell of Past and Future," Dec. 22] told of some of the past, but to my dismay, incorporated little about the future. While it was enjoyable, it did not make any reference to the inequalities in public policy that almost brought the railroads to extinction.
I work for the New York State Thruway Authority as an emergency responder on the Tappan Zee Bridge. Every day I see the rat race Americans call commuting. High Occupancy Vehicle lanes lie idle as one-driver cars cram into long lines at EZ Pass and cash toll booths. Impatience, excessive speed and lack of driver attentiveness result in 90 percent of all incidents on the span. Politicians focus their attention on ameliorating conditions by exercising cosmetic changes. The flanged wheel riding atop a steel rail is still the most efficient form of ground transportation. 
 Without the railroad the Industrial Revolution would not have reached the farmers in Nebraska or the fishermen in Seattle. Yet in America the railroads were almost abandoned because of the vested interest of a consortium of key corporations. That group's lobbying led to the passing of the Interstate Highway Act of the 1950's. The consortium purchased key interurban train and trolley transit systems and replaced them with buses and automobiles. Americans were robbed of their transit investments and steered to riding buses and cars.
The car, bus and truck flourished on publicly financed streets, roads and highways. American railroads had to capitalize and maintain their assets. It is a wonder that the railroads, overly regulated and strongly taxed, survived into the 1990's.
While I am not saying we should all sell our cars, I am asserting that transportation solutions should solve the problems we have today with an eye toward the future. Not one mile of new railroad track has been laid in Westchester County in 80 years. Yet politicians still talk of widening roads, building new bridges for traffic and instituting more H.O.V. lanes. The past has proven that those actions will only put more vehicles on the roads.
We must get people out of their inefficient cars and buses and off our saturated highways. Your figures of increased ridership on Metro-North indicate that many commuters are fed up with the traffic situations and are willing to use alternatives. Yet in spite of the increasing appeal of railroad ridership, mass transit projects lay idle on drawing boards or go unfinished, such as the Second Avenue subway or the East River tunnel that would allow Long Island Rail Road trains to ride into Grand Central Terminal. Rather than focus on the benefits of mass transit, we choose to spend millions on rebuilding the antiquated and woefully inefficient F.D.R. Drive.
Cars and buses have choked our metropolitan area to the point that it often takes longer to commute to our suburbs than it takes an astronaut to circle the earth.
By investing in a new rail line between, say, Port Chester and Tarrytown, building a bridge or tunnel to cross the Hudson River and continuing the rail line through Rockland and Suffern, we would create a viable alternative to commuting from our suburbs to New York City and across Westchester County. Regardless of the initial investment costs, the results would be the creation of an enormous financial initiative for commuters and a tremendous surge and benefit to our entire region. This economic model could be extended with the building of a second rail tunnel under the Hudson River to allow New Jersey Transit's Bergen and Passaic Valley line commuters access to Grand Central Terminal. We should invest in rail links between our three major airports, and we should resume rail service on Conrail's West Shore line.
I commute from Yonkers to Tarrytown at different hours. Once a month, though, I take the train from Hastings-on-Hudson. Yes, it takes 30 minutes longer than in my car, but it is safer and more economical and allows me to unwind.
Today's stainless-steel commuter trains are not the parlor, sleeping and dining cars of the 20th-Century Limited, but the view is still spectacular and generally unchanged. The red carpets may be rolled up, but the all-water-level route survives, a tribute to the mass transit concepts of the past.
 
THOMAS M. CARUSO SR.
Yonkers

HEADLINE: ART;
Retrospective Reflects Artist's Eye to Nature

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR 

DATELINE: WEST NYACK

 BODY:
LARGE though it is, the gallery at Rockland Center for the Arts here can barely contain its present attraction, a show by Hugh Mesibov, which covers 60 years and numbers almost 100 works. The congestion is spiritual as well as physical and small wonder, given the political, economic and esthetic turbulence of the period.
The artist, who celebrated his 81st birthday in December, has a long line of exhibitions to his credit -- in Manhattan and his hometown, Philadelphia, as well as in Rockland, where he has lived for 30 years. Not only that, he is represented in many prestigious collections, notably those of the Metropolitan and Whitney Museums, and murals by him adorn a score of public buildings, among them Temple Beth El in Spring Valley. Add to that an academic record that includes 23 years as a professor of art at SUNY Suffern, not to mention several awards and honors. 
 Yet, inexplicably, this show is the closest Mr. Mesibov has come to a full retrospective, and, a joint effort by his daughter, Deborah, and Eudice Charney, an art historian, it apparently took some organizing. A complete survey of his output would require, the artist said in a recent phone conversation, "more than one museum."
The son of a Russian emigre painter, Mr. Mesibov studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts until 1936. Though forced to leave the school by the death of his father and the exigencies of the Depression, the young man continued attending classes at the Barnes Foundation. No doubt some credit for his assured drawing style is due to these two Philadelphia institutions, particularly the Barnes, which first acquired his work in 1947.
In 1937, Mr. Mesibov signed on with the graphics arts division of the Works Progress Administration, where he became among other things a pioneer of the carborundum print. A lithograph pulled from a stone coated with carborundum resembles an aquatint, which is taken from an etching plate dusted with rosin. To the degree that the image is "extracted" from its background by means of burnishing, the process is akin to mezzotinting.
In any event, the granular surfaces of the prints in the show, three colored and one black and white, not only reflect the grittiness of the Depression era but also seem perfect for the artist's then rather somber approach to figuration.
Mr. Mesibov counted Social Realists like Joseph Hirsch and Robert Gathmey among his friends but steered clear of the movement himself, perhaps because he regarded art as more important than politics.
But if there is no sign of the typical Depression picture, which a wit once described as "an interior seen by the light of a 15-watt bulb," there are images that in one way or another reflect his awareness of the world. One is a small 1937 painting of a city on fire: Nanking, bombed -- presumably by the Japanese. Two are Surrealist landscapes with wrecked buildings that seem inspired by World War II. As for two 1970's scenes of small craft riding turbulent seas, it may be enough that they echo Gericault's sketches for "The Raft of the Medusa." Based on an actual shipwreck, this magnum opus of 1819 is regarded as the first example of high-art journalism.
Works of the 1940's and 50's imply the influences of, variously, Cezanne, Klee and Hans Hartung as well as Pollock and Motherwell. But the show as a whole indicates that, abstract or not, Mr. Mesibov seldom paints without an eye to nature, and this is never more obvious than in "Flaming Duet," a flurry of red, yellow, blue and black gestures dated 1959. In this canvas and others like it the artist blossoms as a colorist while at the same time laying the foundations of his present style.
While his principal inspiration now seems to be landscape, Mr. Mesibov's piece de resistance for the 1990's is the watercolor, "Bobbie No. 4." The subject, beautifully outlined in charcoal, lounges on a sofa, half clad in a red satin slip and extending one booted foot as if she were posing for an Expressionist like Egon Schiele. The artist has always been a man of his time, yet this picture reminds the viewer that for all his awareness of Surrealism, automatism and, to a lesser extent, Cubism, Mr. Mesibov has kept to his essentially Expressionist self.
A show that may surprise those who think they know his work, "Hugh Mesibov: 60 Years of Art" continues at Rockland Center for the Arts through next Saturday. The information number is 358-0877.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Standing Negro," in crayon and ink, by Hugh Mesibov at the gallery at Rockland Center for the Arts in West Nyack.

HEADLINE: Hard Times at the Chapel Square Mall

BYLINE: By JANINE LaMEDICA WOLFE 

 BODY:
WHEN Terry Cranville opened Zab's Backyard Hots in the Chapel Square Mall in 1984, downtown New Haven was a much different place.
"Back then, we had major stores, national chains, advertising, and there was a good draw to this area," said Mr. Cranville. "Now, without a major draw, parking is a real issue downtown, and we are not an alternative for any shoppers at all." 
 Following the withdrawal of Macy's in 1993 and Conran's in 1994, the future of the Chapel Square Mall became uncertain. To make matters worse, the Rouse Company, the Columbia, Md.-based real estate development company which managed the mall for 12 years and spent between $13 and $14 million renovating it in 1983, left the project in 1995.
"We have many properties in our portfolio," said Cathy Lickteig, vice president and director of corporate public affairs for the Rouse Company. "Certain properties like the Chapel Square Mall didn't have the same growth potential as many of our other properties."
"The Rouse people had a time frame," said Matthew Nemerson, president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce. "When they approached us in November of 1994, it was made clear we were talking 90 days. One of the things that we had to deal with is that a lot of people in the community, in fact, a lot of people around the country, said when places like Rouse want to get out of malls like this, you turn out the lights and you give it up.
"It really became for the community a kind of yes or no situation," Mr. Nemerson continued. "Were we going to be in a situation where there would be another bankruptcy, another closing of the doors and shutting out of lights? Remember this was six months before the Special Olympics World Games and we were thinking 'What's the message that we're going to present to the world?' "
Mr. Nemerson's first stop was the office of New Haven Mayor John DeStefano Jr. "He was totally supportive," said Mr. Nemerson. "We became total partners in this effort."
"Once Macy's left, it became clear it was only a matter of time," said Mayor DeStefano. "There was a discussion between the city and the Chamber of Commerce in which we decided that the chamber should take over the mall. We knew we couldn't let the mall go into free fall and the city didn't want to have interim ownership."
Joining the city and the Chamber of Commerce in the effort to save the mall were Yale University and the Bank of New Haven. Linda Lorimer, vice president and secretary of Yale, described it as a collective effort to begin a community revitalization program.
"The mall is just one of an enlarging series of projects that will enable the community to pull its forces together to revitalize the downtown area and promote the humanitarian and financial future of the city," Ms. Lorimer said.
Mr. Nemerson said that Yale and the Bank of New Haven helped negotiate a price, then put in roughly half a million dollars to support the project.
"There was over $13 million worth of mortgages on the mall," said Mr. Nemerson. "The way it was structured was that there were three levels of mortgage. The first level was a traditional major real estate mortgage. When Rouse came in 1983, and rebuilt the mall, they spent about $13 or $14 million. They got about half of that from the New York State Teachers Retirement Fund. By the time that we were ready to take over the project, they had given up on it and they were willing to sell it to us for about five or six cents on the dollar.
"Then you had Aetna, who was an in-between mortgage holder, they had put in $5 or $6 million," he continued. "They had just written it off. Then you had another $2 or $3 million from local institutions, and they realized that the best thing that they could do would be to invest that money back into the community. Yale and the Bank of New Haven were willing to come up with an additional $500,000 to allow us to buy the debt that had to be bought."
The Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce has been running the mall since 1995 out of cash flow, according to Mr. Nemerson. "Our challenge has been to run a major project that's over 300,000 square feet and that had a lot of deferred maintenance and a lot of marketing challenges, just out of cash flow."
Barbara Johnson, senior vice president and New Haven regional manager for People's Bank, was chairwoman of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce during this transition. "The critical component to the success of this project was a willingness to step forward and take ownership," said Ms. Johnson. "We never expected to be mall owners, but it was critical to keep the mall open."
After earning the distinction of possibly being the only Chamber of Commerce in the United States to own a mall, the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce will soon turn over the Chapel Square Mall and the adjoining site of the former Park Plaza Hotel to a partnership between the Cordish Company, a real estate development company based in Baltimore, and the Omni Hotel Corporation, a developer of luxury hotels and resorts, based in Corpus Christi, Tex.
"We had been involved with the city in trying to look at alternatives for the Park Plaza Hotel when it was slipping toward bankruptcy," said Mr. Nemerson. "As the hotel got into bankruptcy court, it was going to end up on the auction block if a deal wasn't cut with some developer to come in and buy it. The way the deal worked was the developer said 'O.K., I'll buy it for a million and a half dollars out of bankruptcy, but if this whole thing doesn't work, I give it back to you for a million and a half dollars'."
David Cordish, president and chairman of the board of the Cordish Company, has overseen hotel development and gentrification efforts throughout the United States. Downtown New Haven, he feels, is an ideal location for a four-star hotel. Slated to be completed by the fall, the hotel project is expected to cost $27 million.
"Downtown New Haven is surrounded by two of the largest hospitals in the area, Yale-New Haven and St. Raphael's, and also by Yale University and, of course, the green," Mr. Cordish explained. "What we're working on is the 'hole in the doughnut,' those few blocks that need to be turned around."
Keith Coe, vice president of development for Omni Hotels, agrees. "In this one city you have a world-class university, an outstanding hospital system and business base, plus outstanding cultural activities like the tennis tournament and the Shubert Theater. We're convinced that this will be a hotel that New Haven will be proud of and we'll be proud of."
The city put a caveat in the contract that the developer could exercise the option to develop the Chapel Square Mall site once the hotel is 50 percent completed. Mr. Cordish said that his company fully intended to exercise that option, and was also planning "to put in a movieplex which can serve as a stadium-style conference center during the day and a movie theater in the evening."
In addition to an increase in conference, restaurant and retail activity, Mr. Nemerson sees an additional benefit for the residents of New Haven. "When the hotel opens, the difference in terms of jobs will be 350 jobs at the hotel," he said. "If it has a restaurant, that could be another 40-50 jobs. If it brings in only six or seven retailers, that could be another 50-60 jobs. These jobs will run the gamut from entry level right up to management track, that anybody who comes in at the entry level could go to."
Bringing people in from all over the country for conferences will also give the city of New Haven a chance to "cross sell" its cultural activities, Mr. Nemerson says. "Most conferences have a guest or spouse program and are going to want to have an event or reception or one of the sessions outside of the hotel. So that means that the British Art Center can get more business, that the local restaurants can get more business, that we can show off all New Haven has to offer."
For Mr. Cranville, whose Backyard Hots made it through the hard times, that's a hope and a promise.
