HEADLINE: How to Find a Fit in the New Job Market

BYLINE: By KATHY KATELLA 

 BODY:
MICHAEL GORDON was unemployed when he signed up for Eugene Hodge's career class at Quinnipiac College in Hamden. Mr. Hodge offered this solution: Go discuss it with 10 or more people a week. With few alternatives, Mr. Gordon went to the New Haven green and started talking to strangers about sports, gradually steering the conversation his way: He had certain skills, he wanted to work with computers, what did the person think about it?
He grew less timid as he saw the payoff: Lawyers and other professionals were giving him encouragement, advice and leads. One tip led the former parking valet to Microtech International in East Haven and a temporary job that could open doors in a high-tech field. 
 "I found that there is so much more out there because someone else was telling me about it," Mr. Gordon said. "I went down different avenues I never would have known about."
The class he took is called the Job Readiness and Computer Literacy Training Program. Mr. Hodge introduced it at Quinnipiac after several years at Gateway Community College in New Haven and other places. The kind, but no-nonsense adjunct professor, popular among his students, invented the course while rising through the corporate ranks in computer-oriented positions at the Cigna Corporation, Pitney Bowes and the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston.
His theory is that companies today want workers who are doing what they like to do, what comes naturally to them, and they also want workers to be computer literate. He tells stories of students from factory workers to Ph.D's who say these ideas helped them get off unemployment and start turning their careers around.
Of the 720 people who have taken the course in the last several years, 88 percent found work during or soon after completing it, he said, with salaries ranging from $8 to $75 an hour. One student started a new job in the Middle West as a construction engineering manager before finishing the course, and convinced his new employer to fly him back for the remaining classes.
Mr. Hodge seeks out the most promising applicants based on a questionnaire on their accomplishments and goals.
"I want people who want something, and they don't know how to get it. I only want those. I don't want people who need to be pushed," he said.
He also wants to reach such people by offering the course in educational institutions throughout the country. He is looking for support from corporations, foundations and other sources, specifically $150,000 to hire sales, marketing and training staffs. Connecticut Department of Labor funds, which helped launch the program at Quinnipiac in Hamden, have run out, and he would also like money to help students who can't afford the $1,300 tuition the college is now charging.
In some ways, it's been difficult promoting a course that many traditional educators would consider "radically different," Mr. Hodge said. Explaining that society has encouraged people to pursue what they are good at instead of what they enjoy, he throws words like qualifications, attitude and skills out the window. Rather than rely on aptitude tests, he encourages students to look inward for answers, basing their career goals on natural strengths and past achievements.
Then he tells them to go out and find out what other people think about them. "I've got a bunch of degrees, but if you don't like me because I'm black or because I'm tall, it doesn't matter," he said. "The person across the table says, 'I don't care what you're good at. It's not good enough for us.' "
In his classroom, students are encouraged to be straightforward in assessing each other, even if it means talking about "the scar on your face or how thin your hair is." The idea is to face reality, change or accept it, then move on to other things, Mr. Hodge said.
He also tells them chances at a good job are slim if they don't understand computers, and he teaches such basics as document and spreadsheet creation, data processing and desktop publishing.
"Especially as employers are going global, and downsizing is forcing people to produce more, the technology is what has limited a lot of people," Mr. Hodge said. "The company is moving along, and it needs to know how it can get its people to speak the same language."
Such ideas impressed the Department of Labor, which usually reserves its support for small and mid-sized businesses, said Janice Hasenjager, program manager for customized job training. The department liked the way Mr. Hodge addressed the rapid changes in the workplace. "He has been able to place people who have been out of work for a long time," she said.
Mr. Hodge said his ideas for the course came from his own experience. He described himself as "a youth at risk" growing up in Springfield, Mass., and entering the workplace with "limited perceptions" that held him back. One day he began listening to the people around him. "Once I began to follow their direction, things began to open up," he said. "I realized people were opening the door for me to go places I'd never been before. I went from almost being fired to being put on the fast track."
In the classroom, he tries to re-create that office environment with its mix of employees. Students have ranged in age from 19 to 72, and come from a variety of educational and professional backgrounds. One recalled taking the class with a mother trying to get off welfare and a Yale graduate trying to find the best career path.
"When I visit the class, I notice a mix of students, from people laid off from Pratt & Whitney -- they were machinists -- to Ph.D.'s," said Edward Kavanagh, dean of the Samuel W. Tator School for Lifelong Education at Quinnipiac. "The common thread is that these are people who had not expected to be out in the job market, and they needed some guidelines on how to go about it."
Many of them were finding that the rules had changed since their last job hunt. For instance, while some have computer skills, many have no experience with the Internet, an important job hunting as well as work tool, he said
Students say it also helps to have friends who are truly interested in their plights. Mr. Hodge, they say, encourages them, builds bonds among them and never lets anyone skip an assignment.
Mary Ellen Squeglia of West Haven recalled her discouragement after losing her job in property management. "I really didn't have a lot of motivation or enthusiasm at the time," she said. "I was really sort of disgusted with everything." Soon after meeting Mr. Hodge, she found her kitchen table piled with coursework, and realized it was up to her to make things happen. "He taught us different approaches to use and to never say 'not' to yourself."
She is now in a new industry -- having gone from a temporary job at the Yale School of Medicine to another for a pharmaceutical company since the class. "Really, in a way, temping is an inconvenience," Ms. Squeglia said. "Everywhere you go you have to learn something new. But the pluses are you get to see the different workplace environments before being permanent. I never thought I'd be in a medical environment -- never, never, never."
Robert Fiore of Milford, who was laid off as a boiler operator, is also looking at new possibilities He once had a job in a hotel and wanted to return to the industry, but needed skills.
"When I started working in the industry, you just needed to have a good pen, a smile and a lot of refills for the pen," he said. "Now, you go for a job interview and you have to be computer literate."
After realizing that he could get where he wanted if he developed the right skills, Mr. Fiore is now dreaming of managing a hotel, and ultimately owning his own hotel and restaurant. "I feel I have the foundation," he said. "It's a matter of taking what I have and polishing it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eugene Hodge at Quinnipiac College, where he offers an innovative course on employment. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THEATER;
A Power Behind the Play Emerges Into the Light

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
THEATER IS A GROUP ENTERPRISE. It represents the joint labor of playwrights, actors, directors, set designers, costume designers and a long list of more or less anonymous foot soldiers celebrated only in the fine print of Playbill. Perhaps the most mysterious of these is the dramaturge.
The term dozed in comfortable obscurity until November, when a dramaturge named Lynn M. Thomson sued the estate of Jonathan Larson, the creator of "Rent," who died in 1996. Ms. Thomson claimed that she is entitled to 16 percent of any royalties paid to the Larson estate as compensation for her help in shaping the musical with Larson at New York Theater Workshop. Although the show is a hit on Broadway and already has one road company, with more on the way, it is impossible to predict how much it will generate in royalties. At the moment, say people familiar with the production, royalties may amount to between $15,000 and $30,000 a week. 
 Ms. Thomson is the first dramaturge who has tried to claim the status of a co-creator for her contribution, which, she argues, was so extensive that by the time "Rent" left the workshop stage, one third of it was new material. Her lawyers have requested a trial in May.
Suddenly, a vexing question was in the air: What on earth is a dramaturge?
Lloyd Richards, the artistic director of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., asked himself that same question in 1969 during the National Playwrights Conference, the center's annual summer event for new plays. Seeking to defuse antagonism between critics and playwrights at the conference, he invited certain critics to sit in on rehearsals and offer advice.
"When I explained this procedure to someone, they said, 'Oh, you're using dramaturges,' " Mr. Richards said. "I said, 'What?' I had to go look it up."
Today, nearly 30 years later, more than 300 dramaturges work at 180 regional theaters in the United States, and many more teach at universities. They are instrumental in adapting classic works for the modern stage and in finding and developing new playwriting talent.
The word is German. It came into being when the playwright G. E. Lessing became an in-house critic at the Hamburg National Theater in 1767 and published "Hamburg Dramaturgy," a series of critical articles on the theater's productions.
In a distinguished line running from Lessing through Bertolt Brecht to Heiner Muller, the dramaturge became a fixture in German theater. As a resident theoretician and artistic conscience, the dramaturge played a major role in shaping repertory and establishing a theater's artistic identity. French theaters, too, made use of dramaturges, and in England, Kenneth Tynan functioned as one at the National Theater.
In the United States, commercial stages did without dramaturges and, for the most part, still do.
"The commenting and reshaping can come from anywhere, and in the past it was always the function of the producer and director," said Evangeline Morphos, the chairwoman of the dramaturgy department at Columbia University. "Think of Tennessee Williams and Elia Kazan. Kazan was right in there, getting Williams to do entire rewrites, like the third act of 'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.' "
The rise of the dramaturge in the United States coincides with the explosive growth of nonprofit regional theaters beginning in the late 1960's. Institutions like the Goodman Theater in Chicago and Arena Stage in Washington needed someone who could support the dual mission of presenting classic works and developing new ones. For the classics, a dramaturge advises the artistic director on which works to produce, which texts or translations to use, and how to adapt a work, if necessary, for a modern audience.
When theaters turn to new plays, they need someone to assume a role analogous to that of an acquisitions editor at a publishing house, a professional who can solicit, read and recommend scripts to the artistic director, and then work with new playwrights whose scripts show promise. Some theaters assign the soliciting and reading of scripts to a literary manager. Others combine the two positions.
Dramaturges often go forth and make new projects happen. When Anne Cattaneo, now the dramaturge at Lincoln Center Theater, was at the Acting Company, she selected stories by Chekhov and persuaded playwrights like David Mamet and John Guare to adapt them for the stage.
All over the United States, theaters followed the example of Mr. Richards. At about the same time, Robert Brustein, now the head of the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., created a dramaturgy department at the Yale School of Drama.
The job is protean. "I like to think of the dramaturge as a kind of friend, helping the playwright realize the play he or she wants to write," said Carol Rocamora, who teaches theater at New York University. "The dramaturge is an erudite and canny guide, a sounding board and a gadfly."
Dramaturges can be many other things as well. They can do research for the playwright, the director and even the set designer. Kimberly Flynn, for example, provided Tony Kushner with extensive background material on AIDS and Roy Cohn for "Angels in America."
The dramaturge might write program notes, assign reading lists to the cast or lead post-performance discussions with the audience. When Lincoln Center Theater produced "The Heiress," the director, Gerald Gutierrez, wanted to know how much the heroine's inheritance would mean in current dollars. Ms. Cattaneo went to the economics division of the New York Public Library and researched the matter, which found its way into a program note.
"It is the most interesting job in the theater," said Ms. Cattaneo. "It requires no fund-raising, and you can combine knowledge of languages and literature with practical theater work."
The back-and-forth between dramaturge and playwright takes as many forms as the plays themselves. Jack Viertel, the creative director of Jujamcyn Theaters on Broadway, said: "In some cases it's a matter of asking questions or writing letters and notes. Playwrights are sometimes better off if they don't have to defend themselves face to face."
With Lanford Wilson, whom he worked with at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, Mr. Viertel took the epistolary approach. "He told me, 'I throw darts at your letters until I calm down enough to read them and see if there's anything worth reading,' " Mr. Viertel said.
One thing dramaturges do not do is change the playwright's words, as an editor does with a novelist's manuscript in a publishing house. In the theater, playwrights own their material and no changes can be made without their permission.
If the playwright-dramaturge relationship requires tact, the three-way dance that ensues when the director enters the picture demands superpower diplomacy. Normally, the dramaturge attends rehearsal but takes a secondary role, making notes and offering suggestions, but always as an adviser to the director. Some directors loathe the idea of dramaturges, but many rely on them heavily.
"In rehearsal, the director sinks into the sea of subjectivity," said Jon Jory, the producing director of the Actors Theater of Louisville. "The dramaturge tells the director what it is he's seeing."
As time goes on, Mr. Jory said, the director tends to focus on smaller and smaller bits of the production puzzle. "The thematic aspects of the play can empty out of your head like a water pitcher," he said. The dramaturge, ideally, retains the big picture.
Recently, dramaturges have begun to receive heightened recognition, in part through the efforts of the Literary Managers and Dramaturges of the Americas, a 325-member organization created in 1985 to advance the interests of the profession.
At the Joseph Papp Public Theater, the name of the dramaturge is now printed on the front page of the theater's programs, a policy change prompted by the exceptional contributions of Shelby Jiggetts in developing the musical "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk," now on Broadway. Tony Kushner has always made a point of giving credit to his dramaturges, and in some cases he has assigned royalty payments to them.
Although many dramaturges see the Thomson case as a chance to clarify their role and rights, some theater professionals worry that a victory for Ms. Thomson in the "Rent" case could throw the fragile, collaborative process of the theater into turmoil and put a chill on the development of new work. Either way, the widespread concern created by the case is testimony to the entrenched role of the dramaturge in nonprofit contemporary American theater.
"We could not conceivably live without them," said Mr. Jory. "It's not an optional process for us. It seems as essential as having lighting designers, sound designers and playwrights."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 37; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: ART;
An Elegant Flower In a Modest Garden

BYLINE: By DEBORAH WEISGALL; Deborah Weisgall, who lives in the Boston area, writes frequently about the arts.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
IN THE WINTER, YELLOW JASMINE trees decorate the Venetian courtyard of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, their masses of blooms like golden halos. Just behind that courtyard, the museum's intimate temporary exhibition space has been painted with pilasters and capitals to suggest the measured opulence of 15th-century Florence.
"Botticelli's Witness: Changing Style in a Changing Florence" opened in that gallery 10 days ago and runs through April 6. This small, elegant show of just 12 paintings and engravings that span Botticelli's life, 1445 to 1510, raises a big issue: the effect of politics and faith on an artist's work. It is an issue as urgent today as it was in Florence during the 1490's, when art and religion and politics were fatally intertwined. 
 Equally important, it demonstrates how a small museum with great art can, in effect, leverage that art to produce an exhibition ambitious both in its theme and the quality of its offerings.
 "There is a remarkable concentration of Botticellis in the Boston area, both paintings and lesser-known graphic works," says Hilliard Goldfarb, the Gardner's chief curator of collections. In addition, the authors of the catalogue have Boston connections.
Mr. Goldfarb organized the privately financed exhibition as an inquiry, presenting new research, on Botticelli and Florentine history. The gallery's limited space has become an advantage; viewers (only 15 are allowed in the room at a time) can see at once the continuities and the shifts in Botticelli's style. Those changes were so radical that some of his works have only recently been identified, but why Botticelli's art changed remains a mystery. The show illuminates that mystery; wisely, it does not try to solve it.
Bostonians were among Botticelli's earliest modern fans. He had been considered second-rate until the critic John Ruskin, in 1874, proclaimed him the greatest Florentine painter. Ruskin's protege, the Harvard professor Charles Eliot Norton, brought the cult of Botticelli to America. Encouraged by Norton, Mrs. Gardner acquired a copy of Dante's "Divine Comedy" printed in 1481, with engravings executed from Botticelli's designs. Later she bought three Botticellis, including the exquisite early "Madonna of the Eucharist" and his late masterpiece "The Tragedy of Lucretia," the first important Italian painting in her collection and the first she obtained through Bernard Berenson, who studied with Norton. The Gardner is the logical place for this show, given its holdings, and the fact that according to Mr. Goldfarb, "we could never have allowed both paintings to leave."
Botticelli's career flourished under the patronage of Lorenzo de' Medici, who set out to establish Florence as a New Athens. Botticelli's best-known paintings, like "La Primavera," embody the Neoplatonic belief in the mirroring beauty of body and soul. Laced with literary allusions, they take sensuous delight in reinventing antiquity and blurring the line between sacred and profane.
But according to Vasari, who published the second edition of his influential "Lives of the Most Eminent Painters, Sculptors and Architects" in 1568, Botticelli was also drawn to Savonarola, the Dominican friar who condemned the lust and pagan excess of Lorenzo's court. Lorenzo died in 1492; two years later, Savonarola ruled the city. In his sermons, he envisioned Florence as a New Jerusalem, purged of sin and the Medici's tyranny. His reforming zeal culminated in a bonfire of the vanities, a public burning in 1497 of art, books, musical instruments and sumptuous clothes. Just over a year later, Florentines turned against Savonarola, and he was imprisoned and tortured to confess that his visions had been lies. Condemned as a heretic, he was hanged and his body burned.
Wall texts and labels set up the exhibition as a drama of personalities: Lorenzo, Botticelli, Savonarola. In the catalogue, James Hankins, a professor of history at Harvard, writes that Lorenzo's New Athens and Savonarola's New Jerusalem, while very different, were also strikingly similar: grand plans for cultural and moral renewal through a return to an idealized past. Indeed, Savonarola came to Florence at Lorenzo's invitation.
Vasari claims that under Savonarola's influence Botticelli's art suffered and his output dwindled. But Vasari worked for the Medici, who were once again in power and inimical to Savonarola's movement. Botticelli kept working, but his paintings grew less seductive, sometimes even awkward. At the heart of the exhibition is the question, What happened to Botticelli? Did he lose his powers or transform them?
The Gardner's tender "Madonna of the Eucharist," with its Venus-like Madonna and gorgeous St. John, painted around 1472, hangs near its "Nativity," dating from a decade later and only with this show attributed to Botticelli. For years it was called a studio work because Joseph's rough features and coarse hands were inconsistent with Botticelli's famous delicacy. But at that time he had just finished illustrating Dante's "Inferno." The turbulent engravings show Botticelli learning to tell painful, visual stories directly and economically in 1481, nine years before Savonarola began preaching.
No document links Savonarola with Botticelli, although Botticelli's brother was one of the monk's followers. The badly worn "Mystical Crucifixion," however, painted two years after Savonarola's death, is dense with imagery from his sermons and visions. Devils hurl firebrands, Mary Magdalene embraces the cross, an angel holds an animal (with a slit throat?) by its hind legs; nobody can figure out exactly what is going on. Sarah Kianovsky, an assistant curator at the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard University, says, "We took this painting out of a brand-new installation to lend to the Gardner because it is a very important exhibition."
Laurence Kanter, formerly of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, now curator of the Lehman Collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, points out in the catalogue that Savonarola's sympathizers could have commissioned the painting; it does not prove Botticelli's own beliefs. "Botticelli is an artist," Mr. Kanter writes, "who is far better known than understood."
Yet few artists have painted emotions so directly. "The Tragedy of Lucretia," dating from 1501, sets tiny figures before a relentless architecture; Botticelli even incised the lines of columns and walls into the gesso, the layer of chalk priming the panel. There is no way out: Lucretia is raped, and she commits suicide rather than live dishonored; angry, grieving men whose drawn swords stab space surround the bier where Lucretia lies, her face bloated in death.
In "Lucretia," Botticelli no longer conjures a magical tension between air and flesh, observation and invention. The lilting dance of "La Primavera," with its goddesses whose feet don't touch the flowery ground, has squared into a march. Did this harsh change in Botticelli's art come about because of religious beliefs, some private despair or simply life? Was he reacting to new styles (Michelangelo was already working on his "David" in 1501) or trying to satisfy clients? Botticelli might have painted "Lucretia" to celebrate a marriage between two families of anti-Medicean republicans; its visual allegories are disputed.
In "Lucretia," Botticelli confronted a brutal story with clarity and physical immediacy, just as he had painted love. But starting with Vasari, people have wanted only sweetness from Botticelli. He painted "The Mystical Crucifixion" on unprimed canvas; despite its flaked paint, it reveals something of the "Madonna of the Eucharist" in the beautiful faces of the angel and Mary, their sublime disregard for gravity and in the play of their plain robes. It's as if in this small, private drama of penitence, Botticelli had finally redeemed his lyrical gift and reconciled the agonies of faith and the dangers of politics with his own art.
But how can we ever know? "That is the excitement of the continuing debate over Botticelli," says Mr. Goldfarb, the Gardner curator. "Documentary evidence can take you only so far. Then you respond to the work. And what we see essentially reveals our connection with our own world and times."

GEOGRAPHIC: UNITED STATES (94%); MASSACHUSETTS, USA (94%); BOSTON, MA, USA (94%); 

SUBJECT: ART; REVIEWS MUSEUMS & GALLERIES (94%); EXHIBITIONS (91%); PAINTING (90%); VISUAL ARTISTS (78%); ARTISTS & PERFORMERS (78%); POLITICS (75%); CULTS & SECTS (74%); RELIGION (74%); 

PERSON: WEISGALL, DEBORAH; BOTTICELLI, SANDRO (1445-1510)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 4; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2625 words

HEADLINE: Church v. State: Landmark Case

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
WHAT can be done with a house of worship that is treasured by the public but no longer wholly suited to the needs of its congregation? Must it be maintained? For whom? And by whom? Since the beginning of the century, and the early stirrings of the historic preservation movement, Americans have wrestled with the question of where to draw the line when religious freedom and civic responsibility collide.
The core of the debate is whether religious institutions, whose buildings are often among the most beautiful and historic in a community, are as bound by land-use rules as any other property owner or whether, under the First Amendment guarantee of free exercise of religion, they are exempt from regulations that burden their ministries,. 
 As the century ends, a definitive answer may be on the horizon -- a hilly horizon -- in a Texas town called Boerne (BER-nie), 30 miles northwest of San Antonio.
In two weeks, the United States Supreme Court is to hear a case involving St. Peter Roman Catholic Church, a 74-year-old Mission Revival structure in Boerne's historic district that has run out of room for its burgeoning congregation. The church, part of the Archdiocese of San Antonio, applied in 1993 to build an addition but was turned down by Boerne's Landmark Commission and City Council.
Archbishop Patrick F. Flores sued Boerne, asserting among other claims that the denial of a permit violated the 1993 Religious Freedom Restoration Act, which states, "Government shall not substantially burden a person's exercise of religion even if the burden results from a rule of general applicability."
In response, Boerne claimed that the act itself was unconstitutional. A Federal district court agreed with the city but its decision was overturned by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
"If the Religious Freedom Restoration Act is constitutional, then churches have just received a windfall," said Marci A. Hamilton, a professor at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University in New York and counsel for the City of Boerne. "It will become extraordinarily difficult for governments to impose their historical preservation laws on religious institutions."
That is why a case involving a Catholic parish 1,600 miles away is being watched by the United Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, at West End Avenue and 86th Street.
"This could have a big impact on what our options might be," said the pastor, the Rev. Edward C. Horne. His church has struggled since 1981 under a landmark designation it did not want, which prevented it from replacing its deteriorating 100-year-old sanctuary, which it shares with Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, Ethiopian Evangelical Mennonites and Cristo Vivo, a group of Hispanic gay men and lesbians.
The impact may extend beyond landmarks. In a joint brief in support of Boerne, the Municipal Art Society of New York and the San Antonio Conservation Society said the Religious Freedom Restoration Act "may render local communities unable to prevent the destruction of historically important structures and unable to enforce zoning laws against religious organizations."
Vice President Al Gore intimated as much in the ceremony at which the act was signed into law. Speaking of problems it was meant to correct, he said: "Those who want churches close to where they live have seen churches zoned out of residential areas. Those who want the freedom to design their churches have seen local governments dictate the configuration of their building."
Because the very architecture of a church or synagogue or mosque expresses religious belief, the imposition of design controls is "like the government coming in and commenting on what song you're going to sing or what Bible passage you're going to be reading," said Nancie G. Marzulla, president and chief legal counsel of Defenders of Property Rights, a national group based in Washington.
"In effect," she said, "the Religious Freedom Restoration Act is a property-rights statute in this kind of context, when you've got a structure which is itself a religious expression or an exercise of religious belief. Government has no business interfering with the exercise of religious beliefs unless it's protecting safety or health."
But houses of worship also play a critical civic role.
"Religious buildings frequently constitute some of the country's finest architecture," said Jerold S. Kayden, associate professor of urban planning at Harvard University. "Over time, these buildings have become secularized by dint of having become a familiar and reassuring presence. The stakeholders of these religious buildings are not just the parishioners but the citizens. That tug is at the heart of the debate."
The debate -- indeed, the Boerne v. Flores lawsuit itself -- will not end at the Supreme Court. Even if the Religious Freedom Restoration Act is found constitutional, several key questions will remain for lower courts to answer:
* In designating and regulating religious landmarks, does the government "substantially burden" the exercise of religion?
* If so, can the government show -- as it must under the act -- that the burden furthers a "compelling governmental interest" and is the "least restrictive means" of doing so?
The Rev. N. J. L'Heureux Jr., executive director of the Queens Federation of Churches and a longtime opponent of landmark regulation of religious properties, said government could not clear these hurdles.
"Landmarking -- as desirable as it may or may not be -- is not a government purpose of the highest order and on that basis alone, it would fail the test," he said. "Even if it were to be regarded as a highest order of interest, there are a number of less restrictive ways for the government to accomplish its purpose than to require that a church pay out all its money to preserve a building it would rather change or dispose of."
But preservationists believe that landmarking does not amount to a substantial burden in the first place. And they have been going out of their way in recent years to convince congregations of the same thing.
"We really do try to keep a strong, cooperative relationship with the religious community," said Jennifer J. Raab, chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. "In light of some past tensions, it's important to let them know we're receptive to their concerns."
Since 1987, for example, the commission has included a clergyman among its 11 members. (It is currently the Rev. Thomas F. Pike, rector of the Episcopal parish of Calvary St. George's in Manhattan.)
Also for the last decade, the private New York Landmarks Conservancy has given small grants, made low-interest loans and offered technical asssistance and referrals to eligible houses of worship under its Sacred Sites Program.
The Conservancy was brought in at Ms. Raab's suggestion in the case of the Reformed Dutch Church of Newtown, 85-15 Broadway, at Corona Avenue, in Elmhurst, Queens. The landmark complex includes a 166-year-old Georgian church and a 137-year-old Greek Revival chapel, known as Fellowship Hall, connected by a porch along Broadway.
LIKE St. Peter's in Boerne, the Reformed Church is thriving and needs more room -- specifically, classrooms. It proposed to add a second story to a nondescript 1950's addition behind Fellowship Hall.
The Landmarks Commission denied the application in August 1994. It said the proposed enlargement would disturb the "balance and architectural massing of the historic ensemble"; that the new pyramidal roof "would not harmonize" with the existing gabled roofs and that aluminum siding "would not ameliorate the appearance" of the complex.
Shortly thereafter, Ms. Raab arrived at the commission. "I was very determined to try to help a landmark church that had the uniquely wonderful problem of too many congregants," she said. "This was an exciting challenge, to see if we could help them through the process toward an appropriate addition in the most expeditious, sensible way."
While the overall size of the enlargement did not significantly change, a hipped roof was substituted for the pyramidal roof, gray clapboard siding for aluminum on that part of the new facade visible from Broadway. Meanwhile, the Conservancy helped prepare photo overlays to show that from most vantages, the enlargement would not be conspicuous.
"We went back to the commission and strongly supported their application," said Peg Breen, president of the Conservancy. "With the additional material we were able to present, it helped them change the commission's mind."
More recently the Conservancy made a $25,000 loan and $7,500 grant and provided engineering services valued at $15,000 to the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew. It is being used for a $100,000 stabilization project in which precarious pieces of terra cotta are to be removed or patched and roof tiles are to be replaced to prevent leaking.
The problem remains, however. "Even if you do $100,000 worth of work," Mr. Horne, the pastor, said, "it is by no means a long-term answer. The long-term answer is multimillions of dollars to renovate or rebuild."
Just fixing a leaky roof can be dauntingly expensive when the architectural integrity of a designated structure has to be preserved.
Last winter, wind, ice and snow ripped a large hole in the base of the copper-clad steeple at the 105-year-old St. John's Lutheran Church, 155 Milton Street, in the Greenpoint Historic District in Brooklyn.
Faced with the prospect of restoring the steeple, the first impulse of many in the church was simply to remove it, said the Rev. Daniel L. Anderson, pastor of St. John's and the nearby Church of the Messiah.
That idea was abandoned and now the 50-member congregation faces a repair bill that might run from $70,000 to $300,000, if a scaffold were built. It has applied for a grant from the Landmarks Conservancy.
"We don't view working with landmarks as competition," the pastor explained, "but as something that needs to be done, both esthetically and in terms of the mission of the church. We realize that it's a public building, so it's not just a matter of repairing at the most economical cost but to try to restore it with integrity so it would serve the community.
"In my younger days, from the seminary, I used to preach sermons that it was either bricks or mission, buildings or the gospel," Mr. Anderson said. "But it's not that kind of simple choice, because both are involved. Religion always involves a place, whether it's a storefront or a cathedral."
THE bricks-or-mission dilemma is not new. In 1908, Trinity Parish opened what its own historian, Charles Thorley Bridgeman, called a Pandora's box when it announced the closing of St. John's Chapel on Varick Street, south of Canal Street, implicitly dooming the lovely 100-year-old building to demolition.
Trinity's move was protested by President Theodore Roosevelt, Mayor George B. McClellan, J. Pierpont Morgan and the city's Art Commission, among others.
In a response that sounds as contemporary as the briefs in the Boerne case, the rector of Grace Church defended Trinity as existing "to further the interests of religion and only incidentally to care for ancient monuments of civic interest." He challenged the protesters to purchase St. John's Chapel if they cared to preserve it as a historic memorial.
They did not do so. Nor did any other efforts to save the building succeed after the congregation departed. It stood, little used, until 1918, when it was demolished to accommodate the widening of Varick Street.
Over the next 50 years, numerous religious landmarks were razed, including the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and 24th Street; All Souls' Unitarian Church, Park Avenue South and 20th Street; Congregation Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 43d Street; St. Agnes Chapel of Trinity Parish, 120 West 92d Street; Temple Beth El, Fifth Avenue and 76th Street and St. Nicholas Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and 48th Street.
Preservationists gained a strong hand in 1965 with the creation of the Landmarks Commission. Today, there are 99 individually designated religious landmarks and 78 religious properties within historic districts. (Noting that the "courts have upheld the Landmarks Commission's ability to designate and regulate so far," Ms. Raab said the Boerne case is "certainly something we're watching.")
Perhaps the most famous challenge from a religious institution involved the landmark St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue. In 1984, the church sought permission to tear down its Community House on 50th Street and replace it with an office tower. When the Landmarks Commission denied the application, the church sued the city, citing the First Amendment among other protections.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld the city in 1990, relying in part on a case titled Employment Division v. Smith, in which the Supreme Court had recently indicated that religious beliefs did not excuse compliance with generally applicable laws.
In response to the Smith decision, Congress passed the Religious Freedom Restoration Act in 1993. Churches in several cities -- Washington; Berkeley, Calif.; Ypsilanti, Mich., and Cumberland, Md. -- have already brought challenges to local landmarks laws under this act.
St. Peter's Church in Boerne was built in 1923, modeled in part on the 18th-century Mission Concepcion (Nuestra Senora de la Purisima Concepcion de Acuna) in San Antonio. It was designed for 230 worshippers, but the parish has grown so large in recent years that as many as 290 people seek to celebrate the 11 o'clock Mass on Sunday mornings and must do so in a local auditorium.
The church sought permission in 1993 to expand the sanctuary by tearing down the rear of the building while retaining the front facade, with its twin bell towers. But the Landmark Commission said it would not approve any plan that included demolition of the existing structure.
"This case is about a request to tear down a beautiful stone church whose times and memories are graven into the souls of a city," said the brief filed at the Supreme Court for the City of Boerne. "This highly visible church set on a hill speaks directly of the history of this city and its people."
The archdiocese frames the case much differently in its brief: "This case involves the right of a religious community to worship together and the right of excluded individuals to attend the Roman Catholic Mass."
Should the Supreme Court uphold the constitutionality of the 1993 act, the archdiocese still has to convince a lower court that it faces a substantial burden. "But that should be a pretty simple hill to climb," said Thomas Drought, a lawyer for the church. "We can't house our parishioners."
On the other hand, the National Trust for Historic Preservation believes that Boerne has imposed merely an incidental burden, since the denial of a demolition permit neither penalizes church members for their religious conduct nor coerces them to do something their religion forbids.
Mayor Patrick R. Heath of Boerne has grappled with the issue from both sides, as he is also an ordained Methodist minister.
"The church, along with all its facilities, finds itself in the middle of history," he said. "And part of its mission is not to destroy community but to build, along with other institutions, a sense of community, a sense of place, a sense of caring and a sense of responsibility.
"You don't step outside society and claim to judge it and claim to be outside its norms," Mr. Heath concluded. "You stay in society and help build the church on earth and help build the earthly city."

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Where Eyesores and the Economy Collide

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
PETER B. DORRAM, dapper in vest and bow tie, tapped his pointer at a chart propped on an easel in Eddie Goldberg's office. The office is a remodeled trailer at Tri-Way Kars, the used-car lot Mr. Goldberg has run for almost 30 years on Route 46 in South Hackensack.
"I wish for you to pay attention," Mr. Dorram, 72, commanded in a clipped Czech accent. Compliance was immediate. Mr. Dorram, a Harvard-educated architect and land-use planner, immigrated here in the early 1950's after serving as a commando in the original Israeli army. He runs a tight ship. 
 There were 12 charts, including more than 100 photographs of local businesses within a 37-acre tract beside the half-mile of Route 46 that runs through South Hackensack. Last year, the town, population 2,200, decreed that the highway area was a civic embarrassment. It commissioned a grand plan to condemn the car lots, motels, bars and small service businesses along the highway, and an adjoining section of land containing offices, warehouses and light industry, to clear the way for something more attractive, like a sprawling retail mall. To begin condemnation, under state law, the area had to be declared blighted and crime-ridden.
This is where Mr. Goldberg and the 33 other business owners affected sprang into action in October, raising $50,000 and forming a group they called BASH -- Businessmen's Association of South Hackensack -- to fight the condemnation. They hired Mr. Dorram to draft an alternative plan to spiff up the area without bulldozing it for a typical suburban asphalt retail prairie.
"Most towns would beg to have all these businesses," Mr. Dorram declared, rapping his pointer on a chart showing photos of well-maintained businesses. One, a formerly ramshackle car wash, just spent $4 million on a very sleek renovation.
"What kind of an idiot would invest $4 million in a depressed area?" he scoffed.
Ugly is in the eye of the beholder. But no one disputes the numbers. The 37-acre tract contains businesses that employ 658 people, many in skilled jobs, with an annual payroll of $18.6 million. Vacancies are near zero.
So what's the problem?
"They say we're ugly," Mr. Goldberg grumbled.
"Rejuvenation is needed," Mr. Dorram agreed. But he and the business owners insist they can do it privately, under a well-designed plan to improve highway esthetics while addressing problems like parking and access on a major roadway used by 69,000 cars a day.
The town's alternative, condemnation, would lead to years of expensive litigation and an ensuing period of deterioration, since banks don't lend money to possibly doomed businesses. "Deterioration would then become a self-fulfilling prophecy," said Mr. Goldberg, who has become an avid student of Mr. Dorram's ideas about improving the character of a highway business district.
You could use the acronym DUH -- Drastically Ugly Highways -- for stretches of road like this part of Route 46 in Bergen County. Other examples include segments of Routes 17 and 22; Route 1 from the Lincoln Tunnel to the Garden State Parkway; Route 130 and Admiral Wilson Boulevard in Camden County. These are the original highways to suburbia, laid down 30 years before anybody heard the name Wal-Mart.
South Hackensack's redevelopment plan argues that the low-rate motels and bars on the highway bring crime and account for a large number of police calls. But the police chief, Joseph E. Brown Jr., said that was true mainly because the motels and bars had pay phones and stayed open at night. Most of the police responses, the Chief said, are to minor incidents, or "service calls" like car breakdowns. Serious crimes are rare, he said.
"I really can't say we have a problem out there," he said. "Other than some of those cars Eddie puts out on his lot."
Mr. Goldberg laughed at the gibe. Chief Brown added that he agreed with the businessmen, who say they can pay for their own solutions, without seeing a major part of a town's economic base bulldozed to make way for low-paying retail businesses.
As to appearances, "we get the message," Mr. Goldberg said later in his tiny office. He looked wistfully out the window, where rows of plastic flags snapped gaudily in the gusts of wind kicked up by the endless traffic. This decor would not comply with the recommendations Mr. Goldberg and his competitors would agree to under Mr. Dorram's plan.
"We'd draft an ordinance," Mr. Dorram said. "No flags. You'll get more business making it attractive."
Mr. Goldberg nodded but said glumly, "Well, I will miss the flags."

HEADLINE: Honoring Cow College Tradition At UConn

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM

 BODY:
TO walk into the auditorium of the Radcliffe Hicks Building in Storrs is to step backward in time. One of the largest classrooms on the main campus of the University of Connecticut looks less like a bastion of academia than a rodeo ring. Several rows of chairs surround an earthen pit some 90 feet in diameter. The floor's sawdust covering is redolent with the odor of the barnyard.
For many UConn students, the auditorium, if seen at all, is seen as a quaint reminder of the university's roots as an agricultural college. Built in 1951 for demonstrations of animal husbandry, the auditorium, like the academic subject it was built for, may seem to belong to another era. After all, in 1951 it was fairly common for a Connecticut resident to have grown up on a farm. These days, it is more common to have grown up without ever seeing one. These days it is also more common for a student to arrive at UConn in search of an engineering, business or liberal arts degree, but the study of agriculture not only remains at Storrs but also flourishes. The dean of UConn's College of Agriculture and Natural Resources, Kirklyn M. Kerr, says the program is taking some giant strides toward the 21st century, largely because it has to. 
 "The farmer needs every tool to survive," he said. "If you notice, the price of food never goes up. It's cheaper now, if you count inflation, than it was in 1940. The only way you can manage that if you're a farmer is to use the new technology to control costs and inputs. That's the only way agriculture can stay in business."
Farmers in Connecticut still pump more than 9,300 jobs and $844 million into the state economy. There may be only 300 dairy farms left in the state, but they produce more pounds of milk per day than more rural states like New York and Vermont. The amount of farmland in the state has shrunk drastically over the last half century, but farmers can maximize the use of the land they have better than ever before.
Production is not a problem; cost management is. "You go and talk to one of our graduates who was here 10-20 years ago and ask him, 'How was your education?' " Mr. Kerr said. "He'll say he had a wonderful time and learned a lot, but then he'll say, 'If I hadn't gone back and gotten my business training I'd be out of work.' "
Gone are some of the benchmarks of UConn's ag school past: The chicken coops that dotted the pastureland along Route 195, the classes on farm machinery, the creamery where milk was processed for campus use. In their place are courses on pollution control, business management, computers.
"The college is moving away from traditional agriculture and developing areas that are nontraditional," said Derek W. Allinson, a professor of agronomy at UConn. "For example, there's a new major in landscape architecture that has been attracting students on a regular basis."
Horticulture accounts for three-fourths of state agriculture, and it is in that subject area that some of the college's most notable changes continue to take place. Tucked away in the farthest reaches of campus, beyond Horsebarn Hill where an 18th-century farmhouse slowly rots away, are a pair of cramped trailers that constitute the college's Agriculture Biotechnology Facility. In the center, ferns are grown not in pots or garden beds, but in petri dishes and tiny glassine envelopes. More than 500 tiny plants can be fostered in a single bag, says Mark P. Bridgen, an associate professor of plant science at the university who helps run the center.
"The money is moving from farming to social horticulture," Mr. Bridgen said. His laboratory already produces 10,000 ferns a week, which is expected to be up to 35,000 by next June. Other plants grown in bulk include lilacs, rhododendrons and mountain laurel.
Kent Kratz, owner of an Eastford-based plant business, Just for Starters Inc., is working with the university, trading his expertise and technology for the chance to use the university labs as an incubator for his product.
"Connecticut has a lot of potential growers," Mr. Kratz said. "Demand is outstripping production like crazy."
The operation will enjoy a greater public profile in the very near future when it takes up residence in the soon-to-be-constructed Agricultural Biotechnology Laboratory, an 80,000-square-foot building that will represent a $20 million investment in the future of agricultural study at UConn. (It is part of a larger program of campus-wide upgrades and additions known under the umbrella term "UConn 2000.")
Getting financial support from the state and Federal Government was cumbersome enough, yet the final stumbling block for the college turned out to be a piece of its own history, an 85-year-old pale yellow barn that sits alongside Route 195, across from the dormitory quadrangle known as Towers.
The barn, which once housed many key agricultural programs but currently is used mostly for storage, was to have been torn down to make room for the new center, but a public outcry for its preservation forced a retinkering of the laboratory layout. The new laboratory is now slated to be constructed next to the barn, in an existing parking lot.
Dean Kerr accepts these circumstances with perceptible chagrin. "There's nothing historic about the barn," he said, saying the structure is listed on the National Register of Historic Places only as part of the Horsebarn Hill vista. "It was built on a low-bid contract. It has nothing special about it. But they wanted to keep it, so here it is." Now he said he faces the costly hurdle of replacing the parking lot.
Mr. Kerr took over the agricultural college in 1993, charged with bringing a fading program up to date. The college, which had 1,596 students as recently as 1976, saw enrollment dip to less than half that by the late 1980's.
"There was a major concern that this college was living in the past, that they were still teaching the same animal courses they were 20 years ago. That there was too much emphasis being placed on things like how to put a halter on a cow. And there was some truth to that."
Established as a land-grant college for the purpose of educating a then-largely agarian region, UConn began in 1881 as the Storrs Agricultural School. It went through several name changes, but it wasn't until 1933 that the school finally dropped the word "agricultural" from its name.
"One could interpret the change in name having actual as well as symbolic importance," said the university archivist Bruce P. Stark. By the 1970's, the College of Agriculture had expanded its purview to include ecological concerns, a change reflected when it altered its name to the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.
Louis Pierro, a professor emeritus of animal genetics at the college, said the agricultural emphasis at UConn was in decline "probably as early as the 1940's." But the real slide began when Homer Babbidge became the university's president in 1962.
"In the 1960's and 1970's the college wasn't appreciated as much as it should have been," said Dr. Pierro, who arrived at UConn in 1960. "By most yardsticks, Homer Babbidge was an outstanding president. But his vision did not include a major role for agriculture."
Instead, Mr. Babbidge built up the university's other programs, including its only other college, the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences. "It's not that the College of Agriculture was degraded, it's just that the other schools were growing," Dr. Allinson said.
Neglect continued to be a program for the agricultural college long after Mr. Babbidge's departure in 1972. Larry Carville, executive director of the Connecticut Nurserymen's Association, recalled serving on the original UConn 2000 panel in the late 1980's with the university's then-president John Casteen.
"We had a hard time convincing Casteen that agriculture is important to the university, that it got its start as a land-grant cow college," Mr. Carville said. "There has been a steady erosion in agriculture at the university over the last five administrations."
There are signs that may be changing. Harry J. Hartley's last official act before stepping down as university president last September was to preside at the groundbreaking ceremony for the laboratory. Whether his successor, Philip E. Austin, builds on that has yet to be seen, but members of his administration say he will.
"Our College of Agriculture and Natural Resources is a critical part of our history, but also a part of our future," said Mark A. Emmert, UConn chancellor and provost of university affairs. He added that UConn was a leader of the Green Revolution, the postwar period that saw giant leaps in farm productivity: "Now we are in a position to lead the next revolution, the biotechnology revolution," he said.
The university's investment in biotechnology goes well beyond ferns. Thomas T. Chen, a professor of cell biology, has been developing a program for talapia, a food fish prized in Asia that he believes can be bred in faster-growing and space-intensive ways, to meet the demands of a growing world population.
Also being developed at the college is the Integrated Pest Management program, which is working to increase the effectiveness of pesticides so that they can be used more sparingly, with less toxic exposure to the surrounding environment.
Such programming is reflected in the courses offered, Dean Kerr said. Ironically, one of the major criticisms about the college he hears from the students is that there is not enough emphasis being placed on more basic elements of agriculture -- like putting a halter on a cow. Fewer than a fifth of UConn's agricultural students were raised on farms, he noted, and he conceded they may have a point.
"Students coming from an urban setting need to be taught some basic skills, or they're going to be kicked in the head," he said. "We try to teach that, but that will be incorporated into a class like beginning animal science."
There are also student groups like the Dairy Club and the Block and Bridle Club that put on livestock shows at the Radcliffe Hicks arena, but Dean Kerr said more needs to be done. One goal of the college is to implement internship programs for all students in agriculture-related activities.
There are other criticisms of the college as well. "One continuing problem is that students come out with good academic records but no real-world expectations" as to what kind of salaries are available, Mr. Carville said. "I fault the professors for that. As a result, we're exporting our graduates to other parts of the country."
One common concern about the professors at the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources is the paucity of them. For several years now, the school has had a hiring freeze imposed by the state government. From 1990 to 1996, while the agricultural student body increased from 606 to 842, the number of professors dropped from 100 to 73. Dean Kerr said that figure could dip to 65 by next year.
Making their case to Hartford has proved difficult. Only 2 of the 151 State Representatives are farmers, which is nevertheless 2 more than the number of farmers in the State Senate. At separate times in his administration, Gov. John G. Rowland proposed abolishing the State Department of Agriculture and the Agricultural Experiment Station in New Haven, only to drop those stands after meeting strong resistance.
"It has been difficult," Amy Hanaburgh, director of governmental relations for the Connecticut Farm Bureau Association. "We have to remind people where their roots are. It was nice at the laboratory groundbreaking to see people in the state government addressing the fact UConn was established as an agriculture college. As with agriculture itself, sometimes we have to step back and realize where our food is coming from."

HEADLINE: Habitats/491 West 22d Street;
Great-Grandma's House

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
THE ghost of Rosanna Zuckerman's great-grandmother is watching. "I hope she'll be happy with the garden," said Mrs. Zuckerman, a handsome, gray-haired widow in her "early 70's" who has embarked on a total renovation of the two bottom floors of her great-grandmother's house at 491 West 22d Street. Ms. Zuckerman, who charmingly related the saga of the old house in Chelsea, lives in another family house two doors down.
The house at No. 491 was built in the 19th century, one of a long row of exquisite brownstones on the north side of the block between Ninth and 10th Avenues. The house is adjacent to the Empire Diner, the Art Deco restaurant on the northeast corner of Ninth Avenue. 
 It was this house that Mrs. Zuckerman's family bought first. "Chelsea was very Old World then," she said. "Clement Moore, who wrote 'The Night Before Christmas,' developed the area and divided streets into different economic levels: houses on 23d Street are bigger and grander; those on 22d Street are smaller.
"My family bought into Clement Moore's design," she continued. "I'm not really sure of the year, the 1880's." Her great-grandmother, Ann Thornley Cox, lived at No. 491; after being widowed, she moved two doors down to live with her children.
Somewhat daringly, the family rented out the house at No. 491. "Other people on the block were aghast," she said. "They said: 'Oh, they're not really renting; how could they?' " The neighborhood went through the ups and downs of the era; at first, the house was rented out to a single family. But during the Depression, it was cut up into single rooms -- with common kitchens in the hallways.
"The poverty of the Depression was a terrible thing," said Mrs. Zuckerman, a clinical social worker. "The rents for the whole house brought in $16. But I remember my mother saying: 'I don't care how much money we take in -- I don't want the vandals in there.' I was just a child."
After the war, Mrs. Zuckerman's husband, Gabriel, helped to care for the house the family had rented out. "He renovated it piecemeal," she said. "He built in kitchens for each of the apartments." Then, when Mrs. Zuckerman's mother died, her husband officially took over management. In the last couple of years, four of the studio apartments at No. 491 became vacant, two on the ground floor and two on the first floor.
"It was now or never," Mrs. Zuckerman said. "We decided to make a duplex." So they started ripping out the partitions, and the kitchens Mr. Zuckerman had carefully put in.
NOW the white space seems gaping, gigantic. Johnathan Cunningham, a local contractor, was chosen; Mrs. Zuckerman was particularly impressed that he had gutted out a house in the neighborhood several years ago. The term "gutted out" makes preservationists shudder, especially when dealing with a 19th-century town house, but Mrs. Zuckerman said the house had lost all its original details decades ago -- a process that was completed in the 1960's, when her husband did some extensive renovations.
The space that was created, designed by Robin Ostler, an architect who is the founding partner of her own firm, EOA, is simple and clean. Downstairs is the kitchen, which leads out to a backyard garden, being recreated with stone pavers and a new lattice wall separating the property from the one next door. There is a bedroom downstairs, with the master bedroom and living room upstairs. The apartment is empty now, but will soon be occupied by a family friend who will stay until late spring, when it will be rented out.
Several months ago, a real estate agent told Mrs. Zuckerman she might get $4,500 a month rent for the two floors. But an attempt to rent the property fell flat -- partly because some families didn't like two bedrooms on different floors, she said. Now, she said, she'll try for $4,000.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Optimism Drives New-Home and Resale Markets

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
WHEN Joseph D. Simon, a Garden City lawyer, and his wife, Dana, signed a contract on Dec. 26 to buy a new house in the Villages at Huntington, a Melville development, they did so without making the $340,000 purchase contingent on finding a buyer for their three-bedroom town house in Wantagh.
After living for nine years in an attached house, Mr. Simon said, he and his wife and their two children are ready to move on to a larger house on its own land. And with a closing date nearly a year off, they are not worried about finding a buyer for their present home, he added. 
 The desire to upgrade from an existing house to a new house, coupled with optimism that the resale market has revived, brought many buyers like the Simons into the new-house market last year, and predictions are that strong sales will continue this year.
The total number of residential building permits issued last year in Nassau and Suffolk Counties rose by almost 30 percent over 1995 in the 11-month period ended Nov. 30, the latest month for which figures were available. The number, including multifamily residences, rose to 4,921 from 3,810.
In the resale market, there was a 10 percent increase in completed sales, with 15,689 closings taking place in Nassau and Suffolk over the 11 months ended last Nov. 30, against 14,210 closings in the same period the year before.
"We've been doing very well here, and with the unemployment rate relatively low now, and interest rates low, we have broken out of the doldrums," said Robert A. Weiboldt, the executive director of the Long Island Builders Institute, a trade group.
The Simons, who expect to close around the end of the year on their Melville house, a four-bedroom colonial on a quarter-acre lot, had considered buying an older home.
"But here you get everything new, you get to choose the color and style of the house, and particularly important is that we will be in a community with children our children's age, and with people with similar situations as our own," Mr. Simon said.
The Villages at Huntington, a subdivision of 248 mostly detached houses, is being developed by McGovern-Barbash Associates of Babylon. Prices for the detached houses range from $295,000 to $335,000.
Debora Ruisi and her husband, Joseph, a dentist with a practice in Floral Park, also wanted to purchase something new. They expect to close in July on a five-bedroom traditional colonial being built for them and their three children in a Muttontown development called Ponds Edge. They are moving there from Garden City.
"After living first in a very old house, and then in one that is 20 years old, we decided it was time to buy something new," Mrs. Ruisi said.
Their Muttontown house, which will cost $605,000, will be one of 16 in the development where prices range from $535,000 for a 2,200-square-foot ranch to $650,000 for a 3,800-square-foot colonial. Twelve of the houses have either been sold or have gone into contract since sales began a year ago.
"People want to make a change, and they are making a change because they are able to sell their houses," said Steven A. Klar, the president of the Klar Organization of East Meadow, the developer of the Muttontown project.
The once-listless town-house market has also revived, he added. His town-house project, Willow Wood, in Hauppauge, opened for sales last September and is already half sold, he noted. Prices for the two- and three-bedroom attached and semi-attached one- and two-story houses range from $190,000 to $220,000. The units and grounds will be maintained by a homeowners' association.
"It's not the 80's boom days, but we have a nice, solid flow of people who are buying at a good pace, including an awful lot of seniors," Mr. Klar said.
Thomas Ammentorp and his wife, Christy, both engineers in their early 30's, are first-time buyers. They selected one of the three-story Willow Wood town houses for which they will pay $210,000. "We live in an apartment complex now and we liked the idea that everything would be taken care of," Mr. Ammentorp said.
THEY are now renting a two-bedroom apartment in a Holbrook complex that has a pool and a clubhouse, as does Willow Wood.
"We kind of got used to that, and we felt that buying a detached house would almost be a step down," Mr. Ammentorp said. "I see too many of my friends spending all their weekends working on their homes."
Sales are strong in all price ranges said Charles B. Mancini, vice president of Park Ridge Homes in Ronkonkoma, which has four developments under construction.
At his Park Ridge Estates at Setauket development, where 52 detached houses ranging in size from 2,700 to 3,500 square feet are to be built, six are already in contract although construction hasn't begun, he said. Prices there range from $279,000 to $350,000.
And at his Hunting Hollow Farm development in Dix Hills, where prices range from $500,000 to over $1 million, six houses have gone into contract since the first of the year, Mr. Manicini added.
Brian Farrell, a bank vice president, and his wife, Maureen, already own a house in Setauket. But they are purchasing one of Park Ridge's Setauket houses because with three children, Mr. Farrell said, they need more space. The four-bedroom colonial will cost around $290,000.
They signed a contract Dec. 10 after looking at almost 60 houses over a three-month period. Although they liked many of the older houses, Mr. Farrell said, there was always some compromise they would have had to make. "With a new house, we are getting the layout and everything we wanted," he added.
Builders say they are introducing fresh designs and new ideas to give themselves a competitive edge over resale houses.
"We are not building the repetitive shoeboxes we were five years ago," said Anthony F. Monaco, president of Springbriar Homes, a developer with offices in Kings Park.
Hip roofs, reverse gables, front porches, decorative details, nine-foot ceilings and maintenance-free exteriors are some of the features that differentiate houses now being built from those in the past, he said.
Springbriar will be starting two new projects this year -- one in Selden with 45 houses priced from $179,000 to $230,000, the other in Manorville with 79 houses priced from $160,000 to $250,000.
At Leisure Glen in Ridge, Donald M. Eversoll and Peter D. Klein, partners in Klein & Eversoll in Commack, are building 244 houses in a project called Timber Ridge Homes at Leisure Glen. It is the final phase of a 650-house retirement community started by another builder, Leisure Technology, in 1986.
The partners have redesigned the houses "to bring them from the 80's into the 90's," Mr. Eversoll said.
Instead of being attached, houses will now be detached, occupying quarter- to half-acre lots. They will have nine-foot ceilings, more storage, two-car instead of one-car garages and stone exteriors. Prices for the two-bedroom, 1,400- to 1,700-square-foot homes range from $185,000 to $200,000.
THE preference of buyers is still the detached house said Lennard Axinn, a Jericho developer. But at the same time, people want recreational amenities and maintenance-free living, he said.
So more and more of the new developments are being structured as homeowners' associations in which purchasers can buy a single-family detached house, yet still share recreational facilities.
Mr. Axinn. in partnership with Gerald Friedman and Harvey Gessin of Ronkonkoma, is building 75 houses priced from $299,000 to $399,000 in a Setauket development called Island Estates at the Three Village Club.
The dwellings will share a pool, a gatehouse and other facilities with 89 houses being built on adjoining land by another developer, AVR Realty of Yonkers, under the name Pondfield Estates at the Three Village Club. Those houses will be priced from $289,000 to $340,000.
The Villages at Huntington, where the Simons are purchasing a house, also has recreational amenities, as does Country Pointe in Melville, where Michael Dubb and Leslie Lerner of the Beechwood Organization of New Hyde Park are building 111 detached houses and 82 town house. Prices at Country Pointe range from $204,900 to $294,500.
People feel confident about the economy, so they are buying houses, said Mr. Dubb, who is the past president and now the chairman of the Long Island Builders Institute. At Country Pointe, he noted, 40 contracts were signed in the last two months.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Loews Details Plans for White Plains Movie Palace

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
WITH the announcement last month of the decision by Regal Cinemas to drop out of the competition to build this city's first multiplex movie complex, the path is now clear for Loews Theaters to go ahead with its plans to build a mega-movie palace similar in style to its flagship Lincoln Square theater in Manhattan.
Like Lincoln Square, at 68th Street and Broadway, the proposed White Plains theater will "pay homage to the grand movie palaces of the 1920's," said Marc J. Pascucci, a spokesman for Loews, which is owned by the Sony Corporation. 
 The 130,000-square-foot, 20-screen theater will have "stadium seating [each row on its own level] and digital sound," Mr. Pascucci said. "And the interior design will create a sense of excitement the moment you enter the door."
White Plains has been without a movie theater since one closed in the Galleria mall six years ago. For the last year and a half, Regal Cinemas, based in Knoxville, Tenn., had been competing head-to-head with Loews. Each contended that its site would best stimulate downtown business.
The companies' proposals had been on parallel tracks, each with its own set of supporters. Regal's was favored by many downtown merchants since the company planned to build a 15-screen theater on a site bordered by Main and Court Streets and Hamilton Avenue, in the heart of the city's business district.
In partnership with Jon L. Halpern, a local developer who owns most of the site, Regal also proposed development of 30,000 square feet of complementary retail outlets and a community theater.
Apparently everything changed for Regal in October when the city gave Loews the go-ahead to build its theater on an empty parcel of urban renewal land, at Bank Street between Main Street and Martine Avenue. The site is at the western entrance to the downtown, near the Metro-North train station.
On Jan. 17, Mr. Halpern announced Regal's decision to withdraw. "Regal believed that having 35 movie screens within such a short distance of each other did not make good business sense," said Mr. Halpern.
"Nevertheless, following the city's decision last fall to clear the way for the railroad station site to move forward, Regal throughly re-analyzed its own plan." he continued. "Once again, Regal concluded that it simply didn't make economic sense to have two large multiplexes so close to one another; and, thus, it has withdrawn."
THAT Loews has emerged the victor should come, perhaps, as no surprise. From the beginning, the company stated its determination to build its theater regardless of any other company's plans.
Regal seemed equally determined to be this city's only multiplex. "I'm sure Sony will do very well with their site," said Greg Dunn, chief operating officer for Regal. "But we always said that if the city approved both projects, we'd drop out. We've always maintained that the area would only be able to support one large multiplex."
Since Regal's announcement, Sony has wasted no time in moving its plans closer to fruition. Last month, it presented design drawings to the city's Urban Renewal Agency.
The Loews' proposal is scheduled to go before the Common Council tomorrow for final site plan approval. "Ground could be broken as early as next month," said Mayor Sy Schulman. "The theater could be open in part by the end of the year."
To counteract the image of the concrete bunker look so often associated with suburban movie theaters, Loews has designed a structurally graduated facade with architectural flourishes such as lighted finials and ornamental copper cornices. "The drawings show a superior architectural tour de force," said Mayor Schulman. "It casts you back to the movie palaces of the 1920's with the richness and variety of the materials they plan to use.
The exterior will be composed of two kinds of limestone, said David Rockwell of the Rockwellgroup, of Manhattan, which is designing the theater. "At the front, there will be lots of glass, which will serve to spill the theater out onto the street."
The lobby will feature 30-foot ceilings and lighted fluted columns that lead to a rotunda. "In the old movie palaces, there might have been a fountain or sculpture in the center of the theater," Mr. Rockwell explained. "In our building, the concession area will occupy that space. But it will have a sculptural look and feel to it."
Beyond the concession stand will be a "salon," Mr. Rockwell said. "It will be a place to meet a friend, have a snack or relax and watch previews on video monitors."
LOEWS plans to run a public arts competition for mural designs to decorate the north facade of the building, the side facing Main Street. "It's the gateway to the city," Mr. Rockwell said. "We want something special there. The mural designs will be thematically linked." The Westchester Arts Council will coordinate the competition.
Mr. Rockwell has designed other Loews theaters, including one that recently opened in New Brunswick, N.J. "I base my designs on theaters from the golden age of movies," he said. "Those buildings were public celebrations. They had elegance, permanence and timelessness. They represented civic pride. That's what we want for White Plains."
Loews is developing the project jointly with a local development team called Rmap, a partnership of the original designated developer for the site, the Jack Parker Organization of Manhattan, and the Robert Martin Company, of Elmsford.
At one time, the Jack Parker Organization had planned to build a Parker Meridien Hotel on the site now slated for the movie theater. Years later, the plans changed to a 400,000-square-foot office building that was to have been developed in partnership with Robert Martin.
"That was just when the real estate recession hit," said Brad Berger, chief executive officer of Robert Martin. "This is the third time we're back at the drawing board for this site. But this time, it's the perfect use at the perfect time."
In October, the Urban Renewal Agency conveyed the four-acre site to Rmap, which in turn will lease it to Loews, Mr. Berger explained. "Loews will build its theater since that is their expertise," Mr. Berger said. "Rmap will be responsible for everything from the sidewalk out, the entire road infrastructure."
Loews plans to build a 370-car garage under the theater. It will also lease a 254-car commuter lot from the city for use in the evenings and on weekends. And Robert Martin has agreed to let theater patrons use a 1,500-car parking facility at an office building it owns directly across the street.
Mr. Berger expects business to be so good at the new theater that other operators will soon take notice. Without referring specifically to Regal, Mr. Berger said: "It's inappropriate to expect a monopoly. Everywhere Sony operates now, it has competition. And I expect the same will eventually be true of White Plains."
