HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Acquisitions;
Westchester Firm Becoming Part of Jersey REIT

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
FOR 40 years, the company created by Robert Weinberg and Martin Berger was a major factor in the two counties immediately north of New York City, with their Robert Martin Company eventually owning 4.1 million square feet of office, mixed-use and industrial space in Westchester and in Fairfield County, Conn.
The name will continue to exist, but Robert Martin is about to become part of a fast-growing New Jersey-based real estate investment trust, Cali Realty Corporation. The $440 million transaction will mark the demise of yet another family-owned real estate company attracted by the ready access to capital and the favorable tax treatment a REIT provides. 
 The transaction had little effect on the price of Cali stock, but investors have been positive about its prospects for the last year. The shares, which traded at about $21 a share early last year, were at $32.375 late last week.
"We had been looking to find a way to recapitalize the company for 18 months," said Brad W. Berger, the chief executive of Robert Martin and the son of Martin Berger. "We wanted to grow the company and diversify geographically, and after exploring a spectrum of alternatives, both public and private, this seemed to be the logical way to go."
He said that without the REIT structure, the company had been at a disadvantage when trying to make acquisitions. "When were were negotiating to acquire Blue Hill Office Plaza, that's 1.2 million square feet in Pearl River, we had to find a financial partner to get it done," he said. "Now, when we negotiate to buy a property, we won't have to negotiate the financing at the same time."
Cali agreed to acquire 65 properties and the management operations of Robert Martin for $211 million in cash and 1,401,225 operating-partnership units. The units are convertible into shares of Cali stock worth about $44 million. The company also assumed $185 million of Robert Martin debt.
The Robert Martin acquisition by Cali parallels the takeover of Halpern Enterprises by Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville, N.Y., in November 1995. Like Robert Martin, Halpern, also based in Westchester County, survived the real estate downturn caused by the recession and corporate downsizing of the early 1990's, but found itself scrambling to find capital to finance growth.
"The recession was a tough period, but we got through it and found ourselves in a position to make a discretionary decision," said Jon Halpern, who was president of Halpern and is now an executive vice president of Reckson. Some, of course, did not make it. The Shulman Realty Group, which had 3 million square feet of office space in Westchester, lost control and most of its properties were taken over by lenders in 1993.
"It became clear that the best access to capital is public markets," Mr. Halpern said. "So the question became whether you go public yourself or join with someone who is already established. It is clear that Robert Martin made a decision similar to what we did. It just took them longer because they are larger."
AT the time of its acquisition by Reckson, Halpern owned 935,000 square feet of office space in Westchester. In addition to the 4.1 million square feet of owned space Robert Martin brings to Cali, it has 1.9 million square feet it manages and in which it has an equity interest.
The Halpern and Robert Martin transactions are part of a larger trend toward public ownership in the real estate industry, said Milton Cooper, the chairman of the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts. "Real estate is a huge industry, amounting to trillions of dollars nationwide," he said. "It is one of the few of its size that has a relatively small percentage of public ownership."
Mr. Cooper, who is also chairman of Kimco Realty Company in New Hyde Park, N.Y., said the principal advantage to public ownership "is access to nontemperamental capital; private real estate companies are subject to the manic-depressive swings of lenders."
And as real estate becomes more of a business than a class of assets, he said, working executives want to know that the enterprise is not dependent on the health of the founder and are attracted by corporate perquisites such as stock options, which are not possible in a private company.
There are tax advantages as well. If a family-owned company sells its assets for cash, it could trigger a huge capital gains tax for properties that have been held for a long time. "If an entrepreneurial firm contributes its assets to an operating partnership controlled by a REIT, it triggers no tax," said Roger L. Johnson, national director of real estate practice for the KPMG Peat Marwick accounting firm.
"Those partnership shares can be converted to shares of the REIT, again triggering no tax," he said. "So now you have converted an illiquid investment into a very liquid investment -- shares that are traded on the New York Stock Exchange -- and one whose value is easy to determine. You look up the stock listing in the newspaper."
Thomas A. Rizk, the president and chief executive of Cali, said the acquisition was a quick way to achieve the company's goal of becoming a "super-regional" real estate power, with properties extending from suburban Philadelphia to Stamford, Conn. "We were unrepresented in Westchester and Fairfield," he said. "Robert Martin is the biggest and best company up there, so the acquisition seemed like the best way to accomplish that."
Although corporate mergers usually result in the departure of many senior executives of the company that has been acquired, Mr. Rizk said the Robert Martin structure would be left essentially intact to manage and acquire properties in Westchester, Fairfield and Rockland Counties.
In addition, he said Brad Berger and Timothy M. Jones, Robert Martin's chief operating officer, would become executive vice presidents of Cali, with corporatewide responsibility. "We are a fast-growing company and we think it is important to add senior managers to help with that growth," Mr. Rizk said.
"Tim and I will have companywide responsibility at Cali," Mr. Berger said. "I expect that we will spend a day a week in New Jersey and the other four days in Elmsford," the headquarters of Robert Martin. In addition, Robert Weinberg will have a place on the Cali board of directors along with Brad Berger.
ONCE again this arrangement parallels the Reckson-Halpern deal. Jon Halpern and his organization were left in place to manage property in Westchester and buildings later acquired in Stamford from another troubled family company, F. D. Rich. Now, Mr. Halpern said, he is being asked to play a broader corporate role.
Executives of Cali and Robert Martin say they expect to be compatible because of their similar backgrounds. Both were started by young men who parlayed a small house-building business into a real estate empire. Both have passed active management to a second generation. Although Mr. Rizk is chief executive of Cali, John R. Cali, the son of one of the founders, is director of acquisitions, and Brant Cali, son of another founder, is chief operating officer.
Upon completion of the acquisition of Robert Martin, Cali will own 122 properties with over 11.3 million square feet of space. That is quite a change from its beginnings as a public company in 1994 when it had 13 buildings with 2.2 million square feet of space.
There is no reason the company cannot continue to grow, Mr. Rizk said. Indeed, Cali appears to be a favorite on Wall Street, where the company raised $545 million in cash last year in two secondary stock offerings. The company can use this low-cost capital to make acquisitions or, if circumstances permit, new developments.
"Investors in REIT's are looking for returns in the mid to high teens," said Steven L. Kantor, managing director of the real estate operations group at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "The dividend and increases in cash flow get you to 10 or 11 percent, so the rest comes from acquisitions and development. REIT's are very active acquirers and developers."
"We are at heart a development company," Mr. Rizk said. "It has been our history to buy land, get the approvals, build without a general manager, lease and manage." He said rents are currently still too low to justify speculative construction: "They would have to go up 15 to 20 percent, but that is possible in a couple of years."
To prepare for that day, the company has been quietly building up its land bank. "We have enough land to do 5.5 million square feet of development and options on 2.5 million more," he said. He said the company was discussing building projects with specific tenants, a less risky undertaking than a purely speculative project.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
For '96, a Slow, Steady Commercial Market Upturn

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE state's commercial market ran a relatively smooth course of slow but steady improvement last year.
"It was," said David T. Houston, of Colliers Houston & Company, a brokerage concern in Bloomfield, "a year of consistent if unspectacular growth." 
 The forecast is for more of the same, with some brokers, analysts and developers talking about the possibility of a rise in new construction.
The big surprise, almost everyone interviewed agreed, was that AT&T's split into three companies did not result in a flood of space returned to the market.
The low rate of new construction and the relocation and expansion of many companies within the state pushed the office vacancy rate down and rents up in the 11-county northern New Jersey market. Most of the deals were for quality space in well-situated buildings, "which succeeded in burning off most of the available Class A and B opportunities in the market," said Robert J. Rudin, executive director of the Saddle Brook office of Insignia/Edward S. Gordon Company, the national brokerage.
Developers responded to the space squeeze by starting construction on four new buildings in the tightest markets, with key tenants in hand or secured soon after the first steel went up.
Among them is the 207,000-square-foot office building that the Bellemead Development Corporation of Roseland, a subsidiary of Chubb Insurance, is developing in Warren Township on Interstate 78. The building landed one of the year's biggest leases when Hoechst Celanese signed on for all the space.
Meanwhile, tenants were forced into weaker markets with significant vacancies, such as Franklin Township in Somerset County; while the space there has been thinned out, vacancies remain.
In the industrial and retail sectors, stores and distribution space came back onto the market with bankruptcy filings by major retailers, such as Rickles, the hardware chain, and Giant Carpet. Moreover, Procter & Gamble pulled out of 610,000 square feet of space in Dayton and Okonite, a cable manufacturer, left 650,000 square feet of space in North Brunswick.
But demand for space from new tenants and the expansion of existing ones helped keep a lid on vacancy rates, as did the ongoing trend to consolidate scattered distribution centers under one roof. New construction also sprouted to meet specific size requirements or the need for modern space.
Most industry experts expect the market, for the most part, to stay on a similar track in 1997. Among the reasons they cite is that the state's economy will continue to improve and that while some companies will downsize, others will grow.
In the process, 40,000 jobs are expected to be added in 1997, up from 32,000 in 1996, according to Nancy Mantell, director of the Economic Advisory Service at Rutgers University. There is no sign of a recession in 1997, which is expected to be another reasonable growth year, she said.
A DETAILED examination of the commercial market's past year and a look into its near future shows that the office sector was getting bad news through the first quarter. "But since March," said Eric N. Witmondt, president of Associated Realty, a commercial brokerage in Parsippany, "tenants have been fighting for quality space."
AT&T's breakup did not have the harsh impact that was expected. This was because the space the company gave back in some buildings, it or one of its spinoffs took in others, brokers said. Indeed the market closed the year in a better situation than at its outset as firms, following AT&T's space-swapping lead, took more space than they vacated. "It was a record-setting year for absorption of space," said David A. Simson, senior vice president at the Teaneck office of the CB Commercial brokerage.
The vacancy rate in the northern New Jersey office market fell 3 percentage points to 16.4 percent, according to the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield. Most of the demand came from expanding companies, not from new arrivals, which is "a missing element in the market," said Donald P. Eisen, Cushman & Wakefield's senior managing director.
Average asking rents for prime space rose to $23.41 from $22.53, and overall rents crept up to $19.50 from $19.35, his firm reported. Concessions also vanished, indicating that "we are in the middle of a landlords' market," he said.
Among the top space takers were pharmaceutical firms, evidenced by the Hoechst Celanese deal and Bristol-Myers Squibb's lease for 162,871 square feet at 100 Nassau Park Boulevard in West Windsor. (It has since expanded to 195,871 square feet. High technology, communications and financial services are expected to continue to be significant players.
The scarcity of big blocks of space led to build-to-suit deals, and to construction starts on four buildings, each of which has signed on tenants for all or part of their space. The biggest is the 240,000-square-foot building SJP Properties of Parsippany is developing in Bridgewater in the I-78 corridor. In the last month leases were signed for 190,000 square feet, said Peter Eppie, its executive vice president.
The pressure for new construction will continue in 1997 in prime markets, including the Hudson River waterfront, brokers say. Many of them are betting that at least one of four developers who now have all approvals in hand will sign on a major tenant and begin construction in Hoboken or Jersey City this year.
While there will also be more renovations of older buildings, speculative construction will be minimal, brokers said. "Everyone sees the structural imbalance in the market," said Mr. Eisen of Cushman & Wakefield, "but they are not ready to risk their funds."
Added Mr. Houston of Colliers Houston: "Things are going well, but the 80's are not back."
THOUGH the industrial sector's overall supply of available space rose, it was unable to meet the strong demand for modern warehouse and distribution space from tenants seeking to expand or consolidate their operations. That led to a spate of build-to-suit and speculative projects and to an increase in rental rates, said John G. Orrico, senior vice president of the local offices of Grubb & Ellis, the national brokerage.
While the activity was widespread, traditional magnets along the New Jersey Turnpike remain the hot spots. One is the Exit 8A area where Playmobile, a toy manufacturer, will be expanding to an 80,000-square-foot warehouse/office structure being built for it at the Centerpoint business park straddling Monroe and South Brunswick townships.
The other hot spot is Exit 10 in Edison where the Heller Construction Company is building a one million square foot speculative warehouse, distribution and office center, now about half leased.
Edison was also the site of one of the year's larger leases: Exel Logistics, a storage company, took 419,000 square feet at the Raritan Center business park in Edison, reflecting an emerging trend toward farming out goods that a company needs to store.
Mr. Orrico said the market in 1997 would be a repeat of 1996, though with renovations of older buildings increasing.
As for the retail sector, new companies, like Target and Kuhls, the discount department store chains, are entering the state and the ones already in place, such as Home Depot and CompUSA, continue to expand.
Amid all this reshuffling "weaker players are being replaced with newer, stronger ones, helping to stabilize the market," said Ted Kraus, who runs a retail advisory firm in Mercerville.
Supermarket and movie theater chains, which are also in a growth spurt, are helping as well, he said, noting that the retail vacancy rate remains flat at around 5 percent.
While empty stores are evident throughout the market, new construction is taking place, mainly by big-box retailers. For example, a 1.2-million-square-foot factory outlet center is under way in Elizabeth and others are planned in Jackson and Carteret.
Developers are also planning "power centers" -- mainly made up of big boxes -- and shopping strips. Three projects planned in Linden, Watchung and Carlstadt could produce nearly 4 million square feet of space.
But Dr. Mantell of Rutgers cautioned that there would be a continued shakeout in the retail sector.
"There will be some losers," she predicted.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Casting a Wider Net For Web Site Workers

BYLINE: By BARBARA B. BUCHHOLZ 

 BODY:
COMPANIES are still struggling to find ways to profit from the Internet, but many people who set up and run corporate Web sites are not having the same problem.
As the number of sites on the World Wide Web has tripled, to 300,000, since last year, the demand for people to manage corporate sites has far outstripped the supply. Companies have been recruiting computer-savvy workers right out of college and, in some cases, high school. Some positions come with salaries higher than those of comparable positions in other computer fields. 
 The Software Publishers Association says a computer graphics artist makes an average salary of $36,400 and a programmer $42,600, but a recent survey by Buck Consultants, an employee benefits and compensation consulting firm in New York, found that the same Web-related positions were paying $46,600 and $46,200, respectively.
 Salaries are continuing to rise as more companies scramble to open Web sites. And what better place to find qualified workers than at the Web sites and graphics departments of other companies?
Brian Paris was a graphics designer at an insurance brokerage firm when the Web came knocking. He now manages the Web site at Maxwell Architects in Nashville; the new job has increased his salary 20 percent, to more than $40,000.
Graphical Business Systems, an Elmhurst, Ill., company that develops Web sites, lost two of its eight programmers in December. One began his own Internet company; the other moved to an executive recruiting firm to manage its site for more than $60,000 a year, a 30 percent increase from his previous salary. Recently, another programmer, Craig Huber, changed his mind about leaving after the company said it would give him a percentage of his billings. That could raise his salary 40 percent, to more than $60,000.
"You're constantly recruiting," said John Kilcullen, business development manager at Graphical Business Systems. "You find people with the right skills, call them back and they're gone."
Fruit of the Loom, the clothing company, hired 15 people for its Web site in 1995 and lost two of them to other companies within two months. "Retaining them has been difficult," said Glenn Banfield, director of electronic commerce at the company.
The Weather Channel in Atlanta had trouble finding more Web workers last year when it expanded its site. After unsuccessfully looking for 30 people with the right skills, it hired people with various backgrounds and then trained them. The jobs have salaries from $25,000 for Web customer service representatives to $100,000 for the new manager of Web operations.
A director of on-line business typically has 10 to 15 years of corporate experience and has come up through a company's marketing or information services department, while a Web programmer may have no corporate experience, but will be fluent in several programming languages, said Paul Gavejian, a principal at Buck Consultants.
Most in demand are workers with extensive advertising or direct-mail experience, said Bob Chatham, senior analyst at Forrester Research, a computer industry consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. "What you need to make a Web site successful is to get customers there and keep them there," Mr. Chatham said. "That requires workers with hybrid skills."
When Greg Siskind, the author of "The Lawyer's Guide to Marketing on the Internet" (American Bar Association, 1996, $64.95), founded an immigration law firm in Nashville two years ago, he wanted to set up a one-page Web site. But he did the work himself. "There was no consulting industry to tap," he said. As the site grew, he hired two lawyers who also had Web skills to design and manage the site.
"We were seeking two things: lawyers knowledgeable about immigration law and attorneys who were Internet-savvy and could help with all the traffic on our Web site," he said. "We were willing to make them partners right away to reward and keep them."
Freelancers can profit, too. Brent Brotine, 47, left a Chicago advertising agency three years ago to start his own communications firm. He writes the content for the Web sites of several banks, insurance companies and mutual funds. Although he would not disclose his income, he said it had increased about 50 percent since he left the ad agency.
HOW long can the boom last? At least five years, said Josh Bernoff, a senior analyst at Forrester Research. "The industry is where television was in 1952: in its infancy," he said.
Others are more skeptical, saying companies may begin to abandon Web sites if they don't lead to an increase in revenue. "It's the Gold Rush of the 90's," said Alan Johnson, a compensation consultant in New York, "but don't be shocked if it doesn't work out."

HEADLINE: Opposite Views On Cross-Island Bridge

 BODY:
Congratulations to John Waldman. Resurgence in interest in a Long Island Sound crossing is long overdue.
It is high time a bridge or tunnel be constructed to access any area outside Long Island. Obvious reasons would include (1) the simple convenience of reaching a destination perhaps 20 miles away as the crow flies in 20 minutes instead of two hours, and (2) the cost saving of either gasoline/car wear and tear (driving around the horseshoe) or expensive ferry charges. 
 Furthermore, as eastern Long Island continues to be built up, it is obligatory to concomitantly build up all roadways and accesses. Access off Long Island across the sound may greatly diminish the parking lot atmosphere of major east-west highways for which Long Island is famous, or rather, infamous.
Mr. Waldman's opinion (on potential and likely political opposition) that "there are times when the common good should prevail over the preferences of the few" is extremely well-taken and right on the money. However, the same political forces that continue to build up Long Island (e.g., the tremendous build-up on Nesconset "Highway") and thus the population and traffic, must accommodate the population in return with easy traffic flow. It is also surprising that when political forces shut down the Shoreham nuclear plant due to lack of access off Long Island that a sound bridge or tunnel was never considered. For that matter, there should be access off Long Island in case of any emergency (e.g., weather or other natural disaster).
I also firmly believe that a span across the sound would have the great potential of boosting Long Island's economy. If a tunnel can connect such major entities as England and France, certainly a span can connect two local, closer places such as Connecticut and Long Island.
 
ELLIOTT DREZNICK
Port Jefferson Station

HEADLINE: VIEWPOINT;
Deflating an Inflation Worry

BYLINE: By NORBERT WALTER; Norbert Walter is the chief economist of Deutsche Bank.

 BODY:
IN testimony before Congress two weeks ago, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, discussed his worries about the danger of wage inflation. Specifically, Mr. Greenspan is concerned that shortages of qualified people for job openings may lead to excessive wage offers to fill those jobs. Some people take this uneasiness to suggest that a rise in interest rates may be in the offing -- if not at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting starting on Tuesday, then sometime later this year.
While German economists like myself are supposedly born with a penchant to worry themselves sick about even the slightest signs of inflation, I cannot quite share Mr. Greenspan's concerns. From my perspective, the most important dimension in evaluating future wage pressures in the United States is regularly overlooked: the increased global outsourcing of services like data processing and computer programming. Computers let American companies tap into a labor pool without national borders -- thus shattering old-school assumptions about tightness in domestic labor markets. If the labor market becomes tight at home, a company can look abroad. 
 In this sense, the United States is again the trailblazer. In the 1970's, big American manufacturers scoured the world to find cheap sources of offshore labor to control production costs. Undoubtedly, the decision to move production abroad not only helped American companies' bottom lines, it was also a crucial factor in keeping the nation's inflation rate in check. Other nations, like Germany and Japan, jumped on the bandwagon only much later.
United States companies are now repeating this process in the services sector. The global services labor pool, after all, is just a phone call or an E-mail message away. Accordingly, credit card providers, insurance firms, phone companies and technology service concerns are placing crucial business functions all over the world. Even important value-added skills, like software design, are being moved offshore.
This ability to tap into the global labor pool without headaches may well be a special advantage for American corporations. Because English is the second, if not first, language of many people, American companies can readily depend on service providers who speak the same language as headquarters does. Compare that with the problems of, say, a German or Japanese insurance company trying to start a billing department in Barbados or Sri Lanka.
While the effect of global telecommunications and computer networks is increasingly understood, little thought has been given to what it means for the labor-shortage debate in the United States -- specifically, whether inflationary pressures will result.
If the United States economy is supposed to grow faster, signs of inflation from a tight labor market would not be welcome because they would probably lead to higher interest rates. Economists typically refer at this point to a concept called Nairu -- the nonaccelerating inflation rate of unemployment, or the lowest level of unemployment the economy can sustain without setting off inflationary pressures. But we have seen little to no inflation even though the American unemployment rate has fallen below 5.5 percent -- generally seen now as the point at which the labor market supposedly becomes tight enough to become inflationary. Basically, policy makers and analysts have tried to cope with their failure to capture the correlation between unemployment and inflation by lowering the Nairu.
In my view, though, the issue ought to be cast in somewhat starker terms. I wonder whether, instead of fidgeting with numbers, it would not be more appropriate to assume that the Nairu concept may have been destroyed by the creation of global labor pools -- like the one in India generated by Jawaharlal Nehru himself, who, as India's first Prime Minister and a determined modernizer of Indian society, created a work force that is solving many of America's Nairu-related worries from afar.
Such skill pools around the world demonstrate the limitations of any economic model, like Nairu, that does not look beyond national borders. After all, for Nairu to remain a meaningful economic concept, the labor pool must be rather clearly defined on a national, or at least regional, basis. The globalization of services throws this requirement overboard. As a result, it is hard to draw reliable conclusions about slight pickups in wage levels in regions of the United States.
Labor supply is much more elastic today than in the past -- and not only because of old-fashioned (and much debated) immigration. These new forms of "labor sharing" provide great flexibility. This not only benefits American companies in their focus on the bottom line, but it also helps the American economy as a whole -- with its overblown inflation worries. And it helps other parts of the world to link into a better division of labor.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
New Budget: A Primer For Investors

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN he lays out his vision for the nation during his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, President Clinton will no doubt speak in sweeping terms of the country's problems and his solutions. But when he sends his budget to Congress two days later, he will include detailed proposals that could affect investors in many ways.
The President's budget is nothing more than his opening negotiating position with the Republican leadership on Capitol Hill. And many of Mr. Clinton's proposals will be similar, if not identical, to those included in his previous budgets but rejected or ignored by Congress. But they will help frame the policy debate, and with both sides pledging bipartisanship, the proposals are being taken seriously in Congress. 
 Here are some of the investment-related proposals Mr. Clinton is expected to proffer in some form.
 
AVERAGE-COST ACCOUNTING Mr. Clinton will again propose that investors be prevented from reducing capital gains taxes on the sale of securities by claiming to have sold the shares that had cost the most within a holding in any particular company or mutual fund. An investor would not be able to use that "specific identification" method, but would have to use the average cost of all the shares. Last year, the Administration said the change would raise $4.1 billion in taxes over six years.
Because it is effectively a tax increase, Republicans said they would oppose it again this year.
 
SHORTING AGAINST THE BOX The Administration will again seek to bar this practice, sometimes used by investors to get around capital gains taxes. The technique involves borrowing an equal number of shares in a stock that an investor already owns, and then selling the borrowed shares while holding on to the original investment. The investor can lock in gains on the original stock, but does not have to pay any tax until the positions are closed out -- and does not have to pay the capital gains tax at all if the short position is left open until the owner dies.
The Administration's proposal got little Republican support last year. But with both parties under pressure to reach agreement on a balanced budget this year, it could get another hearing.
 
INDIVIDUAL RETIREMENT ACCOUNTS Mr. Clinton is expected to renew his call for an expanded I.R.A. program that would allow more people to make tax-deductible contributions and would permit penalty-free withdrawals at any time to pay for higher education, first-time home purchases, medical care or living expenses while unemployed. He has also proposed a second type of I.R.A. that would not allow tax-deductible contributions, but would permit tax-free withdrawals of earnings after five years.
There is much support in Congress for expanding I.R.A.'s. Proposals similar to Mr. Clinton's are being pushed by Senators William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, and John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana. The problem with any I.R.A. plan, however, is the cost. The Administration said last year that its plan would reduce revenue by $7.7 billion over six years.
 
CAPITAL GAINS Mr. Clinton will make a proposal to reduce capital gains taxes by permitting married homeowners to exclude from taxation as much as $500,000 in profits from the sale of a primary residence (for single filers, the exclusion would be $250,000), and to take the exclusion as often as every two years. Under current law, there is a one-time exclusion of as much as $125,000 for people over age 55.
Republicans want a far more sweeping reduction in capital gains taxes, including a steep reduction in the top rate, now 28 percent. Even some Democrats are pushing for a broader cut than the President is proposing. Mr. Clinton has signaled a willingness to negotiate.
 
EDUCATION Mr. Clinton has a variety of proposals that might affect investors' planning for college. He wants to allow annual tax deductions of as much as $10,000 a family for college tuition or job-training programs, subject to income limits. He has also proposed a $1,500-a-year tax credit, limited to two years, for students who maintain a B average in community college. Families would have to choose between the tax credit and the deduction.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A Low-Key Fund Group Nears a Limelight Level

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
COMING off one of its best years ever, the mutual fund industry is approaching yet another milestone, this one in a nook of the business that has attracted far less attention than stock funds and their persistent waves of cash.
Total assets in money market funds, now at $933 billion, are expected to top $1 trillion within a few weeks. The $1 trillion mark itself has little significance beyond its ability to satisfy humans' fascination with a figure that ends in a string of zeros. But the money market fund, often thought of as the runt of the mutual fund litter, is probably more responsible for the industry's success than either its stock or bond siblings. 
 "Money market funds were the launching pad for the whole mutual fund business," said Bruce R. Bent, president of the Reserve Fund, introduced in October 1971 and the first money market mutual fund. "They sensitized investors to the fact that they could do something with their money other than put it in a bank account."
Indeed, the growth of money market funds has been spectacular. While mutual funds that invest in stocks took at least 55 years -- from the Investment Company Act of 1940 until 1995 -- to reach $1 trillion in assets, money market funds will do it in less than half that time.
Stock fund assets, which totaled $1.75 trillion at the end of 1996, still are much bigger than those in money market funds. But late last year, for the first time since 1991, the amount of assets in money funds surpassed the amount in bond funds. Just over one dollar of every four in mutual funds was in a money market fund at the end of the year.
Also last year, and again for the first time, American households had more of their financial assets in money market funds than in checking accounts. While savings accounts and bank time deposits still exceed household investments in money market funds by five to one, savings assets have been relatively flat for five years. Money funds, meanwhile, have grown.
They probably will continue to do so, and for several reasons, industry analysts say. Short-term interest rates have remained stubbornly high, "well above the psychologically important level of 5 percent," said Peter Crane, managing editor of IBC Money Fund Report, a newsletter.
The level is significant, Mr. Crane said, because "it makes investors feel like they're earning something substantial, and it leaves too small of a spread between the yields on bonds and money market funds to attract many people to bonds."
"Investors don't like money funds when they yield 4.7 percent," he added, "but they love them when it's 5."
Many investors have not forgotten the pain inflicted on their bond fund investments in 1994, when the Federal Reserve Board began a series of interest rate increases that sent the value of bond funds tumbling down. And with Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, apparently intent on nipping in the bud any resurgence of inflation, it appears unlikely that short-term rates, and, therefore, money fund yields, will fall sharply anytime soon.
Money market mutual funds differ from money market accounts at banks, of course, in that money funds are not federally insured. That has not hindered their growth, thanks to a couple of key marketing innovations within the mutual fund industry.
One was to obtain a ruling from the Securities and Exchange Commission that allowed money market funds to maintain a stable net asset value of $1 a share. While each money fund emphasizes in its documents that the $1 share value is not guaranteed, fund companies have vigilantly guarded that provision. In 1994, when rising rates took a bite out of some investments in complex financial instruments known as derivatives, several fund companies bought back these tumbling investments from their money market funds to keep their shares from falling below $1 each.
ANOTHER innovation, instituted in 1974 by Edward C. Johnson 3d, the chairman of Fidelity Investments, was to allow check writing on money market funds. Today, money funds offer a host of other conveniences, too, like the use of a debit card or credit card to deduct payments automatically from a fund account.
Customers were slow to respond in the early days of money market funds, uncertain of the promises of easy access to their money. "In 1973, we had one investor who kept moving $10,000 in and out of the fund every few days for three or four months," recalled Mr. Bent, of the Reserve Fund. "He was driving me crazy, and I was close to telling him to take his business elsewhere. But then, suddenly, he put a couple of million dollars into the fund. He said he didn't believe that the system could work the way we said it would, so he was just testing it."
When money market funds were introduced, banks were restricted from paying more than 5.25 percent a year on federally guaranteed savings accounts. That restriction was removed in late 1982, and banks immediately began to offer insured money market accounts that paid as much as 11 percent. So great was the demand for the insured accounts that the assets in money market funds shrank by more than a third.
Banks then reduced their rates. Not since April 1983 have banks offered a higher rate on insured accounts than that available on money funds, Mr. Bent said.
Money market funds have also been used by investors as a holding pen for money going into stock and bond funds, or as a haven in market upheavals.
Investors have aggressively pursued the highest possible returns in money market funds. But because the funds can invest in only certain types of securities under Federal regulations, about the only way a fund company can raise a yield is by achieving economies of scale and by lowering the operating expenses. Fund companies often waive a portion of the fees or expenses on a fund, especially a new one, to attract a critical mass of money.
THE role of expense waivers is nowhere more apparent than at the Strong Funds of Milwaukee. For most of the latter half of 1994, assets in the Strong Money Market fund crept upward, reaching $481 million at the end of November, from $433 million at the beginning of May.
Then, in December, Strong agreed to waive all fees and expenses on the fund, sharply raising its yield. Assets nearly doubled in two months, topping $2.4 billion in less than a year.
In August 1995, Strong slowly began adding back the operating expenses to its money market fund and assets immediately began to dip. But many of the departing assets went directly to another Strong money fund, the Heritage Money Market fund, which was introduced in June 1995 and which charged no fees or expenses in its first six months.
Assets in the Heritage fund continued to grow even after it charged investors for fund expenses and even though its minimum investment remained high, at $25,000. The main reason is that Heritage's charges were kept low, in part because the fund was big and transactions were minimal. In addition, the Heritage fund charges a fee for most transactions, including checks.
The low expenses gave the Heritage fund the highest yield of all money market funds for the 12 months ended Dec. 31, at 5.7 percent, according to the IBC Money Fund Report of Ashland, Mass. Assets in the Heritage fund, which last week totaled $1.946 billion, are close to surpassing those in the Strong Money Market fund, which had $1.949 billion.
Besides Strong Heritage, the retail funds with the highest yields for last year were the Olde Premium Plus fund, at 5.67 percent; the Frank Russell Money Market fund, 5.61 percent; the AIM Short-Term Investments fund, 5.50, and the E-Fund, 5.47 percent.
Each of the top five funds waived some or all of its management fees and expenses to achieve its yield -- a factor that investors should consider carefully. In most cases, funds can reinstate fees at any time.
Investors should also distinguish between yield and total return. The E-fund offers a debit card refund that contributed nearly half of a percentage point to its total return of 5.96 percent for the year, or above that of Strong's top-yielding money fund.
In response, the S.E.C. is considering a new rule that would restrict money funds to advertising their 12-month yield, not their total return.
Despite its top-yielding fund, Strong is not in the top ranks of money fund companies. Fidelity Investments and Merrill Lynch, the leaders, together control 20 percent of the assets in money market funds. Among the 10 biggest companies in money market funds, only one is associated with a traditional banking company -- Dreyfus, a unit of the Mellon Bank, which ranks as the fourth-largest money fund provider.

LENGTH: 796 words

HEADLINE: COPING;
The Education of a Health Care Customer

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
DARRIN JACKSON-WEEKS got his Medicaid card two years ago. He had been an H.I.V. counselor, a member of a private health plan. Suddenly he was an H.I.V. client on public assistance. As smart, informed and assertive as he still was, he felt the difference right away. He had been walked around the desk. He was looked upon as a poor person now. What could he possibly know?
"Not enough people are listening to the people who use health services," he said. "It's life and death for us. We put doctors and the system on a pedestal. But we have to ask them questions and we have to get answers so we can make choices. We have to have a voice." 
 To coach those voices into full throat, the Community Service Society of New York has been sending Mr. Jackson-Weeks and 15 other volunteers around the city to give classes to people on Medicaid. There is a new urgency to their need to know and be heard. The state is seeking permission from the Federal Government to require Medicaid recipients to select and join a health maintenance organization by the end of this year. There are 1.9 million Medicaid patients in this city, mostly children.
Last month, based on its survey of 421 Medicaid recipients in Harlem and the South Bronx, the society issued a study concluding that their transition to managed care would be difficult. They had not been educated to be medical customers, the society said, and would be at a severe disadvantage when faced with what the report called "aggressive, and often misleading, marketing by H.M.O.'s."
Ultimately, a poorly run system will not only worsen an individual's health, the society says, but will cost the city more money.
Last week, Mr. Jackson-Weeks, a lively 36-year-old with a forceful presentation, and Alice Simmons, an elegant 61-year-old with a theatrical voice, led 22 students of the Literacy Volunteers' Begin program in lower Manhattan into a preview of their new health care world. The students, many of them single mothers, are on welfare. They are preparing for jobs as home health aides, clerks and maintenance workers. Some are already in health plans that accept Medicaid. Most are used to a system in which they can go to any doctor who accepts Medicaid. They make their own appointments with specialists, which would no longer be allowed under the proposed changes, and they often use emergency rooms for primary care, which would no longer be reimbursed. In managed care, they were told, "everything changes." There would be advantages and disadvantages.
"You will have to become your own advocate," Mr. Jackson-Weeks said. "H.M.O.'s are about cutting down cost. They make money by keeping you from seeing the doctor. If things go wrong, you will have to speak up or they will do whatever they want and you will get lost in the system."
Mrs. Simmons, smiling, stepped up. "I deal with how to complain when things go wrong, which is the reality of this world," she said. "When you call the H.M.O., you must always get the name of the person you are speaking with. Keep a paper trail, time and day and what they said to you. It never hurts to ask for a supervisor."
One student, Reba Rush, 26, talked about her toddler's scalp infection. Four years later, he still has it, she said, because no one would listen to her early account.
"When they see that Medicaid card," Ms. Rush said, "they have this type of attitude, like we are dirty and don't know about ourselves. You shouldn't ask questions; you're supposed to just take what they give because you're poor."
"You are not poor!" boomed Mrs. Simmons, a retired bank worker who was once on Medicaid. "I don't allow that. Say to yourself, 'I am just in a situation where I need some help from a system that was set up for my benefit.' Accident, unemployment, it could happen to anyone." Community Services has a number, (212) 614-5400, to answer questions about managed care (don't always expect a live voice at the other end) and a readable booklet with excellent suggestions on how to navigate the new system.
The switch to mandatory managed care is of particular concern to patients with so-called special needs. Mr. Jackson-Weeks, 11 years H.I.V.-positive, says his survival would cost $20,000 a year on the open market. He feels comfortable with his doctors and nurses at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. He's worried about his future, even more worried, he says, about patients less sophisticated than he.
"We should also be giving workshops to the gatekeepers, to the doctors," Mr. Jackson-Weeks said. "There's a lot of doctors from other countries dealing with Medicaid recipients. There's a culture clash. There's a lack of sensitivity. I face it all the time. But as long as I can give these workshops, I haven't lost my voice."

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (Mark Matcho)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Meet Some Buyers of the New Inflation Bonds

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
SALLY HEINEMANN has been going to Treasury auctions for nearly two decades. She remembers those inflationary days, in the early 1980's, when the prime rate hovered near 21 percent and people flocked to the Federal Reserve Bank near Wall Street to snap up bonds paying 15 percent interest.
So why was she pacing the halls of the Fed last Wednesday at a time that inflation is barely eclipsing 3 percent? 
 She was buying the new inflation-indexed bonds, those 10-year investments that regularly adjust both interest and principal to changes in the Consumer Price Index, all on top of a real interest rate of 3.375 percent.
Wednesday was the first day the Treasury sold the bonds, at the Federal Reserve Bank in Manhattan and at other Fed banks across the country. And Ms. Heinemann, a newspaper editor in her 50's who lives in Great Neck, L.I., wanted to buy some for herself and for her daughter.
"This is a hedge," Ms. Heinemann said, standing in the Fed's colossal stone foyer, just a few blocks from the New York Stock Exchange, where somewhat riskier investments are traded. "I think interest rates are going up," she said. "And if inflation goes up, I won't be one of them who says, 'Why didn't I buy those things?' "
But Ms. Heinemann couldn't understand why there were so few like-minded people in line. "Today, it's dead," she said, squinting through her glasses at the handful of ordinary citizens who had also trekked to the bank. "This is the smallest auction I've ever seen."
The sparseness of the crowd might have been because of the January cold, the newness of the bond or even the chance that the Labor Department might revise the price index to measure inflation more conservatively. But the scene was misleading; over all, the bond received a warm reception in its debut. In fact, investors demanded $37 billion of the bonds, more than five times as much as the $7 billion offered.
Most of those investors were institutions, however, not individuals like those who had lined up at the Fed. And opinions differed on the size of individual interest in the bonds.
While Peter Hollenbach, a Treasury spokesman, said the interest was "great for a new security," two mutual fund companies that have started new funds based on the bonds gave more modest reports. Dreyfushad just a handful of inquiries. And at American Century, James A. Benham, a spokesman, noted the popularity of the auction among institutions but added, "Whether or not that spills over to retail folks, we'll just have to wait and see."
As with other Treasuries, the new bonds will be auctioned quarterly, with the next offering in April. Individuals can buy the bonds through a broker, a bank or directly from the Fed bank in their region. In the New York area, call Treasury Direct at (212) 720-6619. Tender forms can be ordered through the World Wide Web: www.publicdebt.treas.gov.
At the New York Fed on Wednesday, Fred Bernstein was also surprised at the small turnout. "I thought there'd be crowds," said Mr. Bernstein, a 40-year-old lawyer from Los Angeles, who was in New York for a job interview.
Earlier, when he was having breakfast at his downtown hotel, he came across a newspaper article about the sale of the securities and decided to buy a few.
"I asked the concierge, 'Where is 33 Liberty Street?' And he said, 'It's right there,' " Mr. Bernstein recalled. So he walked over.
"Some of my bank C.D.'s matured recently, and like a lot of people, I sat around wondering what to do," Mr. Bernstein explained. "None of the options seemed good. I had bank C.D.'s at 6, 7, 8 percent, and it hurt too much to even think about reinvesting the money at 3 percent. So I let a lot of money pile up in my checking account."
Since he has read only one article about the new bonds, much of Mr. Bernstein's decision to buy them rested on simple trust in the Treasury.
"As far as the Federal Reserve goes, you just stand in this building, and you know it's solid," he said. "I have a philosophy about investing: I don't invest in anything I don't understand, and that rules out just about everything."
Some of the buyers said they had bought the new bonds out of curiosity, a sort of test drive of the Government's latest security. Others talked of the thrill of being first. But even more, the buyers seemed to like the bonds for the same reason that investors have traditionally been drawn to Treasuries: safety. Indeed, with their safety net against high inflation, the new bonds are an even safer way to secure a nest egg.
"With Treasuries, you can sleep at night," Ms. Heinemann said. "You won't get rich, but you can sleep."
Safety was also on the mind of Lawrence Hayes, who bought $15,000 of the inflation bonds. "This is for my daughter's college education," he said, holding the hand of 5-year-old Lanay as his wife, Darlene, looked on. "We're not a wealthy family, so it's important for us to preserve the principal."
Mr. Hayes, 37, an electrician from Washingtonville, N.Y., is an active investor who bought the bonds both to combat inflation and to diversify a portfolio containing an equity mutual fund, savings bonds and other investments. He did his homework on the new bonds. He knew that because the inflation adjustment would be taxed each year, the bonds might work best in a tax-deferred account like a 401(k) plan.
Nor was he the only avid student of these new investments. Ms. Heinemann even called an analyst at J. P. Morgan to quibble over a paragraph in an analysis of the security.
But uncertainty was also common. Edward Holtzmann, a lawyer in New York, bought one bond out of "curiosity." He said that just as he was completing the transaction, he heard that there might be a sales charge. He said he usually buys his Treasury bonds at the Fed just to avoid such fees at banks.
In fact, the Federal Reserve does not charge a fee.
"I don't think many people understand how it works," Ms. Heinemann said of this new security.

HEADLINE: Next Front: Animals That Aren't So Cute

BYLINE: By DAVID COLMAN 

 BODY:
BIG brown eyes, furry coats, playful quirks. Most animals hunted and ranched for their fur have another thing going for them: they're cute. Judging by the species of animals that have won sympathy points with the public and those that have not -- lizards, alligators, cows and pigs -- Darwin's treatise might need an update, like survival of the furriest.
"In general," said Simon Doonan, the creative director of Barneys New York, "people tend to get outraged about the animals that are warm and fuzzy rather than about those which are less so, like snakes." 
 The fur debate reared its head afresh this winter with the release of Disney's "101 Dalmatians," with its plot to turn cute little puppies into outerwear, along with reports that fur sales were showing signs of life after a decade-long decline. But the issue has overshadowed the fact that a vogue for animal skins -- high-quality leather, shearling and exotic animal skins -- has blossomed.
Since 1988, when Patrick Cox began using python for his stylish shoes, others have followed suit, some with python-print leather but many with the real thing. And now, even python jackets and pants are being sold at Mr. Cox's Madison Avenue boutique.
Last month, at Alexander McQueen's first couture show for Givenchy, he showed full-length coats rendered in snakeskin. Prada, Richard Tyler and Marc Jacobs have begun to make shoes, handbags, belts and jackets in various reptile skins as well. And Gucci, Chanel, Fendi and Saks Fifth Avenue have all been fined over the last decade for illegal trade in crocodile hides.
Animal-rights advocates, having invested heavily in antifur awareness, are now in a tangled web about how to confront an issue with considerably less sex appeal.
"The exotic wildlife trade issue is a bomb ready to go off," said Priscilla Feral, the president of the Friends of Animals, an international group. "There's a tremendous number of animals smuggled into the United States and killed to satisfy that trade. The fur issue is really only the tip of the iceberg."
Dan Mathews, the director of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, or PETA, a group known for its theatrical protests, also calls exotic skins a priority.
While the fur industry suffered a recession in part caused by the swaying of public opinion over ethical concerns -- an antifur feeling that some think has abated -- the reptile leather industry has only boomed.
The alligator-hide business more than quadrupled between 1987 and 1995, according the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, yielding more than 200,000 hides in 1995, an impressive number for an animal that was on the endangered species list less than 20 years ago.
Some 150,000 whole skins of reticulated pythons alone, which are caught in the wild in Asia, have been brought legally into the United States for each of the last 10 years, said Craig Hoover at Traffic, the trade monitoring arm of the World Wildlife Foundation.
From a conservation standpoint, trade in reptile skins is a much more serious problem than fur ranching, Mr. Hoover said. Since reptiles are difficult to monitor, conservationists are concerned about the potential for endangerment.
"From the humane standpoint, you can compare the two," Mr. Hoover said, "but I don't think you're going to see anyone throwing red paint on a pair of python shoes."
Mr. Mathews said that raising awareness of reptile farming and hunting for skins was becoming increasingly important to the organization. He said that Twiggy Lawson, the actress, former model and a PETA member, recently wrote to designers asking them to stop using exotic skins, describing how some snakes are skinned alive.
"It is going to be more difficult," Mr. Mathews said. "Alligators may not be the most cuddly animals, but when people find out how they're farmed and horribly mutilated, they'll find it offensive."
But the reptile agenda remains secondary to fur, Mr. Mathews said. The same goes for leather. He says he does not wear it and members are encouraged not to, but the group, he said, is more involved in promoting vegetarianism. "As long as there are meat eaters, there will be leather," he said. "And it only goes to reason that when people stop eating the insides, they'll stop wearing the outsides."
For retailers, the long list of potential offenses and the high demand for luxury products has meant that the only rule is no rule.
"We don't sell minks and sables because we don't think a big sweeping fur coat is modern," Mr. Doonan of Barneys said. "As a retailer, it's such a nuanced and tempestuous issue that we've really had to approach it from a style standpoint only." Hot items at the store for spring, he said, are python bags from Prada and suede dresses from Marni.
As a result of such attitudes, others would like to see the bigger picture examined further. Ms. Feral said the sharp focus on fur might be counterproductive to raising awareness of other animal issues like meat consumption and leather. "This movement has not made that as burning an issue as fur, and yet animal agriculture ought to be," she said. "If you're talking about sheer numbers of animals consumed, it's in the billions, whereas with fur, it's in the millions. And with pollution, what happens to the water and the land, factory farming is wreaking havoc on the environment.
"Really, the only ethical way to go is for people to forgo meat and animal products entirely. And that should be an issue that people begin to tune in to. Some have, but fur has taken a front seat, perhaps."
The designer Todd Oldham does not use fur or exotic animal skins, but does use leather occasionally for shoes. "It's a tough issue," he said. "There's no cut-and-dry way to look at it. I view it as recycling, because it is a byproduct. I do realize that all of this is justification, but it's very hard to find materials for shoes that work on the human skin as well as leather does."
Another designer, Cynthia Rowley, says she refuses to design or work with fur, but does use leather and shearling (sheep's skin with the wool attached) and would have no problem working with snakeskin. "I hate to say it, but if it's an animal that's soft and cuddly, people are more offended, so that's the whole funny thing about it."
Ms. Rowley says she walks a fine line between being sensitive to and oblivious of animal-rights concerns, which might be how many consumers feel.
"If I'm going to worry about something, there's a lot more important things than whether the whole world eats meat and wears leather," she said. "It's important to have a responsibility, but it's so complex that everyone has to draw the line where they want."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
How to Overpay For a Muni Fund

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
If you had $100 to invest, and could buy a diversified portfolio of municipal bonds worth $93, or one worth $112, which would you choose?
The market, it appears, values them equally. Or at least the market in closed-end New York muni-bond funds. 
 This is significant now because municipal bonds are starting to look awfully attractive as an investment, and closed-end funds can be a good way to invest in them, particularly if the fund in question is reasonably well-run and has low expenses.
But not all funds trade at fair prices. Too often, investors in such funds look only at yield. And that can be misleading.
Consider the Nuveen New York Investment Quality Municipal fund. As a fund, there is nothing wrong with it. Its annual expenses, less than 1 percent of assets, are reasonable. Its bonds are insured, so the chances of its being hurt by a default are practically zero. And you get a tax-free yield of around 6 percent.
Or consider one of its competitors, the Muni Yield N.Y. Insured Fund II, which is run by Merrill Lynch. Its expenses are a bit lower, but otherwise the story is the same.
Closed-end muni-bond funds, for those not acquainted with the breed, are similar to open-end mutual funds, but with two key differences. The first is that the closed-end variety can, in effect, borrow money by issuing preferred stock. As long as short-term muni-bond rates remain lower than long-term rates, that leaves more money for the common shareholders, and therefore higher yields. Both funds have done that.
The other difference is that closed-end funds trade on the New York Stock Exchange, for whatever investors are willing to pay. That may be more -- or less -- than the bonds in the fund are worth.
And that brings us to the important difference between these two funds. One, the Nuveen fund, is trading at 111 percent of what the bonds in the portfolio are worth. The other, the Merrill fund, is trading at 91.8 percent of its value. (A list of such premiums and discounts is on page 18.)
Why? Some of it may reflect Nuveen's excellent job of getting its story out to brokers. But mostly, it is a matter of yield. A look at the portfolio of the Nuveen fund shows it is full of bonds with high coupons that trade well above par value. The high yield comes from bonds that are sure to decline in price, simply because they will eventually be repaid at par value.
The Merrill fund, on the other hand, has more bonds that are trading around par. Its yield is lower, but its bonds are less likely to lose value.
There is nothing wrong with either strategy. Depending on the course of interest rates, one or the other might do a bit better in terms of total return. Buying high-coupon bonds that are sure to see their value drop is a way of maximizing current income, and for some investors it is appropriate. But investors need to understand that some of the yield from the Nuveen fund is really a return of capital. There is no good reason why the Nuveen fund should trade at such a premium to the one from Merrill.
Many investors could not care less about such things. It's more exciting to buy stocks and watch them soar. But with the Dow Jones industrial average in a manic-depressive move that can see it add or lose 100 points in an hour, there is a lot to be said for taking some profits and settling for 6 percent, tax free.
If that course appeals to you, consider closed-end muni funds. But don't pay too much when you buy.
