HEADLINE: DOWNSIZED PROMISE -- A special report.;
Black Workers Bear Big Burden As Jobs in Government Dwindle

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
In a better, fairer world, Wallace Riddle would have been a carpenter. He could build anything, his daughter Donna said.
But he was a black man, and in New York City in the late 1940's that meant he could not get a construction job because of the industry's color bar. So he went to work as a bus driver for the city, which had dropped racial barriers to employment, and that changed the fortunes of the Riddle family forever. 
 "When I was coming up, all I ever heard was, 'Get that good steady city job,' " Ms. Riddle said. She listened. In 1972, she joined the welfare agency as an income maintenance specialist. For 23 years, she proceeded on and up, as her father had before her, through the Civil Service hierarchy, ending as an administrative manager. Increasing prosperity brought a move as well, from Brooklyn, where she was born and reared, to southeast Queens, where thousands of city workers were building an island of middle-class success.
But now the Riddle family's connection with city government, spanning half a century and two generations of upward mobility, has ended. In 1995, Ms. Riddle took a buyout package to leave her job, burned out, she said, by stress in her early 50's. Waves of previous staff reductions had ripped through her department, raising the workload for those who were left.
A way of life grew up in the mostly minority Queens neighborhoods at New York City's easternmost edge. It was built around government work and suffused with government's assumptions of dependability and equality. The new way, life after government, is still unfolding -- in the neighborhoods, in individual lives and in the spaces inside families.
The changes cut both ways, as the children of city workers enter the work force, rethinking the paths taken by their parents. Ms. Riddle's two children, both in their 20's, want nothing to do with Civil Service, and she can't blame them.
"The previous generation was looking for job security," said Emily Marshall, who quit her job as a program director with the Department of Housing Preservation and Development in 1994, in her mid-30's. "Job security was everything."
Ms. Marshall is finishing a master's degree in city and regional planning at the Pratt Institute and working as the deputy director of a nonprofit foundation in Manhattan. "People in my generation are looking for more," she said.
Like garment making and retailing, the city government has absorbed successive groups of immigrants and members of minority groups. Three waves of newcomers in the last 150 years found a place there. In the 1800's, it was the Irish and Germans, and after World War I, Italians and Eastern-European-born Jews. Black and Hispanic workers entered in the 1950's, and especially since the 1960's.
 
Shrinking Ambitions
Government Seeks To Accomplish Less
But in the 1990's, the foundation of that world shifted and weakened, as government shrank its ambitions and its work force. The various levels of government have eliminated more than 93,000 jobs in New York City in the last five years, more than 1 in 7 positions, State Labor Department figures show.
The combined local, state and Federal work force reached what will almost certainly stand as its high-water mark for this century in May 1990, when 621,200 workers had government jobs. Every indicator since then has pointed downward.
For the region, the steady hemorrhage of government jobs has become a major theme of the economy, worsening the recession of the early 90's and dampening the recovery.
For Hispanic workers, and particularly for blacks, the implications of government downsizing are more profound. The city says it does not record the racial composition of the people leaving jobs under the various work force reduction plans that began in early 1994. But the cumulative evidence, including dozens of interviews with current and former city workers, is overwhelming that black workers have been hit the hardest.
One snapshot study of 14,000 departing workers, commissioned by the City Council, said 43 percent were black. Another study of 11,000 former workers found that a majority lived in black neighborhoods. Yet another study found that the racial composition of the work force had changed in just two years, to 36 percent from 38 percent black.
A factor is that while participation in city government by black New Yorkers is large, it is also narrow, and concentrated in agencies like social services and health care that had their most rapid growth in the last 25 to 30 years. It is in precisely those areas where the greatest cost-cutting pressures are being felt by governments, as big changes in welfare and health care sweep away the old patterns and the old jobs.
"The downsizing of state and local governments is going to have a predictable, disproportionate, negative effect on people of color generally and especially the black community," said Bennett Harrison, a professor of political economy at the New School for Social Research. Professor Harrison, who has studied urban government workers since the early 1970's, said minority groups benefited disproportionately from the growth of the public sector and are now simply in the wrong place as history's wheel has turned. "The case is unambiguous," he said.
The New York State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, who as a young black man in the mid-1960's got his start working on antipoverty programs in the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay before going on to a career at Citibank in the 1970's, said his greatest fear was not so much for the people leaving jobs now, but for their children and grandchildren.
"Public sector jobs helped establish a stable middle class for the minority community, but the next generation will not have that opportunity," he said.
Mr. McCall said government downsizing is just half the problem. The other half is that private industry, facing many of the same cost-control pressures as government, is not creating jobs fast enough in New York. "The major issue facing our city and state government," he said, "is the lack of planning for these major changes: the transformation of the work force."
Certainly, government downsizing is not merely a New York phenomenon. Nationally, economists estimate that governments have shed more than 454,000 jobs between 1979 and 1993, a trend that has accelerated since. Cities like Indianapolis and Milwaukee and Phoenix have invented whole new ways of performing city services, using fewer workers or private contractors.
But only in a few places, like Washington, has government assumed the role in local economics and culture that it has in New York. The city's pure size gives its lessened employment a resonance. If the city government were ranked alongside the Fortune 500, it would be the 14th largest financial entity in the nation, with annual revenues of $39.5 billion in 1996. That makes it smaller than the Chrysler Corporation, but bigger than State Farm Insurance, 15th, or the state government of Texas, 16th.
 
A Different Path
New York Tries To Avoid Layoffs
New York is also proceeding along a different path from other cost-cutting cities around the country, urban economists say, with more emphasis on job reduction in particular. As the city has downsized, it has also introduced new ways of defining how jobs are counted and paid for.
Last year, the city was able to eliminate, on paper, 1,800 positions from the Police Department through a shift of those workers from a city payroll account to one paid for by Federal anticrime money. Privatization of city jobs, through granting contracts to private companies for services, has also made inroads in certain parts of the government.
Of the roughly 3,000 jobs that have been eliminated in this way, according to the State Comptroller, more than half are in social services, primarily services for the homeless. In this area, workers and clients are disproportionately members of minority groups. But because New York sought to avoid layoffs, relying instead on voluntary buyouts and early retirements, the effect of the downsizing has also been subtle and often invisible. The story is not one of neighborhoods laid waste, but of large and small accommodations that suggest the end of a chapter for minority groups.
The contrast with the mid-1970's, when New York laid off thousands of workers as it struggled to avoid bankruptcy, is particularly stark. Then, the job cuts were demanded by creditors. Laid-off government workers tended to be those with the least seniority, a group that included many recently hired minority group members. But the 1970's were just an interruption. Hiring resumed as good times returned, and employment totals ultimately surpassed the old peak.
The downsizing of the 1990's, by rewarding voluntary departure, weeds out senior workers and managers and has thus hit minority employees who in many cases only broke into management levels in the 1980's. Equally important is that 1990's downsizing represents a change in policy and philosophy about what government is supposed to do, and not a short-term change in the city's fortunes, which have been in an upswing. Since 1993, the private sector has created thousands of new jobs. In the 1970's, recession was everywhere.
The momentum of minority hiring by the city began in the 1940's, even as doors in much of private industry remained closed. By the late 1960's, it was an economic engine in its own right, as Mayor Lindsay began big recruiting efforts to increase the minority work force. Hiring surged again in the 1980's, when the numbers of white applicants declined as the city's private economy boomed.
And it had its own place: southeastern Queens.
Dennis M. Walcott, the president of the New York Urban League and the son of two New York City public-school teachers, vividly remembers growing up in the sea of black city workers who had made their way up from Harlem and Brooklyn to Queens neighborhoods like Cambria Heights, Ozone Park and St. Albans.
The Riddles were just one of the networks of family and tradition that formed as the public sector economy evolved. Michael Leo Owens, a 27-year-old researcher at the Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University at Albany, said government connections were everywhere in the Queens he had known growing up. Mr. Owens's grandfather, who worked for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, first took the family to South Ozone Park in the early 1960's.
"I had an aunt who was an administrator in child welfare, aunts and uncles and cousins who were bus drivers, three female cousins who work for the Police Department," said Mr. Owens, who recently went back to study the culture and economy of government workers in southeastern Queens. "My sister works for the Federal Bureau of Prisons and her husband is a professor at Queens College. It's amazing once you start to think about it."
Some city workers and residents see the changes in those patterns as reasons for hope. As education levels and opportunities have expanded, many young people like Mr. Owens with deep city government roots reject the idea of government work because they have options that their parents and grandparents could not even contemplate.
Others, like Ms. Riddle, think that the black connection to government work stifled the spirit of private enterprise that flourishes in other minority groups. She has started a home-based business, selling health food and natural medicines, and wants to train others to make the same leap.
Minority workers with government experience might also get some of the private sector jobs that are expected to grow in number as the city contracts out services that it now performs. And not every part of government is shrinking. Some agencies with large minority work forces, like the Police and Correction Departments, are still hiring, or are at least holding steady.
But there are also bleaker signs. The shrinking of jobs is accompanied by a national overhaul of the welfare system that is pushing the city to put tens of thousands of welfare recipients to work to earn their payments. In a previous era, those positions might have been traditional jobs with benefits and pensions. And both the public and private sectors in New York are demanding increasingly high levels of education and technical skills to fill new jobs. That leaves out many former and prospective city workers.
Willie Wren, the president of the Miracle Makers, a nonprofit social service group in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, said he frequently gets calls from people who took buyout payments of $10,000 or more to leave a city job, only to find themselves in trouble a few months later, with no new job and the money running out. "We have advised them, 'Why don't you go back and say, "I'd like to give the money back," then whatever they offer you, take it,' and some have done that," Mr. Wren said. "But I believe it's going to get progressively worse. I get frightened by it."
There is also a political element to downsizing that could resonate this year in New York's mayoral election. G. Nesbit Benjamin, a retired Transit Authority police officer from St. Albans whose two brothers and father were all city government workers, said that to his generation, Civil Service was more than just employment.
It represented hope, and that hope, he said, is being shredded by the policies of downsizing that accelerated with the election of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who took office in 1993 after defeating New York's first black mayor, David N. Dinkins. Even though the job cuts began under Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Giuliani has become the symbol of the changes and their impact.
Mr. Benjamin, repeating a frequent comment among blacks, said he believes that the downsizing trend represents, in part, a backlash by white society that began with the highly publicized reports after the 1990 Census about economic gains by black families in Queens. Median household income by black families surpassed that of whites in the borough for the first time.
"People said, 'Hey, how come they're doing so good?' " he said.

A Sense of Promise
When Government Wasn't Just a Job
 In 1967, when Valerie A. Walker began her conquest of municipal government as a clerk in the New York City Department of Finance, working for government was more than just a means to a paycheck. In a way that now seems quaint, government then had an aura, a promise, a sense of dynamic opportunity. It was flush with assertive attitudes about civil rights and fueled by a booming 1960's economy and an agenda to end poverty within a generation.
Mayor Lindsay, elected in 1965, had set as one priority an expansion of municipal employment among minority groups. Recruiting teams were dispatched to high schools. A cadet program was established in the Transit Authority police, aimed at putting minority-group teen-agers on a track toward becoming officers.
It worked. In 1963, the work force at the agencies under the mayor's budget was 13.6 percent black; by 1990, the work force was 36.7 percent black, according to a new book about the city's work force, "Still the Promised Land?" by Prof. Roger Waldinger, a sociologist at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Professor Waldinger said that in some agencies, the transformation was even more striking. The Transportation Department went from 4.5 percent black in 1963 to 42.3 percent black by 1990, and blacks attained majority status in the Housing Authority and the Health, Corrections and Social Services Departments.
For the first time, blacks in New York had found and exploited an economic niche all their own. But the downsizing of government, and the changed attitude by many young people about the desirability of city jobs, suggests just as strongly that that window has closed.
Of the 14,058 city employees who left under the first four severance programs through early 1995, 63 percent were women, and 43 percent were black, according to the city's Equal Employment Practices Commission.
Severance records from the Office of Payroll Administration show that of 11,362 people who left city agencies in the last two years, a majority lived in neighborhoods classified by the Census Bureau as having majority black populations. Altogether, of the nine city neighborhoods that had the most job cuts, eight had majority black populations.
A recent study by the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, a Manhattan research group, similarly concluded that while Hispanic workers held onto their piece of a shrinking municipal pie, with 13 percent of city jobs, blacks, and especially black women, disappeared by the thousands.
In just 24 months, the institute said, the percentage of black workers fell to 36 percent from 38 percent of the city government work force.
"People don't want to talk about the racial dimension of these issues," said the institute's president, Angelo Falcon.
"But there is an extreme segregation within the government work force," Mr. Falcon said, "with some job titles 60 percent African-American and others 90 percent white. And when you have the kind of cutbacks of this administration that focus on the social services sector, then you have this racial disparity."
Jobs were also changed along the way. Christine Hughes ended a 30-year career at the New York City Human Resources Administration last year as a job cutter. Her final task was to downsize her own department from 200 people to 70. Then she was gone too.
Her former husband, Martin Hughes Sr., took early retirement from his job as a security officer at the Human Resources Administration at about the same time as his department was being turned over to a private security service.
"I said the heck with it," Mr. Hughes said. "That way I didn't have the aggravation of somebody constantly saying, 'We're going to get rid of you all.' "
Many residents say that as one door shuts, another door, to private enterprise, may be opening. Valerie Walker, who took a buyout at 50, five years before she can get her pension, specifically discouraged her three children from working for the city, telling them over and over that "they could do better." One child works for a hotel in Manhattan and another for an ambulance company. The third did choose government, working for the Federal Aviation Administration.
Ms. Riddle, whose life after government has been partly consumed by her grandchildren -- three of whom, at ages 3, 4 and 5, live with her in St. Albans -- said she hopes to use much of the rest of her life encouraging young black people to go into business and not government.
She has joined a one-year-old network of black businesses, which include home-based companies like hers as well as more conventional businesses like house painting and construction, aimed at helping one another through referrals and sales.
"Downsizing might be one of the best things that happens," she said. "It's forcing us to take another look and not leave our financial happiness to other individuals."

Roots and Rewards
Upward Mobility, Centered in Queens
Government work did not create from scratch the solid middle class communities of single family homes just north of Kennedy International Airport and west of Nassau County. Its roots and its reputation as New York's premier black middle class enclave go back further than that, to the 1940's, when Count Basie and Lena Horne and Jackie Robinson made their homes in St. Albans.
But government work gave the neighborhoods their muscle and their sense of assertive identity. In the New York region as a whole, about 18 percent of the population works for a governmental entity. In southeastern Queens, according to Mr. Owens's study at the Rockefeller Institute using 1990 Census numbers, 29 percent of all jobs were with government, while 10 census tracts had rates of over 40 percent. During the 1980's, 26 percent of all the new jobs in southeastern Queens came from government.
A high level of home ownership -- 63 percent, as against about 30 percent in the metropolitan area as a whole -- combined with relatively high household income place these neighborhoods among the upper tier of black communities in the country.
In a society in which blacks still have far higher poverty rates than whites, and where huge barriers still exist between many black neighborhoods and the style and culture of America's middle class, southeastern Queens became a kind of promised land that beckoned to those who could reach it.
It had its pantheon of founders like Mr. Basie and Miss Horne and Ella Fitzgerald and John Coltrane and Fats Waller and Roy Campanella, whose images are emblazoned on a huge mural under the Long Island Rail Road tracks in St. Albans.
In these neighborhoods, people felt in control of their lives. In the early 1990's, the residents of Addisleigh Park, perhaps the most affluent section of St. Albans, persuaded the city through hearings and petitions to reroute traffic on their streets to stop trucks from rumbling past their stately homes.
The quiet pride was evident at a meeting of former city workers organized for a reporter at the home of Thomas and Jean Leach, both retired school administrators, in Addisleigh Park. As the winter sun streamed through the dining room windows, residents spoke with pride about sending their children off to college, and the careers they had made, the challenges overcome. When it was over, all joined hands in a prayer of thanks.
Most St. Albans residents seem not to feel any need for gates or bars on their windows, a measure of any New York neighborhood's fear of crime, and the specter of idle and intimidating teen-agers hanging out on street corners seems almost entirely absent. On thoroughfares like Linden Boulevard, one of the main shopping strips of St. Albans, people walk with purpose and bustle.
Still, there is a sense of fragility in many homes and neighborhoods of southeastern Queens now as the underpinning of the economy changes.
Amy Berry, an owner of Berry's Florist in St. Albans, has cut her payroll from nine employees in the early 1990's to four today because her customers have simply stopped spending on luxuries like flowers.
"Our heyday was 10 to 12 years ago," Ms. Berry said. "Those were the good years."
Other signs of the change flicker like lightning.
The annual job fair in Rochdale Village, which for years drew recruiters from city agencies, was shrunken and diminished last year, while a new one at St. Catherine of Siena Catholic Church in St. Albans recently was vibrant with private employers.
State Senator Aldon R. Waldon Jr. said a neighbor in Cambria Heights approached him asking for a letter of recommendation. The man was being forced out of a high-level city job, Mr. Waldon said, and was trying to make a transition. Mr. Waldon, who represents much of southeastern Queens, said that with a private economy growing and creating jobs, his neighbor landed a new position and still goes off to work every morning. Mr. Waldon fears that the worst is yet to come.
"There is an eddying effect from the downsizing, but it has not burst through the dam yet," he said.
At Richard's Place, a restaurant in St. Albans where talk is served up as generously as the Southern cuisine, an owner, Rhonda Jones, said health-care workers are the ones she hears from most.
One woman, a nurse in a city-owned hospital, comes in just to talk, Mrs. Jones said. The woman has been too upset to eat much.
"She said her stomach is so upset because every day, coming to work, the changes in her department, people being laid off and you don't know from week to week whether you're going to have a job," Mrs. Jones said.
Real estate professionals say home prices have remained stable, but patterns have changed. With a widespread housing shortage in New York, many adult children are still living at home.
Other young people are banding together in groups of friends and relatives to buy homes, setting up unconventional households to make the costs more affordable. Some residents say they fear the ebbing of government employment in the 1990's will weaken the traditions of local civic involvement in these tidy neighborhoods with their well-cared-for homes and lawns.
The number of foreclosures has risen as well, real estate brokers say, as overextended buyers who bought in the market peaks of the 1980's are finding themselves in trouble.
Bill Jones, who has sold real estate in southeastern Queens since the late 1970's, says he thinks that the market is still working off the excesses of the 1980's. The correction is based more on overpriced housing values than downsizing, which he thinks has yet to make its impact felt.
But either way, he added, "The chickens have come home to roost now."

HEADLINE: No Background Checks Done On Guests at Clinton Coffees

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The White House acknowledged today that it had never reviewed the backgrounds of any of the hundreds of visitors who saw President Clinton in scores of intimate White House meetings arranged by the Democratic National Committee.
Background checks are routinely done on other guests to the White House, an Administration official said, but the guests on the lists proposed by the Democratic committee were simply put on President Clinton's schedule. 
 The committee never performed any review of the people coming to see Mr. Clinton, said a committee spokeswoman, Amy Weiss Tobe. She said the committee merely supplied the Social Security numbers and birth dates of the White House guests so guards could match a guest to a name on the list.
The acknowledgment by the White House that the background checks had not been done came today after The Washington Post reported that a felon with possible ties to the Bonanno organized crime family had attended a Democratic coffee at the White House in December 1995, a few months after his second conviction. The felon joins a list of other questionable figures who were guests of the President at the White House in meetings arranged by the Democratic Party, often as part of an effort to reward or encourage contributors.
"No vetting was ever done for these events, other than asking for Social Security numbers or dates of birth in order to verify the identity of the guest," said Lanny J. Davis, a White House special counsel.
Ordinarily, officials said today, the Secret Service uses Government computer data bases to check the backgrounds of people who come in contact with the President to see if any visitors pose a security risk. Secret Service officials have been reluctant to describe the security measures at the White House.
But for reasons that are not clear, the Secret Service did not perform such checks on the lists that the Democratic National Committee provided to the White House for guests going to political functions, like the coffees.
"We never did any vetting either," Ms. Tobe said.
The details of the lax security procedures emerged in response to questions about The Washington Post article, which disclosed that a New Jersey man who was convicted of penny-stock fraud had met President Clinton at a White House coffee a few months after his second conviction. Law-enforcement officials and news accounts about the man, Eric Wynn, have said he had ties to figures in organized crime.
"Based on the facts and circumstances as we understand them," Mr. Davis said, "Mr. Wynn was not an appropriate person to be included in this White House event."
The White House has provided some details about 103 coffees there; most were small gatherings attended by President Clinton. Among those who have already been identified as attending the coffees are Wang Jun, the head of a Chinese conglomerate that includes a major arms manufacturer, and Roger Tamraz of Lebanon who has been sought under an arrest warrant issued eight years ago by Interpol.
The coffees began in 1995 under a program set up by Harold M. Ickes, the White House deputy chief of staff who was helping to oversee President Clinton's re-election campaign, an Administration official said.
Officials at the Democratic committee and the Clinton Administration said today that senior committee officials would compile the list of guests for a White House coffee from the names of prominent donors and party supporters and then provide it to the White House political affairs office, headed by Douglas Sosnick. Mr. Sosnick or his aides would then send the proposed guest list to other White House officials who set Mr. Clinton's schedule. Nowhere along the process would the guests' backgrounds be reviewed.
Ms. Tobe said Mr. Wynn had been put on a guest list for the Dec. 21, 1995, coffee at the suggestion of Richard T. Mays, an Arkansas lawyer appointed to the Arkansas Supreme Court by Mr. Clinton when he was Governor in the 1980's. Law-enforcement officials say Mr. Mays had sought to represent Mr. Wynn in one of his criminal trials, but it is unclear how much work he actually performed for Mr. Wynn.
Others at the small gathering, in the White House Map Room, included Erskine B. Bowles, now the White House chief of staff; the two chairmen of the Democratic National Committee, Donald L. Fowler and Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut; Thomas F. McLarty 3d, counselor to the President; Dana G. Mead, chairman and chief executive of Tenneco Inc.; Robert N. Elkins, chairman and chief executive of Integrated Health Services of Owings Mills, Md., and two top Democratic committee fund-raising officials, the finance chairman, Marvin S. Rosen, and the finance director, Richard Sullivan.
Ms. Tobe said one of the party officials at the event said the coffee had involved "a discussion about the economic outlook for the country and how the economy was doing."
"One of the attendees doesn't remember Wynn saying anything," Ms. Tobe said. "He remembers him sitting pretty quietly."
A few months earlier, on July 21, 1995, Mr. Wynn was convicted by a Federal jury in New Jersey on 13 counts of conspiracy, security fraud and wire fraud for a 1988 scheme to manipulate penny-stocks. Dick Lavinthal, a spokesman for the United States Attorney's office in New Jersey, said today that evidence in the trial showed that Mr. Wynn's scheme had been done in part for the benefit of the family of Frank Coppa, who has been identified in news articles and court documents as a Bonanno crime family captain.
Mr. Lavinthal said that court evidence showed that Mr. Wynn had manipulated the stock to the benefit of Richard Tienken, an entertainment manager who has also been described as having ties to organized crime.
Last October, the Democratic National Committee returned $75,000 in contributions from Mr. Tienken and a company he is associated with. The committee acted after learning that at a 1991 racketeering trial, an informer from the Mafia said Mr. Tienken had engaged in business dealings with a captain in the Luchese crime family.
In September, Mr. Wynn, who is 37, was sentenced to 52 months in prison and fined $50,000. He remains free, pending his appeal.
While the Democratic committee has no access to Justice Department and other confidential Government records, details about Mr. Wynn's background are publicly available.
A check of Mr. Wynn's name in the Nexis data base, for instance, would have unearthed a 1989 article in Forbes that said, "Federal documents say Bonanno family capo Frank Coppa, his associate Eric Wynn and other friends paid a visit" to a stock promoter under indictment named Perry Constantinou and "bashed him on the side of the head with a telephone."
The Forbes article described how Mr. Wynn and Mr. Coppa might have laundered money to evade taxes and also reported that Mr. Wynn was serving a three-year prison term at the time for fraud and for filing a false tax return.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
This Takes the Cake: Lyle to Manage

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Lou Piniella saw it in his morning newspaper and said, "They can have a cheeseburger before they pitch."
Fran Healy was told the news and said, "Just don't have any cakes in the clubhouse." Then, he added, "There will be no curfew and the pitchers won't have to run." 
 Willie Randolph greeted the news with a smile. "I'll tell you one thing," he said, "the players will have a lot of fun playing for Sparky." Then Randolph laughed.
Sparky Lyle laughed, too. "You probably didn't believe it," said the former reliever. "Yeah, I'm the same guy, just more mature. But not that much more. Don't get carried away."
Some players, from the day they first put on a uniform, have the word "manager" written across their chests. Some develop the interest and the aptitude as their careers near an end.
Others were just not meant to be managers. Sparky Lyle was one of those. But at age 52, 15 years after he last wore a major league uniform, he is prepared to prove that perception is a misperception.
Lyle has become the manager of the Somerset Patriots. The New Jersey team does not exist, but then, neither do the Arizona Diamondbacks, and Buck Showalter has been paid about $1 million to be their manager for the past year.
The Patriots will be a member of the Atlantic League, an independent minor league that its developers hope to unveil in 1998. The former major leaguers Bud Harrelson and Rick Cerone are involved in the league. And now, so is Lyle.
"Sparky's going to manage? Good for him," said Randolph, a second baseman behind Lyle during the pitcher's Yankee years in the 1970's. "I didn't know he had any aspirations. Sparky has changed a little bit, but from my experiences as a player, he's the last guy who I thought would want to manage."
Piniella, the Seattle Mariners' manager, gave Lyle the benefit of the doubt, based on his own experiences. "Could anyone ever imagine me being a manager?" Piniella said. "Probably not, right?"
Fred Stanley, now the player development director for the Milwaukee Brewers, said: "I would envision him as a pitching coach more than a manager, but he'll probably do a pretty good job. A lot of managing is getting guys to play hard, and I imagine they'll play hard for him."
Healy, a Mets announcer and a former catcher, said: "I think it's terrific. He never blamed anyone for anything, even when he pitched. If he won, it was good. If he lost, too bad, come back and get 'em tomorrow. I think he'll be great."
Dick Tidrow, the San Francisco Giants' new player-personnel director, was not surprised. "I thought he'd get back in baseball one of these days; it's his first love," said Tidrow, a former pitcher. "I think that's a great selection. Whoever made that selection should be commended."
Any credit goes to Steven Kalafer, a Flemington, N.J., automobile dealer and the owner of the Patriots. And give an assist to John Vukovich, a coach with the Philadelphia Phillies.
"I've known Steve," Lyle said. "My lease was up on my car, and I went to see him about a new car. Steve is good friends with John Vukovich. A couple of years ago I had put my name in through Vukovich for the bullpen coach's job in Philadelphia. They said no, they wanted to stay in their organization. That's about as far as it went.
"I guess when Steve was talking to Vukovich, he said I have this ball club, I need a manager. John said: 'You know Sparky. What about Sparky?' I go to pick up my truck, and Steve said, 'I want to talk to you when you get all your paperwork done.' "
Lyle said his time since his playing days has been spent "beating around, doing all these personal appearances."
"It'll be a different thing having a real job," he added.
Lyle acknowledged that he had not given managing any serious thought. "It was too far out of the realm," he said. "I was not going to go hop around Double A and Triple A, gaining experience, so to speak, to get a job in the big leagues. I felt that was pretty well closed to me."
One of Lyle's immediate worries is about flashing his players signals. "I'm concerned about giving signs because I use my left hand so much," he said. "I told Bud Harrelson: 'I know you guys are going to steal signs. I can't use my right hand.' "
Does that mean Lyle plans to coach third base? "I'm sure I will," he said.
"Oh, my!" Tidrow said at the thought of Lyle standing in the coach's box. "This is going to be exciting. That would be fun to watch in itself."
It would be fun, too, watching Lyle attempt to become a disciplinarian, but that is not likely to happen. "Jim Fregosi asked me who's going to check curfew," Lyle said, referring to the unemployed major league manager. "He said, 'You're gonna be out.' "
His pals don't expect the job to change Lyle's behavior and outlook.
"He's going to be Sparky," Randolph said. "He's not going to deviate from enjoying life."
Does this mean the Patriots will have a nightly or weekly promotion for fans to bring cakes to games, to see which one Lyle sits on? That was one of Lyle's favorite out-of-uniform clubhouse pastimes when he played for the Yankees.
"They brought that up the other day," Lyle said. "Of all the things I accomplished, I'll never live that down. I just told everyone I'm in therapy. I'm not allowed to have birthday cakes."
 
 
 
Randolph Wants a Chance
 Speaking of managing, Willie Randolph hopes to do that soon, not in the Atlantic League, but in the majors.
"It's time for me to step out and let people know in what direction I want to go," said the Yankees' third-base coach. "I do want to manage. I've had three seasons as a coach. I think I've proven myself. I don't want to coach third base the rest of my life. I'm looking to challenge myself and move up."
Randolph, who has no managerial experience, said he would not necessarily refuse an opportunity to manage in the minor leagues.
"I'd have to look at the situation and see if it's right for my family," he said. "Sometimes they throw that on you as a way of holding you back."
He then cited Lou Piniella, Don Baylor, Ray Knight and Larry Dierker, current major league skippers who never managed in the minors. "I wouldn't say flat-out no," Randolph said, "but if I felt I was ready to move in, I would do that."
Randolph, 42, said he has "played for some of the best managers in the last 20 years."
"I've always taken notes and learned, playing games in my own mind."
 
 
 
One for the Home Team
 Jack Morris began the parade in 1991. Dave Winfield followed two years later. Paul Molitor got in line last year. Now, Terry Steinbach has become the latest player to go home to Minnesota.
"It's sure not the weather, I'll tell you that," said Tom Kelly, the Twins' manager. "I don't know what it is. The chance to play in front of family and friends, for the team they grew up watching, for stability."
Steinbach, who could have earned more money had he remained in Oakland, grew up in one Minnesota town, has lived in another and is building a house in another. Morris, Winfield and Molitor were born and raised in St. Paul. Winfield, Molitor and Steinbach went to the University of Minnesota.
"We could put together an all-star team," Kelly said. "It's great that we've had people wanting to come back here and play for the hometown team. Kent Hrbek led the way with that by wanting to play in his hometown. But I think we're running out of people."

HEADLINE: Caseworkers Aren't Sabotaging Welfare Reform

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Bradley R. Schiller argues that welfare reform efforts are being undermined by discretionary exemptions from work requirements (Op-Ed, Jan. 28). The reason, he asserts, is that "the army of social workers who carry out welfare at the local level is by and large liberal." 
 During my time as a caseworker in Boston, any client who exhibited even modest competence was sent off to job training and so-called opportunities. Most clients were unemployable: illiterate, pathological or overwhelmed by the stress of caring for extended families. Exemption decisions reflected caseworkers' practical judgment, not politics.
Mr. Schiller perpetuates the myths that most people on welfare are living a life of ease at taxpayer expense. Let him study the decisions of caseworkers where they are made and he'll see the reality: the chaotic lives of the desperately poor.
 
TERESA J. PARKER
Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 29, 1997

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: QUEENS UP CLOSE -- BOROUGH REPORT;
The State of Queens

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
In her annual State of the Borough address delivered last week at the Queens Theater in the Park, Borough President Claire Shulman said unemployment in the county was down, infrastructure and library projects were under way and thousands of new seats had been created to ease overcrowding in the public schools -- although that remains one of Queens's most troubling problems.
"Our borough's schools remain among the most overcrowded in the city," she told an audience of about 500, including a half-dozen Giuliani appointees, among them Police Commissioner Howard Safir. "Thirty thousand seats are needed, and we have no capacity." 

 
POINT BY POINT -- Here is a look at other items from the report, which reviewed changes in the borough in 1996:
JOBS -- The unemployment rate in Queens was 7.4 percent in 1996, well below the citywide rate of 8.3 percent. Mrs. Shulman said 1,200 jobs had been created with the opening of Caldor's in Glen Oaks, Toys "R" Us in Jamaica and Sears and Marshall's in Rego Plaza Park.
CRIME -- The murder rate in Queens dropped 33 percent to 1996 from 1995 and motor vehicle theft, a perennial problem in the borough, fell by 15 percent over the same period and was down nearly 50 percent from 1993. Arson fires have decreased by nearly 25 percent.
SCHOOLS -- Among the new schools completed in 1996 are Public School 43 in Far Rockaway, with a 1,200-student capacity; Intermediate School 5 in Elmhurst, also with 1,200 students, and the Occupational Training Center, a 500-student vocational school in Elmhurst.
LIBRARIES -- Construction of the new $30 million Flushing Library is under way, and new libraries are planned for South Jamaica and Cambria Heights.
HOUSING -- Fifty-two of the 100 units planned for the Allen-Hall Estates project in South Jamaica were finished in 1996, and 25 of the 200 units planned for a development in Hallets Cove, near Long Island City, were completed. CHARLIE LeDUFF

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercedes-Benz SLK230;
Retro and Retractable

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
AUTOMOTIVELY speaking, I was born a generation too late.
Having grown up yearning to be behind the wheel of an MG or a Triumph, I instead found myself wallowing around in a decade-old 1961 Chevrolet Bel Air, my first car. But finally, and especially in the last year, I have been able to live out the dreams of my youth in several new vehicles with strong ties to great sporting cars of the past: the Jaguar XK8, which echoes the sensuous E-Type Jaguars of the 1960's; the BMW Z3, which recalls the 507 roadster of the 50's with its gill-like side vents, and even the Pontiac Grand Prix GTP, which is reminiscent of the wide-track Pontiacs that cruised American boulevards in the 60's. 
 Most recently I have been in the driver's seat of the Mercedes-Benz SLK230, which just went on sale in the United States. My automotive fantasies came true once again.
The SLK's introduction opens a second chapter of what promises to be a modern automotive love story. The stars are sexy European roadsters like the Z3, a phenomenal success since it made its premiere last spring (and now available with a more potent six-cylinder engine that answers criticisms that the car was underpowered). The trend continues with the Porsche Boxster, which is reaching showrooms now.
Mercedes executives in North America already believe they have produced a superstar with the SLK, and I'm convinced they are right. The company originally intended to send to the United States 5,000 of the 35,000 cars produced in Germany in 1997, then increased the number to 6,000. Every one is expected to disappear as soon as it reaches the showroom, and many dealers have long waiting lists.
Mercedes is positioning the SLK as an innovative roadster that represents, despite its $40,000 price tag, a good value. Its styling and design touches are intended to be reminiscent of SL roadsters of the 1950's.
The styling is alluring indeed. The car got raves in my suburban neighborhood, and women in particular seemed smitten by the calypso-green test car.
Nearly a foot and a half shorter than Mercedes' high-dollar SL roadsters, which begin at $80,000, the SLK is more youthful and more sporty, though it is not a sports car like its rival from Porsche. The car's proportions and styling cues, particularly the bulges in the hood, hark to the past. But the SLK comes in MTV Generation colors like Bahama blue. One interior hue -- a vibrant red -- is called "salsa."
The SLK's most distinctive feature is an automatic retractable hardtop -- which is also a retro touch, since it recalls the Ford Skyliner retractables of the late 1950's. With the top up, the SLK feels like a coupe. But wait 25 seconds. With the push of a red button on the console, the metal top folds like an accordion into the trunk, magically creating a convertible. Unfortunately, as often seems the case when I have possession of a convertible, the top was raised and lowered little during my week-long test drive in the snow. But no matter what position the top was in, the SLK was extremely quiet.
As attractive as the SLK's exterior is, the interior is my favorite part of the car. The designers skillfully blended retro cues with thoroughly modern touches. The round gauges, trimmed with chrome, have black numbers on white backgrounds, and the red needles glow a warm orange at night. The face of the center console is not the ubiquitous polished wood, but a modern woven material that resembles the carbon fiber used in the aerospace industry.
I felt more comfortable in the SLK than I have ever been in a Mercedes. Typically, my short stature requires that my seat be so close to the steering wheel that my knees rub against the bolsters under the dash. That was not the case in the SLK. With the multiple seat adjustments and a telescopic steering wheel, I was able to find an ideal driving position. And tall drivers said they had ample headroom and legroom.
Despite the car's diminutive size -- it is just two inches longer than a Mazda Miata and a bit shorter than the Z3 -- the interior does not feel claustrophobic. But with two occupants, there is no room in the cabin for even a briefcase. The trunk is roomy for a roadster when the top is up; when it is down, the cargo bay is reduced to 5 cubic feet.
The SLK is much more than an interesting design exercise. It is every bit as much fun to drive as its appearance suggests.
The rear-drive SLK, which stands for sportlich, leicht and kompakt (sporty, light and small), is powered by a four-cylinder, dual-overhead-cam engine with a displacement of 2.3 cubic liters. With the boost of a supercharger (which accounts for the Kompressor badge on the front fenders), the engine is rated at 185 horsepower. The acceleration is quite respectable, and the fuel economy (21 miles a gallon in town, 27 on the highway) is reasonable.
A five-speed electronically controlled automatic, which adapts its shifting patterns to the style of the driver, is the only transmission available. A five-speed manual may be added later.
While the ride is comfortable for cruising around town or speeding along highways, the SLK is fun to fling around on curvy country roads. (Indeed, the car registered the second-fastest speed ever in a slalom test by Road & Track magazine, trailing only the Ferrari F355. The slalom, in which cars are driven through eight cones set 100 feet apart, indicates how well a car can be controlled in quick maneuvers.)
Unlike virtually all convertibles, the solidly built SLK has not a hint of body shake even on rough gravel roads.
The SLK is packed with standard equipment, and safety is a priority. The SLK has side air bags in addition to dual front air bags and integrated rollover bars. A child-seat-recognition system disables the passenger air bag when it detects the presence of a new type of child safety seat -- an industry first intended to prevent children from being injured by the rapid inflation of a bag in an accident. Other SLK features include seat belts with retractors that tighten in microseconds in emergencies, strong anti-lock brakes, automatic traction control, heated windshield washers, retractable heated headlamp washers and an antitheft alarm system with an engine immobilizer.
If you consider that the Mercedes SL320 roadster costs twice as much, the SLK's price seems fair. Only three options are available: metallic paint at $595; heated seats at $600, and a package that includes a compact disk changer and cellular phone at $1,495. A Sport package, similar to one introduced last year for the SL-Class, will eventually be available.
The SLK is part of a new Mercedes corporate strategy to deliver not only engineering excellence and safety innovations, but to generate more emotional appeal than its cars have stirred in the past. Indeed, the SLK stirs passions, whether one is behind the wheel or just looking over its clean lines.
The company expects loyal Mercedes owners to add the SLK to their household fleets. But it also hopes to attract first-time buyers in their 30's, and a lot of women.
I only wish I were one of them.
 
INSIDE TRACK: One more time, with feeling.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

SOCIAL SECURITY
Fix the C.P.I.? After You
Politicians are noisy sorts, ever willing to rant and rave on nice safe topics like coddling prisoners. Utter two little words, though, and they'll clam up in an instant: Social Security. You hear more and more these days that the Consumer Price Index -- which dictates the increases in retirees' checks -- badly overstates inflation, costing Uncle Sam and Aunt Samantha hundreds of billions of dollars. But fix the index? Political suicide. What of the Administration? It will consider it, it says, if there's a consensus. After you -- no, no, after you -- and politicians pile up in the doorway. Last week, though, Alan Greenspan said, in effect, get on with it. Fix the index, quickly. He may be the only person around with both the nerve to speak up and the weight to get things moving.
 
STOCK MARKET
Crash? File Under 'History'
Are stock-market crashes ancient history? Today's investors must think so. Why else would they send prices higher and higher, entrusting their futures to this huge poker game? (There is even talk of putting Social Security money into stocks.) The idea of a price collapse is treated as distant, dusty, "can't happen again" history. If you doubt it, consider this: the New York Stock Exchange ticker tape for the first few minutes of trading on Oct. 29, 1929, was just sold for $5,000 to the Museum of American Financial History. On that fateful day, it seems, a Boston broker sensed that something historic was happening -- it was -- and squirreled the tape away. "It can't happen again, it can't happen again," Dorothy says, clicking her heels frantically.
 
INDEXED BONDS
Take That, Inflation!
So here's your choice: You can bet that stocks will keep up their run, or you can turn to something teddy-bear safe like Treasury bonds. Until now, the second choice seemed foolish: not only would you get meager returns, but inflation could knock you for a loop at any moment. Last week, with the advent of inflation-indexed bonds, it suddenly looked a lot less foolish. Yes, the return will be meager -- 3.4 percent now -- but that's a real, after-inflation return, guaranteed for 10 years. If prices rise, the value of your bond moves higher in lock step. Considering the tax angle, though -- you pay tax on your whole return, even the part you don't see for 10 years -- the bonds may be most appropriate for tax-deferred retirement accounts.
 
BANKING
Giving, on Credit
The Roman Catholic Church is often accused of being behind the times -- on, say, women's rights. But in one area, it's at the forefront -- at least at San Claudio's Church in Leon, in northern Spain. San Claudio's, recognizing that "the age of plastic money" is upon us, has installed a bank machine in its entryway. No, it's not an A.T.M., exactly -- you give it money, not the other way around. Just pop in your bank or credit card, punch in what you want to donate -- and presto! The church gets its money without risk of theft, and you keep your privacy -- and have a receipt to show the tax collector. A local newspaper couldn't resist the headline "Through Visa Toward God."
 
TOBACCO
891 Billion Cigarettes
In the fourth quarter, Philip Morris had net income of $1.47 billion, mainly because of growth in its international tobacco business that, in one analyst's words, "defies gravity." In those three months, it sold 891 billion cigarettes -- about 156 for every human on the planet.
 
SUPER BOWL ADVERTISING
Men Behaving Strangely
This, as the millennium looms, is the glorious height to which humans have evolved: a bunch of guys in bumpy outfits with numbers on them smash into one another for a couple of hours, occasionally throwing a ball around, and fully half -- yes, half! -- of the nation's population feels compelled to watch on TV. And advertisers spent, for the first time, more than $100 million -- a record $1.2 million, on average, for 30 seconds -- to entertain these cheering masses with such uplifting fare as soft drinks throwing street parties. This is evolution?
 
'STAR WARS' INC.
The Force Gets a Paint Job
How times have changed. It used to be that 20-year-old movies were relegated to the faded, flickering depths of, say, Manhattan's old Thalia or Regency theaters. But that was before the age of -- need one say it? -- "Star Wars." Yes, "age." The "Star Wars" series is no one-year or one-decade phenomenon. No way. With T-shirts and all, it's a $4 billion business -- even before "Star Wars" blasted into theaters last week, dusted off, redigitized, respectacularized, whatever it is George Lucas and his techie buddies do out on that California ranch. It'll make millions, of course -- perhaps $100 million. But that's a drop in the galaxy. This is all part of a master plan, with more merchandise, more marketing -- all building to that long-awaited next trilogy in 1999.
 
BUDGETS
Miracle of the Ballot Box
What an astounding coincidence. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, after three tightfisted years, announced a preliminary budget last week that included his first overall increase in city spending and his fewest reductions in services. Practically as he spoke, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman -- a highly visible champion of slashing government spending -- proposed her own budget, one that increases spending for public schools and the environment. Could it, by chance, have anything to do with election calendars?
 
TECHNOLOGY
90's Taxes, 60's Computers
What pays most of this country's bills? Simple: $1.4 trillion in taxes. So considering how vital this money is, the I.R.S. surely has the best, most up-to-date computers around, right? Sadly, no. It has a crazy quilt of systems, some dating to the dark ages of the 60's -- and often those computers can't even trade information with one another. The agency recently spent $4 billion to make it all better, but last week it conceded that the system still didn't work, threw up its ink-stained hands, and proposed contracting out some processing of returns. And farewell privacy.
 
CYBERMESS
America on Hold
Yes, yes, this is a painful coming-of-age period in the exploding on-line world -- someday (really!) things will get worked out. Right now, though, confusion piles atop confusion. Last week America Online, which had opened the electronic floodgates with its all-you-can-eat pricing, responded to the inevitable gridlock with an offer to compensate subscribers who couldn't dial in. Try to call for that refund, though, and guess what? You get put on hold. (We spend increasing chunks of our day, it seems, either on hold or trying in vain to fit our particular needs to the touch-tone choices allotted us.) So, what next at America Online? Probably a new number to call to complain about the busy refund number. Think you'll get through?

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
For Mohawks, Casino Dream Is Still Alive

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: ST. REGIS MOHAWK RESERVATION, N.Y.

 BODY:
A STEADY stream of cars and four-by-fours pours in and out of the Bear's Den gas station, as though it offers some sort of wonder everyone must experience. And in a way, of course, it does.
Gas at the Bear's Den starts at $1.24 a gallon, 20 cents less than at the Mobil station a few miles down the road in St. Lawrence County. This is making the Bear's Den one very popular place, even while there is half a foot of snow on the ground and roads so slippery they send macho trucks spinning into ditches. 
 Though not much in the way of a scenic attraction, the Bear's Den and a handful of other stations on the St. Regis Mohawks' land are bringing the tribe on the United States-Quebec border a much-needed sense of security. Alma Ransom, chief of the Mohawk Tribal Council, says she doesn't know what the Mohawks would do without them. "The gas stations and the tax-free cigarettes are the only thing keeping us alive," she said. "If we didn't have them, there'd be a lot more people out of work."
 ON this land of gnarled forests and wild, wind-swept fields, the St. Regis Mohawks are weathering hard times. Unemployment, always high, hovers somewhere around 50 percent. There are small businesses -- crafts shops, diners, restaurants, convenience stores -- dotting the roads within the reservation, but all together, obviously not enough.
Now, the ailing Mohawks are in an unusual position. Over the last week, this remote 7,000-member tribe has been transformed by Catskill resort owners into the last best hope for the Borscht Belt's economic salvation. When the State Senate defeated a bill that would have allowed a statewide referendum on legalizing casinos in the Catskills and other aging resort areas, the Sullivan County business owners turned to their Plan B: a casino agreement with the St. Regis Mohawks to run a gaming hall at the Monticello Raceway.
Cliff Erlich, a co-president of the race track, said "Mohawk" has become the buzzword throughout the county. "When the bill was defeated," he said, "the entire county was in shock. Then everybody started calling up the race track and calling me and saying what can we do to bring the Mohawk casino here?"
 THE tribal council says the answer is simple: If Gov. George E. Pataki would just agree to the casino, then the Federal Government would give the O.K. to a 12,000-page land trust application that the tribal council submitted to build a casino in partnership with Watermark Investments Ltd. at the race track.
But it is not that simple. Not everyone in the Catskills supports the Mohawk-Watermark casino. (Some are suspicious of Watermark, which had entered into a deal to build a casino with the Oneida Indians that fell through before it turned to the Mohawks.) Just as important, not all the Mohawks support a casino, either here or in Monticello.
The St. Regis Mohawks know firsthand how divisive the issue of a casino could become. In 1990, two tribal members were killed in fighting over the closing of what the Federal Government called illegal gambling halls on the reservation. Ms. Ransom says the tribe is now united. But at least a third of the tribe does not recognize her council's authority, and divisions about the merits and sins of gambling are still wide open.
"Nothing has changed," said Loran Thompson, at his steakhouse, Loran's, by the St. Lawrence marina. As Mr. Thompson, a former traditional tribal leader, described it, the tribe's three often-competing branches of government are at cross purposes. One, the bank council, is negotiating with Canada to open a casino in Ontario; another, the traditional council, wants a casino only if the council runs it, and the tribal council wants to open at least two casinos.
Some members of the tribe say they are skeptical that the casino issue will be resolved. Teyonienkwatseh, who is 19, unemployed and uses only his traditional name, said his future is probably pumping gas. "I don't think a casino is ever going to open," he said. "We need something that everybody agrees to, and nobody agrees to everything."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 9, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Our Towns column last Sunday, about efforts to bring casino gambling to the St. Regis Mohawk Indian reservation, misstated the view of one of the tribe's three governing councils. The column quoted a restaurant owner, Loran Thompson, as saying that the traditional Mohawk council would support a casino as long as the council ran it. The traditional council officially opposes casino gambling, according to its administrator, Joyce Mitchell.

HEADLINE: As Seen on TV

BYLINE: By James B. Stewart; James B. Stewart is the author, most recently, of "Blood Sport."

 BODY:

Behind the Oval Office
 Winning the Presidency in the Nineties.
 By Dick Morris.
 359 pp. New York:
 Random House. $25.95. 
 "BEHIND THE OVAL OFFICE" tells several stories. The rise of Dick Morris from New York City pol to sophisticated pollster to Presidential adviser to disgraced john is one. The behind-the-scenes story of the making of policy in the White House is another. President Clinton's transformation from unpopular captive of liberals to victorious New Democrat is a third. But its most persuasive story seems almost inadvertent: the extraordinary dominance of television, and the money to pay for it, in Presidential politics.
Thus, in Mr. Morris's view, the "key to Clinton's victory" wasn't the President's track record, wasn't the economy, wasn't the Republican-led Government shutdown, wasn't Bob Dole's age. It was Mr. Clinton's "early television advertising. There has never been anything even remotely like it in the history of Presidential elections," Mr. Morris writes. Spending a staggering $85 million, he exults, "We created the first fully advertised Presidency in U.S. history." No wonder Mr. Clinton had to consort with wealthy foreigners.
The television ad campaign had to "begin early, be continual, stress the same themes week after week, and above all, not be jammed or countered by the press." While the campaign blitzed most Americans with three ads a week, it deliberately avoided New York, Washington and Los Angeles, because of these cities' concentrations of national news media. Mr. Morris is positively gleeful that he succeeded so well -- "a brutal comment on the free media's limitations." He is less forthcoming about why it was so important that the "free" (as opposed to "paid") media be kept in the dark. Perhaps he feared scrutiny of the accuracy of these ads (a subject he discusses only glancingly), or media claims that voters were being manipulated. But surely none of that would have stopped the juggernaut he describes.
Mr. Morris, as befits a pollster, seems to have the numbers to back up his assertion that television turned the Clinton Presidency around. He notes that during all of 1996, a time when the President's poll-inspired agenda and re-crafted image were being relentlessly driven home through television advertising, his popularity remained constant. "Through Whitewater, Filegate, Travelgate, Hillary's supposed seances, three terrorist bombings, reversals in the Middle East, the Republican primaries, the Republican Convention -- through all the ups and downs of Clinton's Presidency in 1996, the numbers remained basically the same."
Given television's importance, it's hardly surprising that the science of Q ratings, the instant polling long used by the networks to determine everything from a star's hairdo to plot twists, has been carried to its logical absurdity. Mr. Morris insisted that Mr. Clinton take a hiking vacation, even though the prospect bored the President, because polls show swing voters like hiking and the outdoors. When polls demonstrated that voters opposed teen-age smoking, Mr. Morris pressed Mr. Clinton to go on the offensive against the tobacco industry, even though the President worried about the repercussions in states like North Carolina and Kentucky. These are just two of what seem innumerable examples, the most revealing of which may be the account of Mr. Clinton's sweeping "values" agenda, the philosophical underpinnings of the second half of his first term.
Like so much else in the Clinton Presidency, this agenda began with a poll. (Mr. Morris reports that the President doesn't have time to read newspapers, but would "start his day with a summary of the latest polling information.") On one occasion, Mr. Morris's pollsters asked five "so-called values questions":
1. Do you believe that sex before marriage is wrong?
2. Do you believe that homosexuality is morally wrong?
3. Is religion very important in your life?
4. Do you personally ever look at pornography?
5. Do you look down on people who have affairs outside of their marriage?
Mr. Morris doesn't say who may have been present when these questions were answered -- spouses and children, for example -- but given their wording, it's hardly surprising that the answers suggested that "a third of the country was socially conservative" and "another third answered conservatively to three of the five." Mr. Morris's conclusion: "We had to get the values voters back."
In short order, the values agenda emerged as public policy. Mr. Clinton ordered his Secretary of Education to promote "religious observance and moral values on public-school grounds." He called for the wearing of school uniforms and denounced violence on television. He immediately embraced and then signed the Republican-inspired Defense of Marriage Act, permitting states to outlaw same-sex marriages. "Over the months, the focus of the Administration shifted more and more to values," Mr. Morris concludes with evident satisfaction.
All of this is narrated without the slightest hint of irony, even though Mr. Morris was seeing a prostitute at that very time. How would Mr. Morris himself have answered the "values questions" his pollsters put such store in? For that matter, how would Mr. Clinton? After the tabloid Star revealed Mr. Morris's affair just as the Democratic Convention was getting under way, he saw no reason to resign from the Clinton campaign. Mr. Morris tells us that Erskine Bowles, then deputy chief of staff, visited him in his Chicago hotel room to discuss his resignation.
"I was shocked, hurt and devastated" at the suggestion he resign, Mr. Morris writes. "I recognized the seriousness of the situation, but still hoped that somehow I could stay. 'Why?' I asked. 'What the hell did I do that he wasn't accused of doing in the exact same magazine four years ago?'
" 'You've admitted it's true,' Bowles replied." In the Clinton inner sanctum, truth is evidently the one unforgivable sin.
Hypocrisy aside, the entire values agenda and all the polling to support it would have been wastes of time and money unless they could be exploited on television, which is where the $85 million came in. "We formulated each ad according to our polling," Mr. Morris reports. The ads themselves, before being broadcast, were tested with shoppers in malls to assess their impact. At first, poll questions were cleared with President Clinton. But as time passed, Mr. Morris reports, "he let us proceed on our own." Thus the initiation of the entire chain of polling/ policy/television advertising seems largely to have passed out of the President's hands -- and Mr. Morris acknowledges that questions can be worded to produce almost any desired result. Is it any wonder that in Mr. Clinton we have a President who seems more interested in polling and advertising than he does in governing? Or that the likes of Dick Morris would have ended up as Clinton's closest adviser? ("I don't think any President has ever had someone as close as you are to me," Mr. Clinton tells him.)
That I find all of this profoundly depressing is no criticism of Mr. Morris's book, which, as best I can tell, delivers on his promise to write "simply the truth about my role in a series of extraordinary events." As the first of the Clinton White House insiders to publish his memoirs, Mr. Morris reveals much new detail, if no shocking disclosures. The portraits of Bill and Hillary Clinton are hardly uniformly flattering, with the President's childish temper and Mrs. Clinton's cold vengefulness amply on display (though it was Mrs. Clinton who was most compassionate about Dick Morris's demise). The portrait of Mr. Morris's rival and the President's former deputy chief of staff, Harold Ickes, is scathing, and George Stephanopoulos fares only slightly better. One can only sympathize with Mr. Clinton as he presides over what seems like endless backstabbing and squabbling by his White House staff.
And Mr. Morris succeeds in demonstrating his own real contributions, as he moves steadily from pollster to adviser. He percolates with ideas, all of which seem well intentioned if occasionally unsound, an amazing number of which were embraced by Mr. Clinton. As the President said on "The Newshour With Jim Lehrer" after Mr. Morris's resignation, "What I miss the most is his creativity, his ideas, his energy -- he would come up with lots of ideas. I'd go through them and pick the ones I wanted and discard the others, but I miss his ideas."
"Behind the Oval Office" suffers badly, if understandably, from Morriscentrism. We never hear anyone else's version of events, especially Mr. Clinton's. Mr. Morris's emphasis on polling and its implementation in policy and on television may ultimately demean both Mr. Clinton and the Presidency. But Mr. Morris, humbled by his recent public downfall, does not seem boastful. He has written an account that future historians of the Clinton Presidency will not be able to ignore.
Toward the end of his tenure, Mr. Morris invites Mr. Clinton to discuss with him the President's place in history, suggesting somewhat bluntly that he places Mr. Clinton only in the "third tier" of Presidents, and a borderline third tier at that. First tier, he suggests, a ranking he accords Washington, Lincoln and F.D.R., may be unattainable, requiring as it does crises of historic significance. Second tier -- where Mr. Morris places Jackson, Polk and Ronald Reagan -- may be possible, but in what seems an extraordinary concession for a professional pollster, Mr. Morris opines that "popularity doesn't get you on the list." Neither, he notes, does a strong economy, a nation at peace or a lower crime rate. What does? Great deeds: "Big things."
Mr. Morris doesn't say so, but the great deeds of our history -- Lincoln's freeing the slaves, Johnson's civil rights legislation, even Reagan's defense buildup to hasten the end of the cold war -- required strong leadership and a sense of underlying justice in the face of intense opposition, in many cases from members of both parties. These Presidents "triangulated," to use Mr. Morris's favorite phrase, not by moving to the center but by moving away from it, even at the risk of great unpopularity. Without benefit of hindsight, these steps took personal conviction and courage -- a quality Mr. Morris hardly mentions.
By such a standard, welfare reform, balancing the budget and preserving affirmative action, however laudable or politically astute, will not meet the test. Securing civil rights for gay people, including allowing them to serve openly in the military, might. So might overhauling immigration standards and protecting and encouraging those who immigrate. Or, maybe, to mention the politically untouchable, improving the nation's health care and extending its availability.
President Clinton can no longer be re-elected. Perhaps Dick Morris and all he represents have served their purpose.
