SECTION: Section 7; Page 31; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1524 words

HEADLINE: BOOKEND;
Making Book on Oprah

BYLINE: By Gayle Feldman; Gayle Feldman writes often about publishing.

 BODY:
LAST fall Oprah Winfrey, the queen of talk television, started an on-air reading club and the book business hasn't been the same since. For 10 years publishers had watched as self-help, inspirational and celebrity titles rose to best-seller status on the tides of telegenic emotion flooding each day across the screens of Ms. Winfrey's 14 million American viewers. Think of "Simple Abundance," "The Soul's Code," "Don't Block the Blessings," "Down in the Garden" and Ms. Winfrey's own "Make the Connection," written with Bob Greene. They all got their sales starts from her.
But the book club has taken her power to sell books to a different level. On Sept. 17, Ms. Winfrey stood up, in save-your-soul evangelist mode, and announced that she wanted "to get the country reading." She told her adoring flock to hasten to the stores to buy the book she had chosen, and a month hence they would discuss it together on the air. 
 "The Deep End of the Ocean," by Jacquelyn Mitchard, was not the easy romance or thriller that might have been predicted. It was a first novel that, to be sure, was a "woman's book," but also serious fiction, the kind that has never glued the nation to its television screens.
An Oprah's Book Club segment typically consists of extracts from a videotaped dinner-party discussion with Ms. Winfrey, the author and four members of the audience; soft-focus, heartstring-tugging biographical tidbits; and a studio chat between Ms. Winfrey and the author, with the dinner participants and audience looking on.
The initial reaction was astonishing. "The Deep End of the Ocean" had been doing very nicely for a first novel; 68,000 copies had gone into the stores since June. But between the last week in August, when Ms. Winfrey told her plans to the publisher, and the September on-air announcement, Viking printed 90,000 more. By the time the discussion was broadcast on Oct. 18, there were 750,000 copies in print. The book became a No. 1 best seller, and another 100,000 have been printed since then.
A business tycoon, Ms. Winfrey is also an attentive student of popular culture and is well aware that reading groups are one of the phenomena of the 90's. The club fulfills her on-air promise to bring higher-level content to her show, and has brought her admiring media attention. The club has also made manifest that Ms. Winfrey is the most powerful book marketer in the United States. On a really good day, she sends more people to bookstores than the morning news programs, the other daytime shows, the evening magazines, radio shows, print reviews and feature articles rolled into one.
Just look at the arithmetic for the next two club selections. At the end of the Mitchard discussion, she told the waiting world to go out and read Toni Morrison's 19-year-old classic, "Song of Solomon." On Nov. 18, when the Morrison segment was broadcast, Jane Hamilton's 1989 novel, "The Book of Ruth," was anointed for January air date (skipping December). More than 985,000 new copies of each have appeared (in combined hardcover and paperback), and each selection in turn became a top-selling fiction paperback.
How does she do it? More women than men buy books, and Miss Winfrey's audience is primarily female; various marketing surveys and the Nielsen market ratings show that her appeal crosses wide educational and income levels. This is reflected in the sales surges she produces, which, booksellers say, defy regional or economic differences, apart from a slight skew in favor of the suburbs and her home base, Chicago. More important, Ms. Winfrey's book club is apparently reaching nonreaders whom nobody and nothing else can touch.
The club segments have not made for great television. Little was said about the plot or significance of the books. Some of the show's executives worried about how the club would be received. Tim Bennett, the president of Ms. Winfrey's Harpo Productions, said he feared losing viewers during the club segments in the second half of the program, but the ratings studies he commissioned proved the contrary. So perhaps the phenomenon is more about Ms. Winfrey than about books.
It is a truth universally acknowledged among serious Oprah watchers that the more intimately she is perceived to identify with a guest or book, the bigger the off-screen payoff. She is a latter-day Dear Abby who can also send women running to the bookstores.
In our brand-name culture, "Oprah" is a brand name, something that publishing houses in America no longer are -- if they ever were. Random House, Doubleday or Viking on a book's spine doesn't signify much. But Oprah signifies a lot, which is why she controls the uses to which her name and image are put, and why publishers of club selections sign contracts specifying how and when the connection can be used.
Do publishers do Ms. Winfrey's bidding? Of course. They are sworn to secrecy about her selections and tremble lest there is a leak that will cause her to change her mind. They cannot use the show's name or logo or a photograph of Ms. Winfrey in their advertisements without prior written approval from Harpo Productions. They are contractually obliged to ask bookstores not to feature displays associating the book with her show until after Ms. Winfrey announces the selection on the air. They jump through whatever hoops she sets up.
The publishers, the bookstore chains and major wholesalers all track the sales of books that she features, sometimes daily. Their shared universe has become awesomely Oprahcentric. The sales she unleashes are especially meaningful now since adult book sales have been stagnant for the past few years.
Of course publishers have long tried to harness television's marketing power to their own ends, cultivating the producers and staff, just as the producers, in this symbiotic relationship, competed to be the first to snag the really "hot" books. But the relationship gradually began to lose symmetry as television's tremendous power to jump-start book sales on a mass scale encouraged publishers' marketing plans to grow more and more television dependent.
Years before the reading club, that dependency was exploited by producers of book segments on programs like the "Today" show who demanded exclusivity, dictated the timing of author appearances and so on. Now, in Ms. Winfrey's latest variation, the relationship between the media and the book industry has reached an extreme. Moreover, Ms. Winfrey has always played by slightly different rules, which have kept her much more firmly in control than other talk-show hosts. Thus when authors appear on other shows, their travel and living expenses are paid for by their publishers, but guests of "The Oprah Winfrey Show" are flown to Chicago and accommodated there by Harpo Productions.
Her dominance has gradually been consolidated in other ways, too. It used to be that for "regular" (as opposed to book club) appearances a publisher could suggest a book to one of her producers and see a segment built around it. Now, typically, an author or publisher receives a call from a knowledgeable staffer who knows exactly what she wants. But after a segment is taped, it is never certain when or whether the edited segment will appear.
Only the publisher of a reading club selection is given a firm air date several weeks in advance. And Ms. Winfrey's club choices will not be influenced by publishers' suggestions, but will be purely personal, made behind closed doors in consultation with her staff.
So major publishers now spend even more time and energy on strategies for cultivating Ms. Winfrey and her staff, to get their authors chosen to appear with her. They are delighted by the sales she stimulates, awed by the control she exercises and obsessed by how to find ways to whisper in her ear.
But if Ms. Winfrey doesn't listen to the publishers, she is very attentive to her audience's interests. After "The Deep End of the Ocean" was chosen and viewers complained about the cost of a new hardcover book, she asked the paperback publisher of "The Book of Ruth," Anchor/Doubleday, to donate 10,000 copies to libraries. A hardcover edition of "Solomon" was repriced from $26 to $18.95.
Ms. Winfrey says the club will continue at least through August (the next selection is "She's Come Undone," by Wally Lamb). Before the club was a factor, a publisher lamented to me, "Can you imagine if Coke sales depended on getting on 'Oprah'?" That says a lot about the work publishers and booksellers need to do better, as well as the formidable problems in bringing some 40,000 new trade books to market every year.
When the usefulness and pleasure and sheer importance of reading are remote to many, Ms. Winfrey, the high priestess of self-help, has laudably reminded millions of the rewards that can come from reading a good book. She has also made herself into yet another gatekeeper for the book to pass through, and the power of that position frightens some. The feverish obeisance that she exacts and is paid by those who produce and sell books says a lot about how distorted our book culture, like so much else, has become.

HEADLINE: The Great Exception

BYLINE: By Francis Fukuyama; Francis Fukuyama is the Hirst Professor of Public Policy at George Mason University.

 BODY:

THE STATE OF THE NATION
 Government and the Quest for a Better Society.
 By Derek Bok.
 483 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $35. 
 That American public policies differ substantially from those of other advanced industrialized democracies has been well documented by observers of American exceptionalism for many decades. The liberal political theorist Louis Hartz, asking why there is no socialism in America, answered that Americans were "born equal." Lacking European class distinctions, the United States had neither the radical labor movements nor the hidebound conservatives who spawned them. The absence of a serious socialist party accounted for the fact that the American welfare state developed later and was smaller than its European counterparts. American individualism and distrust of state authority left much more up to private initiative in virtually all public policy areas save education.
Much of the literature on American exceptionalism written in the 1960's and 70's assumed that the European welfare state, with its high wages and extensive social protections, constituted a norm for civilized societies and assumed that the United States would eventually conform to that standard. Derek Bok, a former president of Harvard University, has written a book that fits squarely within this tradition. Like critics of American public policies from a generation ago, he concludes that we are far behind the Europeans and need a larger, albeit more efficient, government to solve our many social problems.
"The State of the Nation" is an extensively researched compendium of statistical data on how the nation compares with other industrialized countries, in areas ranging from economic growth, competitiveness and science to education, health care, the environment, crime, occupational safety, poverty and the arts. The data, while up-to-date and admirably comprehensive, do not contain any major surprises. The postwar period during which Europe and Japan were rapidly catching up with the United States in terms of gross domestic product (measured per capita) and productivity is now over; in the 1990's, the United States has maintained and in some cases widened its competitive lead. Whereas Europe has persistent high unemployment rates but more equal income distribution, this country has nearly full employment and increasing disparities between rich and poor. But, despite the problems of inner-city communities, African-Americans (particularly women) have been closing the gap between them and their white counterparts quite impressively.
The areas in which the United States does not compare favorably are familiar: violent crime, health care, long-term disability, protection of mothers and children, and poverty. Americans, while feeling overtaxed, pay substantially less tax than Europeans, and Washington consequently undertakes much less in terms of worker retraining, maternity leave, day care, health insurance and programs to aid the unemployed and poor. Primary and secondary education, once superior in America, has deteriorated. Mr. Bok believes that these problems could be successfully addressed by more activist public policies, which the United States could easily afford.
Consider the last proposition first. A generation ago, when European unemployment rates were lower than ours, it was plausible to argue that we could trade a bit of growth for more equality. Today, with globalization, the price has risen considerably, and it will continue to do so. For Continental Europe, the rate of unemployment below which it is impossible to go without triggering substantial inflation pressures is easily double that of the United States, while rates of youth unemployment in countries like France reach 25 percent or more. European policies aimed at raising wages and increasing job security have killed new job growth. While the American economy added 18 million net jobs in the Reagan years and more than 10 million since the 1991 recession, the entire European Union has seen an employment gain of about 1 million in the same period. And the inability to hire new workers restrains European competition in fields like information technology and biotechnology, dominated by small American start-up companies.
Mr. Bok counters that the relationship between the size of welfare states and unemployment in Europe is still being debated among economists. Not to be deterred by uncertainty, he advocates stronger unions and German-style works councils. Other proposals -- better state-financed preschools and day care, longer maternity leaves, more support for the arts -- are unobjectionable, but their value has to be weighed against future growth and employment.
Apart from economic concerns, there is a broader question about what government can do in America. Mr. Bok would have done well to consult Seymour Martin Lipset, the most thoughtful contemporary authority on American exceptionalism, on the way in which our public policies are deeply rooted in basic American values. Mr. Bok misunderstands their role when he says Americans don't value crime, poverty or expensive health care. What Americans do want is consumer choice, social mobility and freedom from authority -- not just of government but families, neighbors, clerics and bosses. So it is not surprising that they get a wealthy, entrepreneurial, dynamic country -- but also more crime, litigation, broken families, job insecurity and unnecessarily legalistic regulation.
Mr. Bok notes that individual liberty, underwritten by an activist judiciary, is more advanced in the United States than anywhere else. He also notes that the decline in personal responsibility, as measured by factors like broken families, deadbeat fathers and cheating, is correspondingly more severe. He briefly entertains the notion that the two phenomena might be related, and should perhaps have pondered this question more closely. The sphere of individual liberty has expanded dramatically in a couple of generations at the expense of community and of institutions from the family to the state, and the rights revolution has been both cause and consequence. Mr. Bok's work, for all of its statistics, provides less insight into what is really bothering Americans than a book like "The Lost City," by Alan Ehrenhalt, which describes in rich detail the decline of community life in Chicago. These conflicting demands for ever-increasing liberty and stable community are key to present-day American discontents, and as value issues are largely beyond the reach of any public policy.

HEADLINE: Now Refashion U.S.-Caribbean Economic Tie

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Jan. 30 front-page article on the impact of the North American Free Trade Agreement on the Caribbean and the failure of the United States Government to enact legislation to remedy this situation underscores an urgent problem. 
 In the past few years, American-Caribbean relations have been squeezed as foreign and trade policies have shifted American resources elsewhere.
Foreign aid levels to the region have dropped by more than 50 percent since 1985, and last year Congress eliminated a provision in the United States tax code that generated more than $2 billion in low-interest loans for the region over the last decade.
More recently, the United States and the European Union agreed to eliminate tariffs on American rum imports from non-Caribbean countries. Yet when Caribbean countries ask for similar treatment on some of our most valuable exports -- like apparel made from American fabric -- our requests were rebuffed.
As you note, the United States has benefited significantly from its relationship with the Caribbean.
The Caribbean is now the United States' 10th largest market for exports. Any economic dislocation of the region will have severe repercussions across many American communities.
Rather than allow the erosion of this relationship to continue, the United States and the Caribbean should find ways to fashion a new partnership.
 
RICHARD L. BERNAL
Ambassador of Jamaica
Washington, Jan. 30, 1997

SECTION: Section D; Page 10; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1050 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Fallon McElligott drops McDonald's and Leap moves deeper into the Los Angeles market.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
TWO prominent Midwestern agencies surprised Madison Avenue with significant moves late last week.
One, Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis, is abruptly ending its relationship with the McDonald's Corporation, in part to solve a potential client conflict. The other, the Leap Partnership in Chicago, is raiding the executive ranks at TBWA Chiat/Day for an ambitious expansion into the Los Angeles market. 
 The decision by Fallon Elligott came only 13 months after McDonald's added the agency to its roster to create campaigns for the Arch Deluxe. That sandwich, introduced in May, was the object of the biggest advertising and promotional blitz in fast-food history, with spending estimated at $150 million to $200 million.
It was quite the coup for Fallon McElligott to join the McDonald's roster alongside far larger shops like the Chicago offices of the Leo Burnett Company and the DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group. Fallon McElligott subsequently landed additional blue-chip clients like the Miller Brewing Company, part of the Philip Morris Companies, and the United Airlines unit of the UAL Corporation.
Why, then, has Fallon McElligott parted with McDonald's? The agency decided to take part in a review for another fast-food account, Domino's Pizza Inc., with billings estimated at $75 million.
Six agencies were invited into the review to pick a successor to Grey Advertising Inc. in New York, which resigned rather than participate. Fallon McElligott is one of three that face conflicts with existing clients, the trade publication Advertising Age reported last week.
"We're grateful for our time with McDonald's," said Pat Fallon, chairman of Fallon McElligott. "It has been a rare professional privilege to represent one of the world's most brilliant brands."
"But we have the opportunity to pursue a prospective client," he added, "where if victorious, we would be able to manage their entire consumer voice in a single agency-brand partnership." In other words, if Fallon McElligott wins, it would be the sole Domino's agency.
"We have been in a quandary about how our role for McDonald's has evolved," said Mark Goldstein, president for integrated marketing at Fallon McElligott. "We signed on as the brand stewards for Arch Deluxe, and at this point we're one more vendor of commercials."
Though "we were working on a whole different assignment in addition to Arch Deluxe," he added, Domino's "was the trigger for a decision that was made anyway."
Fallon McElligott was initially the sole agency for Arch Deluxe. In August, DDB Needham Chicago created an Arch Deluxe commercial, which was followed by one from Burnett. Since September, when McDonald's added three more Deluxe sandwiches, commercials have been produced by all three agencies.
"Certainly one of the disadvantages of being a McDonald's agency is that you might have more agencies involved than you'd like," said Brad A. Ball, senior vice president for United States marketing at McDonald's in Oak Brook, Ill. "But as we asked others to participate on Arch Deluxe, Fallon very much participated in that and understood it."
"I love having Fallon as part of our team," he added, but "when Pat called to tell us about a better business and economic opportunity, I had to understand that as a former agency guy myself." Mr. Ball joined McDonald's in 1995 from Davis, Ball & Colombatto in Los Angeles.
As for whether the Deluxe line has stimulated sluggish sales at domestic McDonald's restaurants, Mr. Ball said: "We've succeeded in our kickoff efforts in attracting awareness and generating trial. It's settled back down to about where we hoped it would be."
Turning to the Leap Partnership, the advertising unit of Leap Group, the expansion will mark its first, well, leap outside Chicago. The new office, named Leap Partnership/Los Angeles, will have seven creative and account executives from the New York and Venice, Calif., offices of TBWA Chiat/Day. The office's genesis echoes the founding of Leap by executives leaving DDB Needham Chicago in 1993.
"To service our accounts properly and recruit new global clients, we needed an expansion plan" that would include West Coast, New York and international offices, said R. Steven Lutterbach, chairman and chief executive at Leap Group. The goal is to land accounts in categories like automobiles, consumer electronics and fast food, he added, to complement clients like Nike Inc. and the U. S. Robotics Corporation.
As for luring a large group from TBWA Chiat/Day all at once, Mr. Lutterbach said, "They decided they wanted to do it together, which made it easier for us." The catalysts, he added, were Steve Rabosky, a creative director in Venice, and Carisa Bianchi, an account director there.
Ms. Bianchi, 38, said: "We've all worked together as a group on a number of projects. It was kind of spontaneous combustion with everybody." She and Mr. Rabosky, 43, will be creative partners and co-managers of Leap/Los Angeles in Santa Monica, Calif.
Three colleagues joining them, all as creative partners, are also from Venice: Steve Erich, 29, an account supervisor there; Chris Graves, 35, a senior art director, and Erik Moe, 32, a copywriter. Two will join from the New York office, also as creative partners: Lorraine Ketch, 33, and Steve Le Neveu, 39, who had been managing partners and executive directors for account planning.
The defections occur as TBWA Chiat/Day plans a reorganization to come after Bob Kuperman, president and chief executive in Venice, is promoted to president of the agency's four North American offices. That promotion is expected soon, the trade publication Adweek reported last week.
"I don't think these people were, how shall we say, satisfied with what we were going to do," Mr, Kuperman said, "so they've decided to go out on their own. We wish them all a lot of luck." There was no thought of modifying the reorganization to accommodate them, he added, because they "had decided to leave."
Mr. Rabosky offered this response: "Nothing made me want to leave. I wanted to do something entrepreneurial, with people I could build a good partnership with."
"If I was that miserable at Chiat/ Day, I would've left a long time ago," he added, laughing. "God knows I've had my opportunities." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Lea Kisselgoff, 88, Classical China Scholar

 BODY:
Lea M. Kisselgoff, a Sinologist who specialized in classical Chinese texts, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88.
Mrs. Kisselgoff studied classical Chinese at the School of Oriental Languages in Paris and received a degree in Chinese civilization from the Sorbonne. She studied there with the pioneering Sinologists Marcel Granet and Paul Pelliot and was Professor Granet's research assistant in the 1930's. 
 She also did graduate work at Columbia University after coming to the United States in 1941. In January 1942 she joined the staff of the Chinese History Project, sponsored by the University of Washington and Columbia.
The project published "History of Chinese Society, Liao (907-1125)," a study of the Liao dynasty. The Harvard Journal of Asiatic Studies in 1950 called the volume "a monumental work."
Mrs. Kisselgoff served as president in 1972-74 and 1982-84 of the New York Oriental Club.
Her husband, Avram, chief economist of the Allied Corporation, died in 1983. She is survived by her daughter, Anna, chief dance critic of The New York Times.

HEADLINE: Telemarketing Finds a Ready Labor Market in Hard-Pressed North Dakota

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: LINTON, N.D.

 BODY:
The driving on the Lawrence Welk Highway had deteriorated into whiteout conditions as another blizzard scoured the North Dakota plains. But in a well-heated former tractor showroom, Susan Horner was booking vacations to Hawaii and Florida.
"People ask, 'How are you surviving it up there?' " Mrs. Horner said of the guilt pangs of people who telephoned a reservations center in North Dakota to book sunny vacation trips with Rosenbluth International, the third largest travel company in the world. 
 Calling America's Arctic to book tropical travel may seem incongruous, but for the dairy farmers of this small town the arrival of Rosenbluth on the wings of fiber optic telephone cable has been an economic godsend.
"When this office opened, every fourth business place on Main Street was closed, Linton was headed to becoming a ghost town," said Mrs. Horner, whose husband now milks their 50 cows on his own. "My paycheck makes our house payment and our farm payment."
Telecommunications businesses are transcending geography, searching the outback for pockets of hard-working well-educated people to make hotel reservations, take orders for catalogue companies, process corporate expense accounts or handle panicked calls from owners of new computers.
Omaha has become the "toll-free capital" of the nation, with tens of thousands of people there working in telemarketing. In South Dakota, 5,000 people process credit-card transactions, making that the state's largest industry.
In North Dakota, the explosion of the telecommunications industry has been so sudden, with thousands of jobs added in the last two years, that planners say it may be the way to stop a long-running brain drain.
"A fundamental shift is occurring," said Philip M. Burgess, president of the Center for the New West, a policy and research group in Denver. "For the first time in modern history we have jobs chasing people instead of people chasing jobs. In remote areas like the Dakotas or Montana, you start looking at levels of educational attainment or work ethic, and you find that those states rank among the highest. So companies move out there."
Traditionally, North Dakotans have complained that they have exported their education tax dollars, as well-educated young people leave for jobs elsewhere.
Although the state ranks 49th in teacher pay, the Scholastic Assessment Test scores of high school seniors rank the highest in the nation, according to a study last year in The Harvard Educational Review. The state also boasts an 87 percent graduation rate for high schools, among the nation's highest.
But the population of 638,000 is virtually the same size as it was in the 1920's. One measure of the lack of growth is seen in statistics kept by United Van Lines, the largest moving company. Last year, for every family that the company moved into North Dakota, it moved at least two out.
"We have to create jobs where the younger people can stay and make a good living," said Chuck Stroup, a former banker who is the state's economic development director.
Fiber-optic cable, 4,600 miles worth in the state, may level the playing field, bringing faster and higher quality communications to the northern Plains. In the past two years, telecommunications companies have announced that they were starting or expanding 40 businesses in North Dakota.
In Minot, previously a town known for its Air Force base, 225 people handled 6 million incoming calls last year at a reservation center for Quality Inns. In Minot and Bismarck, 735 people work for Sykes Enterprises, handling troubleshooting calls from buyers of computer equipment and software.
"People here have a real pride in their work, they are generally very well educated, and our absenteeism rate is 2 percent," said Paolo Narciso, who helped open the two Sykes centers last year. "We want to keep this place quiet."
But the secret has leaked out. In 1995, the telecommunications boom contributed to a 1.6-percentage-point drop in the unemployment rate in Bismarck, the second sharpest drop in metropolitan areas.
As North Dakota enjoys the lowest unemployment rate in the country, 1.9 percent, companies move through the countryside searching for the hidden unemployed, largely farm wives or Indians who stopped formally looking for work long ago.
In White Shield, on the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation, 100 people work as data processers. Thirty people work as telemarketers in Bowbells, a county seat of 498 people near the Canadian border, and dozens more do the same work in Hazen and Beulah, two old railroad towns on the Knife River.
The impact of Rosenbluth International, which has headquarters in Philadelphia and recorded $3 billion in sales last year, can be seen in Linton, seat of Emmons County, where it set up shop in 1988.
In the past the only activity in the area came in the summer, when occasional visitors came through the remote expanse to fish for walleye on the Missouri River or to view the wrought-iron cemetery crosses fashioned by Germans who had earlier settled in southern Russia. Some ventured to Strasburg, 10 miles south, which holds the county's biggest claim to fame, the Lawrence Welk Homestead.
In the 1980's, a punishing cycle of drought and farm foreclosures helped drive down the population by 20 percent. Now 4,800 people remain, scattered over a county that is slightly larger than Rhode Island.
"Rosenbluth came at just the right time," said Duke Rosendahl, a restaurateur who also runs the town development office. "People had to go out and find jobs or lose their farms. We had block after block of 'for sale' signs."
Hal Rosenbluth, the president of the company, said it had put half its reservation centers in North Dakota largely because of the hard-working character of the people there.
"People who have grown up in rural America have participated in self-management," Mr. Rosenbluth said. "They know about getting a job done."
While some outsiders may sniff at the company's $5.15- to $11-an-hour wages, the income goes far in a county where the median monthly rent is $266 and the average monthly mortgage payment is $600. Now the county's largest employer, Rosenbluth also provides family medical insurance, a major cost to self-employed farmers.
"With four girls in braces and glasses, the health benefits have been a big help," said Mrs. Horner, the reservations agent. "It's given us more financial security. We have been able to take the kids on some very nice vacations -- horseback riding in Colorado, flying to Florida."
The company's $2.5 million annual payroll has helped fill empty storefronts in Linton, put late-model cars on the streets and helped turn around a depressed residential real-estate market.
"People have come back to Linton," said the Rosenbluth payroll coordinator, JoAnn Humann. "People are moving here from other parts of the state."

HEADLINE: White House Had Ended System of Checking Foreign Guests

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Ten years ago the Reagan White House adopted a rule about foreign businessmen, lobbyists and consultants who wanted to get in to see the President without the blessing of their embassies: they shouldn't.
But President Clinton's aides did not follow that rule. In their eagerness to raise campaign money, they invited friends of the President's fund-raisers -- including China's biggest arms merchant, favor-seeking Indonesian businessmen, a reputed Russian mobster and other dubiously credentialed dealmakers -- to meet with Mr. Clinton. Nor did the White House check the suitability of Americans invited by the Democratic National Committee to meet the President, allowing, among others, a twice-convicted felon to sip coffee with Mr. Clinton. 
 A senior Administration official now calls the unexamined invitations to foreigners "a huge mistake." That mistake would not have happened had a system set up in 1987 remained in place after Mr. Clinton took office, according to nine present and former White House and National Security Council officials.
When the Iran-contra affair erupted in November 1986, the White House became "a glass house," a Reagan Administration official said. In that fishbowl the National Security Council erected barriers in January 1987 to keep foreign agents away from the President and out of the White House. After years of being beset by favor seekers from abroad -- President Reagan had welcomed a billionaire Japanese war criminal and other questionable visitors during his first six years in office -- the President's aides worked "like a hockey goalie," as one put it, to reject foreigners who sought meetings with the President to further their political or business agendas.
The system evolved in the Bush Administration, former White House aides said. One said that the White House and the National Security Council staff all recognized that "this is a common problem -- people trying to get in to see the boss -- and by getting in to see him, they can represent to others that they got something out of him."
The system was straightforward. The White House chief of staff and the White House counsel's office would notify the National Security Council staff when foreign visitors without introductions from their embassies asked to see the President. The staff would vet the potential visitor, sometimes seeking help from the Central Intelligence Agency.
The questions asked, according to a former Bush Administration official, included: "Who is this guy? What does he want? Is this an appropriate meeting? The value for a foreign individual of saying, 'I just met with the President of the United States,' was substantial and subject to a great deal of mischief." In the end, the visitor might win an appointment to see a member of the National Security Council staff -- but almost never the President.
"I was like the fish in the tank at a Chinese restaurant," recalled one former National Security Council aide. "I was supposed to absorb all the evil."
President Clinton's top aides did not follow that practice. Sometimes the White House would ask the National Security Council staff to check out a foreign visitor -- but more often, it would not.
"The N.S.C. staff was dependent on those in the White House to bring these issues to our attention -- usually the political staff," said David Johnson, a spokesman for the National Security Council. "I'm unaware of anyone from the White House counsel's office bringing those issues to us."
So the National Security Council staff, according to one of its more prominent members, ceased to function as a screening system to prevent potentially embarrassing visitors. By 1994, a year after Mr. Clinton took office, the gatekeeping system erected over the past six years was gone.
Clinton aides now concede that the lack of scrutiny was an error. In retrospect, "the missing link in the system here was some kind of enforcement to make the system work," said a National Security Council official. A system that once had been rigorous became "ad hoc," a senior Administration official said. On Jan. 21, on orders from the new chief of staff, Erskine Bowles, the White House began to re-establish the old system.
All involved now recognize that, as the senior Administration official said, abandoning the old system "was a huge mistake."
And that is why nobody on the White House political team saw fit to ask the National Security Council staff a year ago about a man named Wang Jun, who showed up on a guest list for a White House coffee with the President. The question of exactly how Mr. Wang got into the White House has a simple answer: "Nobody ever asked anybody," a National Security Council official said.
So, at the behest of a tireless political fund-raiser from Arkansas, Charlie Yah Lin Trie, Mr. Clinton wound up sipping coffee with Mr. Wang, who runs the Chinese Government's weapons manufacturing and procuring agency, which is involved in secret arms deals around the world. These coffees for fund-raisers and donors began as a way to raise morale among party loyalists after the Democrats' disastrous showing in the 1994 election. By 1995, they became a way to reward big donors and prospect for new ones, according to Democratic fund-raisers.
It was a personal coup for Mr. Trie to be able to introduce one of the Chinese Government's most powerful officials to the President.
Mr. Wang gained incalculable esteem by seeing the President, said former White House aides knowledgeable about Asian affairs. "Any Asia hand would tell you that is a truly rare commodity -- it's not just face and stature, but the appearance of being extraordinarily well-connected internationally," one said.
The meeting never would have happened in President Bush's Administration, contends one of Mr. Bush's aides. "The guy would not have passed the smell test," he said. "I don't recall a situation where a political contributor was bringing in a foreign national to see the President. An appearance of a White House connection or influence could be misunderstood in business or diplomatic terms. And the campaign element -- it would look like this kind of access was being bought and paid for."
Another former Bush Administration official said that in his day, "there was an ethos or an ethic that this was a potentially perilous situation to place the President in."
"Discretion required that such a meeting not take place," the official said.
Under such a rule an invitation would not have been extended to Carlos Mersan, chief economic adviser to the President of Paraguay, whose economy is in large part based on the smuggling of high-tech goods. He was invited to the White House by Mark Jimenez, a Miami computer executive who has raised and contributed three-quarters of a million dollars to Democratic Party campaigns and causes. Nor would an invitation to meet the President have been extended to Grigori Loutchansky, an Israeli citizen whose company, Nordex, was described by the C.I.A. last year as "an organization associated with Russian criminal activity."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Agenda and Budget Will Test Tone of Amity

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
After months of invoking bipartisanship, President Clinton this week formally presents his legislative agenda and his budget, beginning the long struggle that will determine whether the Republican-controlled Congress and the Democratic President can really enter a season of cooperation.
Mr. Clinton starts off this debate in a stronger position than in years, given new legitimacy in his re-election and the highest public approval ratings of his Presidency. Indeed, Republicans are no longer pronouncing his proposals dead on arrival, though that is in part because Mr. Clinton has moved so far in their direction since the Republicans won control of Congress in 1994. 
 He has used two recent speeches, an appearance before the centrist Democratic Leadership Council and his inaugural address, to give an ideological coherence to the small-scale campaign proposals that positioned him in the political center. He has said he advocates a Government "humble enough not to solve all our problems for us but strong enough to give us the tools to solve our problems for ourselves." Now, his aides say, he will demonstrate what he means through concrete programs.
White House officials say the President will seize the moment in his State of the Union message on Tuesday by first calling on Congress and the nation to complete the "unfinished business" of balancing the budget, finding jobs for welfare recipients and overhauling campaign finance laws. To give urgency to the campaign finance issue, he is expected to call for action by July 4.
As he has increasingly since the Republicans won control of Congress, Mr. Clinton will not just urge legislative action but will also call for individuals, communities and states to take steps on their own to grapple with the nation's social ills.
Returning to the family-centered themes of his campaign, Mr. Clinton plans to make education a cornerstone of his agenda for the next four years. He is expected to call for schools across the country to test whether their students are performing up to nationally recognized standards and to explain how the Federal Government can help create the climate for such rigor.
Mr. Clinton also plans to tackle the issue of health insurance once again, this time with a series of initiatives intended to help the 10 million American children who lack coverage.
Many of the other proposals that the President made during the campaign will be fleshed out, among them plans to offer $3.4 billion in grants and tax relief to simulate job creation for those who will be forced off welfare under stringent new time limits; proposals for tax credits and tax deductions to help pay for higher education, and a proposal to help maintain health insurance for unemployed workers.
Two days after his speech, Mr. Clinton plans to provide further detail by announcing his budget proposal for the 1998 fiscal year. Although the outlines of the program -- which call for balancing the budget by 2002 while making $100 billion in tax cuts for specific social purposes -- are almost identical to the proposals Mr. Clinton made last year, this time the Republicans are not dismissing the plan out of hand.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said today that Republican leaders would invite Mr. Clinton to come to Capitol Hill on Wednesday, the day after his State of the Union message, for talks on the budget and a range of other issues.
On the ABC News program "This Week," Mr. Lott said the invitation would send this message: "Mr. President, it's time that we stop the little pigeon steps around here and let's begin to see what we can really do for the American people."
Josh Silverman, a White House spokesman, said that the President had not yet received an official invitation and noted that Mr. Clinton had plans to be in Georgia on Wednesday as part of an effort to speak about education issues across the country. But the spokesman left the door open for a meeting soon, saying, "As always the President looks forward to meeting with the Senate majority leader and bipartisan leadership."
Yet despite the tone of amity and the desire of both Mr. Clinton and Republican leaders to show that divided government can work, serious stumbling blocks could emerge as the two sides start negotiating on how to erase the Federal deficit.
One of the most bitter fiscal issues dividing Republicans and Democrats in the 1996 campaign was how to find savings in Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly. Last month Mr. Clinton made a conciliatory gesture to the Republicans by announcing that his budget plan would trim the growth of Medicare spending by $138 billion over six years -- more savings than he was willing to entertain in the past.
Republicans welcomed the move but have since expressed reservations about the fact that Mr. Clinton would make the roughly $20 billion in additional savings largely by reducing payments to health maintenance organizations, not by asking the elderly to pay more.
Tax cuts are also shaping up as a struggle. The Republicans want nearly twice the number of cuts proposed by Mr. Clinton, with more reductions for upper-income people and a drop in the top capital gains rate. His proposals are largely focused on middle-income families and education, like offering a $500-per-child tax credit and proposals on a $10,000 tax deduction for post-secondary-school tuition or a $1,500 tax credit for each of the first two years of higher education. The education tax breaks would not apply to families earning over $100,000 annually.
Within his own party, Mr. Clinton is likely to face pressure for more social spending. Senate Democrats have already outlined an assortment of plans to extend health care coverage to the 10 million uninsured children. One proposal sponsored by Senators John Kerry and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts goes beyond anything Mr. Clinton is expected to call for. Their plan, at a cost of $25 billion over five years, would buy vouchers for low-income families to buy insurance.

HEADLINE: Global Phone Pact Appears Near But U.S. Conditions May Block It

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Trade negotiators from more than 100 countries are close to reaching an agreement on opening up government-protected telecommunication monopolies to competition, but the United States is still threatening to block the pact if it does not go as far as American officials would like.
With only two weeks left before a deadline set by the World Trade Organization, 10 countries have come forward in the last week with new or improved offers to open their domestic communication markets. And thanks in part to pressure from the Federal Communications Commission, officials at the trade organization say that considerable progress has been made on persuading many countries to start reducing their fees for completing international phone calls, which are often wildly expensive compared with American rates. 
 "I think we will have an agreement by Feb. 15," said Renato Ruggiero, head of the trade organization, in an interview here this weekend. "You can never be sure, but we have made a lot of progress. It is very encouraging."
A global deal would commit countries to move toward the same kind of competition in telephone and cable television services that is being opened up in the United States and the European Union. It would threaten the sky-high prices charged by many foreign telephone monopolies, by allowing rivals to set up new networks. And it would also open new opportunities for giants like AT&T, British Telecommunications or Sprint to build or buy their way into Latin America, Asia and Africa.
But the key to reaching a deal is the United States, which essentially vetoed an agreement last April on the ground that not enough countries had committed themselves to truly opening their markets.
In the last two weeks, officials of the trade organization said, 10 countries have submitted new proposals to open their markets and another 12 have said they will follow suit. But a critical question is whether, on close scrutiny, these offerings are as significant as they purport to be.
For the United States, the biggest obstacle to a deal may turn out to be Canada, America's biggest trading partner. Officials in Geneva, where the W.T.O. is based, and in Washington say that Canada has refused to agree to scale back tough restrictions on foreign ownership of telephone companies. That is a subject of intense interest to the likes of AT&T, MCI Communicationsand British Telecommunications, which is hoping to buy MCI before the end of the year.
"We are not there yet," said Jay Ziegler, a spokesman for the United States trade representative.
The United States and the European Union are already knocking down protective barriers in their telephone, cable television and data markets. But a global trade agreement would provide a powerful new weapon, by allowing rivals to go to international court under the W.T.O. if individual governments stalled competition for the benefit of their traditional telephone monopolies. And it would commit most of the world to the same principles of competition being put into play in the United States and Western Europe.
Mr. Ruggiero and others at the W.T.O. say that there are solid reasons for being optimistic about completing a final deal. One is that many countries are grudgingly giving up their determination to maintain extremely high "accounting rates" for international telephone calls. Accounting rates cover the price of completing international calls into and out of a country, and these prices are often many times more than their true cost in many countries because governments count on the revenue to subsidize other services.
The issue has been a source of contention between the United States and other countries for nearly a decade. But that issue has slipped into the background, in part because the F.C.C. recently imposed new regulations that block American carriers from paying their counterparts in other countries more than certain prescribed amounts per minute.
That, together with the fact that European countries are already well on the way to cutting their rates and introducing competition, has defused tensions over the issue at the World Trade Organization.
Because the American telecommunications market is so immense, and access to the American market is so crucial, the United States has what amounts to a veto on any global trade pact.
American officials have alternatives to a global agreement. The F.C.C. is putting in place policies that essentially set the stage for bilateral deals in which United States restrictions on foreign carriers are dropped if the other country has opened its market to American companies. The United States and Britain are close to establishing that kind of relationship, which is why British Telecommunications has a very strong chance of winning regulatory approval for its deal to buy MCI.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
'The British Genius'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
In the run-up to the British election, now likely to take place in May, it seems increasingly difficult to tell the two major parties apart. Two weeks ago Labor's shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, went so far as to promise that Labor would not raise income-tax rates for five years if it won, or increase public spending for two years.
The political logic of the move is plain. Labor is generally thought to have lost in 1992 because it planned to raise taxes. Like Bill Clinton last year, party leaders want to anticipate and neutralize attacks from the other side. 
 Are there still real differences in what a Labor government would do? I put the question to Mr. Brown, and got a passionate answer.
He began with Britain's relationship to the European Union. Under pressure from Conservative anti-Europeans, Prime Minister John Major has sounded increasingly negative about the E.U., distancing himself in particular from its project to create a single European currency.
Mr. Brown reiterated Labor's position that it will decide about joining the single-currency plan in terms of the national interest. But he saw the increasingly xenophobic tone of Conservative opposition as the signal of a move toward leaving the E.U. altogether -- which would be disastrous for Britain.
"Right-wing Tories are trying to recreate a past that cannot be," he said, "in a world of free trade. They talk of sovereignty, as if NATO didn't exist. They talk of Britain's role in the world as centered on the special relationship with America, but with the end of the cold war that is not the only means by which we can play a part."
There has always been an insular element in British thinking, reflected in the famous newspaper headline "Fog in Channel, Continent Cut Off." Could a Labor government persuade the public that Britain's interests are wholeheartedly in Europe?
"I think people see the Conservatives on the sidelines of Europe," Mr. Brown replied, "carping, half in and half out, always wanting to blame Europe for everything that goes wrong.
"We can lead in Europe, and express our national identity better that way. I think people want to see the British spirit and character in the Community: openness, tolerance, a strong sense of fair play, inventiveness.
"The British genius lies in qualities that are wider than self-interest. That is why it is not anti-British to be internationalist. It is why we can express our sense of being British by being in Europe."
Mr. Brown tied those views to domestic policy, too. He said he had pledged not to increase public spending or income taxes because a modern left-of-center party could not be a tax-and-spend party. But it still could have a principled program, he said, to undertake government initiatives for community purposes.
More education and training are Britain's great needs, he said -- to equip people for more sophisticated work. As it is, the country has a high level of long-term unemployment despite being in a rosy economic period. Official unemployment statistics do not count single-parent families headed by women and certain other categories. Altogether, he said, 19 percent of British families now have no one bringing in wages -- compared with 11 percent in the United States.
"You can't continue supporting a fifth of the population," he said, with unemployment and other benefit payments. To make work more attractive than welfare, he would like when he can to cut the starting income-tax rate in half, from 20 percent to 10. "You need to equip people for work, and you need reform of taxation and benefits to make the work ethic more important.
"We can't be reduced to the notion that self-interested individualism is all Britain is about. A country also needs to have a sense of community, of trust."
Those themes may show up in the campaign when Mr. Major finally calls the election. Right now Labor has to beware of overoptimism. The latest poll gives it a 25 percent lead -- a figure that may reflect not so much approval of reformed Labor policies as a widespread public feeling that the Tories are exhausted after 18 years in power.

HEADLINE: New TV Law in Colombia Provokes Complaints of Censorship

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The Colombian Congress has granted a regulatory commission broad authority to take television news programs off the air on the basis of their content. Many journalists see the move as an attempt to punish programs that have investigated suspected ties between drug traffickers and prominent politicians, including President Ernesto Samper.
The measure, part of a new broadcast law canceling television news concessions that were to have run until 2003, was signed by Mr. Samper in December. 
 Six months earlier, Congress exonerated the President in a scandal stemming from charges that his 1994 election campaign had knowingly accepted contributions from major drug dealers.
"It's a very direct measure against news shows that have been critical of Samper over the last two years," said Enrique Santos Calderon, a columnist for the daily El Tiempo and part-owner of QAP, a television news production company.
Daniel Coronell, an investigative journalist and news director of New Colombian Television, agreed. "It assures the President that he won't be criticized for the rest of his term," he said.
The new law creates regional stations and two private networks in addition to the two public stations currently on the air and grants Congress its own channel. Its most controversial provision allows the two-year-old National Television Commission to review the contents of television programs every six months to determine whether they comply with the Constitution, which promises Colombians the right to their "honor" and demands that the news be "truthful and impartial."
Although news organizations have filed suits challenging the new law, the Constitutional Court is not expected to rule on it for several months.
But the televison commission, four of whose five members are appointed by the Government and Congress, will begin reviewing the contents of news programs this month. Programs can be taken off the air before the court has a chance to issue its findings.
In its annual human rights review, released on Thursday, the State Department in Washington criticized the broadcast law, which it called "an obvious effort by the Samper administration to eliminate troubling television news coverage of a scandal-ridden administration and to reward its powerful backers for remaining loyal."
Supporters of the law argue that it is not intended to censor news shows, but to open the airwaves to a wider range of sympathies. They dismiss the criticism from the United States as part of a campaign in Washington to undermine Mr. Samper.
Complaining that reporters were overwhelmingly hostile to the President during the inquiry into suspicions that he had drug connections, one of the bill's sponsors, Congressman Carlos Alonso Lucio, called it a way to broaden access to the airwaves. "Undoubtedly, during this last crisis in Colombia the news shows went beyond the mission of informing people to assume a defined political position," Mr. Alonso said. "Anybody who was a friend of the Government was a crook, and whoever was against the President became the great ethical saints of the country."
Mr. Alonso, a former member of the M-19 guerrilla organization who reportedly has made frequent visits to imprisoned leaders of the Cali drug cartel, Miguel and Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela, co-sponsored the section of the new law requiring twice-yearly reviews of news programs with another lawmaker, Martha Catalina Daniels. The reviews mean that news programs -- with their employees, leases and millions of dollars in studios and equipment -- are threatened every six months with being shut down and barred from broadcasting for five years.
Mr. Lucio and Mrs. Daniels have been strong supporters of President Samper, and have been highly critical of news coverage of the investigation of possible connections between drug dealers and politicians.
Mrs. Daniels is herself being investigated for corruption by the Supreme Court, and her husband, Hernando Rodriguez, is being sought by the authorities on charges that he stole $13 million from a longshoremen's pension fund.
Mrs. Daniels said the owners of the news programs, who she estimated earned $35,000 for every half-hour broadcast, were defending not so much freedom of the press as "their own economic interests."
Monica de Grieff, the chairwoman of the National Television Commission, said the commission was studying other countries "that have no connotation of censorship" to figure out how to measure program content.
Last year, Mrs. de Grieff broke off a transmission from Congress when then-Senator Maria Izquierdo took the microphone to confess that she had accepted money from drug dealers to help Mr. Samper's election campaign.
Mrs. de Grieff said the commission did not like the mandatory reviews, "but we have to do it, and that's why we're trying to do it as carefully as possible."
Maria Isabel Rueda, news director of QAP, said the production company was already feeling the effects of the new law. Defense Minister Guillermo Alberto Gonzalez, who is reputed to have ties with a drug trafficker named Pastor Perafan, has complained to the commission that QAP was persecuting him and his family when a reporter questioned him about the allegations. More disquieting, she said, was that her news program stood alone.
"My competition never asked him about the charges at all," she said.
In the face of criticism, most recently from the Inter-American Press Association, President Samper said recently that he did not agree with the twice-yearly reviews, but signed the law because of its overall content. He said that if the Constitutional Court upheld the television law, he would propose a bill to modify it. But a minister in his Government has said publicly that the law is precisely the one the Administration hoped for.

HEADLINE: Private Help for Public Woes

 BODY:
Despite America's robust economy, unemployment remains stubborn in the inner cities. Millions of urban residents are not only jobless. They are growing increasingly out of touch with potential employers. At a time of reduced government spending, salvation lies increasingly with the private sector. Two recent developments offer glimmers of hope.
Henry Kravis, founder of the legendary buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, rounded up more than 50 companies that invested $1 million each in a new and exciting vehicle known as the New York City Investment Fund. Either as partner or lender, the fund will provide money to firms that locate in blighted neighborhoods or hire large numbers of low-skilled workers. 
 The fund will not provide grants. It expects to back companies that can survive on their own and fully repay the fund so the money can be recirculated to other deserving ventures. The fund also says it will back companies that cannot attract traditional sources of money. Exactly what projects will fit these two criteria is unclear. No doubt the fund will learn as it goes along.
If the goal of the Kravis fund is to create jobs, the goal of the Rockefeller Foundation is to prepare long-term unemployed workers to find and keep jobs. In nine cities, not including New York, the foundation, in partnership with the Department of Housing and Urban Development, will set up programs to put residents of public housing to work. Employment rates in public housing projects hover around 20 percent, which the foundation intends to triple. The program will train these residents for entry-level jobs, provide job-search assistance and, most important, provide support services after residents find jobs -- including child care and participation in peer advisory groups.
In cooperation with Chase Manhattan Bank and HUD, Rockefeller will also create 6 to 10 demonstration projects, including two in New York, to find jobs for residents of low-income, high-unemployment neighborhoods. The projects will build on the experience of the New York City Partnership, a business advocacy group, that is already working with private purchasers of city-owned rental properties in Harlem and Brooklyn to create jobs for their tenants. The Rockefeller-Chase Manhattan project will expand the reach of the jobs programs beyond tenants to other disadvantaged workers in the neighborhoods.
The Kravis fund and Rockefeller Foundation projects could provide guidance for programs that soften the blow of the new Federal welfare law, which will end cash aid, food stamps and other Government assistance for millions of families. Welfare-to-work programs nationwide have boosted earnings and employment only modestly and no program has worked anywhere near the scale that would be needed in urban centers like New York. One answer is for private firms to create jobs, and then for the long-term unemployed to find and keep jobs.
The Kravis fund seeks to do the first. The Rockefeller-Chase Manhattan projects seek answers about training the disadvantaged for jobs. If the programs yield positive results, the next logical step would be to convert the lessons learned into blueprints for ordinary profit-seeking businesses.

LENGTH: 2224 words

HEADLINE: UNLIKELY ALLIES -- A special report.;
The Bill That Fell From Grace

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Almost a year ago, the Rev. Tom Grey recalled, a rumpled, gruff-voiced man approached him at a convention of evangelical Christians in Rochester and gave him his card. "We have a common interest," the man said.
For Mr. Grey, a Methodist minister and the director of the National Coalition Against Gambling Expansion, that interest was singular: to prevent New York State from legalizing casinos. He thanked the man, David E. Langdon, took his card and they stayed in touch, sharing newspaper articles, political gossip and lobbying tips. 
 It was not until months later that Mr. Grey discovered the nature of Mr. Langdon's interest: he was one of four lobbyists retained by Donald J. Trump to fight the spread of high-stakes gambling into New York.
Mr. Trump, who owns three Atlantic City casinos, had of course long been the enemy for gambling opponents. But Mr. Grey, a former chaplain in the Vietnam War who is fond of military analogies, gladly welcomed the alliance.
"This is combat," he said last week. "This is a guy who you want in your camp."
Thus was formed the backbone of one of the oddest, most disparate coalitions in recent Albany memory. Before long, Mr. Langdon and Mr. Grey, an Illinois resident who is on special assignment from his church to travel the country fighting casino proposals, joined ranks with the Roman Catholic Church, environmentalists like Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the Christian Coalition, groups representing Broadway theaters and New York City hotels, Skidmore College in Saratoga, the New York State Council of Churches and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Last week, their efforts bore fruit as the State Senate resoundingly rejected a constitutional amendment to legalize casinos. As votes were being cast, a glance into the Senate gallery told the story of the public relations fight: the seats were filled with Mr. Grey's allies and their lobbyists.
It was a stunning turnabout for a measure that, just a few weeks ago, had been widely expected to pass. The vote ended years of public debate and backroom intrigue, and dashed the aspirations of business owners and elected officials from the Catskills to Niagara Falls who had envisioned casinos as a golden remedy for their regions' ailing tourist economies. A state study had shown that casinos would have brought $2.6 billion to the economy and created 38,000 jobs.
Had the Senate approved the amendment, it would have gone to the Assembly, which was expected to pass it, and then to voters for a November referendum. So last week's vote also prevented what was expected to be a multimillion-dollar campaign by opponents and supporters to sway the electorate. Now it will probably take two years, at least, before the issue will come before voters, Senate leaders said.
By all accounts, the resourcefulness, size and diversity of the opposition caught casino supporters by surprise. But there were other important reasons behind the measure's failure.
The lobbyists and publicists for big casinos whom opponents had expected to descend like locusts on Albany never arrived. Casino executives in other states said they were either skeptical about the measure's chances or fearful that their intervention might hurt it.
Within the state, supporters complacently expected the measure to pass and were slow to mobilize. A Brooklyn developer who wanted to build a casino at Grossinger's resort in the Catskills did not make his pitch to Democratic senators until 15 minutes before the vote.
Political machinations also helped kill the measure. The five Nassau County Republicans voted against the measure at the behest of their county chairman, who also happened to be president of the local Offtrack Betting Corporation. Sixteen of 17 New York City Democrats opposed it, partly because they thought it did nothing for their districts.
And the two supporters who might have saved the measure, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and Gov. George E. Pataki, did not want to twist arms, apparently fearing that the political fallout from pushing it significantly outweighed the benefits.
But as soon as the measure failed, both sides were predicting that it would return, and both were already preparing for the next battle. "I don't think anyone is going to rest on their laurels," said Joe Dalton, president of the Saratoga County Chamber of Commerce, one of the opposition's leaders. "We'll be ready for a fight next time."

The Players
Pastors and Bishops Ally With Trump
A constitutional amendment must be approved by two consecutively elected Legislatures before it can go before voters in a referendum. In 1995, the first time the casino measure was adopted, there was only scattered opposition from groups largely working independently of one another.
But that vote spurred Mr. Grey to begin patching together a grass-roots operation to block a second passage in 1997.
He found a Chinese-American minister in Manhattan who had been fighting a proposed Offtrack Betting parlor in Chinatown. Mr. Grey hooked up with an antigambling group in the Catskills led by a retired clinical psychologist. He persuaded liberal Protestants in Buffalo to join forces with the Christian Coalition. And he began communicating with Senator Frank Padavan, a Queens Republican who is the Legislature's leading opponent of casinos, which he says foster gambling addiction and political corruption.
By last month, their pool of resources was growing deeper by the day. Roman Catholic bishops in Buffalo and Albany began calling their senators. Skidmore College donated use of a phone bank that would eventually place 3,000 calls to lawmakers in a week. A Saratoga Springs church set aside $10,000 for the cause and recruited teen-agers and widows from its Bible study classes to stuff envelopes.
"Instead of doing First Timothy, we turned into a political action committee," said the Rev. John A. Eckman, pastor of the Presbyterian and New England Congregational Church in Saratoga Springs.
While ministers were running the public campaign, Mr. Trump's team of lobbyists was working the back rooms of the Capitol. Mr. Trump, who contends that casino gambling would hurt his real estate holdings by draining money from the local economy, had carefully selected lobbyists with access to key legislators. Mr. Langdon and a second lobbyist, Francis J. Sanzillo, were former top aides to the Senate Democrats, the largest bloc of swing votes. Brian Meara had strong ties to Assembly Democrats. And the fourth, Albert Pirro, was close to Republicans in both Houses.
In addition to the $855,750 Mr. Trump invested on lobbying last year, he and his wife also gave at least $400,000 in campaign contributions to both parties, including $100,000 to the Senate Democrats.
Though there has been much debate over the role Mr. Trump's money played in killing the amendment, it is clear that his lobbyists helped formulate some of the opponents' strongest arguments. For instance, the lobbyists contended, and many Democrats ultimately agreed, that the Legislature should establish a system for licensing and regulating casinos before passing the amendment. The Republicans refused, prompting many Democrats to vote against the bill.
"I think Donald Trump and OTB on Long Island probably called a lot more of the shots than we did," Mr. Eckman said.
Tensions were inevitable, of course, given the enormous philosophical differences among the opponents. Mr. Eckman, a self-described liberal, initially refused to work with the Christian Coalition, whose leaders he once likened to fascists. And more than a few ministers were unhappy about rubbing elbows with Mr. Trump's team.
Mr. Grey even sent a playful note to Mr. Langdon that paraphrased scripture to sum up their unease: "The lion shall lie down with the lamb, but the lamb shall not get much sleep," it read. Mr. Langdon wrote back, "But who is the lion?" Mr. Grey replied, "You'll know when we come after Trump."
But then Mr. Bruno unwittingly gave the opposition more reason to unite: He announced in early January that the Senate would vote on the amendment within a month. Opponents viewed the move as an attempt to ram the amendment through before they could organize. Fueled by anger and anxiety, they quickly set aside their differences.
"Desperation breeds effectiveness," said Damaris McGuire, director of the New York State Episcopal Public Policy Network and a leader of the coalition. "They did us a favor by putting it on such a fast track."

The Lawmakers
Democrats Play Coy, Bruno Rebuffs Deals
By mid-January, as opposition was building outside the Senate, support for the measure was quickly eroding within.
Part of the problem was that Senate Republicans had never been enthusiastic about the amendment, with many expressing moral qualms about gambling. Indeed, when the measure first came to a vote in 1995, fewer than half of the 36 Republicans were initially willing to support it.
When Democrats said they would not help pass the amendment in 1995 because they had not been given a role in shaping it, it appeared certain to fail. But Mr. Bruno took the Democrats' refusal as a personal challenge. He stormed into a private meeting of the Republicans and demanded that they support him by voting yes. They did, and the measure passed on an almost straight party-line vote, 34 to 21. (Thirty-one votes are needed for passage.)
This year, Mr. Bruno -- who faced stiff opposition to the amendment from Saratoga, which is part of his own Senate district -- promised not to pressure Senators. That meant that at least a dozen Republicans would probably vote no.
Things worsened for the amendment when the Nassau County Republican chairman, Joseph N. Mondello, told the five Nassau Republican senators to vote against the amendment. Mr. Mondello is also president of the Nassau Downs Offtrack Betting Corporation, which stood to lose wagering income to casinos. All five complied.
Mr. Mondello has insisted that he was motivated purely by the concern that casinos would cause an epidemic of compulsive gambling.
"You're talking about a situation where a man who can't control himself has tremendous temptation," he said in a recent interview. "The pay check is never going to make it to the doorstep."
Knowing that their votes were needed to pass the amendment, Democrats played coy, publicly saying that they were undecided while privately hoping that Mr. Bruno would offer concessions on sundry issues.
Some wanted assurances that a portion of tax revenues from gambling would go to New York City, which was prohibited from having casinos under the measure. Others wanted Mr. Bruno to soften his hard-line stance against rent regulations. And still others wanted virtual veto power over the legislation that would establish the system for regulating casinos.
Mr. Bruno refused to deal on all those things. Seeing nothing in it for them, the Democrats overwhelmingly voted no.
"They were always ready to go for it if they got anything for it," the Senate minority leader, Martin Connor of Brooklyn, said after the vote. "I could have pushed them to yes if there was a reason to. There wasn't."

The End Game
Last-Ditch Scramble Fails to Save a Bill
Until early January, the campaign for casino gambling had largely been handled by one man, Lester Shulklapper, an influential Albany lobbyist with strong ties to Republicans who represented Catskills resort owners.
But with the measure clearly in trouble, business leaders and mayors from other communities that stood to gain casinos -- Buffalo, Niagara Falls and Lake George -- finally began pressing their cases.
Some hired lobbyists at the last minute. Others began making weekly trips to Albany to buttonhole legislators. But they never broadened their support outside their communities. It was too little, too late, many supporters acknowledged.
"It came up so fast, we didn't have an opportunity to really get out and lobby," said John Kaczorowski, president of the Buffalo Central Labor Council, which along with the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., supported the amendment because they believed that it would create jobs.
Moreover, except for Circus Circus Development Corporation and a few other casino owners, big gambling interests never joined the fray. Executives for several companies like Mirage Resorts, which spent millions on a failed effort to build a casino in Bridgeport, Conn., said they had decided months ago that lobbying state legislatures can be a tremendous waste of money.
"You become a target," said Stephen Wynn, Mirage's chief executive. "If somebody wants to legalize, they can do it on their own time and then come get us."
By last week, the only person clearly powerful enough to save the amendment was Mr. Pataki. But he, too, faced political problems: cajoling senators to vote yes would have angered powerful interest groups that he has often courted -- Catholics, environmentalists and the state's Conservative Party.
On the morning of the vote, Mr. Bruno called Mr. Pataki, told him the amendment did not have enough votes to pass and asked him if there was anything he wanted to do. "He said he was satisfied with whatever the result might be and wasn't going to get involved in interfering," Mr. Bruno later said.
The amendment was defeated, 41-19.

Rev. Tom Grey (Photograph by Associated Press)
