HEADLINE: Absent Arab Peace Partners

 BODY:
The first weeks of 1997 brought clear evidence that the political leaders and people of Israel are ready to push ahead with the next moves toward building a Middle East peace. So too are the Palestinians and their leader, Yasir Arafat. The question now is whether Egypt and Syria have the courage and wisdom to join them.
In recent weeks Israeli troops withdrew from most of the West Bank city of Hebron. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Mr. Arafat established a pragmatic working relationship and Israel's two main parties began to bridge their differences over peacemaking. Egypt mustered little enthusiasm for all this, and Syria, as is its custom, remained coldly aloof. Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, and Hafez al-Assad, the Syrian leader, need to reassess their positions. By easing the path to regional peace, they could help bring increased security and prosperity to their countries as well as their neighbors. 
 There are some signs Mr. Mubarak may recognize that the peacemaking effort in Israel has reached an important new point. After weeks of urging Mr. Arafat to stiffen his bargaining position on Hebron, Cairo switched gears at the last moment and contributed to the final compromise. Yesterday, Mr. Mubarak met Mr. Netanyahu at the World Economic Forum meetings in Davos, Switzerland, and encouraged expanded peace efforts. But that is not enough. Egypt's largely negative role in the Hebron talks, along with an ugly anti-Israeli campaign in the Government-influenced Cairo press, has badly strained relations with Israel.
Mr. Mubarak apparently concluded last year that the new Israeli Government intended to freeze peacemaking efforts indefinitely. Since then Cairo has turned away from its earlier helpful role as a diplomatic bridge between Israel and other Arab countries. Instead, it has seemed intent on promoting Egypt's Arab leadership role at Israeli expense.
This may serve Mr. Mubarak's domestic political purposes, but it has damaged Egypt's standing with Israel and with the United States. Cairo has also lost touch with the more realistic positions of Jordan and the Palestinians. Egypt should recognize that as the first Arab country to make peace with Israel, its natural leadership role is to lead the way to a wider regional peace.
Syria is now the focus of the Clinton Administration's efforts to build on the Hebron agreement and will be high on the agenda of President Clinton's meetings in Washington with Mr. Netanyahu and other Mideast leaders over the next few weeks. It has never been clear whether Damascus actually wants to reach a comprehensive peace agreement with Israel or simply feels a need to assure Washington it is prepared to pursue negotiations. But talks between Israel and Syria have been suspended for nearly a year, and with progress resuming on the Palestinian front, President Clinton has committed himself to make a new push to get peace talks resumed.
Mr. Netanyahu has been less willing than his Labor predecessors to talk about returning the occupied Golan Heights to Syria in exchange for full diplomatic and economic ties and reasonable security provisions. He also rejects Mr. Assad's unreasonable insistence on binding him to informal understandings reached between Syrian representatives and negotiators from the previous Israeli Government.
Still, Israel seems prepared to reopen talks with Syria that could also include discussions of the Israeli military presence in southern Lebanon. If Syria made a show of good will by acceding to Mr. Netanyahu's plea to restrain Hezbollah units in Lebanon from their attacks on Israeli positions, progress on other issues could follow.
While Egypt and Syria worry about maintaining their leadership roles in the Arab world, they risk being left behind by political and economic forces that are reshaping the region. At some point they may find it impossible to catch up.

HEADLINE: Top Institutions Heat Up Drives For Arts Funds

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
Though it has not been officially announced, the New York Public Library is embarking on a $430 million capital campaign to refurbish its structures, expand its programs and create a new $12 million humanities center, the largest fund-raising drive in the library's 102-year history.
The library is not alone. Spurred by a soaring stock market, huge increases in the number of wealthy patrons, tax incentives and the need to keep pace with new technology, several of New York City's leading cultural institutions are also planning to raise, or have already begun raising, tens and hundreds of millions of dollars. Campaigns for capital funds and endowments by institututions including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art and Carnegie Hall are without precedent in scale or ambition, say arts experts, fund-raisers and donors. 
 At the same time, the campaigns' impact on smaller arts groups in New York City is being fiercely debated within the arts world. Spokesmen for some groups said they feared that the campaigns, coming at a time of reduced public support for the arts, might further diminish money available for smaller organizations.
"There is a just a finite amount of money out there," said Norma P. Munn, who heads the New York City Arts Coalition, which represents small as well as larger institutions.
But a majority of experts said the campaigns would invigorate the city's aging cultural infrastructure and produce a resurgence of the arts in New York unparalleled in recent history, a boom that would benefit smaller and large institutions alike.
"We've entered a period of institutional excitement comparable only to that which occurred after the Civil War until World War I when several of the city's great civic and cultural institutions were built," said Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., the city's former Corporation Counsel. "We are on the verge of another huge leap in the city's cultural life, a new renaissance."
Michael I. Sovern, president emeritus of Columbia University and president of the Shubert Foundation, agreed. Larger institutions, he said, tend to compete for funds against one another, not against small ones. "The effect of these campaigns," he said, "is to increase the size of the philanthropic pie."
The competition itself, said Glenn D. Lowry, the director of the Museum of Modern Art, spurs ever greater giving. "It seems counter-intuitive," said Mr. Lowry, whose museum is planning to announce a multimillion-dollar capital and endowment campaign later this year. "But that is the psychology of philanthropy, which is different from the psychology of commerce."
While universities and hospitals are accustomed to waging virtually permanent capital campaigns, said Elizabeth McCormack, a senior board member of two major foundations and an adviser to the Rockefeller family, she could not remember a time when so many of the city's cultural institutions had initiated major capital drives. "The danger is that they will all go to the same people for funds," she said. But so far, she noted, astonishing sums were being given, from wealth controlled not just by a few families but in many hands.
Charitable giving has steadily risen along with the number of the city's new millionaires, who have tripled in number in the past decade, according to Treasury Department figures. The Metropolitan Museum of Art, for example, which has already raised $240 million of its three-year-old $300 million campaign, has received gifts of $1 million or more from 60 donors.
Giving to the New York Public Library, which is supported by both public and private funds, reflects the breadth and depth of support for an institution that includes 87 libraries spread over 130 miles, a collection of 54 million items and 14 million reader-visits a year, including an average of 40,000 city children who come to the branch libraries a day. In addition to the 29 donors who have given the library $1 million or more and the trustees, who have pledged $100 million, some 42,000 "Friends" gave between $1 and $1,250 last year, of whom 20,000 donated between $40 and $125; some 15,000 supporters gave $100 or less. Contributions in all categories, but especially from the "Friends," have risen steadily.
Paul LeClerc, the president of the library, said his institution had no choice but to begin its ambitious "Second Century Campaign." "If we fail to expand and refurbish," he said, "we risk betraying Ben Franklin's commitment at the founding of the American library movement to bring the book, and now the database, to all people, free of charge."
The city's cultural needs are immense. The library alone plans to raise $145 million for capital expenditures at the main library on 42d Street and its branches, $100 million for technological improvements and $185 million to increase its endowment and operating expenses. Computerizing and digitizing essential research documents, that is, scanning images or texts and converting them into digital formats that can be called up and sent electronically, is hugely expensive, Mr. LeClerc said.
A centerpiece of the new campaign is the creation within the library of a $12 million Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers, which Mr. LeClerc hopes to make a hub of humanities scholarship and discourse. The center will occupy renovated space made available at the main library by the transfer of the library's vast collection of science and business books last year to the new Science, Industry and Business Library branch, known to library aficionados as "Sibl."
Mr. LeClerc said that making the collections available through computer technology, a challenge faced by virtually all the city's cultural institutions, is also expensive. "It costs $4 to $8 to digitize one slide of a painting or a page of a book," he said. "Digitizing 'Moby-Dick' costs $4,000; digitizing the research library collection would cost $8 billion."
The library, like so many of the city's great cultural buildings from the turn of the century or even those built in the 1960's, now requires extensive renovation. Renovating the main library alone will cost more than $50 million, he said.
Faced with similar needs, more than half a dozen major cultural institutions have already begun, or will soon unveil capital drives. They include the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which in 1994 announced a $300 million campaign; Carnegie Hall, which has raised $70 million of its two-year-old, $75 million campaign, including $15.3 million last Tuesday night from its gala tribute to Isaac Stern; the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which has raised $14.5 million of an eight-year, $70 million campaign started in 1992, and the Whitney Museum of American Art, which has raised 83 percent of its $40 million campaign from the museum's trustees and may now increase its campaign goal to $45 million. The Museum of Modern Art, the New York City Opera and the American Museum of Natural History are all considering campaigns to raise funds.
"Everybody is doing it," said Betsy Gotbaum, the executive director of the New-York Historical Society, which has decided to defer a campaign until her institution is on firmer financial ground. "I would also hope for a time when there is slightly less competition," she said. But few foresee such a time soon.
Most arts experts attributed the proliferation of capital campaigns to the strong economy and rising stock market. "You go hunting when the ducks are flying," said Leonard A. Lauder, chairman of the Whitney and of its campaign and a major donor to the museum and other New York cultural institutions. "You must raise money now as a hedge against leaner times."
Andrew Heiskell, a former chairman of Time Inc. and of the New York Public Library said: "It would be criminal not to take advantage of the current economic climate. Besides, giving is the best way to avoid taxes."
There is little doubt that tax avoidance has encouraged ever greater generosity among New Yorkers. Elliot Levine, an accountant and partner in Levine & Seltzer, which has advised many clients to form private family foundations for tax and philanthropic purposes, said that giving now has been encouraged by a provision in the tax code which, since July 1996, has permitted individuals to donate publicly traded stock at its fully appreciated value to foundations and nonprofit institutions. "But the ability to front-load a deduction at its appreciated value will expire on June 1, unless Congess extends it," he said.
Denis Azaro, the development director at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, said that the provision had been "hugely helpful" in prompting stock gifts to his institution, and that failure to extend the provision would probably mean "significant" reductions, "particularly troublesome when the Government is cutting back on arts funding."
Loren Renz, the vice president for research at the Foundation Center, in New York, said that giving to philanthropic groups by individuals and the now 39,000 private family foundations (15,000 of which were created since 1980) has risen steadily in recent years, although the tax provision now set to expire in June had expired once in 1994 "without a stampede of giving." But the economy in 1994, she added, was not as strong as it is today.
Most fund-raisers and donors agreed that private giving, no matter how generous, could never compensate for the loss of public funds, a loss that has helped prompt several medium-sized and smaller institutions to step up fund-raising efforts.
A key factor in any capital campaign, they agreed, is timing. Rita E. Hauser, a patron on the board of the New York Philharmonic, said that sometimes a campaign started in heady financial times runs into a recession, as the orchestra's did briefly several years ago. "That's when you can get into big trouble," she said. "But for the moment, everyone is very upbeat. I've never seen such optimism, or such giving."

HEADLINE: U.S.-China Textile Trade Pact Signed in Time for Albright Trip

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Feb. 2

 BODY:
A broad agreement reached by China and the United States today on textile trade is likely to further increase a sector of cross-Pacific commerce already worth billions, American officials said.
The accord, signed in Beijing today after a deadline on Friday was extended into the weekend, also clears away a politically sensitive obstacle to better diplomatic relations in time for Madeleine K. Albright to make her first visit to China as Secretary of State later this month. 
 American officials portrayed today's agreement as a breakthrough that allows American textile-sellers better access to China, in exchange for loosening restrictions on the volume of textiles and garments that China exports to the United States, its largest market.
"China has the largest share of the U.S. market and we now have a share of the China market," Rita Hayes, chief negotiator for the United States, told reporters in Beijing. "Now it is a two-way street, a level playing field."
That upbeat assessment may be aimed at Washington, where China's growing trade surplus with the United States -- $39 billion, by American estimates; $10 billion, by the Chinese count -- is becoming an issue of concern among members of Congress.
Yet calling textile trade "a two-way street," may be a bit premature. In 1996, China exported about $6.5 billion of textile and apparel to the United States, about 1,000 times the $6 million that the United States sold to China in the same category.
Ms. Hayes said that her team won a greater right to sell home furnishings, drapes and designer garments in China, but she was reluctant to describe exactly how. It is not clear how much demand exists for such items in China, even if import restrictions were actually loosened.
Of far greater importance, dollar-wise, is how much the United States will expand the quotas that have been aimed at limiting Chinese textile and apparel exports to the United States. Ms. Hayes and other officials declined to say, but suggested they would be enlarged.
Textile quotas were originally put in place to limit Chinese exports to the United States, in order to protect the higher prices charged by American textile makers and, arguably, the jobs of American textile workers. Chinese trading companies compete with each other hard to obtain quotas, which are allocated by Chinese officials who sometimes favor their friends and acquaintances.
But China's enormous production of clothing, and the seemingly insatiable consumer demand in the United States, has also led many Chinese and Hong Kong companies to find ways around American quotas, on an immeasurable scale, by mislabeling garments or shipping them through third countries. The problem has existed for years, so when the United States decided to impose penalties last September, some Chinese officials accused them of doing so simply to gain leverage in trade talks.
Many trade experts argue that textile quotas are now outdated, and some point out that the United States' membership in the World Trade Organization requires it to abandon all such quotas within 10 years anyhow.
Today's agreement, which formally takes effect in January 1998 and lasts for four years, replaces a 1994 agreement. As is often the case, the accord was negotiated in an atmosphere of down-to-the-deadline brinkmanship, with final negotiations held in a series of tense and drawn-out meetings that included two all-night sessions.
"I think this morning at the beginning we were unhappy with each other but now we have become friends," said Li Dongsheng, China's chief negotiator and a senior official at the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation. "This agreement eloquently demonstrates the common interests of the United States and China in developing trade and economic relations."
But a separate trade-related obstacle remains, since American complaints that Chinese companies are improperly transshipping some apparel through third countries, to avoid American quotas, prompted the United States to impose $19 million in textile penalities last September. Ms. Hayes said the penalties were still in effect.
That is a drop in the bucket, when compared with the $6.5 billion in textiles and apparel that China sold to the United States.
Another American trade official, Lee Sands, held two days of talks in Beijing last week to gauge the status of China's effort to join the World Trade Organization. American officials have said they will support China's application if Beijing takes steps to cut tariffs and treat Chinese and foreign companies equally.

HEADLINE: GOVERNORS LIMIT REVISIONS SOUGHT IN WELFARE LAW

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Under pressure from Congressional Republicans, leaders of the National Governors' Association today decided not to seek wholesale changes in the new Federal welfare law. Instead they issued a cautious appeal to Congress and the Clinton Administration to work with them to meet the needs of a relatively small group of legal immigrants who will lose Federal benefits.
Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a Republican, was in the vanguard of governors urging Congress to restore benefits for legal immigrants. He made a strong statement of those views nine days ago, and at the time the association seemed poised to follow his lead. But today, in the interest of getting an agreement, Mr. Pataki and a fellow Republican, Gov. Pete Wilson of California, joined other governors in supporting a compromise statement of policy. 
 The compromise came on the same day that the House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said he wanted to see how the law worked before any major changes were made.
The compromise, approved today by the association's human resources committee, expresses concern about the effects of the new welfare law on one group of legal immigrants, those who are already in the United States, but who cannot become citizens because of age or disability.
The statement as originally drafted by the staff of the association said that such immigrants "should not be barred from Federal Supplemental Security Income benefits and food stamps."
Republican Congressional leaders and conservative Republican governors objected to that wording. So the human resources committee softened the language.
The governors now urge Congress simply to "meet the needs of aged and disabled legal immigrants who cannot naturalize and whose benefits may be affected."
Their statement goes on to say that "an equitable solution to this issue could be achieved without reopening" the welfare law. Governor Wilson acknowledged that there was an apparent contradiction here because most legal immigrants will lose food stamps and Supplemental Security Income benefits unless the welfare law is revised.
Comments by Mr. Pataki and other Republican governors, like Jim Edgar of Illinois, had created expectations that the association would call for more extensive changes in the welfare law.
In the last decade, the governors association has become an influential voice on domestic social policy, and governors helped shape the new welfare law. While they welcome the transfer of authority to the states, they also worry that the law will impose financial burdens on those with large numbers of immigrants.
More than 40 percent of the law's savings, $24 billion of $55 billion over seven years, result from restrictions on benefits for legal immigrants.
That curb was hotly debated in 1995 and 1996 as the welfare bill moved through Congress. But at a news conference today, Governor Pataki said, "We were unaware of this provision."
Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, a Democrat, repeatedly expressed alarm about the likely adverse effects on states like Florida with many immigrants and refugees.
Mr. Pataki has now concluded that the law will shift $240 million a year in costs from the Federal Government to the State of New York, which intends to provide assistance for 80,000 immigrants who lose Federal benefits.
"I don't think that it's appropriate for states to have to pick up the tab," Mr. Pataki said today. "These legal immigrants are here in the United States, and their status is legal, because of the policies of the Federal Government."
In his new budget this week, President Clinton will ask Congress to restore benefits for some legal immigrants. Some Republican governors said they did not want to be seen as siding with the President on this issue or calling on Congress to reopen the bill.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, has cautioned Republican governors not to press for changes in the welfare law. And Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House Republican majority leader, said today that he saw no prospect of such changes.
Asked whether Congress would revise the law to assist legal immigrants, Mr. Armey said: "The answer is no. We will not change that." Immigrants are welcome to work in the United States, but "we do not want to encourage people to come here for benefits," Mr. Armey said on the CNN program "Late Edition."
Gov. John Engler of Michigan, a Republican who helped Congress write the new welfare law, defended his work today. "We cannot be seen to say, 'Here's the deal we negotiated a year ago, and now here are all the things we want to change in it,' " Mr. Engler told other governors.
But Gov. Gary Locke of Washington, a Democrat, said the restrictions on benefits for legal immigrants were not a trivial part of the new law. "In my state," he said, "we have a large population of legal immigrants who have paid local, state and Federal taxes. To deny them coverage is contrary to what America stands for."
Mr. Gephardt said today that Congress should see how the welfare law worked before making big changes.
"I think we ought to let the bill be implemented and then see what the actual problems are and then try to solve those problems if they appear," said Mr. Gephardt, who voted against the bill.
To date, few people have lost benefits as a result of the law. The restrictions on benefits for immigrants have not yet taken effect, and few people have reached the time limits on cash assistance in any state. Moreover, the effects of the law have been cushioned by a strong economy, which has reduced the number of welfare recipients and created jobs for many people seeking work.
President Clinton says the restrictions on benefits for immigrants are not an integral part of the law, whose main purpose is to move people from welfare to work.
Several governors who agreed with Mr. Pataki said he would have been more effective if he had worked quietly behind the scenes to put the governors' association on record in favor of restoring benefits for some legal immigrants. By holding a news conference here to publicize his concerns on Jan. 24, he shone a spotlight on the issue, highlighting a split between himself and Republican leaders of Congress.
Mr. Pataki defended his actions. He said he had been invited to Washington to discuss his concerns on Jan. 24. "We were asked to outline our feelings on this issue," he said today. "That's what we did."

HEADLINE: Hispanics Suffer Loss of Health Care, Too

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Hispanic Households Struggle Amid Broad Decline in Income" (front page, Jan. 30) does not mention the health care implications resulting from the expansion of the working poor. 
 Hispanic children are more likely than any other group to go without health insurance for at least one month during their first three years of life. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has found that Hispanics have the highest rate of diabetes and asthma, and the rate of AIDS cases is three times higher than for non-Hispanic groups.
At the same time, the number of Hispanic physicians is diminishing because of the anti-affirmative action climate and budgetary cutbacks in higher education. In California, the state with the largest and fastest growing Hispanic population in the nation, medical schools have reported a 19 percent drop in minority enrollment from 1995 to 1996.
Since minority physicians are 40 percent more likely to practice in low-income communities, it is in the country's best interest that we support them. Bilingual and bicultural physicians are a cost-effective way to provide health care services to diverse populations.
 
BRIAN I. BYRD
New York, Jan. 30, 1997

HEADLINE: Hispanics Suffer Loss of Health Care, Too;
Americans by Birth

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article highlighting the decline in Hispanic household income (front page, Jan. 30) underscores the difficulties inherent with ethnic categories, specifically with the term "Hispanic." The article notes that Hispanics "range from typically prosperous Cuban-Americans of Miami to Puerto Rican Americans, largely concentrated in New York." However, there is no such official category as "Puerto Rican American." This categorization is redundant and awkward, akin to referring to "Texan Americans," or "New York Americans." 
 This issues goes right to the heart of American identity -- in this case, a misrepresentation of the relationship Puerto Ricans have had with the United States. Since 1917, American citizenship has been granted to all Puerto Ricans born either on the island or on the United States mainland. This alone differentiates Puerto Ricans from other Hispanic-Americans, who must go through naturalization and other immigration procedures to obtain citizenship.
Citizenship clearly does not automatically translate into success or inclusion in American society, nor should it. But relegating ethnic groups into categories that implicitly denote second-class citizenship only insures the continued fragmentation of our society and the further marginalization of America's ethnic minorities.
 
LUIS R. MEDINA
Astoria, Queens, Jan. 30, 1997

HEADLINE: An Inventive Los Angeles Music Station Will Change Format, a Casualty of Radio Economics

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
Junior Wells, a Chicago harmonica legend known as the godfather of the blues, was never a regular on the pop charts. But his remake of the singer Tracy Chapman's "Give Me One Reason" in the gut-bucket Mississippi Delta blues style, his harmonica wailing over an acoustic slide guitar, was a regular on the play list of KSCA-FM (101.9) in Los Angeles.
Since going on the air in July 1994, the station's blend of acoustic, electric, pop and roots music, along with live studio performances, never broke into the top 25 in the radio rankings. But it did develop a loyal following among listeners, including Bonnie Raitt and Bruce Springsteen. 
 "It doesn't get any better than that," said Nicole S. Sandler, KSCA's music director. "If serious musicians listen to us to hear other serious musicians, then we're doing something right."
Even so, at midnight Tuesday KSCA will sign off, to be reborn a day later as the 11th Spanish-language station in the nation's No. 2 radio market. In its reincarnation, the station, now owned by Gene and Jackie Autry, will be managed by a company controlled by Clear Channel Communications Inc. That company already owns two top-rated Los Angeles Spanish-language stations, KLVE-FM and KTNQ-AM.
"If I were them, I'd do exactly what they're doing," said Bill Ward, KSCA's general manager. "But listeners are the poorer for it."
The makeover of KSCA is, in many ways, a parable for the changes sweeping the radio business. It reflects the industry's deregulation, which allows one company to control several stations in one market, as well as skyrocketing station prices and new audience demographics.
The Autrys paid $15 million in 1985 for the 600-watt station, eventually increasing its transmitting power to 5,000 watts. On Jan. 15, the Clear Channel unit, the Heftel Broadcasting Corporation, signed an option to buy the station for $112 million on Gene Autry's death. The deal is part of the Autrys' continuing liquidation of assets; Mr. Autry is 89.
"Revenue has no relationship to the purchase price," said Allen S. Klein, a ratings consultant in Encino, Calif. "The signal is the commodity. There's a chess match going on because everyone is maneuvering for the future. In order to be a player in L.A. today, you have to match the ethnic profile of the marketplace."
KSCA's mostly white, baby-boomer audience earned the station a ranking of No. 30, or 1.1 percent of the audience tuning into the 48 commercial stations in Los Angeles and Orange Counties, in the most recent Arbitron ratings. Mr. Ward said the station had been profitable since its inception as KSCA in July 1994, but it generated no more than $10 million in gross revenue, by one estimate.
But revenue is the reason KSCA's format will vanish, Mr. Klein said.
In paying such a high price for KSCA, Heftel is hoping to better exploit opportunities for selling advertising with three stations. Spanish-language advertising represents 13 percent of the region's $550 million in annual ad revenue, and the bet is it will soon start to catch up with the growing Hispanic population.
According to Mr. Klein, low-power stations are commanding high prices "to fill in weaker coverage to make sure they cover the entire market."
Since limits on radio ownership were lifted last February, a record 2,159 stations have changed hands in deals totaling $13.8 billion, according to Radio and Records, a trade paper. Among the most voracious buyers was Clear Channel Communications of San Antonio, which spent $1.2 billion in four separate group acquisitions last year. Mark Mays, a Clear Channel executive, did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
"I don't blame the Autrys," said Mr. Ward, who helped review auction proposals for the station. He said no potential bidders would commit themselves to retaining its current format and "no one came close to Clear Channel's offer."
"With prices going through the roof, larger companies aren't willing to take a chance," he said.
Steven Baker, the president of Reprise Records, went on the air last week decrying the station's loss, particularly for a stable of artists that got little air play elsewhere.
"When we go away," said Ms. Sandler, "there'll be a lot of artists who'll be homeless." 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 11, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Feb. 3 about a change in the format of a Los Angeles radio station misstated the title of Steven Baker, a record company executive who lamented the change. He is president of Warner Brothers Records, not president of Reprise Records, a Warner Brothers label.

HEADLINE: Twists and Turns in Chimp AIDS Research

BYLINE: By DAVID BERREBY 

 BODY:
IT was not easy for scientists to decide to use chimpanzees for AIDS research back in the 1980's. But as much as they hesitated to give the animals a fatal disease, researchers believed that they could console themselves with two thoughts: the chimpanzee would turn out to be a useful model for human AIDS, and the animals would come down with the disease soon after being infected, and thus would not suffer long.
Both assumptions turned out to be wrong. Years passed, grants expired and still the H.I.V.-infected chimps did not come down with AIDS. Researchers shifted to other animals. 
 Meanwhile, confined to windowless quarters and attended by caretakers in biocontainment "spacesuits," the chimps spent year after year living under conditions that were only supposed to last two or three years. Just last year, for instance, the Yerkes Regional Primate Center in Atlanta installed windows in the building where it keeps its H.I.V.-infected chimpanzees.
Now, nearly 13 years after the first infection of a chimp with H.I.V., one has died and a few others are sick, apparently from AIDS. Jerom, a 13-year-old male who was first infected in 1985, died early last year at Yerkes. Another chimp at Yerkes, a male named Nathan, received a transfusion of Jerom's blood before the first ape's death.
"We're certainly studying the effects on Nathan on a virological and immunological basis, and possibly looking at other chimps as well," said Dr. Frank Noviembre, a biologist who does AIDS research at Yerkes. "It's going to be interesting to look at what happened to Jerom and what's happening in Nathan and what possibly is happening in other chimps and try to correlate that with humans."
H.I.V. isolated from Jerom's blood was introduced into two more chimpanzees three months ago, one by injection and the other by application to her cervix. They have shown a steady decline in CD-4 blood cells, the immune cells that are attacked by the AIDS virus, said Dr. Patricia Fultz, a professor of microbiology at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, who is conducting the study. Two more chimps will be infected anally within the month, Dr. Fultz said. The purpose of the experiment, she said, is to develop a model of how H.I.V. is acquired through different mucous membranes, which will be used to test and evaluate the effectiveness of possible vaccines.
Some AIDS researchers are focusing on factors that make the virus more easily transmitted. For example, a recent paper by Dr. Preston Marx, based on work done in monkeys at a Westchester research laboratory owned by New York University Medical School, suggests that vaginal transmission of the virus is enhanced by progesterone, a hormone whose synthetic version is used in birth control pills. Such work on methods of transmission might be another area in which chimps could prove useful to researchers.
"I think we can use long-term infected animals," Dr. Fultz said.
Not all researchers are convinced that Jerom died of human AIDS, but "there's a strong possibility that the consensus will shift," said Dr. Marx, who is director of the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center in New York. "There is at least a variant of H.I.V.-1 that is causing an AIDS-like disease in chimpanzees," Dr. Marx said. "The question becomes, How different is that strain from the human strain?" The chance that larger numbers of chimpanzees could once again be used in AIDS research "has emerged," he said, "where a year ago that possibility did not exist."
The prospect that some or all of the country's 150 to 200 H.I.V.-infected chimpanzees will come down with AIDS raises a host of ethical questions. How much care, for example, should an AIDS-inflicted chimp receive? Should the animal be given AZT or protease inhibitors? At what stage of suffering, if at all, is euthanasia appropriate? If chimps with AIDS live on for decades, who will support them?
"It's a problem of economics more than anything," explained Dr. Noviembre, who said that he had not made up his mind about the question of euthanasia.
"If you have these chimps that are not progressing to disease," and another strain of H.I.V. is available that scientists want to test, Dr. Noviembre said, "but you have no other building, well, should you not do that research because you won't euthanize the chimps you have?"
He said: "When I first presented some of our results last year at a conference, I was talking to a guy from Bristol-Myers Squibb, and he said, you realize you've opened a big can of worms because the N.I.H. is about to say chimps aren't needed in AIDS research? I said, I know, but what can we do, really? We're just reporting what we're finding."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Investment Shift Cited in Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Global investments will shift from the United States and Western Europe to the developing economies of Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe in the next five years, according to a French Government study.
Of those three regions, Asia is expected to be the big winner, according to the survey commissioned by the French Ministry of Economic Affairs. Africa and the Middle East will hold little appeal. 
 Fabrice Hatem, chief of the ministry's Study Center on International Investment, said yesterday that from 1985 to 1990, the United States and Western Europe received 85 percent of the direct investment by transnational companies.
Although investment in developed countries remains high, the report predicted that Asian nations would become the "favored investment destinations among developing countries during the next five years."
Former Communist countries of Eastern Europe and Latin America offer encouraging investment prospects, the report said, because of improved economies and deregulation.

HEADLINE: Officials Protest Reduced Housing Tax Credits

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The Pataki administration has sharply redirected the benefits of a Federal housing tax credit program to upstate New York, provoking protests from city officials and housing advocates in New York City, where the program has been a cornerstone of efforts to build homes for the poor.
Adding to the dispute is an audit of the program, released last week by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, which found widespread cost overruns and inefficiencies that it said had funneled off too much money for administration and investor profits instead of housing construction. 
 Statewide, the audit said, only 29 percent of the money raised through the tax credit program had been spent on housing construction, compared with an average of 50 percent across the nation. It looked at data from 1986 until July 31, 1995.
Some housing advocates, who said the program has been administered far more efficiently in New York City, said the city's share of the credits was now being reduced just as the program was taking on a more critical role for its poorest residents.
"We are very much aware of our smaller allocation, and it is creating problems in financing projects," said Cassandra Vernon, a spokeswoman for the city's Commissioner of Housing, Lilliam Barrios-Paolil. She said city officials were in discussions with the state, hoping to have the city's share of the tax credits increased.
Housing advocates said recent changes in the allocation of Federal tax credits were particularly troublesome, at least for poor people in the city, because they have come when a severe housing shortage for people at all income levels has combined with steep cuts in Section 8 rental subsidies and other Federal programs that have traditionally provided a safety net for the poor.
"No one suggests that poor people in New York City are any more deserving than poor people in Syracuse, but there is a housing crisis in the city and the tax credit program is about all we have left," said Paul Grogan, president of the Local Initiative Support Corporation, a nonprofit housing group that has administered most of the Federal tax credits made available in the city since the Federal program began in 1986.
According to an analysis by Mr. Grogan's group, the value of the Federal tax credits used by the state has been nearly constant, about $22.6 million a year, since 1992. But since Gov. George E. Pataki took office in 1995, New York City's share of the credits has declined sharply, from $18.2 million in 1994 to $11.4 million last year, the analysis showed.
A separate analysis by Mr. Grogan's group found that about 70 percent of the money generated through its Federal tax credits had been used for housing construction, far better than the national average.
Officials of the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which controls allocation of the credits, challenged the analysis by Mr. Grogan's group, but acknowledged that under Governor Pataki, a smaller share of the Federal assistance was flowing to New York City
Harry Ryttenberg, a spokesman for the division, said the state had changed its formula for allocating the credits to conform to how the state's population is distributed, without regard to income levels. He said the reason for the shift was to be fair to other parts of the state.
During the state's current fiscal year, ending on July 1, he said 43.6 percent of the state's tax credits would be allocated in New York City, compared with an allocation to the city of more than 70 percent before Mr. Pataki became Governor.
Under the Federal tax credit program, developers of low-income housing can apply for the credits to help them finance their projects. Once assigned to a project, the credits are sold to corporations or wealthy individuals, who provide cash needed for construction and use the credits to reduce Federal personal or corporate taxes owed.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Trade Pacts By Regions: Not the Elixir As Advertised

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
When efforts to liberalize world trade stalled in the early 1980's, Washington turned its attention to opening trade on a regional basis as the second-best choice. That produced the North American Free Trade Agreement and a dozen similar pacts among other nations. And most economists, who hold that free trade is close to heaven on earth, widely applauded. The regional agreements, they argued, would not just prod reluctant nations like Japan and France to drop their opposition to open markets to global trade, but they would also help developing countries lock in free market initiatives and improve the climate for foreign investment.
But this pragmatic consensus is fraying as the Clinton Administration's drive to create preferential trade areas reaching across the Pacific and Atlantic, as well as throughout the Americas, takes on a life of its own. Some economists are no longer convinced that all roads to open markets really do lead toward the economic Valhalla of a world without trading barriers. 
 "It's time to raise the warning flag," said Claude Barfield, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington.
The latest evidence that regional trade pacts like Nafta can have harmful effects on those excluded from the zone comes from the Caribbean Basin, where a World Bank study recently warned that Mexico could grab as much as one-third of the Caribbean's $12.5 billion in exports to the United States.
But the impact could be considerably broader. An unpublished study by a senior economist at the World Bank suggests that Mercosur, the preferential trade agreement intended to eliminate national barriers at the southern end of South America, has diverted substantial trade from more efficient producers outside the region.
The result of preferential trade areas, said Jagdish Bhagwati, a Columbia University economist, has been a "spaghetti bowl of tangled, inconsistent trade standards that just can't be good for efficiency."
It's a safe bet that the doubters will not remain on the sidelines much longer. For while much-ballyhooed trans-Atlantic and trans-Pacific trade initiatives have met considerable resistance both overseas and in Congress, President Clinton is asking lawmakers for the right to pursue "fast track" negotiations toward a preferential trade area for all the Americas, starting with Chile. Moreover, some Administration officials still hope to extend Nafta to the Pacific, admitting, say, South Korea, in hope of putting pressure on the rest of Asia to join.
Every college text on international trade offers grounds to be skeptical of regional trade agreements. If, for example, Mexico trades freely with the United States but maintains barriers against imports from Japan and Europe, it may lose more from the loss of access to Toyotas and Fiats than it gains from easier access to Fords and Chryslers.
But most economists put aside such worries almost four decades ago to celebrate the creation of the European Economic Community, now the European Union. "Economic integration was seen as a bulwark against Communism," Mr. Bhagwati recalled. And while the rationale has changed, economists continued to defer to political strategists on issues of economic regionalism.
When Nafta was being negotiated, policy strategists for President George Bush and Mr. Clinton were never very serious about the argument that a regional pact with Mexico was needed to foster exports of American corn and computers. But they agreed that the pact would commit future Mexican governments to economic modernization that would reinforce the political stability of the continent. And history, they say, has proved them right: "The Mexican currency crisis in 1995 would have had catastrophic consequences" if Mexico had not been treaty-bound to keep its borders open to trade and investment, said Lawrence H. Summers, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury.
C. Fred Bergsten, the head of the Institute for International Economics, argues that the Administration still sees regional zones as advancing world trade: "The idea has always been global liberalization initiated by regional agreement."
Why, then, have many other economists grown skeptical? For one thing, they worry that President Clinton's casual but often repeated equation of trade and warfare is tilting American policy toward economic nationalism -- a kinder, gentler version of what Pat Buchanan and Ross Perot have advocated, to be sure, but still a subtle form of mercantilism that threatens to undermine efforts to knit the global economy together.
The new mantra of opening foreign markets while defending our own, they suggest, points toward a "hub and spoke" trading order in which the United States dominates numerous regional preferential trade areas, rather than a worldwide system in which the American economy is merely first among equals. Within Nafta, for example, Washington can muscle preferences for Florida tomato growers that would never pass muster with the more independent bureaucrats at the World Trade Organization.
"People have begun to wake up to the U.S. policy of pressing regional arrangements as an end in themselves," said Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan.
The skeptics are also influenced by new research examining the risk that productivity-sapping trade diversion will outweigh productivity-enhancing trade creation. In the study that the World Bank has thus far refused to release, Alexander Yeats, principal economist of the organization's International Trade Division, draws disturbing conclusions about Mercosur, the preferential trade pact linking Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Uruguay. The most- traded products within Mercosur "generally are highly capital-intensive goods which members have not been able to export competitively to outside markets," he wrote.
Arvind Panagariya, co-director of the University of Maryland's Center for International Economics, voices related concerns about the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas. Even if it would help other Latin American countries and Caribbean islands avoid excessive losses to Mexico, virtually all the gains would go to the United States, he concluded. And South American countries with high barriers against imports would risk serious losses from reduced trade with Europe.
Mr. Summers dismisses such doubts, suggesting that the Administration's aggressive pro-regionalism is a kind of policy maker's jujitsu -- one that redirects dangerous protectionist impulses into benign market-opening initiatives. "Regionalism is not just good mercantilism, it's good economics," he said.
Trouble is, Mr. Barfield of the American Enterprise Institute said, is that the argument is no longer so convincing to economists themselves.

HEADLINE: Unlock Family Planning Funds

 BODY:
Responding to pressure from anti-abortion activists, Congress has put so many restrictions on spending for international family planning programs that, according to the Clinton Administration, millions of people in developing countries are being denied access to contraceptives. America's role in population planning has thus been transformed from generous benefactor to parsimonious scold. The new Congress has a chance to turn matters around.
The United States helps to underwrite family planning programs in more than 60 countries, offering contraceptives like condoms and birth control pills and providing technical assistance to local family planning organizations, including training of health-care and family counselors and demographic research. 
 Many foreign groups that provide these services also offer information about abortions or actually perform abortions in countries where they are legal. As a matter of law and policy, no American money can be used for these purposes. That is, foreign organizations can only spend the money on contraceptives and other preventive programs. Even so, anti-abortion activists in the U.S. have managed to scare so many legislators that funding for even non-controversial birth control programs has suffered a dramatic decline, from $548 million in 1995 to $356 million in 1996.
Congress compounded the problem by putting a big chunk of this money in escrow. Only $72 million was actually released to foreign organizations last year, amounting to an effective decrease of 87 percent from the previous year. For 1997, Congress appropriated $385 million but delayed disbursement from the start of the fiscal year last October until July.
Congress promised to reconsider some of the restrictions if the Administration could show that the cuts had caused harm. The Administration now confirms that 17 of 95 overseas programs may have to shut down and that the reduced funding will result in "increased unintended pregnancies, more abortions, higher numbers of maternal and infant deaths and, of course, more births."
These arguments are echoed in a recent report from the Rockefeller Foundation. The foundation argues that family planning programs have reduced average family size and improved the health and survival of women and children, resulting in better economic and environmental prospects in developing countries.
Congress is expected to vote later this month on whether to allow the funds allotted for 1997 to be released starting March 1, instead of waiting until July. That vote is supposed to be yes or no, with no amendments. But Representative Chris Smith, a New Jersey Republican and an outspoken opponent of these programs, wants to offer a separate measure requiring overseas recipients of American money to promise not to perform abortions or give abortion counseling.
Neither the White House nor the Senate is likely to find that acceptable, leading to a stalemate that would keep the funds locked up until midyear. House leaders should ignore Mr. Smith's divisive tactics and abide by their original agreement. Worthy international family planning programs have already been punished enough. They deserve a fair vote on the merits.

HEADLINE: Dow Edges 6.93 Lower to Finish at 6,806.16

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stocks put in a mixed performance yesterday after the release of a report showing that manufacturing activity weakened last month.
The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 6.93 points, to close at 6,806.16 in a lackluster day of trading, but the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.57, to 786.73. And bond prices rose as the market reacted favorably to the economic news, sending the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond down to 6.73 percent from 6.78 percent on Friday. 
 Analysts said that many investors were already looking ahead to today's Federal Open Market Committee meeting. While few expect the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates this week, investors usually keep an eye on such meetings for any signal about the economy.
"Today's market really says very little about investors' state of mind," Alan Ackerman, an executive vice president at Fahnestock & Company, said. "I.B.M. took some of the starch out of the Dow, but the bond market performed very well."
Most of the Dow's loss was attributed to I.B.M., whose shares fell 2, to 154 7/8, in light trading. Du Pont also fell, off 1 1/2, to 108 1/8. Texaco, Exxon and Chevron also lost ground. Texaco fell, 5/8, to 104 3/8; Exxon was down 1 3/8, to 102 1/4, and Chevron fell 1/8, to 66 1/4.
The Dow's best performers yesterday were Philip Morris, General Electric and Coca-Cola, all of which have had strong runs this year. Philip Morris rose 3 1/2, to 122 3/8; G.E. was up 1 3/4, to 105 1/4, and Coca-Cola was up 1 5/8, to 59 1/2.
Broader market indexes were also mixed. While the S.& P. 500 was up, the Nasdaq composite index fell 3.80, to 1,376.05.
Several technology stocks took a drubbing yesterday, but Intel continued to rise strongly. Its shares gained 1 5/8, to 163 7/8, another high. For the year, Intel has risen 25 percent, and in the last 52 weeks, the world's largest semiconductor company is up 191 percent. That has been enough to push its market capitalization into third place among American companies, at $134.5 billion, behind G.E. and Coke.
While small-capitalization stocks -- as measured by the Russell 2000 index -- have risen just 1.9 percent this year, the Nasdaq's index of its 100 largest stocks, which include leading technology companies, has gained 11.8 percent.
On Nasdaq, Dell, Intel and Microsoft have all gained more than 22 percent this year. Apple Computer, which is in a major revamping, continues to perform dismally, however. It lost 5/16 yesterday, to 16 5/16. For the year, Apple has lost 22 percent. Apple shares have not traded this low since 1986.
Some analysts say technology stocks continue to benefit from a market that is flush with cash. Portfolio managers, the analysts say, are eager to put their money to work, and foreign investors are hoping to participate in one of the longest bull runs in history. Consequently they invest heavily in the best-performing stocks.
"This market's being driven by liquidity," Gail Dudack, a market strategist at UBS Securities, said. "We have a new buyer in the foreigner, and you can see his footprints when the market moves early and late in the day. That's classic foreign buying."
But Ms. Dudack, who says she has been bearish since August, warns that the market is overvalued, noting that the S.& P. 500 companies have been trading close to 20 times earnings.
In August, she said that UBS Securities trimmed its equity holdings to 45 percent from 55 percent, with 25 percent in cash, up from 15 percent. "That's the highest cash I've had since 1990," she said.
Asked whether the market has taken notice of high valuations, she added: "We've disconnected from valuation. It's going to take something that really shoots the whole Goldilocks economy full of holes before the market gets any meaningful correction."

HEADLINE: First Lady Talks of Mice and Men on 'Rosie' Show

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
"This is getting too nice," Oscar the Grouch finally grumbled on "The Rosie O'Donnell Show" today, after Hillary Rodham Clinton had finished warbling about "goin' steady," and chortling about getting kissed on the cheek by Tom Cruise, and showing off a picture of herself in ponytail and pink poodle skirt at a White House 50's party in the arms of "my handsome husband."
Mrs. Clinton amply demonstrated today the quality that her old friends and White House aides universally ascribe to her: complexity. On the same day that she made her confectionary appearance on Ms. O'Donnell's syndicated show, which was taped last week, she delivered a speech at a development conference here, declaring: "Microcredit is an invaluable tool in alleviating poverty, promoting self-sufficiency and stimulating economic activity." 
 On the television show, Mrs. Clinton sat smiling in an easy chair, occasionally reached over to pat Ms. O'Donnell's hand and dropped the policy wonkery altogether.
"Sometimes I'll look at my husband," she confided, "and he'll be doing something really official and important, and I'll think, my gosh, he's the President, and we live in the White House."
It is safe to say that Hillary Clinton is no longer hiding her light under a bushel. Since just before President Clinton's second inauguration last month, she has made several high-profile public appearances and granted a series of interviews, generally in cozy formats.
Ms. O'Donnell is known more for warmth and enthusiastic if off-key singing than for withering interrogation of her guests. There was no talk today of Mrs. Clinton's role in setting health care policy or her success in trading cattle futures. The only frightening visitors to the Lincoln Bedroom that the two women discussed were ghosts -- not the big Democratic financial donors who, since the campaign, have come back to haunt the Administration.
"We run a very open house," Mrs. Clinton said, describing sleepovers held by her daughter, Chelsea, and her own visits from friends.
The only hint that there might be a mailed fist beneath the velvet came when Mrs. Clinton revealed which traps were used to catch mice in the White House. "We have the humane ones until we get really tired of them," she said. "Then it's: Nuke 'em."
Mrs. Clinton entered to the theme music from "The Mary Tyler Moore Show," and the two women fell quickly to chatting about their shared passion for the comedy. Mrs. Clinton said she particularly enjoyed "anytime when she would get into one of those great snits with Lou Grant. She'd go" -- Mrs. Clinton faced the audience and squinched her eyes shut -- "Ahhhhhhh!"
She added, "I feel like that all the time."
Mrs. Clinton provided Ms. O'Donnell with some White House M&Ms, explaining her weight-watching theory that "if you eat these quickly, they don't count."
There was much digging of elbows and winking at the audience. Mrs. Clinton said at one point that she would reveal that the White House had mice if Ms. O'Donnell would "promise not to tell anybody."
Mrs. Clinton seemed happy to talk about family life at the White House, showing off pictures of herself at parties, including one in which she dressed as Dolly Parton in gingham skirt and abundant blond wig. Mr. Clinton is a Dolly Parton fan of long-standing, and kept a life-size poster of her in his private bathroom when he was Arkansas state attorney general, according to the biography "First in His Class," by David Maraniss (Simon & Schuster, 1995).
Among syndicated talk shows, Ms. O'Donnell's program is second only to Oprah Winfrey's in popularity, drawing an average of 5.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen Media Research.
Those viewers were treated today to the First Lady's rendition of "The Telephone Hour," a number from "Bye Bye Birdie," which Mrs. Clinton performed in as a girl.
She perhaps punned by accident, when, in describing how a teacher ordered her to lip-sync during the performance, she referred to the musical duo Milli Vanilli. "I was the original Milli Vanilla," she said.
"I can't carry a tune at all, not even in the shower," she confessed.
But Mrs. Clinton launched into the song anyway, trading lines with Ms. O'Donnell like a couple of Pink Ladies from another musical, "Grease," which starred Ms. O'Donnell during part of its Broadway run.
"Did they really get pinned?" Mrs. Clinton inquired in song. "Did she kiss him and cry?" She finished laughing along with the audience, and exchanged a high-five with Ms. O'Donnell.
Mrs. Clinton closed out her 40-minute appearance with a chat with Oscar the Grouch, who, nervously fingering the edge of his trash can, confessed to a crush on the First Lady. "You have brains," he said. "Grouches like that."
Mrs. Clinton kissed Oscar -- though not on the lips, as he has none -- and presented him with what she called "real honest trash from the White House," including a coffee filter.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing and Design Links Are Encouraged

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
New York City's failure to link its designers and manufacturers is costing the city jobs and marketable products, a new study says. To solve the problem, the two sectors should create a design center and a trade council, and foster more communication, the report suggests.
The work, by the New York Design/Production Project, is a joint effort of the Municipal Art Society, a nonprofit group dedicated to urban design and planning, and the Industrial Technical Assistance Corporation, a nonprofit organization seeking greater manufacturing productivity. The report, follows a six-month survey of design and manufacturing capabilities. 
 To be released tomorrow, the report is meant to strengthen the bond between designers and manufacturers and enhance New York's status as a design hub.
The city may be missing an important chance for growth, the report says.
It gave examples of missed opportunities, including one of a sign designer working for a New York architect who ordered $50,000 worth of stainless steel signs from Toronto, while there are 80 companies in New York that supply architectural metal work. And some major merchandisers, the report said, are more familiar with Far East producers than those in New York.
The report, "Designed in New York/Made in New York," does not quantify just how much money New York may be losing, but it does list a number of concerns about the lack of communication.
Some steps to remedy the situation are already planned, though, including a symposium tomorrow to discuss the report, an exhibit mounted by the Municipal Art Society to profile local products and a manufacturers' database called NYConnect, to be developed by the Industrial Technical Assistance Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed as Some Traders See Pressures to Halt Its Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday, reflecting growing nervousness over whether the leading industrial nations would act to halt the currency's rise at their meeting in Berlin this weekend.
Traders said the dollar was supported by more evidence of a healthy American economy and by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's reaffirmation that the Clinton Administration favored a strong dollar. 
 Nonetheless, the will among traders to bid the dollar higher was noticeably absent for the first time this year, and some used the opportunity to lock in profits from the dollar's strength. In January alone, the dollar rose nearly 5 percent against the Japanese yen and more than 6 percent against the German mark.
Traders said concern that the Group of Seven leading industrial nations -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, Italy and the United States -- might take action to stop the dollar's ascent played a major role in the market's behavior. The group is holding a two-day meeting, starting Saturday.
In New York yesterday, the dollar cost 121.68 yen, up from 121.38 yen on Friday. The dollar cost 1.6400 marks, up from 1.6383. The pound reached $1.6189, up from $1.6007.
The dollar's mixed showing began in Asian dealings, reflecting the impact of official Japanese comments that suggested that Japan would seek help from its Group of Seven counterparts to stop the dollar's appreciation against the yen.
The dollar showed further weakness as an indirect result of strength in the mark and the Swiss franc, partly because of new doubts whether Europe's efforts to establish a single currency in 1999 would remain on schedule.
George Soros, the financier who has often been successful speculating in currencies, told the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, over the weekend that he was skeptical of the single-currency plan. Kenneth Clarke, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, also repeated his doubts about the plan.
The dollar began to strengthen in American trading after the bond market rallied when the National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly report on the economy depicted moderate growth and little inflationary pressure.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
U.N. Plaza Hotel Is Back on Market

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Amid a surge in tourism and growing demand by investors for New York City hotels, the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday brought one of the city's choicest business assets, the 427-room United Nations Plaza Hotel, back onto the market following a failed attempt to sell it in 1995.
The hotel is considered a centerpiece of the Mayor's campaign to sell off city assets, particularly those that cast it in the role of landlord or property manager. It occupies about a fifth of the space of the United Nations Plaza, a complex of two 39-story towers across the street from the United Nations at First Avenue and 44th Street. "The Mayor has always said the city should not be in the hotel business, and this is an excellent time to sell," said Charles Millard, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. 
 J.P. Morgan, the city's financial adviser, was to begin circulating documents spelling out the terms of the sale today among several large international hotel concerns, including Hyatt International, which already has a management contract to operate the United Nations Plaza complex. People close to the transaction said the city hopes to receive several bids by the end of March. Mr. Millard declined to say what price the city was seeking. Although the United Nations Plaza has been consistently profitable since it was built -- the first tower in 1975, the second in 1983 -- its sale is complicated by its complex ownership structure, which involves the city and the United Nations Development Corporation, a separate legal entity.
 THOMAS J. LUECK

HEADLINE: South Korea's Growing Pains;
Despite a World-Class Economy, a Nation Senses Decline

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
During the dirt-poor years after the Korean War, South Koreans were exhorted to extend the lives of pencils by attaching sticks to stubs that had become too short to grip.
Four decades later, the Seoul Education Office is reviving the slogan. "It's time to grasp the used-up pencils again," it said in a recent newspaper advertisement that called on students and their parents to "take the lead in saving our economy." 
 "Let's turn off the lights, even a single lamp, and save water, even a single drop," the ad said. "Let's correct the habit of showing off by wearing expensive clothes or using imported stationery."
Such penny-pinching might seem out of place in a nation of 45 million people that is now the world's 11th-largest economy, with a per capita output that has quadrupled in the past decade to more than $10,000.
But though it has performed an economic miracle, South Korea is now gripped by a deep unease about its future. Economic growth is slowing, the stock market is near a four-year low, the Korean won has sunk to its lowest exchange rate against the dollar in a decade, and the trade deficit has more than doubled in the last year. Banks are hobbled by bad debt, businesses are strangled in red tape, and wages are soaring, weakening industrial competitiveness.
Suddenly, it seems to Koreans, the era of fast growth is ending, endangering hopes that their country will make the leap from industrialization to a high-technology economy on a par with the United States and Japan. The sense of crisis has been punctuated by two events in the last month -- a nationwide strike in reaction to a new labor law that threatens job security, and the stunning collapse of Hanbo Steel, flagship of the nation's 14th-largest conglomerate, under nearly $6 billion in debt and a cloud of corruption.
"Most people don't think it's a cycle but that structurally something is wrong," said Kim Pyung Koo, a professor of economics at Sogang University in Seoul. "South Korea is being sandwiched between fully industrialized economies and less developed, low-cost economies like China."
In fact, though, some of the gloom is unwarranted. Yes, the pace of growth has faltered from 9 percent two years ago to an expected 6 percent this year, but that is still more than twice as fast as expected growth in the United States. And while a recent newspaper editorial was headlined "Soaring Unemployment," the jobless rate it lamented was 2.4 percent, a figure most other countries can only dream of.
Moreover, some problems are cyclical. One reason for the surging trade deficit, for instance, is that prices of computer memory chips, which make up 16 percent of South Korea's exports, have collapsed to a fifth of their levels a year ago because of oversupply, not because South Korean companies are losing competitiveness. The fall of the Japanese yen in the last year has made Japanese products more competitive, hurting South Korean exports.
What is happening is that South Korea's economy is maturing. And the development model the country has used -- heavy Government direction of business, tightly closed markets, export-led growth and the funneling of resources to industry at the expense of consumers -- is running out of steam, just as it is in Japan, where the model was first perfected.
The Government has announced plans to embark on economic changes -- deregulating the financial system, opening markets, chipping away at the power of the family-owned conglomerates known as chaebol as well as at lifetime employment, seniority-based pay and other workplace practices that seem ill suited for a more competitive age.
But the changes so far have been gradual and sometimes half-hearted, just as they have been in Japan. And some critics say that the Government of President Kim Young Sam seems adrift. Rather than taking bold measures, they say, it is offering half-measures or symbolic gestures, like exhorting against the consumption of expensive foreign goods.
The issues at the heart of South Korea's economic malaise are such serious ones as:
*A quadrupling of wages since 1987, a faster rise than in other Asian "tigers" like Taiwan and Singapore. That has forced a mass exodus of light industries, such as shoe manufacturing, to lower-wage countries in Asia. Such a migration is now starting for cars, electronics and other heavier industries as well.
*Banks weighed down by bad debts and a lack of business acumen that stems from their longtime role as little more than agents of the Government, funneling loans to favored industries run by chaebol. Bribery of Government officials and bankers by businessmen wanting loans is common.
*A near-monopoly of credit by the chaebol that has allowed them to expand so fast that industry is swimming in overcapacity. It has also frozen out the sort of small entrepreneurial companies that in the United States have often been the pioneers in new technologies. Additionally, South Korea lacks the base of small, nimble parts suppliers that undergird the success of Japan's manufacturing giants. "Korea's industrial structure has an Arnold Schwarzenegger upper body on Woody Allen legs," said Stephen E. Marvin, head of research at Ssangyong Investment & Securities Company.
*A current account deficit, the broadest measure of trade, that more than doubled in 1996, to about $23 billion. Part of the problem is the dearth of small companies and the technological laggardness that force South Korea to import Japanese components and production machines for the cars, videocassette recorders, computer chips and ships it makes.
Now, the need for financial reform seems most urgent. With the financial system nearly closed to foreign capital, interest rates exceed 12 percent and the economy is starved for cash, said Park Ungsuh, president of the Samsung Economic Research Institute. Companies typically take six months to pay bills, meaning that smaller firms live from hand to mouth. "Stronger corporations survive; weaker ones simply collapse," Dr. Park said.
The Kim Government has lifted some restrictions on bank lending and raised the ceiling on foreign ownership of a South Korean corporation's stock to 20 percent from 15 percent. The President has promised further sweeping changes in the bloated financial sector, but since that would lead to mergers and layoffs, most analysts do not expect drastic action with a presidential election coming up at the end of the year.
One potential sticking point is that if banks are to be strengthened, it might be necessary to end the ban on chaebol ownership of them. But that would only strengthen these conglomerates that many people believe are already too powerful.
Once again President Kim appears to be vacillating. He came into office in 1993 pledging to force the conglomerates to concentrate on a few key businesses. But the Government then permitted the Samsung Group to enter the automobile business (though it did block the entrance of Hyundai into steelmaking).
On Mr. Kim's watch, in fact, the share of gross national product accounted for by the 30 largest chaebol actually rose, to 16.2 percent in 1995 from 13.5 percent in 1992, according to the Korea Economic Research Institute.
Some Government policies strike some analysts as silly or self-defeating. The push to use pencils down to the nub and other clarion calls to frugality -- like requesting that nightclub owners stop serving imported whisky and that vacationers stop spending so much on foreign travel -- are unlikely to have the desired effect of cutting the trade deficit and might only produce charges of protectionism by South Korea's trading partners. Besides, far from being profligate, South Koreans have one of the highest savings rates in the world.
The Government has taken one decisive move to raise the country's competitiveness: a new labor law that makes it easier for companies to lay off workers and tame breakneck growth in wages. But that has led to labor strife, and many economists think the move was unnecessary.
In many cases, companies are offering bonuses to workers, particularly higher-paid managers in their 40's and 50's, to retire "with honor," though it is usually anything but. News reports and television dramas characterize these humbled men as "fathers with bowed heads."
The seniority system, in which everyone's wages advance together with years of service, is also starting to give way to merit pay, a concept that does not sit well in a nation that prides itself on egalitarianism.
"I don't necessarily like the Wall Street system either," said Milton S. Kim, president of Ssangyong Investment & Securities, referring to the huge salaries paid to Wall Street stars. "But if our market is opening up and Morgan Stanley and Goldman, Sachs are poaching our best people, what choice do I have?"
For all South Korea's travails, other fast-growing nations of Asia, where export growth and economic growth have slowed in the last year, are in the same boat. And for South Korea, at least, the boat isn't about to capsize.
In most industries now at the core of the Korean economy -- steel, shipbuilding, cars and electronics -- the major rival is Japan, where wages are much higher. South Korea can still sell products that are less expensive, if lower in quality, than the Japanese.
"Korea is midpriced, midtech capital and intermediate goods," Mr. Marvin of Ssangyong Securities said. "Midpriced, midtech goods are exactly what China needs, it's what Eastern Europe needs and Latin America needs."
Some analysts are even hopeful that the forces of global competition and deregulation will force the chaebol to reform on their own. The Ssangyong Group, for instance, is now negotiating to sell its money-losing automobile business to the Samsung Group, so it can concentrate on areas like cement and oil where it is stronger.
Sakong Il, a former finance minister who is now chairman of the Institute for Global Economics, a Seoul research organization, said that, amid all the economic turmoil, South Koreans must accept that they are moving a notch up the international economic pecking order. That means, he noted, they cannot expect the breakneck growth of old.
"It's like you're doing 80 miles per hour and suddenly you have a speed limit and have to drop to 60," Dr. Sakong said. "You have to get used to it."
