HEADLINE: In Address to Governors, Lott Opposes Medicaid Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Even while pledging to work with President Clinton in a bipartisan spirit, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said today that he opposed Mr. Clinton's proposal to set firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending. He also said there was little money available to fix the new welfare law in ways sought by the President.
Mr. Lott told the National Governors' Association that he agreed with its position on Medicaid, adamantly opposing a limit on Federal spending in the program. Governors fear that such a limit would shift costs to the states, which already pay 42 percent of Medicaid costs nationwide. 
 "I never have liked the idea of a per-capita cap," Mr. Lott said. "Your policy statement is right on target."
To be sure, Mr. Lott said, "we're going to have to find some ways to control the increasing cost of this program," which finances health care for 37 million low-income people. But neither he nor the governors specified how that should be done, except to say that state officials should be given more control over design of the program.
Since its creation in 1965, Medicaid has been an open-ended program, providing health insurance to people who meet eligibility criteria set by Federal and state laws. While preserving the entitlement, Mr. Clinton would, for the first time, impose a firm limit on Federal Medicaid spending to guarantee that per-capita Medicaid costs rise no faster than the nation's per-capita economic output.
In the budget he announces this week, Mr. Clinton will also ask Congress to restore food stamps and disability benefits for some legal immigrants who lose such assistance under the new welfare law, which he signed on Aug. 22.
Vice President Al Gore, in a speech to the governors today, said that "it is just plain wrong" to deny benefits to legal immigrants who "work here, live here legally, pay taxes, even serve in the military." Referring to the immigrants' plight, he said: "It needs to be addressed. And it can be addressed without 'opening up welfare reform.' "
Governors of New York, Florida, Illinois and other states with large immigrant populations have sought such relief, and the governors' association is poised to adopt a cautiously worded resolution calling on Congress to meet the needs of legal immigrants who are too old or disabled to become citizens.
Rahm I. Emanuel, a senior adviser to the President, said, "We're pleased to see bipartisan agreement that the restrictions on benefits for immigrants are extraneous to the welfare law and welfare reform."
But Senator Lott said that "it would be very hard for us to come back and open up" the welfare law. "If you open that barn door, a lot of horses will run out," he said, alluding to the desire of Democrats to change other parts of the law.
Mr. Lott promised to work with the governors but said that even their proposal to restore benefits for a limited number of immigrants would erode the savings achieved by the new law. "You're talking about taking away maybe a quarter of what we had in terms of savings in our welfare bill," he said. The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the law would save the Federal Government a total of $55 billion over seven years.
Mr. Clinton met with governors at the White House this morning. After the meeting, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a Republican, said he welcomed the President's effort to restore benefits for some immigrants. Asked if Republicans in Congress would accept the idea, Mr. Pataki said: "It's going to be part of the totality of the budget negotiations. I hope that, as the process moves forward, they would accept it."
Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, a Democrat, said the President recognized that there would be "a lot of resistance" to his proposal on benefits for immigrants. But, Mr. Chiles said, the President indicated that "as we get further down the line, it might be part of an overall settlement."
On Medicaid, the governors spoke with one voice. Gov. Pete Wilson of California, a Republican, said the President's proposal to set a limit on Federal Medicaid spending would not be acceptable unless states had much more power to design the program and control costs.
"If the Medicaid cap is not accompanied by the kind of flexibility that would allow us to set eligibility, benefit levels and the rate of reimbursement for health care providers, then it virtually handcuffs us," Mr. Wilson said.

HEADLINE: Reports Show U.S. Economy Is Moderating

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Several economic reports issued today suggested that growth was moderating, which could persuade the Federal Reserve to refrain from raising interest rates at its meeting this week.
A survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management found that the previously robust manufacturing sector had slowed in January, while a Commerce Department report showed that construction spending fell in December for the first time in six months.
The Commerce Department also reported that personal incomes outpaced consumer spending in December. Consumer spending represents two-thirds of economic activity.
The reports suggested that Fed officials, when they meet on Tuesday and Wednesday, would not feel compelled to raise interest rates to keep the economy from overheating and igniting inflation.
"The reports seem to show the economy is not accelerating as we begin the new year and, in fact, may be showing more moderate growth," said Lynn Reaser, an economist with Barnett Banks in Jacksonville, Fla.
"The message seems to be that the economy is doing well, but price pressures in general are going to remain relatively subdued," she added.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin agreed, telling reporters as he left a Congressional hearing that the economy was "on the path of solid growth and low inflation."
On Friday, the Government reported that gross domestic product rose at a 4.7 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, considerably more than economists had expected, but that inflation remained subdued.
Today, the purchasing managers said their index, based on a survey of corporate executives, fell to 52 points in January from 53.8 a month earlier. While indicating a slowdown in the growth rate, a reading of more than 50 suggests that the industrial economy continues to expand.
"The manufacturing sector grew, but less rapidly in January than in December, with production and new orders indicating a decline in growth," said Norbert J. Ore, head of the association's survey panel.
A price index in the purchasing survey rose for a second consecutive month, but Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said the increase chiefly reflected higher natural gas prices and a temporary pickup in copper and aluminum prices.
"We don't see much inflation risk in the report," he said.
The Commerce Department said construction spending on residential, nonresidential and government projects fell seven-tenths of a percent in December, holding the year's growth to 4 percent, little changed from the 3.8 percent gain of 1995.
Analysts attributed some of the drop at the end of the year to severe weather in the West, but predicted that residential activity would level off this year and nonresidential construction would grow more slowly.
In December, spending on single-family homes -- more than 25 percent of total outlays -- slipped three-tenths of a percent, the fourth consecutive decline. Spending on apartments and condominiums fell 1.4 percent.
Spending on nonresidential projects like factories and office buildings fell 1.9 percent. Government outlays were down 1.3 percent in December, the first drop in four months.
The department also reported that personal incomes shot up eight-tenths of a percent in December, the biggest advance since an increase of nine-tenths of a percent last June. As a result, incomes in 1996 were 5.5 percent higher than in 1995.
At the same time, personal spending rose five-tenths of a percent, after gains of four-tenths of a percent in November and nine-tenths of a percent in October. For the year, it was 4.6 percent higher than in 1995.
"The income data point to buoyant demand in the first quarter," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "While consumer spending in the fourth quarter was quite strong, consumers kept some of their money in the bank."
"As a result, the savings rate actually increased, to 5.4 percent," he added. "This additional liquidity will buffer the effect of high consumer debt loads and keep spending growing at 2 to 2.5 percent in the first few months."

(Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: January Car Sales Up 2.3%; Foreign Makers Have Surge

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Foreign auto makers showed the biggest sales gains in the American auto market last month as the strong dollar continued to help them offer generous lease deals and low prices.
Among the nine auto makers reporting January results today, sales rose 2.3 percent from a year ago. Foreign auto makers reporting results today saw their combined sales rise 10.9 percent, while the combined sales of the two American auto makers reporting results today dropped a tenth of 1 percent. 
 The Chrysler Corporation said today that its sales rose 1.5 percent in January, while the General Motors Corporation's sales dropped nine-tenths of 1 percent in the month, compared with 1996. The Toyota Motor Corporation and the Ford Motor Company are expected to announce their January results on Tuesday, with Toyota's January results expected to be strong and Ford sales to be flat or up slightly.
Japanese manufacturers reporting results today saw their January sales rise 11.1 percent. American executives said that the strong dollar had given their competitors an unfair advantage.
The Japanese have the ability to offer subsidized leases, "cut prices and provide incentives because the yen is as weak as it is," said Steven A. Torok, Chrysler's executive director for sales and marketing operations. "The industry over all is concerned about it; we don't think it is a fair situation."
The dollar has risen 52 percent against the Japanese yen and 20 percent against the German mark from its lows in April 1995. A strong dollar makes it cheaper for auto makers to ship cars here from overseas, and even to build cars here with a lot of imported parts. Their profits on the substantial numbers of cars built in the United States become stronger when they are translated into yen or marks.
Foreign auto makers have lured customers by passing on some of those gains, leaving prices unchanged at the beginning of the current model year on Oct. 1 while American auto makers raised their prices roughly in line with inflation.
The weak yen amounts to a "tailwind on a very good set of products," said Nicholas J. Colas, an auto analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston.
The market share of Toyota, Honda, Nissan, Mazda and Mitsubishi combined is likely to reach 21 percent in January, Mr. Colas said. Their share of the United States market in January 1996 was 19 percent, while the Big Three had 73.5 percent.
Among foreign auto makers, the Honda Motor Company and Subaru, a unit of Fuji Heavy Industries, set the pace, with Honda's sales up 21.1 percent and Subaru's up 24.5 percent. Trailing them today were the Nissan Motor Company, up 10.7 percent, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, down 4.2 percent, and Isuzu Motors Ltd., down 28.5 percent.
But with overall sales up just 2.3 percent so far, today's results could provide yet another reason for top Federal Reserve officials to keep short-term interest rates on hold when they begin meeting in Washington on Tuesday. Some dealers said past labor strife hurt their sales. Raymond J. Scarpelli Sr., a Chevrolet and Oldsmobile dealer in Antioch, Ill., complained of a shortage of sport utility vehicles, like the Chevrolet Blazer, and pickup trucks, a lack he attributed partly to G.M.'s four strikes over the last year.
"Sales have been pretty good; if we had more inventory, they would be fine," Mr. Scarpelli said.
Ronald L. Zarrella, head of G.M.'s North American vehicle sales, service and marketing, predicted that overall sales would pick up during the second half of the year. "Late model-year changes and a strong January a year ago affected the percentage comparison this January," Mr. Zarrella said.
G.M.'s competition might soon be crimped. Toyota's ability to ship more cars and trucks to the United States over the coming month might be affected by a fire at an auto parts factory in Japan today. Marjorie Schussel, a Toyota spokeswoman, said the company would have to close eight of its nine assembly plants in Japan on Tuesday for lack of brakes and clutches normally produced at the factory.
She added that Toyota hoped production would be back to normal by early next week, and that there would be no immediate effect on assembly operations in North America or car shipments here. The parts factory belongs to the Aisin Seiki Company, which is 22.6 percent owned by Toyota.
Many auto makers reported slower truck sales after a year in which buyers could not get enough pickups, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans. G.M.'s truck sales fell 6.7 percent, while its car sales rose 4 percent.
Chrysler said its car sales rose 8 percent while sales of its mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickups fell 1 percent. Mr. Torok said the decline might have been related to weather.
That was the conclusion reached by Kelly Rooney, sales manager at Hampden Dodge in Springfield, Mass., who said that pickup truck sales were slower than a year ago. "The lack of snow has kind of set it back a little," he said.

HEADLINE: Job Search Lures Mexicans to Far Corners of U.S.

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: GUADALAJARA, Mexico

 BODY:
Few places in the United States would seem less likely to attract Mexican migrant workers than Alaska.
But that's where Dr. Martin D'Giesecke Garcia headed after the peso devaluation wiped out his medical practice here and tripled his mortgage payments in 1995. He boarded a plane for Kodiak Island, where in a growing community of Mexican workers he found a job gutting cod on a trawler in the Bering Sea. 
 Rigoberto Ayala provides another example of how Mexico's migrant labor patterns are changing. Starting in 1984, Mr. Ayala traveled back and forth each year between his hometown, 50 miles east of Guadalajara, and Stockton, Calif., where he harvested sugar beets. But since 1991 he has been traveling instead to Hawaii to work in the pineapple and cane fields.
Over the decades, millions of Mexicans have headed from Guadalajara, and the vast agricultural region that surrounds it, north to traditional work sites like the lettuce fields of California, the cattle ranches of Texas and the restaurant kitchens of Chicago. But now Mexican workers are finding new frontiers, responding to a demand for cheap labor in parts of the United States far from its southwestern border.
Growing numbers are traveling not only to Alaska and Hawaii, but also to cultivate mushrooms in Pennsylvania, build offices in Atlanta, milk cows in Idaho, harvest tobacco in North Carolina, slaughter pigs in Iowa, manicure lawns in New Jersey, wash dishes in Michigan, clean fish in Maryland and bale hay in South Dakota.
As Jorge Durand, a University of Guadalajara demographer who has studied migration since 1980, put it: "Mexican workers are traveling to new areas, crisscrossing the United States in ways that break dramatically with traditional patterns."
The dispersion of Mexicans into virtually all 50 states has increased since 1986, when passage of the Immigration Reform and Control Act legalized the status of more than two million Mexicans who had been working in the United States without documents. The law enabled them to migrate to remote regions without risking arrest, Mr. Durand said.
The trend has accelerated since the 1994 peso crisis, when many middle-class Mexicans began traveling north in search of work, demographers say. Those more affluent workers have found it easier to migrate into areas previously unexplored by their countrymen, because many have tourist visas and can afford air travel.
Not counting migrant workers, there were 6.7 million Mexican-born people living in the United States in 1996, according to Jeffrey S. Passel, a demographer at the Urban Institute in Washington, a nonprofit research organization. The number of workers who travel seasonally between Mexican homes and American work sites can be only roughly estimated, he said, but it may be as large as two million. Mexicans are now America's largest immigrant group by far, he added, constituting 28 percent of the foreign-born population, up from 7 percent in 1970.
"There's an identifiable presence of Mexicans in all kinds of states where there's never been any before," Mr. Passel said recently at a Mexican Government-sponsored conference on Mexican migration. "This has really exploded since the 1990 census."
Ever since Mexican migration to the United States became institutionalized during World War II, when a Government-sponsored program brought thousands of farm workers north, California has been Mexicans' main destination.
But since California's economy plunged into recession and anti-immigrant fervor spread, many Mexicans have gone elsewhere, said Rudolfo Figueroa, a diplomat who directs a Mexican Government program to provide health, education and other services to Mexicans in the United States.
The new patterns are reflected in the increasing number of Mexican Government offices in the United States. They now total 54, many in unexpected places like Charlotte, N.C., and Buffalo. Since 1991, four consulates have been opened, in Orlando; Portland, Ore.; Santa Ana, Calif., and Douglas, Ariz.
"Many Mexicans who worked in California have gone east and north," Mr. Figueroa said, "provoking the growth of new Mexican communities in the center of the country and on the eastern seaboard. And that's obligated us to expand into areas that we didn't work before."
A consular office has also opened in Honolulu to serve the estimated 15,000 Mexicans now working in Hawaii. One is Mr. Ayala, 31, who said in a telephone interview from Maui that after migrating between his hometown of Ocotlan and Hawaii for six years, he had obtained American residency documents.
But he is not sure where he will settle. "That depends on whether I get married in Mexico or Hawaii," he said, adding that he had been laid off by a sugar company and was unemployed.
Anchorage has a new consular office as well. Some 20,000 Mexicans have settled in Alaskan cities including Juneau and Fairbanks, where most work in hotels and restaurants. There is also a contingent on Kodiak Island, where many clean fish in the 11 canneries, said Hugo Abel Castro, the Mexican consul in Seattle, who supervises the Anchorage office.
Among the Mexicans traveling to Alaska to work have been many unemployed teachers, lawyers and other professionals. One was Dr. D'Giestecke, who concluded after reading help-wanted advertisements placed by American fishing companies in a Mexican magazine in 1995 that a trip to Alaska might help him pay off his debts.
There were five American crew members on the Kodiak Island fishing vessel where he found work. The three others were Mexican: one experienced seaman, an agronomist and an accountant. The latter two had lost their jobs in Mexico.
After cleaning cod on the open sea for two months, Dr. D'Giestecke returned home with about $3,000 in savings, which helped him reduce his debts, he said. Will he go back?
"If I need money I will," he said. "I have friends in Alaska now."

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Warns Rhode Island About Water Quality Efforts

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency has warned Rhode Island that unless the state increases its spending on water pollution programs, the Federal agency might revoke its authority to carry out the Clean Water Act.
If that were to happen, the E.P.A. would assume the responsibilities. 
 John P. DeVillars, the E.P.A.'s northeast regional administrator, issued the warning on Friday in a letter to Gov. Lincoln C. Almond. He said his "grave concern" over how the state had been carrying out the Federal law was "caused by a history of cuts and the disturbing prospect of future reductions."
Peyton Fleming, a spokesman for the state's environmental agency, said today that state officials were still considering how to respond to Mr. DeVillars.
The Federal agency has never revoked the authority of a state to issue and enforce water pollution permits. The agency is reluctant to do so because it lacks the staff and budget for direct control of these permits, which are at the heart of the nation's water pollution control program. The permits regulate all discharges of waste water into streams, lakes and oceans.
If the E.P.A. were to take back control of water quality permits from Rhode Island, the Federal agency would administer current permits, applicants for new or renewed permits would have to apply to the E.P.A., and the agency would become the primary enforcement authority.
Those functions were all assigned to the state in 1984, as is the standard practice under the Clean Water Act.
But in recent years Rhode Island has repeatedly reduced the budget at the state Department of Environmental Management, and staffing dropped by more than 100 employees, or 17 percent, in the last two years. Additional cuts are planned.
The full-time staff of state employees who manage waste-water permits has dwindled to just two people, Mr. DeVillars complained. Meanwhile, permits have expired for most of the largest treatment plants that discharge waste water in the state, and many permit holders are temporarily discharging more pollution than their permits allow while they improve their treatment plants.
"All of this has resulted in closed shellfish beds, loss of habitat and lost recreation opportunities in many of the state's surface waters," Mr. DeVillars said.
Save the Bay, an environmental group in Providence that works to protect Narragansett Bay from pollution, said today that the state already was losing Federal matching grants because it was not spending enough on the environment.
"This situation is outrageous," said Curt Spalding, the group's executive director. "A clean bay is worth millions of dollars to the regional economy."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Imported Cars Show Gains, But Domestic Models Ebb
Foreign auto makers showed the biggest sales gains in the American market last month as the strong dollar continued to help them offer generous leasing deals and low prices.
Seven foreign auto makers saw their combined sales rise 11 percent, while those of General Motors and Chrysler dropped by a tenth of one percent. [Page D4.]
 
Reports Indicate Slowing of Growth
The Commerce Department said construction spending fell seven-tenths of a percent in December, holding the year's gain to 4 percent, in one of several reports that suggested a moderation of economic growth. A survey of corporate purchasing managers found that manufacturing slowed in January. And personal income outpaced consumer spending in December. [D4.] 

The signs of slowing growth buoyed the Treasury market. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.73 percent from 6.78 as expectation of an immediate increase in interest rates by the Fed diminished. [D17.]
 
Trading was lackluster in the stock market, however, with the Dow industrials dipping 6.93 points, to 6,806.16, though the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index eked out a gain of 0.57 point, to 786.73. [D10.]
 
Another AT&T Executive Quits
In yet another high-level defection from AT&T, Richard W. Miller, the chief financial officer and an architect of the company's three-way split, resigned unexpectedly. [D7.]
 
Shanghai Trader Is Sentenced
Two years after Shanghai's leading securities firm was brought down by a trading scandal, authorities said the central figure in the case, Guan Jinsheng, who was the firm's president, had been sentenced to 17 years in prison. [D8.]
 
Taco Bell Plans Account Review
Taco Bell said it would review the creative part of its account, with billings estimated at $200 million. The review, which will include the incumbent shop, Bozell Worldwide, is the second for Taco Bell in less than three years, and comes as a number of fast-food companies are making changes in their agency rosters. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
 
Icahn Names Aides for RJR Fight
Carl C. Icahn named his investment advisers for a proxy assault on RJR Nabisco, reiterating his intent to seek an immediate spinoff of the company's food businesses. [D7.]
 
Perils of Privatization in Venezuela
The future of Viasa, Venezuela's flagship, and currently grounded, airline will hinge on a vote by its workers on a $55 million rescue effort. In the process, one of its major owners, Iberia Air Lines of Spain, has learned hard lessons about investing in troubled foreign enterprises. [D8.]
 
China Eastern Airlines, the nation's most profitable and best-managed airline, is becoming the first to list American depository receipts on the Big Board. But investors looking to climb aboard will find it hard to confirm the flight plan. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Producer of On-Line Guide Is Sold
In a continuing consolidation of start-up Internet companies in Manhattan, WP Studio, which produces a popular on-line guide to the city called Total New York, has been bought by a company that is 80 percent owned by America Online. [B6.]
 
A Hard-Driving Software Chief
Charles B. Wang, head of Computer Associates International, is among the most intriguing billionaires likely to be encountered in a board room or on a basketball court, where he displays the competitiveness and adaptability that have been critical to his success. [B1.]

HEADLINE: Barry Offers Budget (Some See Politics Between Lines)

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. today unveiled his proposed budget for 1998, a $3.3 billion spending plan that he said would balance the capital's budget for the first time in years while still invigorating the local economy.
But while the budget proposal maintains the effort to eliminate thousands of municipal jobs, as required by the Federal control board that oversees city finances, the head of the control board and the city's chief financial officer questioned the way the balance would be achieved. 
 In addition, some elected officials said they viewed the budget as a strong indication that Mr. Barry intended to seek a fifth term in 1998 -- an inference Mr. Barry strongly discouraged at an afternoon news conference at which he presented the budget.
"I'm not even thinking about 1998," he told reporters. "If you're thinking about that, you're thinking about something that I'm not thinking about."
To prevent overspending, Mr. Barry proposed for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 that the city renegotiate its debt repayment, a step he said would preserve $50 million for programs that have already been slashed in efforts to restore the city to solid financial footing.
Arguing that cities restructure debt all the time, Mr. Barry said that if the control board did not approve the step, he would be forced to cut millions more from the Police Department, the Fire Department and the public school system, even though the control board has made public safety and education its highest priorities. By terms of the 1995 law that created the control board, an agreement on a budget must be reached by the Mayor, the City Council and the board before the budget is sent to Congress for approval.
"This community has already taken a tremendous amount of pain and suffering," Mr. Barry said. "I suggest very strongly that they do the restructuring."
But Andrew F. Brimmer, the chairman of the control board, said that restructuring the debt to solve short-term problems "is not a good idea" and that he had told Mr. Barry as much in a recent conversation.
Anthony A. Williams, the city's chief financial officer, said stretching out the city's debt "only drives us deeper into junk bond status."
"But I'm up here in the anchor booth," he added. "I'm not an elected official who has to come up with $50 million, $50 million in real dollars."
Mr. Barry said the main thrust of the budget was economic development throughout the city but with a special emphasis in areas that are east of the Anacostia River, which Mr. Barry said he would designate as an empowerment zone, with $10 million in plans to create tax incentives for businesses, job training programs and assistance in home buying.
While these areas are typically the poorest in the city, they have also formed Mr. Barry's political base through the years, including 1994, when he returned to office for a fourth term after serving six months in prison for drug possession. His widest margins of votes came in Wards 7 and 8, which are entirely east of the Anacostia.
Some elected officials said that by focusing his economic development plan on those wards and on Ward 6, which straddles the river, Mr. Barry was laying the groundwork for a re-election campaign.
"By this budget, was he kicking off his re-election efforts? That did occur to me," said Kathy Patterson, a City Council member who represents the wealthiest section of the city. "Anyway, it was the chitchat in the halls today among some of my colleagues."
Charlene Drew Jarvis, the president pro tem of the City Council, said, "I always read the budget, such as one proposed by the Mayor, as a political document."
But Mr. Barry flatly denied he was playing to his political base, asserting that the budget was intended to attract business to all corners of the city. He defended efforts to help Anacostia because of its high unemployment and lack of neighborhood businesses.
Referring to Ms. Patterson's ward, where the unemployment rate is 2.3 percent, he said, "If the economic indicators were as severe in Ward 3 as they are in Ward 8, I'd do it there."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Signs Growth Is Slowing Lift Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday for the fifth consecutive session, as investors saw further evidence of moderate economic growth.
Reports yesterday on manufacturing and construction spending were weaker than forecasts, bolstering expectations that Federal Reserve policy makers would leave interest rates unchanged when they meet today and tomorrow. 
 Still, many investors expect the Fed to raise short-term rates in the coming months, and the market's focus is now on the Fed's next policy meeting in March.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 18/32, to 97 30/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.73 percent from 6.78 percent on Friday.
Bond prices received a lift after the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of January manufacturing fell to 52 from 53.8 in December, lower than the 53 reading expected by most economists. The report suggested that manufacturing was expanding at a slower pace.
Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities Inc., said the report helped dispel any remaining fears of an overheated economy. But she noted that a reading of 52 in the purchasing managers' index was still consistent with solid growth.
Other data also supported bond prices. Construction spending fell for the first time since July, dipping seven-tenths of 1 percent in December, after a four-month surge. Analysts, however, noted that construction-related expenditures were up a solid 4 percent last year, a further sign that business confidence remains buoyant.
And data on personal income and consumption for December came in about as expected. Personal income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, while consumption posted a decent gain of five-tenths of 1 percent.
Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc., said the market was able to rally because market participants continue to discern a silver lining in every economic report.
For example, he said, the purchasing managers' report reaffirmed the view that the economy was slowing after the strong advance reported last week in fourth-quarter gross domestic product.
"The next test of this rally will be the 6.50 percent yield level on the long bond, with anything out of the 6.50 percent to 7 percent range a major signal for the bond market," Mr. Guild said.
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data, said, "It is important to remember that investors still have a lot of cash and that foreign investors still like Treasury securities for their yield pickup and the fairly strong dollar."
At the Treasury's bill auction yesterday, rates fell sharply on better-than-expected demand, particularly for the three-month maturity. The average discount rate for the three-month issue was 5 percent, down 6 basis points from last week. The six-month bill also improved, dropping 4 basis points to 5.08 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Following are the results of the Treasury auction:

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Inflation at 2.2% In European Union

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The European Union's annual inflation rate was 2.2 percent in December, down from 3 percent a year earlier and matching the low set in November, the trade bloc said yesterday. The November rate was the lowest since the 15-nation group began compiling the figure in 1983. 
 The inflation rate in December compared with 3.3 percent in the United States and two-tenths of a percent in Japan.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
More Jobs, More Seekers

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
New York City's unemployment rate rose to 8.7 percent in December, up from 8.5 percent in November, the State Department of Labor said. The state's unemployment rate also inched up, climbing from 5.7 to 5.8 percent over the same period.
James Brown, a labor market analyst for the department, attributed the increase to the growing number of job seekers encouraged to look for work because of a gradually improving economy. 
 Meanwhile, business activity in the New York metropolitan area started 1997 at a more sluggish pace after a surge in December, according to a report for the New York Purchasing Managers Association. The purchasing managers' index dropped to 61.9 in January from 72.9 the previous month. A reading above 50 indicates growth in the local economy.

HEADLINE: Unneeded Lab Chimps Face Hazy Future

BYLINE: By DAVID BERREBY 

DATELINE: HOLLOMAN AIR FORCE BASE, N.M.

 BODY:
Hands and feet gently slapping concrete, Chandra and Shasta come loping down their sunny outdoor run at the complex operated by the Coulston Foundation here. The little apes do not look up when the black triangle of a Stealth fighter knifes across the sky above them and banks for a landing at a nearby runway.
Born on this base, where the Air Force used chimpanzees four decades ago to establish that human beings could go into space, they are used to jets and buzzards wheeling high above thorny tumbleweeds. 
 But these toddling one-year-olds will probably live until the middle of the next century, and what their long futures will be like -- where they will live, who will care for them, and what experiments, if any, will be performed on their bodies -- are questions at the center of a mounting political and ethical dispute.
They are among the newest members of a captive population of about 1,800 chimpanzees in American biomedical research, each of which costs roughly $15 a day to maintain throughout a 50- to 60-year life span. Many of these chimps, including most of the 150 to 200 that have been infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, are essentially unemployed -- no longer used in experiments.
When they are not caged alone temporarily for an experimental protocol, most of the chimpanzees pass their time in small groups housed in cell-like cages at a handful of sites around the country. Many play with toys and devices designed, as required by Federal law, to make their lives more interesting. Some watch television. "They like programs about chimps, like National Geographic specials," said Kate Baker, enrichment coordinator at the Yerkes Regional Primate Center a federally financed center in Atlanta that holds some 200 of the apes. "They like shows on how to use tools. And they like to see people arguing, so Oprah is a show they like."
The surplus has helped some researchers, like Bill Hopkins, who has plenty of animals available for his Yerkes study of traits like handedness and the ability to recognize faces in chimps.
It has also encouraged speculation about odd-sounding projects that might not be considered if biomedical chimps were regarded as scarce -- a proposal, for example, to use female chimps as surrogate mothers for bonobos, a closely related and much rarer species of ape, or a suggestion that a few chimps be fed meat tainted with mad cow disease, to see if they can become infected.
The debate over the "chimp surplus" extends from the top levels of the National Institutes of Health -- whose director, Dr. Harold E. Varmus, appointed a committee of experts last year to issue recommendations on the handling of the research chimp population -- to Congress, which is being lobbied in this session with at least two proposals for legislation. "It's a tough issue," said Dr. Thomas Insel, the director of Yerkes. "A lot of us are looking to this committee for direction." The chimp committee, after conducting hearings last fall, is expected to produce a report for Dr. Varmus this spring.
The surplus is partly a result of a surprisingly successful drive begun in 1986 by the health institutes to breed chimps for AIDS research (wild chimps have not been imported for research since 1975). The result was a chimp baby boom that unfortunately exploded just as researchers were deciding that infected chimps apparently did not come down with AIDS, and hence could not be used as animal models for the disease. (Now, it seems chimps can contract AIDS.) Nowadays, most chimps in biomedical centers are on some form of birth control, though the breeding program has not been completely stopped. The health institutes, for example, have renewed a grant for breeding at the Coulston Foundation.
The surplus also derives, though, from a cultural change. The very similarity to humans (genetically, they are more than 98 percent identical) that makes chimpanzees attractive subjects for research on H.I.V., hepatitis, malaria, respiratory diseases, Lyme disease and parasites has also made their use troubling to more and more people, including some scientists.
"There is a generational change in researchers," said Frans de Waal, an ethologist who studies social behavior in two bands of especially lucky chimps that live in large toy-filled enclosures at Yerkes. "The younger generation doesn't feel the same right to do whatever they please."
The chimpanzee also has powerful allies in animal rights organizations, some of which have inside sources of information in the primate centers as well as excellent access to news organizations and politicians. Using chimps now invites especially intense scrutiny and it is expensive. "My concern is that a lot of people have been put off from studying chimpanzees in particular because they feel it's too expensive and they'd get beheaded," said Joe M. Erwin, a specialist in captive chimps who has run sites for both zoos and biomedical centers. "Ending all research is just terribly threatening to the animals. What we really need is to find more support."
The surplus debate has attracted groups, like the Great Ape Project and the British-based People Against Chimpanzee Experiments, which sense a chance to remove large numbers of chimps from biomedical research for good. Proposed legislation in Congress, for example, would create a system of "sanctuaries" to which research chimpanzees could be "retired."
At the other end of the philosophical spectrum is the Coulston Foundation here, which is lobbying the New Mexico Congressional delegation for a bill that would direct millions of Federal dollars to support research on aging in chimpanzees. "We don't have enough chimps for what we want to do," said the president of the foundation, Dr. Frederick Coulston.
Dr. Coulston, an expert in toxicology and infectious diseases, likes to taunt his opponents with talk of using the apes as living blood and organ banks. "I wouldn't even rule out in the far future having a colony of chimps providing blood for human transfusion," Dr. Coulston said in an interview in his Alamogordo office near the base. "How many chimps do you want? You can raise them like you do cattle. In 10 years you could have half a million."
Dr. Coulston is a garrulous moon-faced man of 82 who is disconcertingly prone to assert that various commonly feared chemical agents are not dangerous at all.
"Lead?" he remarks. "Lead levels in the blood have no effect on intelligence." Or, "DDT is one of the greatest inventions of mankind, and it doesn't thin bird eggs." He is widely respected in this small town (with 150 employees, he is the surrounding county's third-largest employer) and carries himself as one who is seldom contradicted.
His Coulston Foundation, spun off from his privately held manufacturing company, Coulston International, in 1993, will soon control more than 650 chimpanzees, by far the largest colony of captive chimpanzees in the world. The foundation has about 400 chimps now, and about 100 are being added from the Laboratory for Experimental Medicine and Surgery in Primates, a Westchester research lab owned by the New York University Medical School. (The Coulston Foundation agreed to take over the Westchester facility last year, but the deal appears to be stalled.)
Coulston also has a contract with the military to care for the Air Force's 150 chimpanzees. The foundation runs the state-of-the-art three-year-old chimp center at Holloman, as well as a complex of its own in nearby Alamogordo.
Dr. Coulston has long worked with the military, dating back to his work on malaria during World War II, and he was in charge of the Air Force's chimpanzee colony from 1970 to 1980, when he ran the complex for the contractor, Albany Medical College.
In May 1995, a clause in a military appropriation bill that would have given Coulston ownership of the Air Force chimpanzees was killed after Dr. Jane Goodall, the researcher and advocate for chimpanzees, objected. The bill passed instead with a provision requiring the Air Force to solicit bids for a contract to care for the apes. The California-based animal-rights group In Defense of Animals is among those that will compete with Coulston for the contract when it is opened for bidding later this year, says Eric Kleiman, the group's research director.
Dr. Coulston has long been reviled by animal rights groups as a throwback to days of cruel and indifferent treatment of apes. "His record of animal care is extremely troubling," said Suzanne Roy, president of In Defense of Animals.
Some of the accusations have led to action by regulators. For example, on Oct. 31, 1993, three chimpanzees at Coulston-run buildings died after being left overnight with a space heater that malfunctioned, raising the temperature in their holding area to more than 140 degrees Fahrenheit. The Department of Agriculture charged the Coulston Foundation with violating the Animal Welfare Act in connection with that incident, and last summer Coulston settled the charge and others by paying a $40,000 fine and agreeing to make improvements that would prevent recurrence.
More recently, on Jan. 21, an 11-year-old male chimp named Jello, recently arrived from the N.Y.U. laboratory, died after being sedated for transfer from one cage to another. In Defense of Animals promptly filed a complaint with the Agriculture Department charging that a necropsy had revealed that the ape had food in its trachea. "Everybody knows before you tranquilize an animal you fast him," Mr. Kleiman said. He said the group's account was based on reports of three sources within Coulston, whom he would not name.
The foundation responded with a statement denying that Jello had been fed and calling the allegation a "distortion of fact." It said Jello died after another chimp, which was not yet fully sedated, "placed his foot and some of his weight" on the back of Jello's neck. "This was seen to restrict Jello's ability to breathe," the foundation said, pledging that "the final results of the necropsy confirming the cause of death will be available at a later date." The statement, echoing a complaint often made by researchers, also denounced "irresponsible accusations by people such as these (I.D.A.) who would not know how to take care of a chimpanzee." Indeed, Mr. Kleiman concedes, he has never seen a chimp in the flesh.
It would be wrong to describe all of Coulston's detractors as animal rights absolutists and disgruntled former colleagues. "We get snubbed at conventions," said Elaine Struthers, Coulston's enrichment coordinator. "When I go and hear myself disparaged by somebody who has never been to our facility, I have to think, this is exactly what a scientist is not supposed to do: show contempt prior to investigation."
Some primatologists, though, say they are puzzled about what use Coulston could have for chimpanzees in the current climate. "I'm amazed that anybody would be trying to expand a chimp empire," said Dr. Insel, director of the Yerkes primate center. "He's interested in having more, and more chimps and we're interested in having fewer and fewer."
And others express anxiety about the Coulston Foundation's holding such a large proportion of the chimpanzees used for research. "Can the health of the U.S. population come to depend on a private entity?" asked Dr. Thomas L. Wolfle, director of the Institute for Laboratory Animal Resources at the National Research Council and study director for the health institutes' chimp committee. Coulston Foundation research on chimps is 55 percent federally financed biomedical research and 45 percent testing for pharmaceutical companies and other private enterprises, said Don McKinney, the foundation's spokesman.
On the other hand, Coulston also has plenty of defenders among researchers. "Coulston is an approved facility for primates," said Dr. Patricia Fultz, a microbiologist and a member of the chimpanzee committee. "I've been there and the facilities for the chimps that I have there are just as good elsewhere. I don't think there's a big difference."
In any event, Dr. Coulston is the major player in the chimp debate, even though he declined to join the health institutes' chimp committee because "he said it was a witch hunt," Mr. McKinney said. (The other side has a similar disdain for the panel. Ms. Roy, the president of In Defense of Animals, said the committee "has no one who is a true advocate of chimpanzees on it." )
The debate leaves many different experts and animal advocates speaking the same words -- "surplus," "retirement" and "sanctuary," for example -- but differing about precisely what the words mean. While there are plenty of chimpanzees that are not being used for current experiments, Dr. Wolfle said, there may yet be a shortage of young chimps that have not been infected with anything.
"There is no doubt that there are chimps in biomedical centers that are not being used in research," he said. "On the other hand, if you ask investigators if they have trouble finding the chimps they need, they will say yes." All of which means that many researchers' idea of a sanctuary is a place in which chimps might live relatively pleasant lives, but from which they can be taken as needed for research.
Dr. Preston Marx, a researcher at the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center in Manhattan, who ran the Holloman chimp colony before the Coulston Foundation took over, favors maintaining a few large colonies to keep research chimps in optimal conditions -- housing them in large groups, which are not only better for the animals' mental health but also, according to a recent accounting at Yerkes, cost about $10 a day instead of about $16 for caging. These central colonies, he proposes, would run "a shuttle system, where, for instance, a chimp might go to a medical facility for six months, be involved in a protocol to test a new vaccine, and then go back home."
Such a sanctuary is anathema to animal rights advocates. In Defense of Animals, which says it will raise money and open its own sanctuary, envisions "something like an old folks home," said Mr. Kleiman, where no research or medical procedure would be conducted that did not directly benefit the chimp involved. The sanctuary bill, which is endorsed by Dr. Goodall, compromises by allowing scientists to pick the animals to be retired but then insisting that retirement be absolute and final.
Demand for chimpanzees in research has been cyclic in the past, said Dr. Wolfle of the health institutes' chimp committee. And the situation may change yet again. There was talk of a chimpanzee surplus in the early 1980's, after hepatitis research had slowed, for example. Then AIDS touched off a new boom cycle. And, in fact, part of the committee's mission, Dr. Wolfle said, is to determine how many chimpanzees need to be held "in reserve" for the next infectious agent that comes along.
One thing about which practically all biomedical researchers agree, though, is that experiments on chimps will probably continue at some level. "We do all have this feeling that there will be another two or three infectious agents coming down the pike," Dr. Fultz said. "So we're going to need chimpanzees in the future."
"There is a need to do this research," says Dr. Marx. "I'm not always sure we have the right, but we do have the need."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 7, 1997, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Tuesday about chimpanzees that are no longer needed for biomedical research misidentified the New York county in which the Laboratory for Experimental Medicine and Surgery in Primates is situated. It is Orange, not Westchester.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher, Helped by Official's Remarks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar overcame nervousness among traders about the coming meeting of industrial countries and ended mostly higher yesterday, helped by remarks from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin.
Broad weakness in the German mark also helped strengthen the dollar. Traders sold marks on renewed optimism that Europe's plan for a single currency in 1999 would proceed as scheduled. 
 Although the dollar did not breach its four-year intraday high of 122.78 yen reached Jan. 29 and a two-and-a-half-year high of 165.15 marks reached Jan. 28, it closed near the higher end of its recent trading range and was broadly stronger for the first time in a week.
"Every attempt to push it down has been met by continued buying interest," said Ben Strauss, a currency trader at Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York. "Everything for the moment is playing into the hands of a stronger dollar."
In New York, the dollar cost 122.44 yen, up from 121.68 yen on Monday. The dollar cost 1.6457 marks, up from 1.6400. The pound cost $1.6207, up from $1.6189.
The foreign exchange market remained preoccupied with the weekend meeting of financial ministers and central bankers from Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States -- the so-called Group of Seven.
Japanese officials have said they will seek help at the meeting to stabilize the yen, which has weakened sharply against the dollar.
In Tokyo, Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka acknowledged the difficulty of weakening the dollar when it was supported by a strong United States economy. Later in Washington, Mr. Rubin asserted that exchange rates should not be a tool of American trade policy.
Mr. Rubin's remarks in particular helped the dollar. Traders said they were significant because American auto makers have been complaining that the cheaper yen was hurting their competitiveness.
The mark's weakness partly reflected the impact of a labor agreement reached in Italy with metal workers after six months of negotiations. The results helped resurrect optimism that Italy would be able to participate in Europe's single currency scheduled in 1999.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Firm Dollar And Rate Bet Lift Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices closed higher yesterday for the sixth consecutive session as investors remained optimistic that the Federal Reserve would leave interest rates unchanged. Fed policy makers concluded the first day of a two-day meeting yesterday.
A strong dollar kept foreign investors interested in Treasury securities, despite signs of strength in a report on new-home sales. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32, to 97 14/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.70 percent from 6.73 percent on Monday.
The Commerce Department report on new-home sales showed that sales fell 1 percent in December. But the drop was less than expected, and sales for November were revised to show a gain of 17.7 percent, up from a gain of 14.2 percent that was reported originally. The data suggested to some market participants that strength in the economy might be understated.
Traders said they were surprised by the resiliency of the market after the new-home sales report. But analysts said that the continued rise in the dollar bolstered prices. A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities attractive to foreign investors.
Still, investors moved cautiously in advance of the conclusion of the Fed's policy meeting today and the Labor Department's employment report for January, due out on Friday. Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said it was almost a given that the Fed would not raise short-term interest rates this week. The Fed's next policy meeting is on March 5, "which gives us about six weeks before the trading desks start sweating it out again," he said.
"All the news over the last five days has been good, and bond investors have only focused on the positive aspects in all the releases," Mr. Regan added. "I think the market is looking ahead to Friday's employment numbers for some sort of indication of a Fed timetable."
In the corporate debt market, the Mead Corporation and Philip Morris led a flock of borrowers taking advantage of the lowest rates in a month by selling almost $2 billion of debt securities.
Mead sold $550 million of debt in four parts through Goldman, Sachs & Company and J. P. Morgan. Underwriters priced $100 million of notes due in 2002 to yield 6.60 percent; $150 million of debentures due in 2037 to yield 6.841 percent; $150 million of debentures due in 2017 to yield 7.36 percent and $150 million of debentures due in 2047 to yield 7.58 percent.
The Philip Morris Companies sold $500 million of 10-year notes through Lehman Brothers at a price to yield 7.243 percent, while the Sherwin-Williams Company, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers, sold $400 million of debt in three parts in the public sectors and another $300 million in private sales. The three-part debt offering was priced to yield 6.28 percent for $100 million of notes due in 2000; 6.514 percent for $100 million of notes due in 2002, and 6.873 percent for $200 million of notes due in 2007.

HEADLINE: Venture Capital Discovers New York's New Technology

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Long accustomed to being overlooked in the high technology field, New York City is fast becoming a magnet for venture capital investments in start-up companies offering new-media and Internet-related services, a new national survey says.
The survey, conducted by Coopers & Lybrand and scheduled to be released today, found that the amount of money invested in New York City software, electronics and multimedia companies jumped 125 percent, to $111.3 million in 1996 from $49.5 million in 1995. The survey, which covered 600 companies, found that other economic fields received much less in 1996 than in 1995; health care companies were down 40.6 percent, and consumer goods companies 96.3 percent. 
 In all, the amount of venture capital invested in New York City increased 41 percent, trailing the national figure of 52 percent. But the totals for new-media investment show that a group of investors known to be generally cautious has increasing interest in the city's Internet related businesses.
"For decades, I've seen money leave New York, and for the first time, because New York is being recognized as an emerging technology center, it's nice to see opportunities right here," said Robert A. Fish, a partner at Coopers & Lybrand in charge of the venture capital and high-tech field in New York. "It's like, 'Hello, we're here!' "
The change can be measured in other ways, too. The number of New York conferences focusing on new-media investment opportunities for venture capital companies has increased to 25 from 5 in two years, said Stuart M. Williams, president and chief executive of Strategic Research Institute, which organizes the conferences.
The number of venture capital companies specializing in new media has grown at a comparable rate as well, said Brian T. Horey, general partner with Lawrence, Smith and Horey, one such investment firm.
In 1996, Mr. Horey's firm invested $4.5 million in Ad One Classified Network, which puts classified ads on the World Wide Web. Meanwhile, Flatiron Partners, founded last August, invested $21.5 million in three New York-area new-media companies, said Fred Wilson, a managing partner.
Surveys of venture capital investments should be looked at cautiously, since the commitment of money by a larger company does not necessarily insure success, said Larry Buchsbaum, project manager of the survey, called the Coopers & Lybrand Money Tree.
Venture-capital funds offer money for start-up companies, and if the new companies eventually issue stock, it can yield big payoffs for the investors. It is a risky proposition, for only 1 of every 5 or 10 companies backed by venture funds makes it that far, some analysts say. "It would be unfair to say that New York is at the level of Silicon Valley in terms of investment opportunities," said Alessandro Piol, managing director of Chancellor LGT Asset Management, an investment management firm.
In 1996, there was $700.8 million in venture capital investments in New York City. In the San Francisco Bay area, the comparable figure was $2.365 billion.

HEADLINE: Sales of New Homes Declined 1% in December

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Sales of new homes fell in December and an index of future economic activity rose only slightly, providing further evidence yesterday of moderating growth as Federal Reserve officials began a meeting on interest rate policy.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that sales of new homes fell 1 percent in December, a decline that was smaller than had been anticipated. 
 And the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, reported yesterday by the Conference Board, rose a tenth of 1 percent in December, after a revised increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in November and no change in October. It was the 11th consecutive month with no drop in the index. The slight gain in the December figure was about what Wall Street had expected.
Wall Street generally expects the Federal Reserve to leave interest rates unchanged when the two-day meeting of its policy making committee ends today. Recent economic data suggest that the economy is growing at a moderate pace, without signs of increased inflation.
Between the leading indicators and the housing report, "the home sales data carry a little bit more weight here; it's a surprising number," Kathleen Stephansen, a senior economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said. Wall Street had expected a decline closer to 5 percent.
"Is it a worrisome number from the Fed's standpoint? At this point, it is not," she said.
Both sets of data were in line with other reports this week, which indicated that growth in the first quarter of 1997 might slow from the 4.7 percent rate of the fourth quarter of 1996.
On Monday. the National Association of Purchasing Management index suggested that growth in the manufacturing sector slowed in January. Also, the Government reported on Monday that personal incomes and consumer spending rose in December and that construction spending fell. The moves, however, were modest and generally in line with market expectations.
The small advance in the index of leading indicators, which is intended to predict economic activity six to nine months ahead, suggested that the economy would remain under control through summer.
Of its 10 components, 4 were positive, 3 were negative and 3 were unchanged in December. The biggest positive effect came from money supply and the average factory workweek. Components hurting the index most were weekly unemployment claims and manufacturers' orders for consumer goods.
The index's December reading of 102.8 compares with a revised November level of 102.7 and an October reading of 102.5. The index operates from a base of 100, which was set in 1987.
Regarding the home-sales report, the decline in the year's final month was not enough to damage a strong year in the housing market. Last year, 756,000 new single-family homes were bought, up from 667,000 in 1995.
The yearly sales level was the highest since 1978, when 817,000 new homes were sold.

HEADLINE: American Air Pilots Offer Concessions as Labor Dispute Escalates

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
With a week and a half to go before a possible strike by pilots at American Airlines, the war of words -- or, more accurately, numbers -- heated up yesterday between the company and the pilots union.
In a presentation to Wall Street analysts, leaders of the union, the Allied Pilots Association, drew a clear line in the sand. The pilots said they were willing to make work-rule concessions worth $212 million in savings to the company over five years. The pilots' proposal also includes a 3 percent raise this year as well as in 1998 and 1999, and a 2 percent raise in 2000. 
 They also want 7.25 million stock options granted to them at $10 below market value, and to prohibit the company's American Eagle subsidiary -- at which pilots are represented by a different union and now fly only turboprops -- from flying small jets. The union said such a shift would cost their members jobs.
The pilots said their proposal would increase American's total pilot compensation costs by 8.9 percent by the year 2001.
The cost of giving them what they want, the pilots said, will most likely be exceeded by the loss of business American is going to suffer even if there is no strike; the threat alone is prompting many travelers to book on other airlines. "If American's profit slows, it won't be the result of this contract," said Adam Blumenthal, a financial adviser to the union.
The leaders of American's pilots union tentatively agreed to a contract last fall, but it was voted down by members last month. If American accepted their new proposal, it would cost the company an additional $285 million, the union said.
Chris Chiames, a spokesman for American Airlines, said yesterday that the company had not had time to study the pilots' analysis.
But, he said, "no matter how you add the numbers, the contract that they rejected, by their own admission, would have maintained their status as the best-paid pilots in the industry."
Although American and its parent company, the AMR Corporation, have generated strong profits of late, the airline has a lot of ground to make up, Mr. Chiames said. Since 1990, the company's net profit totaled $136 million, while pilots received $136 million in profit sharing, he said.
"Their talk of not sharing in the fruits of a good year is just overshadowed by the realities of their compensation and our very generous profit sharing," Mr. Chiames said. The airline also said yesterday that according to a study it had conducted, a 60-day strike would cost the United States economy $5 billion.
Kevin C. Murphy, an airline analyst with Morgan Stanley, said he saw some flaws in the pilots' analysis. For example, he said, their comparisons with other airlines did not account for the savings and flexibility that airlines like United and Delta enjoy from their United Shuttle and Delta Express divisions.
Shares of AMR dropped $1.125 yesterday, to $80.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, on a day that the stocks of other carriers also fell.
Efforts to predict the likelihood of a strike occurring are little more than guesses at this point. The pilots plan to make their presentation to the airline on Thursday. The two sides then go into so-called super-mediation talks on Monday. Under deadlines that govern such labor disputes, a strike could happen as early as Saturday, Feb. 15.
"The atmosphere is one of mistrust on both sides," Mr. Murphy of Morgan Stanley said. "Unfortunately, that is the kind of atmosphere that foments a strike."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Says 1996 Film Making in City Set Records

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Television and film production in New York City rose in 1996 to record levels for the third consecutive year, according to figures released by the Giuliani administration yesterday, though the figures in at least one category -- number of shooting days -- are in dispute.
"There is no place in the world that can match the creative vitality, spirit and energy of New York City," said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at a news conference at City Hall, where he was joined by Patricia Reed Scott, the city's Commissioner of Film, Theater and Broadcasting; the actor Michael J. Fox, star of an ABC situation comedy "Spin City," set in City Hall, and Gary David Goldberg, the show's producer. 
 The Mayor presented charts showing these statistics:
*Feature films shot in New York last year totaled 201, up from 175 in 1995 and 157 in 1994.
*Motion-picture-shooting days have risen 142 percent in three years, from 1,715 in 1993 to 4,147 last year.
*Overall shooting, for feature films, television shows, commercials, music videos and student films, rose to 21,286 in 1996 from 15,262 three years ago.
*Film production companies and crews spent $2.2 billion in New York City last year, up from $1.4 billion in 1993, an increase of 55 percent. The spending figure is linked to the growing number of feature films -- the most lucrative projects for the city -- made here.
The figures do not include pre- or post-production work. Therefore, said Ms. Scott, the amount of work generated by film projects is even larger than the figures show.
"We couldn't be happier about being in New York," said Mr. Fox, who was introduced by Mr. Giuliani as the Deputy Mayor, the character he plays on the show. "We feel like we're part of a trend."
Film production has been on the rise in New York since 1991, when a labor impasse resulted in a seven-month boycott of the city by Hollywood studios. After that, film activity in the city began to bounce back. In fact, it has been such a noticeable trend that some city residents say they are inconvenienced by the trailers, boom operators and high-powered lights that increasingly disrupt neighborhood life. Mr. Giuliani acknowledged the complaints yesterday, but said "the contribution to the city's economy more than offsets" the inconvenience.
Some of the city's figures are disputed. The claim of a record year for shooting days -- the days crews were actually filming -- does not hold up when compared with 1990. In the year immediately preceding the Hollywood boycott, the city reported 31,746 shooting days, a 33 percent increase over 1989. The high 1990 figure is attributed to a rush to film projects in New York before the beginning of the boycott.
Ms. Scott, who has been Film Commissioner since 1994, said in an interview that she did not trust the 1990 figures. She also held the post from 1983 to 1989.
Jayne Keyes, who held the position in 1990, said the numbers were accurate. "I trust my figures," she said.
Another inconsistency was in the list of films that the Mayor's office said were shot in New York in 1996. At least one on the list, "Touch," was filmed entirely on location in Los Angeles. Directed by Paul Schrader, it has not yet been released.
"Most of the post-production work was done in New York," said Stephen Peoples, Mr. Schrader's assistant.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "The Mirror Has Two Faces" was filmed on West End Avenue in May. (Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Company's Rescue Expert Once Falsified Credentials

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 4

 BODY:
William A. Brandt Jr., the turnaround specialist chosen on Monday by the Mercury Finance Company to try to salvage the troubled company's credibility with lenders, lied about his credentials in a Federal bankruptcy court in 1988.
Mr. Brandt, who was named Mercury's chief executive and president, acknowledged today that he had been found in contempt of court and fined $500 in a bankruptcy case in Milwaukee for making false claims about his education and early experience in corporate turnaround work -- the rehabilitation of troubled companies. 
 Mr. Brandt falsely testified in Milwaukee that he had obtained a master's degree from Harvard University and master's and doctorate degrees in international economic development from the University of Chicago. His actual master's degree, obtained in 1972 from the University of Chicago, is in sociology. He also falsely said that he had learned the basics of the turnaround trade as an "on and off" contract worker for the Central Intelligence Agency in Eastern Europe, the Caribbean, Washington and at the University of Chicago.
The testimony and the contempt finding were reported in February 1995 by The Pittsburgh Business Times and Journal as part of its coverage of controversy over Mr. Brandt's handling of efforts to revive the Pittsburgh Food and Beverage Company, best known for its Clark candy bars.
In an interview today, Mr. Brandt attributed the misrepresentations to a sarcastic attempt to overshadow the claims of an opposing expert witness at the end of a long, hostile day of testimony. "It had no bearing on the case and it was an incredibly stupid thing to do," he said. "There was no excuse for it and I just lost sight of where I was."
Mr. Brandt said that Mercury's board was aware of the incident and discussed it with him when he was first interviewed with others who were considered for the rescue mission.
Kathleen Connelly, a spokeswoman for the company, said that Mr. Brandt had told board members about the incident and that they had decided his experience with turnarounds was more important than the contempt citation.
While corporate officials usually must disclose criminal convictions in corporate filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, a $500 contempt fine would probably not have to be disclosed, said John C. Coffee Jr., a law professor at Columbia University and an expert in securities law.
Mr. Coffee said that reports about the contempt citation could only increase the difficulty of the task Mr. Brandt faces.
"We're talking about saving the Titanic in this case," Mr. Coffee said last night, adding that to do it, one would have to be an expert at corporate turnarounds and "have absolute credibility" to persuade banks to lend to the company.
Mr. Brandt, who is not a lawyer, has been involved in numerous bankruptcies as a trustee, receiver and consultant. His company, Development Specialists Inc., has managed or consulted for a number of financial service companies in bankruptcy proceedings.
Lawyers describe Mr. Brandt as extremely creative at devising out-of-court resolutions to corporate disasters.
Mr. Brandt's main preoccupation today was his continuing effort to obtain short-term loans to keep Mercury operating while it arranges a longer-term rescue package, the sale of assets, or, if necessary, an organized filing for protection of the bankruptcy court until its finances can be straightened out.
Mercury, which is based in Lake Forest, Ill., is the largest supplier of loans to auto buyers with credit problems. The company also has insurance operations.
Mr. Brandt, 47, replaced John N. Brincat, who resigned as president and chief executive of Mercury, after the company disclosed last week that it had overstated its profits by $90 million over four years.
The auto loan company attributed the problems to its top financial executive, James A. Doyle, and said he had disappeared. But a lawyer for Mr. Doyle said he was cooperating with Federal investigators, and on Monday, the Justice Department served Mercury with a warrant to search its financial records.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Pepsico's Profit Falls, Causing Drop in Stock
Pepsico's earnings fell 85 percent in the fourth quarter, hurt by unexpectedly large losses in the company's international beverage business and by sluggish profits at two of its three fast-food chains.
The company's stock, which had risen after the announcement of Pepsico's plan to spin off the fast-food businesses, fell on the news of the lower earnings. [Page D2.]
 
Apple Makes Small Changes at Top
Apple Computer shifted its top management, but company officials conceded that they were still not ready to say whether they would lay off more workers or sell units. [D8.] 

New Mercury Chief Misled Court
William A. Brandt Jr., the turnaround specialist chosen by Mercury Finance to try to salvage its credibility with lenders, lied about his credentials in court in 1988. [D2.]
 
More Signs That Growth Is Easing
Sales of new homes fell 1 percent and the Index of Leading Economic Indicators rose one-tenth of 1 percent in December, further evidence of moderating growth as Federal Reserve officials met to discuss monetary policy. [D4.]
 
Blue-chip stocks rose, though trading was sluggish as the markets awaited a decision on interest rates by the Fed. The Dow industrials rose 27.32 points, to 6,833.48. Nasdaq stocks were lower. [D8.]
 
Investors were also driven into stocks by the sixth straight rise in bond prices, which pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury down to 6.70 percent from 6.73. [D15.]
 
Ford and Toyota Sales Rise
Ford Motor sales rose 2.8 percent in January; Toyota's sales jumped 55.5 percent. [D4.]
 
S.E.C. Asks a Judge to Reconsider
The S.E.C. is urging a Federal judge to reconsider her decision making it tougher for investor lawsuits against companies to go forward. The judge had ruled that under new legislation to curb class-action suits, shareholders must show that corporations had deliberate intent to commit fraud. [D3.]
 
Strong Volume Growth Helps Sprint
Sprint's operating earnings rose as it posted the strongest annual volume growth in years among the top long-distance companies. [D3.]
 
True North to Expand in Europe
True North Communications said that it would acquire Wilkens International in Hamburg, Germany, which has a European ad-agency network. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
American Airlines Pilots' Demands
A war of words -- and numbers -- between American Airlines and its pilots' union heated up as the deadline for a strike by the pilots drew nearer. In a presentation to analysts, the pilots set out their contract demands. [D4.]
 
Unusual Power-Supply Arrangement
AES, a developer and operator of power plants, said GPU, which owns utilities in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, had agreed to buy electricity from AES in an unusual arrangement. The deal will enable GPU to get out from under expensive long-term contracts for power while providing it with a long-term supply of cheaper electricity. [D5.]
 
Talks on Phone Venture
Cable and Wireless confirmed that it was in talks with Veba of Germany concerning the future of their telecommunications joint venture in light of their differences about how to compete in the European market. [D19.]
 
Venture-Capital Gain for New York
New York City is fast becoming a magnet for venture-capital investments in start-up companies offering new-media and Internet-related services, a survey showed. [B7.]
