HEADLINE: THE SECOND TERM: THE OVERVIEW;
PRESIDENT, CITING EDUCATION AS TOP PRIORITY OF 2D TERM, ASKS FOR A 'CALL TO ACTION'

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
President Clinton tonight assembled the patchwork proposals of his last Presidential campaign into an agenda for his final term, issuing a "call to action" to the nation and arguing that even within straitened budgets the Federal Government could help improve education, modernize technology and provide health care.
The ideas, themes and even phrases of last year's campaign rang through his State of the Union Message tonight as Mr. Clinton strove to show how they would transcend clever electoral politics to become sound and lasting policy. 
 "Now we must rise to the decisive moment, to make a nation and a world better than any we have ever known," Mr. Clinton said in a fluid hourlong speech to both Houses of Congress. [Transcript, page A20.]
Without announcing any major Federal spending initiatives, Mr. Clinton described a "new kind of government -- not to solve all our problems for us, but to give our people, all our people, the tools they need to make the most of their own lives."
He urged Congress to balance the budget without amending the Constitution to do so, and to enact changes in the campaign finance laws by July 4. He returned often to the possibilities of high technology, envisioning a country in which the Internet "becomes our new town square" and laboratories and universities communicate 1,000 times faster than they do today.
Mr. Clinton, at the height of his popularity in opinion polls, entered the House chamber tonight to a boisterous ovation, which prompted him to thank the assembled representatives more than a dozen times before they settled down. His introduction by Speaker Newt Gingrich called forth another ovation, and 10 more thank yous.
As Mr. Clinton prepared to begin speaking, it was unclear how closely Americans would listen, since the verdict in the O. J. Simpson civil trial was pending. But with the verdict delayed for an hour, the broadcast networks devoted their full attention to the State of the Union.
Singling out two eighth-grade students seated in the gallery for a Congressional ovation, Mr. Clinton dwelled tonight on education, which he called "my No. 1 priority for the next four years." He slotted his academic proposals, most of which were announced during the campaign, into a 10-point plan for improving education and expanding its reach, by plugging classrooms into the Internet, helping schools make long-deferred repairs and increasing Federal assistance to college students.
"Character education must be taught in our schools," he said.
Mr. Clinton called for voluntary testing against national standards in reading and math by 1999, emphasizing that the standards were not to be a Federal requirement, but "a challenge to the nation."
The President urged a "new nonpartisan commitment to education," rephrasing the foreign policy mantra of the cold war to declare, "Politics must stop at the schoolhouse door."
With Mr. Gingrich and Vice President Al Gore seated behind him, Mr. Clinton pounded the air periodically with his left fist, punching once for each beat as he declared, "The state of our union is strong."
He departed from his prepared text as he discussed balancing the budget, leaning confidentially over the lectern to make an appeal for comity between the parties, and between the White House and Capitol Hill. "I know this is not going to be easy," he said.
"But I really believe one of the reasons the American people gave me a second term was to take the tough decisions in the next four years that will carry our country through the next 50 years," he continued. "I know it is easier for me than for you to say or do. But another reason I was elected is to support all of you, without regard to party, to give you what is necessary to join in these decisions. We owe it to our country and to our future."
As he did in his second inaugural address, Mr. Clinton called for racial healing, a message he underscored by recognizing several members of minority groups in the balcony.
Mr. Clinton said building "one America" was the country's most important mission.
"Money cannot buy it," he said. "Power cannot compel it. Technology cannot create it. It must rise from the human spirit."
After the speech Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, praised Mr. Clinton for a "good first step toward cooperation." But, he added, "words are nice; we're waiting for the deeds."
A close student of history eager to secure his own place in it, Mr. Clinton has analyzed the pitfalls that tripped up previous second-term Presidents. Three days after the election, he argued that a "driving agenda" was the key to success, and his aides were at pains today to present him as having seized the initiative.
Erskine Bowles, Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, said in almost the same breath that Mr. Clinton would use his speech to present "a real action plan" and "a true concrete plan of action."
Mr. Clinton was satisfied with most of the speech by late afternoon, aides said -- for him, unusually early. Freed from most of his habitual last-minute fiddling, Mr. Clinton used the time to rehearse four times and to rest. His preparation showed in a smooth, often conversational delivery, without a knitted brow or head bob out of place. The speech was interrupted 70 times for applause.
Offering the Republican response, Representative J. C. Watts of Oklahoma also steered clear of explosively partisan fare, stressing instead the values that he said he learned outside Washington.
But Mr. Watts expressed far less optimism in the potential for Government. "Our mission is to return power to your home, to where mothers and fathers can exercise it according to their beliefs," he said.
Mr. Clinton's senior aides believe that, after the Republican takeover of Congress in 1994, the President has gained the upper hand in the debate over the efficacy of Government. Rather than defensively argue that the Federal agencies under assault from the Republicans, like the Departments of Commerce and Education, should continue to exist, Mr. Clinton instead described tonight how they could be put to the best use.
But Republicans were quick to say that Mr. Clinton's speech demonstrated that their view of Government had won out.
"I am very pleased that President Clinton has so heartily endorsed the Republican agenda of a smaller, smarter Federal Government," said Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the Republican whip.
For his part, however, Mr. Clinton apparently felt confident enough in public support for Government to defend Federal financing for the arts and humanities against the perennial attacks of conservatives and deficit hawks -- though he stopped well short of calling for more money.
"The enduring worth of our nation lies in our shared values and our soaring spirit," the President said. "So instead of cutting back on our modest efforts to support the arts and humanities, I believe we should stand by them."
Surveying the international scene, Mr. Clinton urged an expansion of NATO by 1999, although he did not name the countries he would like to invite in. He called for a "deeper dialogue" with China but did not retreat from his policy of engagement.
"An isolated China is not good for America," he said. "Engaging China is the best way to work on common challenges like ending nuclear testing -- and to deal frankly with fundamental differences like human rights."
Mr. Clinton also firmly repeated his support for removing international trade restrictions.
"We must act to expand our exports, especially to Asia and Latin America, two of the fastest growing regions on earth," Mr. Clinton said, "or be left behind as these emerging economies forge new ties with other nations."
Mr. Clinton went on to make what officials said was a veiled appeal for Congressional assistance in expanding the scope of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"We need the authority now to conclude new trade agreements that open markets to our goods and services even as we preserve our values," he said.
Mr. Clinton did not linger on his economic plans at home, barely mentioning his tax cut proposals -- and not mentioning his tax increases at all. He said his budget would "provide middle-class tax relief to pay for education and health care, to help raise a child, to buy and sell a home."
Mr. Clinton's tax cuts would cost $100 billion over five years, and are roughly half of what Republicans are proposing. He did not say that he would pay for about $80 billion of his tax reductions by closing loopholes and extending expiring taxes.
Mr. Clinton explained his education proposals at length tonight, calling education "a critical national security issue for our future." But his proposals, officials stressed, were not budget busters. In all, they said, Mr. Clinton would request $51 billion for education and worker training in the next fiscal year, an increase of 20 percent from the current year. By the year 2002, that total would approach $60 billion, officials said.
Under Mr. Clinton's plan, fourth graders would be tested in reading, and eighth graders in math. But officials said the cost of the program would be minimal. The Federal Government would pay to help create the tests, officials said, and would also cover the costs for each school district of administering them for the first time.
Having long since abandoned plans for sweeping changes in the health care system, Mr. Clinton proposed more incremental steps tonight. He noted that 10 million children go without health insurance in the United States, and declared that he planned to extend insurance to half of them -- a multibillion-dollar proposal that Administration officials put no price tag on today.
Mr. Clinton also urged, as he had before, that the recently changed welfare law be amended to restore coverage to legal immigrants.
"To do otherwise is simply unworthy of a great nation of immigrants," the President said.
Even though he judged the state of the union strong, Mr. Clinton invested his message tonight with a sense of urgency.
"We must be shapers of events, not observers," he said. "For if we do not act, the moment will pass -- and we will lose the best possibilities of our future. We face no imminent threat, but we do have an enemy: the enemy of our time is inaction."

HEADLINE: Republicans Offer to Forgo Drafting Their Own Budget

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Rather than develop its own budget proposal, the Republican leadership in Congress wants to try to reach agreement with the Clinton Administration in the next few months on the broad elements of a program to eliminate the Federal deficit, Congressional aides said today.
The Republicans had intended to spend the next several months fleshing out their own partisan plan as a negotiating counterpoint to the budget proposal that President Clinton will send to Congress on Thursday. Instead, aides said, the Republicans now want to skip that process and work with the Administration and Congressional Democrats to develop a budget blueprint that will be acceptable to both sides before trying to hash out the details later in the year. 
 The effort will not necessarily involve continuing and direct negotiations between the Republican leadership and the White House, they said. But the invitation issued on Sunday by Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, to Mr. Clinton to begin talks was intended to give it some momentum, the aides said. The White House said tonight that Mr. Clinton would go to Capitol Hill on Tuesday to meet with Mr. Lott and the rest of the Republican leadership.
The Republicans said their goal would be to produce a bipartisan "budget resolution," the document that lays out the general shape of the budget and serves as the basis for detailed tax and spending legislation.
Some Republicans warned that the bipartisan process they envision could still fall apart, and it was unclear whether the effort -- led by Mr. Lott and Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader -- had the support of all their colleagues, especially in the House.
Furthermore, even if the two sides can agree on a budget resolution or come close, their battles would not necessarily be over. Many of the details of spending cuts or other changes to programs like Medicare and Medicaid are complex and could be hotly debated. Similarly, agreement on the scope of tax cuts could leave open questions about whether they should be focused on specific problems, like the rising costs of college, as the Administration prefers, or whether they should benefit taxpayers more generally, as the Republicans prefer.
But the approach would allow Republicans to avoid putting forward a complete package of specific spending cuts to offset the $193 billion in tax cuts they have proposed over the next five years while also eliminating a deficit that is projected to reach $188 billion in 2002. Republicans said their leadership was eager to make progress before the commitments to bipartisanship from both sides are eroded by the political give and take of the legislative season.
"If the President's budget is very solid and lives up to the expectations the White House has prepared for it, certainly there's a chance to get things nailed down very quickly," said Michele Davis, a spokeswoman for Mr. Armey.
"Two years ago, the President didn't even have a budget that balanced," Ms. Davis said. "This time, he's starting on our ground, with a budget that balances by 2002 and includes tax cuts. So why counter something that's already on your playing field?"
While arguing that it was the Republicans who had given ground, White House officials today said they were pleased that the Republicans viewed the Administration's budget as a sincere move toward reaching an agreement.
"The President's goal was to put down a serious balanced budget plan that could be the basis for bipartisan negotiation," said Gene Sperling, the chairman of the National Economic Council. "The fact that his budget is being acknowledged as a serious plan that is a good framework to build a bipartisan agreement is good news for everyone."
For the last two years, the Congressional budget resolution and the President's budget proposals have offered starkly different philosophies of government and have left the two sides far apart on tax and spending cuts.
But with both sides having moderated their positions on major issues like Medicare, and with a strong economy having reduced the size of the deficit last year to its lowest level in 15 years, Democrats and Republicans alike have been increasingly optimistic in recent weeks about reaching an agreement this year.
For Democrats, allowing the Republicans to negotiate without putting forth their own budget proposals would carry some political cost because it would deprive Democrats of the opportunity to criticize specific Republican spending cuts. Democratic aides said there would be considerable dissension among Democrats about taking the path the Republicans want.
Still, some Congressional Democrats as well as Republicans said the Republican proposal could speed the budget process along and reduce the risk that heated rhetoric would harden positions on both sides and derail chances of an agreement.
"Rather than go through the Kabuki dance where the President produces something and then we produce something, we will work off the document he sends up and proceed from there," said one Senate Republican aide involved in the budget process.

HEADLINE: THE SIMPSON VERDICT: THE REACTION;
In New York, Many People Anticipated The Verdict

BYLINE: PAM BELLUCK

 BODY:
This time, almost no one erupted in ecstatic cheers or gasped in stunned dismay. This time, almost no one seemed surprised.
Many New Yorkers, in fact, were not even paying attention when the verdict in O. J. Simpson's civil trial was unveiled last night. After all, the Knicks were playing the Houston Rockets. And President Clinton had just finished delivering his State of the Union address. 
 When Mr. Simpson's acquittal in his criminal trial was announced in October 1995, reactions across the country were explosive -- and shaped largely by race. Then, many blacks pumped the air with their fists in victory. Whites shook their heads in disgust or dropped their mouths in stunned silence.
That trial, with its sensational allegations of tainted evidence and racial bias, had transfixed the country. Millions had been glued to the televised proceedings, but the verdict seemed to shock even the most dedicated viewers.
Last night, when the jury announced that it had found Mr. Simpson liable for the deaths of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman, most responses also seemed to be molded along racial lines, but they were more subdued and jaded.
In the Blarney Pub, a bar in Jamaica, Queens, the largely black clientele was avidly watching the Knicks game, dancing to the jukebox or shooting pool when the verdict was announced. No one turned up the volume on the television set.
"This is no case," said Eric Gravesande, 46, an economist for I.B.M. who lives in Jamaica, Queens. "This is almost double jeopardy."
Mr. Gravesande said he had expected the civil jury to find Mr. Simpson culpable. He said he felt Judge Hiroshi Fujisaki had swayed the outcome of the trial from the beginning, by barring most testimony about allegations that the police had framed Mr. Simpson out of racial prejudice.
Others referred to the mostly white jury and the perception that the civil trial was an attempt by the white establishment to find a way to convict Mr. Simpson.
"I know once they brought him for the second trial, he would be found guilty," said Frank Burgess, 52, a high school social studies teacher in Jamaica. "He had to be found guilty to placate the white population."
At Junior's, a family-style restaurant in downtown Brooklyn, Gary Roach, a 26-year-old black minister, said, "I figured it would probably go this way because of the jury's makeup and the judge."
Sitting with him, Steve Wagmon, a 38-year-old white minister from Fort Worth, said he was "very happy about it because it brings a small amount of relief to the parents." He added, "I'm glad he's going to pay, because I think he should have been convicted in the criminal trial."
Some whites, like Anne Waldron, a restaurant manager from Cobble Hill Brooklyn, also thought the verdict was swayed by the majority of whites on the jury.
"I think the jury makeup had a huge bearing on the outcome," said Ms. Waldron, who said she was relieved by the verdict. "I'm certainly glad it's over and he's going to pay the price for what he did."
There was some tension in the eighth floor lounge of Schapiro Hall, a dormitory at Columbia University. As the counts were being read, everyone fixated on the television. Elena Nunez smiled with each yes verdict. She called the civil decision "a redemption." As the yes verdicts continued, students murmured "Uh oh, he's in trouble" and "A clean sweep?" and "Oh my God!"
Melissa Gammon, 18, a freshman, called the $8.5 million award "small peanuts compared to what they should have been compensated."
Ketsia Alexandre, an 18-year-old freshman, flashed with anger.
"People just wanted to punish O. J.," she said. "It was a way to appease the public."
People seemed more disinterested at the West End, a bar on 113th and Broadway, where the bartender had the television turned to the Knicks-Rockets game and said she did not plan to switch it to the verdict.
At Lenox Lounge, on Lenox Avenue off 125th Street in Harlem, Zebbra King said she was "tired" of the Simpson case. Neil Cole, 65, said, "quite frankly, I stopped following it after the first verdict." And Norma Campbell, a bartender, said, "To me I feel like he's being retried."
But at the Blarney Pub in Jamaica, Mr. Gravesande was thoughtful. He said the verdict would only intensify the racial wounds opened in the first O. J. Simpson trial.
"This country was polarized before this civil trial and will remain polarized after the civil trial," Mr. Gravesande said, "because black people will never accept that O. J. Simpson got a fair shake in the civil trial. To most black people, the verdict in the civil trial is immaterial."

HEADLINE: THE SECOND TERM: EDUCATION;
President Reprises the Goals Of U.S. Achievement Standards

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
As the governor who pushed through sweeping changes in Arkansas' schools in the 1980's, Bill Clinton rode the issue of education into national prominence, which propelled his original candidacy for President in 1992.
Now entering his second term as President, Mr. Clinton has turned once again to education as his "No. 1 priority," proposing an increase in education spending and a 10-point "call to action for American education" to mobilize parents, students, teachers and volunteers across the country. 
 The proposals Mr. Clinton announced in his State of the Union address tonight sounded much like those he had advocated when he led the National Governors' Association's education efforts in the late 1980's. He had challenged states across the nation to adopt high standards and test every third grader in reading and every eighth grader in math. He called for a "citizen army of 1 million volunteer tutors" to make sure every child can read by the third grade.
Mr. Clinton announced that he would increase financing for Head Start preschool programs and for charter schools, which are free of some constraints of state and local education bureaucracy. He included a $5 billion initiative for school construction. And he proposed two tax breaks for families earning less than $100,000, to help with the often staggering expenses of college.
The intellectual impetus for Mr. Clinton's education push is clear, as are the politics of it. As the President has said often, education increasingly determines who will succeed and who will fail in the stratified post-industrial information age. Moreover, education has enormous political appeal and was one of the main issues he used in his campaign to court swing voters in middle-class suburbia and set himself apart from the Republicans even as he embraced many of their fiscal principles.
Despite Mr. Clinton's fervent appeal to make American schools "the envy of the world" and his pledge to increase education financing by 20 percent, to $51 billion in the 1998 Federal fiscal year, there is a fundamental difference between being the Education President -- as George Bush once called himself years before Mr. Clinton -- and being the education governor.
Governors, not Presidents, have direct power over education in this country, controlling much of the funding and passing the laws central to the structure and operation of the public schools. Moreover, less than a year ago, Mr. Clinton attended a conference of governors and echoed their contention that setting standards in education should be up to the states. "I accept your premise," he said then. "We can only do better with tougher standards and better assessment and you should set the standards."
In his book, "Behind the Oval Office," Dick Morris, Mr. Clinton's former strategist, said the stand was a "cop-out," and that Mr. Clinton wanted to impose standards but had backed down in the face of polling.
That is why tonight, Mr. Clinton announced that the Federal Government would develop tests to measure student achievement in fourth-grade reading and eighth-grade math, but stopped short of requiring that schools administer the tests. Instead he plans to use his power of exhortation to rally the nation -- including 50 governors and 14,000 public school districts -- to embrace his call for a "national crusade for education standards."
Educators were expecting Mr. Clinton's emphasis on schooling and even before his address they were praising his intentions. "I certainly think a President helps to set priorities and provides a visibility through media and television no one else can," said Michael D. Usdan, president of the Institute for Educational Leadership, a Washington-based education group.
The educators also said that the development of a rigorous national test -- which would be modeled on an existing international test and an existing national one -- would be a valuable tool for localities to measure individual students and entire schools against national and international norms. Currently those tests can only be used to gauge how the nation as a whole ranks against other countries or measure achievement in a whole state. But those rankings are of limited use to a teacher.
A test, as Chester E. Finn Jr., a former assistant secretary of education in the Reagan Administration put it, "is a thermometer, not a therapy. It tells you you've got a fever; it doesn't tell you how to get well."
A crucial test for Mr. Clinton in the next few years will be whether his program really can help America's schools improve student achievement.
For it has been seven years since President Bush and Governor Clinton, along with many other governors, held an education summit and introduced six national educational goals to be reached by 2000. Some of them sounded very much like what Mr. Clinton was articulating tonight. The goals included a standard for American students to leave school with demonstrated competence in English, math, science, history and geography, as well as a call for American students to be first in the world in science and mathematics.
But even after two years in which the Bush administration was committed to those goals and another four years of commitment by the Clinton Administration, American schools still fall far short. Rather than being first in the world in science and math, American eighth graders, according to the recent Third International Mathematics and Science Study, ranked below the international average in math and somewhat above the international average in science, compared with their counterparts in 41 countries.
"There's been no change," said Mr. Finn. "And that has been pretty much the story every year since the goals were set -- that we're not making progress toward them."
Will Mr. Clinton's prescriptions help? While he is infusing money into education, Federal funds make up only about six percent of school financing at the elementary and secondary school levels. His proposals do not deal with the income disparities and huge gap in spending that exists between rich and poor school districts. It remains to be seen whether volunteer reading tutors will have the skills and perseverance to help third graders with reading difficulties become literate, and whether they will really be available for the nation's most troubled schools in the most troubled neighborhoods.
Much of the emphasis of Mr. Clinton's education program, in fact, is not on elementary and secondary education at all but is a tax reduction program designed to make higher education so affordable that a 13th and 14th year of education will become the national norm.
The $10,000 tax deduction and $1,500 tax credit for tuition costs were some of the most popular proposals Mr. Clinton offered on the campaign trail to families alarmed by soaring college costs.
But political figures and even university officials are divided about whether a program that amounts to a new middle-class entitlement for families earning less than $100,000 will have the effects Mr. Clinton desires. Some have asked whether college-based tax reductions costing the Treasury nearly $40 billion will simply lead to further inflation in private college tuition costs and cause states to reduce their contribution to state colleges on the assumption that most students will now have a Federal tax credit available.
"The President's tax credit proposals for college are likely to help some students and raise the cost of college for all students," said Lamar Alexander, Mr. Bush's former Education Secretary, who was a contender for the Republican Presidential nomination last year. "A better idea would be to put the available money into scholarships for low-income students and give middle-income families a tax-free savings account that can be used for education."
But in terms of politics Mr. Clinton had the upper hand tonight. Unwilling to be branded as anti-education, Republicans politely applauded the President and sent out news releases seeking to showcase their own education proposals. And Democrats praised the President, saying as Representative Cynthia A. McKinney of Georgia did that his education proposal "reflects his priority to address middle-class concerns."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Why Be a Temp? For Belichick, Loyalty

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 4

 BODY:
Bill Belichick stood next to the Jets' president, Steve Gutman, this afternoon and assumed the role of good soldier. Belichick agreed to accept the Jets' head coaching job and relinquish it when Bill Parcells, who was named a consultant to the team for 1997, is ready to take the helm.
In effect, Belichick fell on his first green-and-white grenade today. And the big question surrounding Belichick was why a man with five years of head-coaching experience would sublimate his ego and make himself a pawn in the Jets' risky gambit. 
 Part of the reason might be because he is the son of Steve Belichick, who was an assistant coach at the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md., for 33 years. As with his father, loyalty appears to be more than a watchword for Bill Belichick -- it is a way of life. Thus, given that Belichick has had a long, and successful, relationship with Parcells, it is perhaps not hard to understand why he would agree to be a caretaker for his friend during the coming season.
Gutman named Parcells a consultant for the Jets until the team is able to work out compensation for his services for 1997 with the Patriots owner, Robert K. Kraft, or until Feb. 1, 1998, when Parcells will be free and clear. Or until the National Football League possibly rules against the whole arrangement. But in the meantime, Belichick will run the team.
Belichick seemed untroubled by the highly unusual arrangement. He said he was fully aware of the fact that the Jets could conceivably work out compensation with the Patriots to free Parcells tomorrow and that he would then have to give up control of the team and become an assistant head coach. He also seemed undisturbed that Parcells would be looking over his shoulder for a year.
"It's a program and I'm part of it," Belichick said. "It's a team effort. Bill and I will run it in concert. My role may switch back and forth. It may be one way now and another way later."
Parcells and Belichick worked together for 11 seasons with the Giants and earned two Super Bowl rings. This past season, Belichick rejoined Parcells, working as the Patriots' assistant head coach, and again they went to the Super Bowl, although this time they lost, 35-21, to Green Bay.
"He's been probably as important in my career as any individual," Parcells said this afternoon.
Both Belichick and Parcells share a love of defense, so in that sense they are kindred spirits. Belichick has a brilliant defensive mind, is a stickler for details, a workaholic, a strict disciplinarian and something of a taskmaster with his players. He is not a natural with the news media.
Belichick, 44, was born in Nashville, but grew up in Annapolis. In high school he played center and tight end on the football teams and also played lacrosse. He went on to get a degree in economics from Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., where he also played football and lacrosse.
In a sense he is a classic gym rat -- the kind of coach who can lock himself in a dark room, break down film all day and be very content.
"You're looking at a guy who may be the most thorough guy in football," Parcells said. "He's turning over every rock."
No one will question Belichick's ability with X's and O's, but his dour expression and taciturn nature rubs some people the wrong way. In his five years as head coach in Cleveland, Belichick turned off Browns fans, players and staff members. Some staff members complained that when they spoke to Belichick in the hallway, he wouldn't even acknowledge them with a glance.
Belichick alienated the fans in Cleveland when he benched quarterback Bernie Kosar, a local favorite, and replaced him with Vinny Testaverde. Eventually, Kosar was released. The whole episode is what Belichick is most noted for in his tenure with the Browns.
During the 1995 season, while the team was still in Cleveland, Art Modell, the Browns' owner, secretly met with the players and told them he was going to move the team to Baltimore and he was taking Belichick with him. The players groaned.
Later, one player was asked why the players didn't want to continue playing for Belichick in Baltimore and he replied: "It's very simple. He's crazy."
Interestingly, Belichick was replaced as the coach in Baltimore by Ted Marchibroda, who hired the 23-year-old Belichick in 1975 and made him the team gofer when Marchibroda was in his first stint as Colts coach. As Marchibroda's "special assistant," Belichick lived in a hotel room and worked for next to nothing, just so he could learn the game.
After stops in Detroit and Denver, Belichick landed in New York in 1979, where he began as a defensive assistant. He progressed swiftly, moving from linebackers coach to defensive coordinator in four years.
Belichick left the Giants to take the head-coaching job in Cleveland in 1990, a few months before Parcells resigned as the Giants' head coach. And when Belichick was fired in Cleveland last year, he turned down a job as the Dolphins' defensive coordinator under Jimmy Johnson in order to be reunited with Parcells.
Now, they're back together in New York, with the Jets. "For the long haul," Belichick said.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS IN TURMOIL: A special report.;
Adelphi, a Little University With Big Ideas

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I.

 BODY:
This is the story of a university that tore itself apart.
In 1985, Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, a philosopher trained at Harvard and Brandeis who ran a small state college in California, arrived at Adelphi University. As its new president, he had a bold vision: to quickly transform a troubled commuter school best known for its vocational programs into a top-flight liberal arts institution. 
 At the time, Adelphi was close to insolvency. It was just moderately competitive: it accepted 6 of every 10 high school graduates who applied. Only one course, freshman composition, was required. Enrollment was declining.
The university's trustees thought Adelphi had to do something radical to survive in the increasingly competitive world of small, regional liberal arts colleges. And so they hired Dr. Diamandopoulos, who argued that Adelphi could be saved only by raising its intellectual sights and discontinuing or cutting back lesser programs.
He set out to adopt a demanding core curriculum like Columbia's "great books" course of study. He wanted to attract top students with an "honors college" within the university. And he set a daring goal for increased enrollment: to 15,000 students from 7,000 in five years.
He knew his proposal for change was ambitious and risky. Colleges can spend years debating much smaller questions. It took decades -- and $1 billion or more in fund raising -- for Duke University and New York University to make the difficult transition from regional colleges to nationally ranked research universities.
With annual support from a philanthropy that backs conservative causes, Dr. Diamandopoulos hired distinguished visiting professors like Robert Heilbroner, the economist; Maurice Cowling, a Briton who is an authority on intellectual history, and Edith Kurzweil, the editor of Partisan Review.
He raised about $13 million, about average for institutions like Adelphi, and saw the endowment rise to $47 million from $4 million, thanks to a soaring stock market.
The trustees rewarded him with the kind of salary and benefits not even the presidents of Harvard, Yale or Stanford received. In 1994, he was paid $523,000 in salary alone, the second highest in the country, after John Silber, the president of Boston University, who then was receiving $564,000.
Among the trustees on a select three-member panel deciding his salary was Dr. Silber. He justified Dr. Diamandopoulos's pay, saying, "It doesn't take nearly as much effort to run Harvard as it does to take over an institution like Adelphi."
Today, Adelphi has lifted its intellectual sights, refurbished buildings, balanced its budget and increased its endowment. But by many other standards, the university is in worse shape than when Dr. Diamandopoulos arrived.
Its academic reputation has declined. The student-professor ratio has increased to 12 to 1, from 9 to 1, slightly above average for universities this size. Enrollment has dropped to 4,605 last fall from 6,984 in 1985. Worse, the university has become what educators call a bottom feeder. It now accepts almost 9 out of 10 applicants.
In spring 1995, the chairman of the faculty senate, Devin Thornburg, and other faculty leaders, alarmed by declining enrollment and the overall management of Adelphi, joined with alumni and students to stage an unusual revolt. They petitioned the State Board of Regents to remove the university's leadership -- its trustees, including Dr. Diamandopoulos, who as president sits on the board -- for mismanagement and conflicts of interest.
In an unusual move, the Regents agreed to hold hearings -- remarkable in their scope and duration -- that concluded last November. The Regents are expected to announce their decision in a meeting Feb. 10.
The trustees, denying charges of mismanagement and conflict of interest, have responded with a series of challenges, including a lawsuit accusing the university faculty of defaming Dr. Diamandopoulos. It contends, among other accusations, that an Adelphi history professor, Lester B. Baltimore, stated in an article in Newsday that the university had paid for a trip to Greece by the trustees when he knew that the trip had been underwritten by the trustees themselves. Through his lawyer, Professor Baltimore denied the charge.
The trustees are also announcing several new initiatives Feb. 5, including a multimillion-dollar capital fund drive originally planned for Adelphi's centennial last year, as well as a new marketing campaign employing the phrase "because Good is the enemy of Great." The trustees are announcing an expansion of the board, a new governance committee and a new faculty recruitment campaign.
 
A Clash of Ideas
Fast Philosopher Loses His Wheels
Dr. Diamandopoulos and the trustees said Adelphi's current problems are temporary, the predictable side effects of change. "Once you stop the bleeding, we will recover very fast," Dr. Diamandopoulos said in an interview.
But one of the president's many faculty critics, Prof. Brooke Spiro of the social work department, dismissed this as unduly optimistic. "The president doesn't have an educational philosophy, but only a marketing strategy that failed," he said.
What was unusual about Dr. Diamandopoulos's program, said Linda Salamon, a professor of English at George Washington University who has studied college curricular change, was the speed with which he tried to transform the institution.
"In our trade," she said, "it takes a decade to change a reputation. He tried to reshape Adelphi overnight."
When Dr. Diamandopoulos took over Adelphi, the curriculum centered on professional programs like nursing, social work and accounting. He disparaged them as training for "the helping professions" and advocated the stronger core curriculum.
In his first two years as president, he moved quickly to reshape Adelphi's board with people who agreed with his philosophy and vision for change. He nominated three trustees -- Charles Luckman, an architect; Hilton Kramer, publisher of The New Criterion, and Dr. Raymond V. Damadian, a physician and one of the inventors of magnetic resonance imaging.
Apart from a few grumbles, most members of the faculty at first went along with the new president's ideas for revising the curriculum, which it approved in 1990, and for establishing an Honors College, which the faculty approved two years later.
The curriculum is a demanding sequence of courses in the liberal arts and sciences that include excerpts from Plato to Heidegger, Democritus to Darwin. Freshmen and sophomores take yearlong courses about issues of modern civilization and their historical roots, and the nature of knowledge, before they specialize in their majors.
One trustee, Abraham Krasnoff, a Diamandopoulos nominee who calls himself "a balance for some of the outspoken conservatives" on the board, said the way Dr. Diamandopoulos proposed to emphasize the Western canon without becoming ensnarled in the debate over multiculturalism "was absolutely brilliant."
Both sides agree that the current fight is not primarily political -- a conservative president facing opposition from a largely liberal faculty.
"I wish it were that simple," Dr. Diamandopoulos said. "It's much more complex -- psychological and philosophical. The more I have pushed the faculty to reorient the university to the intellectual development of the students the more threatening I have become to them."
Professor Thornburg and others formed the Committee to Save Adelphi in the spring of 1995. But that fall, they were galvanized by a report in the Chronicle of Higher Education about Dr. Diamandopoulos's salary and benefits. The size of the compensation package stunned them, Professor Thornburg said.
"That was like throwing gasoline on the fire," he said. "But it's important to realize that the fire was already there. It's a fight over university governance and the use of limited resources."
 
The Grand Plan
Visions of Adelphi As a Little Harvard
Peter Diamandopoulos, descendant of an ancient land-holding family in Crete, sits confidently in his baronial, mahogany-paneled office as he is asked about Adelphi. He asserts that the university is on the rise again and will emerge stronger because of the changes.
"It is one thing to have a vision and another to make it materialize," he said. "To be good is not good enough."
With a mop of white hair and lively dark eyebrows, Dr. Diamandopoulos bounced energetically on a stuffed chair and delivered pithy remarks in bursts, with a Greek accent.
"I have an incomparably demanding idea of what is suitable for an educational institution," Dr. Diamandopoulos said. "It is to reorient the souls of the students, as Plato said."
Should nursing and social work students be required to take the great-books courses?
"Are we saying these students are less?" he replied, almost leaping from his chair and thrashing the air with his arms. He then apologized for the outburst and continued:
"I cannot say to this student, you should just study accounting and nothing else. Infinite are the possibilities. Infinite are the possibilities!"
Then he leaned back in his chair and spoke softly. "I have faith that the larger world values value," he said.
Dr. Diamandopoulos's mentor, Dr. Silber, speaks glowingly of his protege: "I don't think his ideas are grandiose. They're grand!"
Dr. Diamandopoulos, who immigrated to the United States in 1948, spent a decade at Harvard receiving a bachelor's in classics, a master's in philosophy and a doctorate in the history of science. A teaching fellow during his graduate years, he wrote a dissertation on Aristotle's Nico machean Ethics, a study of the practice of morals.
After a series of academic appointments, he was named dean of the faculty at Brandeis University in the late 1960's and was profoundly influenced, his friends say, by Abram Sachar, the founding president of Brandeis who created, virtually from scratch, a liberal arts college known for academic excellence.
"That example of derring-do," Dr. Silber recalled, "influenced Peter in his conception of what an academic leader can do."
In 1977, Dr. Diamandopoulos was chosen president of the California State College at Sonoma. He is said to have alienated faculty members by intervening in department appointments and in 1983, after receiving two votes of no confidence by the faculty senate, he was forced to resign. For the next two years, he taught philosophy at San Francisco State University. In 1985, he was named president of Adelphi, recruited by the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, John Phelan, an Adelphi alumnus.
In the early years of Dr. Diamandopoulos's tenure, many faculty members, students and alumni found themselves charmed by his charismatic personality and oracular pronouncements.
In his inaugural address, Dr. Diamandopoulos made it clear that major change was afoot. He spoke of the institution's "unlimited possibilities" and the need for "a new sense of risk-oriented enterprise."
A few days later, he told an education reporter for Newsday that he intended to increase the school's full-time enrollment to 15,000 within five years, recruit students nationally and revamp the curriculum. He promised to make the school a gathering place for the world's leading intellectuals.
"We have to move, move, move," he told the reporter.
Soon, a full-page advertisement written by Dr. Diamandopoulos appeared in newspapers and magazines across the country, with the headline: "Harvard is the Adelphi of Massachusetts."
 
A Catch
Students Staying Away in Droves
The first sign of trouble came soon after Dr. Diamandopoulos settled down to work. Enrollment continued to decline, despite his goals. In 1985, total enrollment was 6,984. It fell almost every year for the next decade, dipping to 4,605 in 1995, a decrease of 34 percent.
Dr. Diamandopoulos's supporters say the problem was beyond his control. The number of high school graduates in Adelphi's primary market, the New York metropolitan area, began to shrink during the baby bust of the 1980's, and many regional colleges suffered enrollment declines.
But Adelphi's problem was worse than those of its local competitors. According to figures compiled by the State Department of Education, enrollment at the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University shrank by only 19 percent in the same 10 years, Hofstra's increased by three-tenths of 1 percent and that of the State University at Stony Brook grew by almost 7 percent.
More than a few faculty members recognized that Dr. Diamandopoulos's plan to increase both enrollment and entrance standards was risky. When a college sets out to increase its enrollment, the academic level of entering students usually declines. Further, academicians say that sudden, fundamental changes in an established educational institution risk alienating its traditional students.
"The enrollment drop was dramatic," Professor Thornburg said. "The faculty senate would pass resolution after resolution questioning the administration's moves to eliminate or scale down the School of Nursing or the School of Social Work, but never received a response. The administration was changing the educational focus and allocating resources without any input from the faculty. That made us realize that we could never work with this administration and keep the University going."
Igor Webb, the school's senior vice president for academic affairs, said Adelphi lost students because it was paying the price for "being opposed to the fraud that you can take 12 courses and be guaranteed a great business career."
We say that there's no substitute for education," he added, "but that's a difficult message to get across."
By the early 1990's, another obstacle loomed. Nearly 80 percent of the faculty was tenured -- an unusually large proportion -- and many had decided to take advantage of a newly enacted Federal law eliminating the mandatory retirement age at colleges. This left little opportunity for revitalizing the faculty.
Dr. Diamandopoulos approached the John M. Olin Foundation, a frequent backer of conservative causes, for a grant to support the appointment of distinguished visiting professors whose generally conservative views would balance the liberal leanings of most academicians.
Last year, the Olin Foundation decided to stop the annual grants, which had brought the university $750,000 over five years. "Peter was under terrific attack and we didn't know what the outcome would be," said James Piereson, executive director of the foundation.
In the last year, 22 faculty members, or 10 percent, have left, most voluntarily relinquishing their tenured positions for other jobs. This has come even as administration officials point out that faculty salaries at Adelphi have risen 79 percent since 1985 -- 32 percent above the rate of inflation and 11 percent ahead of the national average for private colleges and universities, according to an estimate by the American Council on Education.
Armstrong Starkey, a former dean of Adelphi's college of arts and sciences, former chairman of the faculty senate and a critic of Dr. Diamandopoulos, said Adelphi's problems arise from the efforts to shift the focus.
"We had been successful attracting students with our preprofessional programs," he said. "This isn't Amherst or Swarthmore, and if you're going to become like them, you must have a massive infusion of funds from outside sources."
But Mr. Byrne, the former chairman of the board of trustees, said: "You have to expect this. We're shaking the status quo."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
An Incomprehensible Bore That Defies Intuition

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

HAMILTON'S BLESSING
The Extraordinary Life and Times of Our National Debt
By John Steele Gordon
214 pages. Walker & Company. $21.
 At the opening of his useful new book, "Hamilton's Blessing: The Extraordinary Life and Times of Our National Debt," John Steele Gordon drops what at first seems an encouraging tidbit of news. The present national debt of more than $5 trillion is certainly "incomprehensible to the average American," he admits. "For the record," he writes, "laid out in silver dollars, it would be about 120 million miles long, wrapping around the equator 5,000 times."
However, "considered as a percentage either of gross domestic product (usually called G.D.P., it is the sum of the goods and services produced within our borders) or of Federal revenues," our debt "is nowhere near as high as was the British national debt in 1819, the year Queen Victoria was born and when Britain was, in the words of the late historian Cecil Woodham-Smith, 'within sight of the heights of power and of wealth from which it was, briefly, to dominate the world.' "
Whew! What a relief! By such a measurement our debt isn't bad at all. So does this mean that the current concern is overblown and that the country can now relax and go on running up deficits?
 Mr. Gordon, who writes "The Business of America" column in American Heritage magazine, thinks not. The problem, he writes, isn't the size of the debt, but instead its recent trend. "For that trend results not from a deliberate political decision to spend in deficit, but rather from nothing more than the sum of myriad decisions regarding taxing and spending that, collectively, now substitutes for fiscal policy."
To understand how the country reached its present pass, Mr. Gordon examines American history using the effects of five wars as focal points. In a chapter called "The Hamiltonian Miracle," he describes how Alexander Hamilton paid off the cost of the Revolutionary War by creating a Federal bank that assumed the debts of the various states and thereby created the first national deficit. In "Andrew Jackson Redeems the Debt," he reviews how after the War of 1812, the seventh President used the surpluses generated by a high tariff "to rid the Federal Government of debt entirely" and thereby circuitously "contribute in no small way to the country's first great depression."
In "Armageddon and the National Debt," Mr. Gordon shows how the imposition during the Civil War of the nation's first Federal income tax eventually raised the question of how the burden of such a tax ought to be distributed. In "The Twilight of the Old Consensus," he traces how fiscal policy after World War I led to the shock of the Great Depression.
And in "Keynesianism and the Madison Effect," he argues that after World War II, economists fell under the influence of the Madison Effect (so called by Mr. Gordon because James Madison said "Men love power") and exploited Keynesian deficit-spending theory to dictate monetary and fiscal policy.
Besides neatly summing up American economic history, Mr. Gordon uses these five chapters to reveal larger patterns. For one thing, as Hamilton dreamed, the national debt always reflected the cost of wars and depressions, at least until after World War II, when instead of reducing debt, economists used fiscal policy to pursue dreams that couldn't be fulfilled because of the inherent flaws of Keynesian theory.
For another thing, Mr. Gordon argues, reducing the burden of taxes on the rich has repeatedly increased revenues, at least until the tax code became too unwieldy to adjust. In short, supply-side economic theory works! The trouble is that the Congress has evolved into a body that can no longer adjust spending to revenues. In fact, he writes, "in recent years, Washington, wrestling with the budget deficit, has come to resemble more and more a drunk wrestling with alcoholism."
How to recover? In conclusion, Mr. Gordon finds four lessons taught by the history he has summed up. First, since Congress, long since democratized by the Jacksonian revolution, no longer provides the brake on spending that the Founding Fathers could count on from wealthy legislators, Mr. Gordon proposes to reverse the Constitution's intent and "give the President the power to set the limit on overall spending, subject to a Congressional override, and the power to enforce that limit with cuts in all spending, not just that specifically appropriated every year, as needed."
Second, since corruption is no longer built into the system, as it was "in the early days of the Republic" when "many sought political office precisely for the potential profits involved," Mr. Gordon wants "the PAC system of financing political campaigns" abolished. "It cannot be reformed," he writes, "any more than slavery could have been reformed and for precisely the same reason: It is inherently morally corrupt."
Third, he wants a modern system of accounting imposed on the Congress. "The effect on the country's fiscal policy," he writes, "and thus on the debt, would be considerable." And finally, as an alternative to the present tax code with its high marginal tax rates ("counterproductive at best, perverse at worst"), he endorses a flat tax, arguing that while its marginal rate is flat, its effective rate is progressive when a personal exemption is taken into consideration.
The point of Mr. Gordon's exercise in succinctness, which began as an article in "American Heritage," is not whether you agree with his proposals for a solution, or even whether you share his view of the problem. The appeal of "Hamilton's Blessing" is the broad perspective it offers in little more space than a chapbook. Mr. Gordon's subject may well be dismal, but his delivery of it is short and stimulating.

HEADLINE: City Opera Plans 8 New Productions Next Season

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
The New York City Opera is to present eight new productions during its 1997-98 season, the first one entirely planned by Paul Kellogg, who has been the company's general and artistic director since January 1996. The season will include the New York premiere of Tobias Picker's "Emmeline" and the American premiere of Tan Dun's "Voyage of Marco Polo," as well as a staging of Benjamin Britten's rarely performed "Paul Bunyan."
A fourth contemporary work, Hugo Weisgall's "Esther," is to be revived for the first time since its premiere at the company in 1993. 
 The concentration of contemporary works, mostly in accessible styles, may allay the concerns of two parts of the City Opera's audience: those who feared that Mr. Kellogg would abandon the company's commitment to modern opera, and those who found the new-music adventures of Mr. Kellogg's predecessor, Christopher Keene, too adventurous.
The new productions in the 19-week season, which the company announced yesterday, are Verdi's "Macbeth," Rossini's "Italiana in Algeri," Gluck's "Iphigenie en Tauride," Donizetti's "Don Pasquale" and Handel's "Xerxes."
The company is also moving up the curtain time of its Monday-through-Thursday performances to 7:30 P.M.
The schedule illuminates Mr. Kellogg's approach to balancing novelty and economy, both perennial concerns at the City Opera. It is unusual for a major company to offer so many new productions in a single season -- four or five is more typical -- or to devote half of its schedule to new productions.
But only "Macbeth" is being undertaken by the City Opera entirely on its own. Two productions, "Emmeline" and "Xerxes," come from the Santa Fe Opera. "The Voyage of Marco Polo" had its premiere at the Munich Biennale last May, and the others are collaborations with the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., where Mr. Kellogg is also the artistic director.
"Macbeth," which opens the season on Sept. 11, is to be staged by Michael Kahn, the artistic director of the Shakespeare Festival in Washington and the director of the drama division at the Juilliard School. John Conklin, the City Opera's director of production, has designed the sets, and the costumes are by Martin Pakledinaz. The cast includes Mark Delavan in the title role and Lauren Flanigan as Lady Macbeth.
"L'Italiana in Algeri" will be directed by Christopher Alden, with sets by Mr. Conklin and Carol Bailey and costumes by Gabriel Berry. Phyllis Pancella, Kevin Glavin and Gregory Cross are to sing the principal roles. It opens on Sept. 12.
Christine Goerke will sing the title role in "Iphigenie en Tauride," which opens on Oct. 4 in a production by Francesca Zambello with sets by Marina Draghici and costumes by Dunya Ramicova.
"Don Pasquale," which has not been seen at the City Opera since 1955, will return on Oct. 19 in a staging by Leon Major, with sets and costumes by Allen Moyer. Laura Claycomb is to sing Norina, with Kevin Glavin in the title role, Christopher Schaldenbrand as Dr. Malatesta and John Osborn as Ernesto.
The "Xerxes" staging, updated to 18th-century England by Stephen Wadsworth, introduces to the company several singers best known for their early-music performances, among them Lorraine Hunt and David Daniels. The cast also includes Amy Burton, Jennifer Lane, Susannah Waters, Kurt Ollmann and Jan Opalach. It opens on Nov. 1.
The last new production of the fall season is "The Voyage of Marco Polo," which opens on Nov. 8. Mr. Dun, one of the most prominent composers in a group of Chinese expatriates who have been flourishing in the United States, is to conduct the performances, and Martha Clarke will make her directing debut with the company. The libretto is by Paul Griffiths, a critic who contributes regularly to The New York Times, and is to be sung in English, Italian and Chinese by a cast that includes Ning Liang, Christine Abraham, Adam Klein, Dong-Jian Gong, Stephen Bryant and Shi-Zheng Chen. Debra Booth designed the sets, and Jane Greenwood the costumes.
Mr. Picker's "Emmeline" opens on March 31, 1998. The work, which has a libretto by J. D. McClatchy, is based on Judith Rossner's 1980 novel, which was itself drawn from a true story in which a woman unwittingly married her son. The production, by Ms. Zambello, with sets by Robert Israel and costumes by Ms. Ramicova, had its premiere in Santa Fe last summer, and the singers from the original cast -- Patricia Racette, Curt Peterson, Victor Lebetter and Kevin Langan -- are to recreate their roles.
"Paul Bunyan" is to open on April 9, 1998, in a production directed by Mark Lamos, with sets by Paul Steinberg and costumes by Constance Hoffmann. Jeffrey Lentz, Elisabeth Comeaux and Erin Caves are in the cast.
Besides "Esther," the repertory productions returning are Mozart's "Magic Flute" (performed in Andrew Porter's English translation) and "Le Nozze di Figaro" (sung in Italian), Verdi's "Traviata," Offenbach's "Contes d'Hoffmann," Bizet's "Carmen" and two Puccini operas, "La Boheme" and "Madama Butterfly." For "Butterfly," the company is returning to the 1906 revision of the score after several seasons of using the original 1904 version.
George Manahan, the company's music director, will conduct "Macbeth," "L'Italiana," "Emmeline" and "Xerxes." Jane Glover, an English conductor who has worked at Glimmerglass and the Mostly Mozart Festival, will make her company debut with "Iphigenie," and Stewart Robertson, the music director at Glimmerglass, is to make his debut conducting "Paul Bunyan."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Sets a Four-Year High Against Yen but Slips vs. Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar surpassed 123 Japanese yen yesterday for the first time in four years as fears of Japan banking problems grew, but it ended mostly lower against other currencies.
Strength in the German mark and the British pound, as well as an abrupt drop in the American stock market late in the day, contributed to the dollar's mixed showing. The Dow Jones industrial average, up about 40 points at midafternoon, fell in the last hour of trading. 
 The catalyst for the selloff in the yen, which occurred against most leading currencies, came overnight on rumors that the Nippon Credit Bank was facing a financial crisis and possible bankruptcy. The bank's stock fell and its senior management vigorously denied the rumors. But the yen continued to weaken.
"Once you added fuel to the fire of another potential banking problem in Japan, the dollar broke through the 123 zone," said Stephen Flanagan, senior currency trader at Credit Agricole in New York. "The market consensus is that it continues to bring to light this debt problem that Japanese banks are all facing."
The dollar reached an intraday high of 123.68 yen, the strongest since February 1993 and its first new four-year high in a week, before settling in New York at 123.25 yen, up from 122.44 yen on Tuesday.
The dollar spent much of the day higher against the mark but settled at 1.6454, down from 1.6457 on Tuesday. The pound rallied to $1.6396, up sharply from $1.6207.
Despite the dollar's mixed performance, traders said that the underlying demand for the currency remained strong and that there seemed to be some diminished anxiety over the outcome of the meeting this weekend of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations.
Japanese officials have suggested that they will use the meeting to seek help to arrest the yen's decline. But their comments have been countered by those of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and some European officials who have suggested that a strong dollar is also beneficial.
"The growing view is that the G-7 won't be able to do much to stem the slide in the yen," said Joseph Pedone, a currency trader at the New York branch of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. "We expect the dollar to continue to grind higher."

HEADLINE: Nothing Says a Global Economy Is Inevitable

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Claims of the historical inevitability of political and economic trends merit skepticism. That was true of Communist assertions of certain triumph, and it is true of Thomas L. Friedman's contention that globalization is inevitable (column, Feb. 2). 
 People and institutions, not technologies, are driving globalization. The ability to make a telephone call from Oregon to Vietnam does not require Nike to produce shoes in Vietnam in sweatshop conditions rather than in the country where the company sells the shoes.
Multinational corporate executives are making conscious marketing and production decisions to globalize their operations. They could only make those choices in a legal and regulatory framework that permits unimpeded capital mobility, maintains low tariffs and provides stable trading rules like those set by the World Trade Organization and the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Those whom Mr. Friedman labels "separatists" are actually democrats who recognize the political choice inherent in the decision to maintain the current framework or to substitute another that enhances local control and democratic accountability.
 
ROBERT WEISSMAN
Washington, Feb. 4, 1997
 
The writer is editor of Multinational Monitor.

HEADLINE: 2 Top Hong Kong Officials Fault China's New Policies

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Even as China moves to revoke a range of laws protecting civil liberties here, two of Hong Kong's most senior officials have begun to speak out against Chinese interference in the territory's affairs.
Until now, none of the leading civil servants here have criticized Beijing or its policies toward Hong Kong. 
 Although China has formally promised that it will respect Hong Kong's autonomy after the British territory reverts to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, there has been a growing unease here over the extent to which Beijing is forcing its will on Hong Kong.
This week, Anson C. Chan, Chief Secretary and the highest ranking civil servant in Hong Kong, accused the Beijing-appointed panel that will revoke or modify the civil-liberties laws of ignoring the apprehensions of Hong Kong citizens toward China.
"I share the community's disappointment that the Preparatory Committee has not seen fit to recognize the widespread concern that has been caused by the legal subgroup's recommendations," Mrs. Chan said, referring to the China-appointed caucus and subcommittee that are drawing up the changes.
Last month Hong Kong's financial secretary, Donald Tsang, who sets forth the territory's budgets and monitors the economy here, was sharply critical of the Chinese official who leads the Land Commission, the panel that releases government land for commercial development.
Mrs. Chan said the decision by the Beijing caucus to return to draconian colonial laws governing the freedom of assembly and the right of association has created doubts abroad about China's commitment to Hong Kong's way of life.
The plans to revoke existing laws, Mrs. Chan said, after returning from a visit to the United States, "sent an extremely negative signal to people in America, and there is clearly concern about whether human rights will be protected after 1997, and in particular there are doubts as to China's commitment to implementing the 'one country, two systems' concept after 1997."
The phrase "one country, two systems" was coined in 1984 by Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, to describe China's intention to allow Hong Kong to maintain its own economic and political system.
American officials have expressed dismay over China's plans to repeal key portions of Hong Kong's Bill of Rights and civil-liberties laws. Mrs. Chan's comments are significant because she has agreed to remain in her post under Chinese rule and work with the leader chosen by Beijing to run Hong Kong, Tung Chee-hwa.
Sonny S. H. Lo, a director of a multi-university project tracking major issues during the transition to Chinese rule, said: "Chinese officials will remember her remarks very well. She will be a temporary figure in the Hong Kong Government."

HEADLINE: Network Formed to Hold Manufacturing Jobs

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Through the years, manufacturers have tried to stop the steady decline of jobs in New York City by forming trade associations and persuading the city to offer tax abatements and loans. Even so, manufacturing jobs have fallen from a peak of 950,000 in the 1950's to 260,000 today.
Now, the manufacturers are trying again. Forty-five manufacturing, nonprofit, financial and government groups have formed the Industrial Retention Network, a nonprofit organization intended to develop an early-warning system to dissuade manufacturers from leaving. Members include the Brooklyn Economic Development Corporation, the Greenpoint Manufacturing and Design Center, the Bank of New York, Con Edison and Locker Associates, an economic consulting firm. 
 The network is noteworthy, because it is the first such broad-based effort in New York City. It is also important, because of a growing sense that doing nothing is tantamount to allowing certain manufacturers to die a slow death.
"I think retention is a great idea," said Rae D. Rosen, senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "If you try to leverage your existing base and retain it, you have far greater potential than if you try to get more companies."
The network plans to develop a database of the city's 12,000 manufacturing companies, tracking employment, sales and other indicators. The network will also help companies improve competitiveness and find additional private investment.
Whether the network, formed last month, succeeds will be hard to gauge immediately, because the focus is on anticipating closings one or two years in advance. Its executive director, Adam Friedman, concedes he has a formidable task.
"We're not trying to save things that are not viable," he said. "We're trying to focus on finding firms that are fundamentally healthy, and looking to get private investment to help them grow."
The State Department of Labor has said manufacturing jobs fell to 260,377 in the first half of 1996 from 270,138 in the first half of 1995, a drop of 3.61 percent. This exceeded the 2.8 percent drop the previous year.
Only 8 industries added more than 50 jobs in the first half of 1996, while 16 lost more than 265 jobs. The most successful companies were smaller manufacturers specializing in household furniture (up 13.6 percent). The least successful ones, like men's and boys' clothing, which fell 29.5 percent, produced goods that could not compete with imports, said Bruce Herman, president of the Garment Industry Development Corporation.
"Old-style manufacturing is gone forever in New York, and calls to revive it are wishful thinking," wrote Mitchell L. Moss, Hugh O'Neill and John Kedeshian in "Made in New York: The Future of Manufacturing in New York," an April 1996 study by the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University.
Manufacturers became smaller, stressing turnaround time and specialized products. Now, 96 percent of manufacturers have fewer than 100 employees, said the Industrial Technology Assistance Corporation, a private, nonprofit group.
Smaller manufacturers, though, have been vulnerable. Only 29 percent of start-up manufacturers in the city received loans from financial institutions, mostly because they tend to be small and family-financed. About 59 percent of start-ups nationally get loans from banks. And 70 percent of family-owned businesses do not make it to the next generation.
But Mr. Friedman takes solace in what happened in Chicago. The Midwest Center for Labor Research has persuaded several companies to stay, including Brock & Brach, the candy maker.
"This is not a short-term quick fix," said Robert Ginsburg, the center's research director. "It's saying that the community and government and industry have a long-term interest in seeing that manufacturing stays there."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Making furniture at Greenpoint Manufacture and Design Center. (Librado Romero/The New York Times)
 
Graph: "AT A GLANCE: Chairs Are Up, Shirts Are Down" shows the manufacturing industries that gained or lost the most jobs in the first six months of 1996, compared with the same period 1995. (Source: New York Department of Labor)

HEADLINE: Mitchell Goodman, Antiwar Protest Leader, Dies at 73

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Mitchell Goodman, the impassioned author who organized an antidraft protest that led to the trial of the Boston Five in 1968 and helped galvanize opposition to the Vietnam War, died on Saturday at his home in Temple, Me. He was 73.
His wife, Sandra Gregor, said the cause was pancreatic cancer. 
 It was known as the Spock trial, for its most famous defendant, Dr. Benjamin Spock. And it was another well-known defendant, the Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., the Yale chaplain, who had hit on the idea that led to the trial: gathering up draft cards from young war protesters in Boston and elsewhere and turning them in to the Justice Department in Washington.
But it was Mr. Goodman who had prodded Mr. Coffin into action. It was Mr. Goodman who spent a series of 14-hour days planning and coordinating the protest, and it was he who was aptly described by the prosecutor as "the detail man" of the conspiracy to "counsel, aid and abet violations of the Selective Service law."
When the trial, in Federal District Court in Boston, was over, one defendant, Marcus Raskin, the co-director of the Institute for Policy Studies, was acquitted. The four others, including Mr. Goodman and Michael Ferber, a 23-year-old Harvard graduate student, were found guilty of conspiracy and sentenced to two years in prison.
The convictions were overturned, and charges against Dr. Spock and Mr. Ferber were dismissed, but the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, ruled that while the judge had erred in his instructions to the jury, the evidence against Mr. Coffin and Mr. Goodman was so strong that they could be tried again.
Not surprisingly, the prosecution was not renewed. The first trial had come close enough to creating antiwar martyrs, and any notion that convictions would suppress opposition to the war was quickly dispelled. Immediately after sentencing, the four convicted men left the courtroom to join a protest march.
Mr. Goodman, who was born in Brooklyn, spent two years as an artillery officer in World War II. After graduating from Harvard in 1946, he began his studies for a doctorate in labor economics.
Expecting to take his orals in the fall of 1947, he spent the summer in Europe, but after meeting a young English poet, Denise Leverton, at a youth hostel in Geneva, he was so smitten his career and life plans changed.
The couple were married that December, and Mr. Goodman became a writer, turning out dozens of travel articles for The New York Times and national magazines in the 1950's and 60's. Eventually, he became an itinerant writing teacher at a series of colleges, including City College, Hofstra, Berkeley, Stanford and the University of Maine.
In 1961 he published a novel, "The End of It," which provided such a horrifyingly vivid account of an American artillery battalion's advance through northern Italy in World War II that it seemed startling that the author, who suffered from asthma, had not served overseas in the war. Considered a classic antiwar novel by some critics, it has been reissued twice.
Although he had a finely tuned sense of justice and was attracted to liberal causes, Mr. Goodman was essentially apolitical, so much so that when his wife told him that she was going to work against the war in Vietnam, he wished her well but said he would stick to his writing.
But by the time Miss Leverton had collected signatures from hundreds of artists and writers for an antiwar advertisement that appeared in The New York Times in April 1965, Mr. Goodman had been drawn in.
Over the next two years he became a powerful force in the antiwar movement. In March 1967, for example, when Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey addressed the National Book Award ceremonies in Philharmonic Hall, now Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center, Mr. Goodman led 50 people in a walkout, shouting, "Mr. Vice President, we are burning children in Vietnam, and you and we are responsible!"
Increasingly impressed by youthful protesters, Mr. Goodman made headlines when he organized a veterans' protest march down Fifth Avenue in Manhattan and again when the veterans burned their discharge papers in Union Square.
By contrast, the protest at the Justice Department on Oct. 16, 1967, was virtually ignored by the news media. But the trial of the Boston Five in 1968 made Mr. Goodman and his co-defendants heroes in the antiwar movement and spurred mass protest rallies across the country.
Mr. Goodman, who continued his antiwar activities even as his marriage disintegrated, was occupying the Chair of Ideas at Mankato State University in Minnesota in 1973 when he fell in love again, this time with a 22-year-old student.
By the time they were married in 1980 Mr. Goodman had settled in Maine, begun writing poetry and found new causes, supporting unionized strikers and opposing nuclear power and nuclear weapons.
Besides his wife he is survived by a son from his first marriage, Nikolai, of Seattle; another son, Matthew, of Temple, and a brother, Howard, of St. Louis.
