HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Drop Ahead Of Jobs Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities declined yesterday for the first time this week as investor concern deepened that tomorrow's employment report might come in stronger than expected and revive fears of higher inflation.
Yesterday's decision by the Federal Reserve to leave interest rates unchanged suggested that the central bank was not overly concerned that the current pace of economic growth was strong enough to increase inflation, which erodes the value of bonds. Still, traders were reluctant to buy securities before seeing the monthly employment report, which is widely viewed as the most important gauge of economic strength and of the outlook for inflation. 
 The price of the 30-year bond was down 21/32, to 96 25/32, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.75 percent from 6.70 percent on Tuesday.
Prices declined despite a Commerce Department report that factory orders were weaker than expected in December. The release of that report sent investors on a brief buying spree that fizzled quickly as talk of selling by hedge funds sent many traders to the sidelines.
The report probably would have been more supportive of bond prices if concerns about an increase in supply had not arisen after the Treasury announced the size of its quarterly debt refunding. The Treasury said it planned to sell $17.75 billion of three-year notes on Tuesday, $12 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday and $10 billion of 30-year bonds next Thursday. The $39.75 billion February refunding is larger than the $38.5 billion at the last refunding, in November.
In when-issued trading, the three-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.05 percent, the 10-year note at 6.44 percent, and the 30-year bond at 6.70 percent.
The Treasury also said that instead of selling a new inflation-indexed note in April, it would sell more of the indexed notes sold in January, meaning that the terms of the sale will be the same. The January sale was the first ever of an inflation-pegged security.
Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco, said that while the market had viewed the risk of an interest rate increase as minimal, there had been some lingering concern among bond investors before the Fed meeting ended.
"The Fed had the patience to await a slowing in growth after a strong surge in the second quarter last year," Ms. Rupert said, "so the expectation was that they will do the same now," after a strong fourth quarter of 1996.
She cautioned, however, that growth remained robust in some sectors and that wage pressures remained a real concern.
Other economists agreed that employment conditions could prove critical to the course of the bond market. Doug Porter, senior economist at Nesbitt Burns Inc. in Toronto, said that in part because of the market's concern about how low the unemployment rate is, the yield on the 30-year bond could rise to about 7.25 percent in the second quarter.
And Bruce Steinberg, manager for macroeconomics at Merrill Lynch, said, "Because the labor market is the U.S. economy's main potential trouble spot, the future path of monetary policy is chiefly contingent on the performance of labor market indicators." Mr. Steinberg said he expected the employment report to show that 190,000 jobs were added to payrolls in January, which is lower than the consensus estimate of 210,000.
"For the Fed to remain on extended hold," Mr. Steinberg said, "payroll gains need to average a bit less than our January estimate on a multimonth basis."
The trend in the labor market, he added, is probably for gains in the range of 150,000 to 175,000 a month. For that reason, he said, he believes that the Fed will be able to keep rates at current levels longer than many economists think.

HEADLINE: Fed's Policy-Making Panel Leaves Rates Unchanged

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, betting that a recent surge in economic growth will moderate and leave wage and price inflation under control.
The decision continues a yearlong pattern in which the Fed has kept monetary policy on hold as the economy has accelerated, slowed and then accelerated again. The Fed's last move was on Jan. 31, 1996, when it reduced its Federal funds target rate, its overnight loan rate for banks, to 5.25 percent from 5.5 percent, and its discount rate for loans to financial institutions to 5 percent from 5.25 percent. 
 Because the Fed's decision today not to raise rates had been widely anticipated for weeks in the financial markets, it was not a powerful enough dose of good news to stop a technology-led swoon in stock prices. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 86.58 points, to 6,746.90.
Since last summer the Fed's official policy has been a "bias" toward tightening, a way of signaling that it will raise rates at the first compelling evidence that inflation might be taking root. Economists said they expected that the Fed kept the policy in place today, although it would not disclose its decision until after the next meeting of its policy-making body on March 25.
By keeping rates unchanged, the Fed is once again waiting for further evidence of whether growth will slow sufficiently to keep wages from spiking up and setting off an upward spiral in inflation. Despite the economy's torrid 4.7 percent growth rate in the fourth quarter, wage increases have remained muted and there is almost no sign of rising inflation.
"The inflation picture still looks pretty good to them," said Richard D. Rippe, the chief economist at Prudential Securities. "At the same time they are concerned that if the economy stays strong we could move from a position where we're running near capacity to where we're hitting capacity or exceeding it and therefore getting more inflationary pressures down the road. So they need to see signs that growth is moderating."
There are tentative signs that the economy was cooling off even before the end of last year. The Commerce Department reported today that the value of new orders to factories fell 1.3 percent in December, the second consecutive decline. The department said shipments of finished goods and inventories of completed products also declined.
But economists and financial markets are now looking ahead to the next major economic indicator, the release on Friday of January figures on job growth and the unemployment rate. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said in recent Congressional testimony that he was watching closely to see whether an unusual period in which workers appeared to be trading job security for restrained wage increases was coming to an end.
Economists remain divided over whether the Fed will have to raise rates at its next meeting in March, or at the following one in May, or perhaps not at all.
"The pressures are going to continue to build," said William Dudley, an economist with Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The economy is going to continue to grow above trend. By March a tightening is more of an even proposition, and by May it's maybe likely."
Economists at Merrill Lynch, however, said in a report today that they did not expect a rate increase anytime soon.
They said they believed the economy created about 190,000 new jobs in January, a relatively strong performance, but that the underlying trend in coming months will be around 150,000 to 175,000 a month, a rate that it said would not threaten to reignite inflation.
"Given our growth, inflation and employment outlooks, we believe that the Fed will be able to remain on hold for longer than most probably believe," the report said. "Nevertheless we expect the next Fed move, whenever it occurs, to be a tightening."
The Fed also said today that it was changing the timing of its release of minutes from meetings of its policy- making Federal Open Market Committee. The Fed has been releasing the minutes of each meeting on the Friday after the subsequent meeting. It will now release the minutes on the Thursday after the subsequent meeting, and will move the release time up to 2 P.M. from 4:30 P.M. The change takes effect on Thursday, when the Fed will release minutes of its December meeting.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Big Brother wants to manage the broadcast spectrum again.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
ASK the nearest economist about Federal auctions of the airwaves, and you're likely to get an "I told you so." Only recently viewed by Washington "realists" as another impractical scheme from libertarian dreamers who never met a free market they didn't like, competitive sales of space on the communications spectrum have been embraced by mainstream politicians as a painless way to raise revenue. With $20 billion garnered thus far and Congress counting on an additional $2.9 billion from an auction in April, the long campaign to unleash market forces has apparently been won.
Or has it? A seemingly innocuous policy statement from the Federal Communications Commission arguing that, in general, free markets can manage the spectrum better than bureaucrats, was recently rejected by a majority of commissioners. A plan to allow winners in the next auction virtual carte blanche in how they use the spectrum is also in deep trouble at the commission. And next week a hostile majority of the House telecommunications subcommittee is planning a day of hearings on spectrum allocation, a none-too-subtle warning to deregulators that Big Brother is alive and well. "The backlash has begun," said Reed E. Hundt, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. 
 For most of the F.C.C.'s 60-year history, scarce radio and television spectrum was parceled out free to those deemed most likely to serve the public interest, a phrase that loosely translated as those who knew best how to feather politicians' nests. When spectrum became so valuable in the 1980's that enough to operate a television station in a medium-sized city was worth $500 million and every high-stakes decision by the F.C.C. was challenged by competing armies of lawyers and lobbyists, the commission tried to finesse the issue by distributing spectrum licenses in lotteries. Only after the absurdity of transforming F.C.C. proceedings into Washington's own version of the Publishers' Clearinghouse sweepstakes became embarrassingly clear -- after tens of thousands of people applied in hope of winning a cellular phone franchise that could be sold the next day for seven figures -- only then did the commissioners turn to auctions.
What good-government types tend to forget, says Peter Pitsch, an economic consultant who advised the former F.C.C. chairman, Mark Fowler, is that Congress's willingness to go along with auctions had as much to do with the drive to balance the budget as with receptivity to deregulation. Indeed, it took an uneasy alliance of free-market policy wonks and politicians desperate to raise revenues to put auctions on the agenda.
But Congress did approve. What's more, it is now demanding that the F.C.C. shove spectrum out the door at a furious pace to keep the revenue flowing. So why are both Congress and the F.C.C. suddenly casting a jaundiced eye on the efficacy of the free market in managing the airwaves?
The answer is straightforward enough. While Congress and the F.C.C. no longer questions the wisdom of auctions to help balance the budget, both claim it as their duty to micromanage the use of spectrum for what is casually referred as the public interest. And both are determined to act as referees in the coming battles over the winners' attempts to move their spectrum from one use to a more profitable one.
The stakes are enormous: five years ago the F.C.C. staff estimated that a transfer of spectrum used by a single television station in Los Angeles to cellular phone service would increase the spectrum's value by $1 billion. Yet free-market types seeking to make newly auctioned spectrum licenses freely transferable cannot expect much help from President Clinton and other political pragmatists.
A first test comes later this month, when the F.C.C. sets the ground rules for the Congressionally mandated auction of spectrum that has been vaguely set aside for "wireless communications." Mr. Hundt wants to give winning bidders the right to use it as they please. But the cellular phone and new "personal communications service" companies -- some of which paid a fortune for licenses -- are lobbying hard to block added competition. And at least at the moment, the chairman does not command a majority.
At the heart of the matter, Mr. Pitsch suggests, lies a fundamental tension between consumer and producer interest. Writ large, the job of the F.C.C. is to reduce economic scarcity, allocating communication spectrum in ways that generate the most value for consumers. On the other hand, he points out, "anyone who already has spectrum doesn't want to make it less scarce" because scarcity drives up market price.
Mr. Pitsch remains an optimist. "There's a great opportunity here for unleashing competition in local telephone service and wireless communications," he argues. The catch, of course, is that the opportunity could mean hard times for those already in the business.

HEADLINE: Russia Is Selling Nuclear Reactors to India; U.S. Protests

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Russia's cash-starved nuclear establishment is planning to sell two nuclear reactors to India, a move that has prompted protests from Washington.
The United States has urged Russia to drop the multibillion-dollar sale, asserting that it violates a 1992 agreement among nuclear suppliers and will hurt international efforts to stem the spread of nuclear weapons. 
 The brewing dispute underscores East-West tension on nuclear issues, as Russia's nuclear energy establishment has turned to exports to try to plug a yawning budget gap.
Western experts worry that Russian exports may undermine the bold promises of cooperation on nuclear issues made at a meeting last year between President Boris N. Yeltsin and Western leaders.
Russia and the United States are already at odds over Moscow's decision to sell a nuclear reactor to Iran, which the United States insists has begun a determined effort to develop a nuclear weapon.
Russia's desire to help Cuba complete construction on a nuclear power plant has also caused worries in Florida, which fears that the plant will be unsafe.
Nor are nuclear exports the only worry. Moscow recently touched off a crisis by agreeing to sell an advanced S-300 anti-aircraft system to the Greek Cypriot Government. After Turkey threatened military action, the Clinton Administration began a furious round of diplomacy to soothe tensions in the area.
But Russian nuclear officials are unrepentant about their drive for foreign sales and say the sale of power plants to India will not enhance its military potential.
"We must expand our exports," Viktor N. Mikhailov, Russia's Atomic Energy Minister, told reporters last month. "We will use the export earnings to repay our debts."
The roots of the Indian dispute go back to 1974, when New Delhi startled the world by conducting a nuclear test. The Indians used plutonium from a research rector sold by Canada for peaceful purposes.
In an effort to stop the spread of nuclear weapons, nuclear suppliers agreed to a system of export controls, which were broadened in 1992.
The 1992 "suppliers' agreement" forbids nuclear suppliers from exporting nuclear technology to aspiring nuclear powers.
Specifically, it says that nuclear suppliers cannot sell nuclear technology to nations that are not formally recognized as nuclear weapons states and which do not allow international inspections of all of their key nuclear institutes, laboratories and plants and of the nuclear material there. Under the treaty against the spread of nuclear arms, only the United States, Russia, Britain, France and China are recognized as nuclear weapon states.
"The basic idea is that countries should not get the benefits of nuclear energy without making a comprehensive commitment to its peaceful use," an American official said.
As a practical matter, the 1992 agreement imposed an embargo on sales of nuclear technology to India, Pakistan and Israel, which are believed to have developed nuclear weapons and have refused to sign the treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons and accept international monitoring.
South Asia has long been an area of special concern. India and Pakistan, both emerging nuclear powers, are bitter antagonists and have fought three wars since 1947.
American diplomats have also been frustrated by India's opposition to a nuclear test ban. India says that it is not willing to accept a ban until the major nuclear powers agreed to a timetable for disarmament.
But American officials say they believe that India's position is simply a rationale for keeping its nuclear option open. American officials became alarmed in 1995 when American spy satellites detected possible preparations for a nuclear test.
As a nuclear exporter, Russia went along with the toughened controls over nuclear supplies. But after it signed the suppliers' agreement, economic pressures began to build.
Racked by budget cuts and driven by a fervent commitment to nuclear energy, Russia's Atomic Energy Minister makes no qualms about the importance of the Indian deal and other foreign sales.
The ministry received only 72 percent of its budget allotment last year and many of its nuclear power customers failed to pay up, forcing it to delay payment of wages to nuclear engineers and workers.
In December, more than a dozen employees at a St. Petersburg nuclear power plant briefly seized the control room and threatened to shut down the plant until they were paid.
The budget crunch was so severe that the ministry it turned to commercial banks for credit at interest rates as high as 70 percent a year.
Mr. Mikhailov said his ministry is now saddled with a debt of about $285 million, and is looking toward exports to help repay its loans. Russia's nuclear exports exceeded $2 billion last year.
Yevgeny A. Reshetnikov, a Deputy Minister of Russia's Atomic Energy Agency, declined to specify the exact value of the Indian deal. But he said in an interview that the value of the sale was $1.5 billion to $2 billion for each of the light-water reactors.
The reactors are to be used as nuclear power plants in southern India and can produce one million kilowatts each. Light-water reactors use ordinary water to slow down the neutrons emitted by nuclear fission to the speed required to sustain the chain reaction.
Russian and Indian officials hope to complete their talks this month, Mr. Reshetnikov said. The talks have been snagged by disputes over credits to be provided by the Russian Finance Ministry, and some American officials have expressed doubt that the deal will be consummated.
But as Russian and Indian officials have moved to complete the agreement, the United States has made repeated, if quiet, protests. "We have made demarches to the Russians objecting to this sale," a senior American official said.
Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia arrived today for several days of talks with Vice President Al Gore. American officials have used such meetings in the past to press their concern over the Russian sale of a nuclear reactor to Iran and other security issues, but officials declined to say if the Indian sale would be discussed in the confidential, informal discussions among the leader or their top aides.
Even as they acknowledge their economic motivation, Russian officials defend the sale. They argue that the reactors they sell will be subject to monitoring, unlike some key Indian nuclear research centers and plants, and thus will not directly contribute to India's military potential.
Russian officials also insist that the sale should be exempt from the 1992 suppliers' agreement because it was included in an earlier understanding between Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet President, and Indian leaders. The initial agreement to build the reactor was worked out in 1987, Mr. Reshetnikov said, though he conceded that much of the technology would be newer.
Indian officials, for their part, say they greatly need nuclear plants because of their shortage of electric power and say Washington's arms- control policies reflect a colonialist double standard.
But Washington insists that the sale is forbidden by the agreement and would be a setback for international efforts to stop the spread of nuclear weapons.
"There are two basic problems," an American official said. "One is the Indians. We worry about what the Indians will do with the reactors. We worry about the safety culture. Even a light-water reactor produces a fair amount of plutonium."
The other problem, he asserted, is Russia's decision to breach the 1992 agreement by selling to an emerging nuclear power like India. "The Russian Federation, as signatories to the 1992 suppliers' agreement, should not be selling these controlled nuclear technologies," he added.
Other specialists say the Russian move is ill timed and appears to reward India at a time when it is being difficult on nuclear issues.
"It is an unfortunate time for Russia to be giving India a nuclear pat on the back," said Leonard S. Spector, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

HEADLINE: 4 Britons Recalled From Nigeria in Visa-Selling Investigation

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 5

 BODY:
At least four British employees of the visa section of the British High Commission here have been sent home in recent weeks because of what diplomats suspect is a major visa-selling ring.
Some were sent home for their own protection and some because of suspected involvement in irregularities, said John Whattam, spokesman for the High Commission. He did not elaborate. 
 Four British police officers have arrived to investigate possible irregularities in the visa section of the High Commission, or embassy.
British visas are said by European diplomats to be available on the black market for around $3,000. Diplomats say they believe much of the business is run by well organized criminal rings.
The United States and European countries are reluctant to grant visas to Nigerians out of the concern that they will remain in the country they visit.
Nigerian newspapers have reported with delight the allegations that British citizens are involved in the illegal sales. A number of newspapers have been quick to take editorial shots at Britain after being the object of disparaging British statements about official corruption in Nigeria.
"Stinking British Embassy," read the banner headline Saturday in the newspaper Concord. Under the headline was the official picture of Queen Elizabeth II.
Word of the British visa scandal has spread a sense of distress through other Western embassies in Lagos. "We are being extra vigilant," said Joseph Melrose, the American charge d'affaires.
The United States Embassy said it has received reports of people from the outside claiming to be able to influence the visa process, and promising to provide visas for a fee. The Embassy said those reported to be involved have no official standing with the embassy.
There have also been reports made by people seeking visas from both the German and United States Embassies that Nigerian gate guards demand bribes just to let applicants pass.
The major concern of American diplomats is the falsification of documents. The Embassy has received reports from international airports of Nigerians traveling on doctored American passports. Embassy officials suspect that attempts are also being made to forge American visas in Nigeria.
Not only is Nigeria one of the world's major drug-trafficking points, but most public corporations have reputations of being corrupt, and fake documents of virtually any kind are easily available on street corners.
American diplomats say more than 40 percent of the documents accompanying visa application forms they receive are false, with the German Embassy saying the figure is 90 percent for its visa section.
"We can't catch them all," said one European diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. "We're lucky if we can identify a fifth of the false papers."
An article published in a Nigerian travel journal last year gave detailed instructions how to make arrangements to get a foreign visa.
"If you want to make everything go faster, turn up for the interview panel with, say, $5,000 to $10,000," it advised, reminding applicants to bring personal documents like marriage certificates, which are available for the equivalent of $6, and to dress well for the interview.

HEADLINE: Ecuadoreans Rally in Drive to Oust President

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: QUITO, Ecuador, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Banging pot covers and bearing placards calling for an end to economic austerity, nepotism and corruption, hundreds of thousands of Ecuadoreans filled streets throughout the country today at the start of a 48-hour general strike staged to force President Abdala Bucaram out of office.
Just seven months after Mr. Bucaram's landslide election, the people who delivered him the most resounding victory in Ecuador's 16 years of democracy are handing him the largest protest of the democratic era and pushing his Government to the verge of collapse. Banks, stores, factories and financial markets closed today; tires and garbage burned at intersections throughout the country. 
 In an emotional speech on Tuesday night, Mr. Bucaram pledged he would defend "the Constitution and democracy with my very life," and proposed talks with business associations, social groups, indigenous peoples and labor to build a new state.
He called former presidents who came out in support of the protests "conspirators" who had "already governed and destroyed the nation."
Cesar Gaviria, president of the Organization of American States, flew here in a show of support for Mr. Bucaram today, at the President's request.
"There is a great concern throughout the hemisphere because of the language of confrontation that's being used," Mr. Gaviria said, also speaking of "fear that this will set back democracy in Ecuador."
Since his inauguration, the vast majority of those who voted for Mr. Bucaram have turned against him, as the President abandoned his populist stance in favor of austerity measures that removed the basic subsidies that many poor Ecuadoreans depended on to make ends meet. As the cost of electricity, public transportation, cooking fuel, gasoline and telephones rose, the popularity of Mr. Bucaram, who has released a rock film called "A Madman in Love" since he took office, plummeted.
Tens of thousands of demonstrators surrounded the Congress today, demanding that legislators begin impeachment proceedings. Some protesters wore costumes or masks, and many made up their faces to resemble Mr. Bucaram, if only with a smudge of dark shoe polish in imitation of the narrow mustache that once was his trademark. Thick black smoke from burning tires billowed around the building.
Demonstrators said they were rejecting not just Mr. Bucaram but also the economic model that has become something of a new catechism in South America.
"People in Latin America are very poor, and they can't be completely oriented toward paying off the foreign debt," said Edgar Zarate, a law professor who joined the protest. "We need an Ecuadorean model adapted to the conditions in our country."
Manuel Ayala, a 65-year-old painter who cheered on the protesters as they passed him, said Mr. Bucaram's administration was "six months of corruption." He said Ecuador's economy had to be oriented toward "social justice and a fair distribution of resources, on the basis of the sovereignty of the country."
Mr. Bucaram's positions have grown increasingly erratic as the opposition to him has built. This week the President said he supported the strike, and announced plans to replace 60 percent of his Cabinet.
The Vice President, Rosalia Arteaga Serrano, accused Fabian Alarcon, the president of the Congress, of planning a coup. As the police surrounded the Congress, word spread that Mr. Alarcon and other political leaders would be arrested, and that the Congress would be dissolved.
Mr. Alarcon denied any involvement in a plot to overthrow Mr. Bucaram, noting that the Congress had the legal means to impeach the President. He showed reporters a congressional resolution to open an extraordinary session to debate the crisis. It carried 52 signatures, 10 more than needed to impeach the President.
Images of corruption and nepotism have tarnished the administration. Last week the United States Ambassador, Leslie M. Alexander, said corruption was so serious that Americans should think twice before doing business here.
Many protesters complained about a party reportedly given by Mr. Bucaram's son, Jacob, 18, to celebrate making his first million dollars, after six months in the job. He is the unofficial head of the customs service. Neither the President nor his son have confirmed that a party took place.
One protester, Alberto Zuleta, an economics student, noted that at the current minimum salary of $30 a month, the amoung earned by many Ecuadoreans, it would take centuries to earn $1 million. His own family, Mr. Zuleta said, cut back on food and medicines because of increases in the costs of fuel and other products and services. "The money we spend on food is hardly enough to maintain us," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Roche to Buy Flavor Maker for $1.1 Billion

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Roche Holding A.G. said today that it had agreed to buy Tastemaker, a flavors company, in a transaction that the two sellers, Hercules Inc. and Mallinckrodt Inc. of the United States, valued at a total of about $1.1 billion, including debt assumption.
Roche, the giant Swiss drug maker, said the purchase of Tastemaker, which is based in Cincinnati, would make it the world's biggest producer of fragrances and flavors. 
 "Roche may be able to reap some economies of scale, so this should have a positive impact on group profits," said Genghis Lloyd-Harris, an analyst at Credit Suisse. "Still, flavors and fragrances is a low-margin business, and I would rather have seen Roche get out of it."
The acquisition would give Roche 16 percent of the global fragrances and flavors market, Mr. Lloyd-Harris said. International Flavors and Fragrances Inc., a New York-based rival, has 15 percent of the world market, he said.
Hercules and Mallinckrodt, each of which owns 50 percent of Tastemaker, said in separate statements that the sale would have a net value to each company of about $550 million. Mallinckrodt said the transaction would include an exchange of stock and debt assumption.
Hercules said it would use the proceeds to buy back its stock. Its board approved the repurchase of an additional 10 million of its 101.5 million shares. A previous plan aimed to buy back as many as 65 million shares.
Mallinckrodt said it planned to focus on its human health care and specialty chemicals operations.
Tastemaker had 1996 sales of about $320 million and has 1,280 employees, Roche said. Analysts estimated Tastemaker's 1996 earnings at $42 million, up from $32 million a year earlier. Roche's own flavors and fragrances division, Givaudan-Roure, had 1996 sales of 1.4 billion Swiss francs, or $980 million.
Today's announcement followed intense speculation that Roche might sell its fragrances and flavors division and expand in areas like pharmaceuticals and diagnostics.
"In terms of Roche's sales and cash position, this acquisition is peanuts," said Patrick Carisch, head of equities at CS Asset Management. "This will put an end to sale speculation, at least for now."
Roche's nonvoting stock certificates fell 95 francs, or $66.51, to 12,190 francs, or $8,534.62, on the Swiss stock exchange today. Since Jan. 13, the shares have risen about 16 percent on talk that the company could sell Givaudan-Roure.
Lifted by the sale and the additional share repurchase, Hercules stock rose 12.5 cents, to $46.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Mallinckrodt stock fell 50 cents, to $40.

HEADLINE: GIANT WALL STREET MERGER: THE IMPACT ON JOBS;
Little Immediate Effect is Seen for City Economy

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Because there is little overlap in the businesses of Morgan Stanley Group Inc. and Dean Witter, Discover & Company, the immediate effects of their plan to merge will be minimal for New York City, company officials said yesterday.
"They will maintain their headquarters and we will maintain ours," Jeanmarie McFadden, a spokeswoman for Morgan Stanley, said.
Though company officials would not say whether job cuts were planned, industry experts said that because the lines of business are so different, the amount of job duplication is not expected to be large. Morgan Stanley, which has about 5,800 employees in New York City, specializes in institutional work and investment banking, while Dean Witter, with about 5,000 employees, has pursued a niche in retail investment services and credit cards. 
 But the combination also raises uncertainty about whether future mergers, with perhaps less desirable consequences for the city, could result.
Analysts said the deal could set off a scramble to consolidate, with firms buying each other to better compete with the new Morgan Stanley-Dean Witter powerhouse or merging to avoid being swallowed by a rival.
And the deal comes at a time when New York's dependence on Wall Street for its economic growth is greater than it has been for decades. As other parts of the New York economy have emerged only slowly from the deep slump of the late 1980's and early 1990's -- or continued an outright decline, in areas like manufacturing and public sector jobs -- the securities industry has boomed. That has provided huge tax revenues for the city and state budgets and resulted in the creation of thousands of jobs, especially among the businesses like accounting and law, which serve the big investment houses.
And the deal would create a giant new player in the local economy -- quiescent for now perhaps, but with the power to roil local markets in real estate and employment.
Real estate professionals say that Morgan Stanley has in the last few years emerged as a major property owner in New York, whose holdings include its headquarters at 48th Street and Broadway in midtown Manhattan. Dean Witter remains a rent-paying tenant at its downtown headquarters in the World Trade Center, with a lease that expires early in the next century.
Real estate experts are already speculating about what will happen, and who will benefit, when that lease ends. While the overlap between Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter may be minimal, some operations are bound to be consolidated.
At that point, the companies will have to decide whether to pick locations in midtown, in the financial district -- where rents are about 30 percent lower -- or somewhere else.
Nonetheless, the effects of the merger are likely to be less direct and immediate than the results of some other recent mergers. For instance, when the Chase Manhattan Corporation merged with the Chemical Banking Corporation last year, thousands of jobs were rendered instantly redundant, resulting in a flood of layoffs.
"When two companies in the same business merge, that's a negative for New York," said Don Brooks, national chairman of the securities and commodities practice at Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm. "That's not this."

HEADLINE: 3 Swiss Banks Plan To Establish Fund For Nazis' Victims

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Switzerland's three largest banks announced today that they are to set up what was called a "humanitarian fund for the victims of the Holocaust," with an initial worth of around $70 million.
The gesture, coming after months of pressure from American Jewish groups, was apparently intended to head off threats from them and from New York institutions of sanctions against Swiss banks, a pillar of the Swiss economy, that would further harm their battered reputation. 
 Banking officials said it represented the first time since World War II that Swiss commercial banks had offered their own money in connection with the long-running effort by Jewish groups to seek compensation related to Switzerland's close financial relationship with Nazi Germany.
A statement by the three banks -- Credit Suisse, the Swiss Bank Corporation and Union Bank of Switzerland -- said they "trust that this initiative will clear the way for the Swiss Government, Switzerland's business and financial community and Jewish organizations to work together toward finding a just and equitable solution to the issues involved."
In New York, the World Jewish Congress said through a spokesman, Elan Steinberg, that it viewed the announcement as "a positive response" to calls by Edgar M. Bronfman Sr., the president of the organization, for Switzerland to make a "good-faith financial gesture."
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who has taken up the controversy and pressed the Swiss Government for a thorough review, called the move "a breakthrough, an acknowledgment of the wrongdoing," and added that it was "an important first step in dealing with this tragic, disgraceful period."
Switzerland's secretive commercial banks have been facing mounting accusations -- which they deny -- that they are hoarding untold wealth in unclaimed deposits by Holocaust victims who opened Swiss bank accounts in the 1930's and were then killed in the death camps.
The three banks said today that they had put 100 million Swiss francs, about $70 million, in an account with the Swiss National Bank and invited other parties, particularly the Government and the Swiss National Bank, to contribute.
Officials said the three banks had contributed roughly a third each and said the move would put pressure on both the Government and the Swiss National Bank, the country's central bank, to match their contribution. Rainer Gut, the head of Credit Suisse, suggested last month that the commercial banks, the Government and the National Bank should all contribute the same amount.
The precise purposes of the proposed fund have still to be fully worked out. Mr. Steinberg said it should meet the "flesh and blood needs of Holocaust survivors in their final years," including claims on dormant accounts.
However, Gertrud Erismann, a spokeswoman for the Union Bank of Switzerland in Zurich, said the mechanics of how the fund would be administered and distributed had still to be legally set up by the Government in Bern. She stressed in a telephone interview, however, that the proposed fund would not draw on dormant accounts or prejudice claims on them.
The amount deposited by the three banks is much lower than the figure of more than $250 million that arose in talks late last year between Swiss officials and the World Jewish Congress. Mr. Steinberg said Swiss officials had contacted the World Jewish Congress on Tuesday night and stressed that the 100 million Swiss francs was "an initial infusion" that could lead to "further contributions from other parties."
"Mr. Bronfman is hopeful that indeed both the Swiss Government and the Swiss National Bank will contribute but we have been given no commitment," he said.
Werner Abegg, a spokesman for the Swiss National Bank in Zurich, said that while it had publicly expressed a readiness to contribute an unspecified amount to a "fund or foundation," it would act in concert with the Government.
The Government has said it will consider a contribution once the function and aims of the fund have been worked out and once a Government-appointed commission of historians issues a preliminary report on wartime Swiss financial activities. The Government says the report should be ready before the summer.
A Government statement today welcoming the banks' decision said it "will now further enable taking the necessary steps to create a fund or foundation in regard to defining its purpose and form."
The announcement came two days after the United States, Britain and France agreed to freeze the distribution of $68 million in gold bars looted by Nazi Germany and said it could be used to form the core of a Holocaust compensation fund. How and when that money will be disbursed is subject to political and logistical uncertainties. In any event, Mr. Steinberg said he believed the frozen money would be kept separate from the proposed Swiss fund.
The issues of wartime Swiss gold dealings with Germany and the postwar reluctance of Swiss banks to quickly identify dormant accounts belonging to Holocaust victims are being investigated in Switzerland as separate issues.
Apart from the historians' commission looking into a wide range of Swiss wartime dealings with Germany -- including the trade in looted gold and Switzerland's treatment of Jewish refugees -- a separate panel headed by Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the United States Federal Reserve, is inquiring into the whereabouts of dormant accounts.
Swiss banks say they have found some $29 million in dormant accounts but argue that only a small proportion can be traced to Holocaust victims. Many claimants seeking access to dormant accounts say Swiss bank officials treated them in an unsympathetic and legalistic way, demanding, for instance, that death certificates be produced for people whose deaths in Nazi camps had gone unrecorded.
"We are breaking with the past," Michael Willi, a spokesman for the Swiss Bank Corporation in Basel, Switzerland, said today. "We are not saying we are guilty. We are not saying we collaborated. We are saying that, in the past, we acted in such a legalistic way and we want to break with that past. Now we want to make a humanitarian gesture."
Previously, he said, the only sums paid out in Holocaust-related claims were from the dormant accounts, not from the banks' own funds.
Today's statement from the Swiss banks said they "stressed that investigative efforts to identify unclaimed assets belonging to victims of the Nazi regime are separate from and unaffected by this initiative."
Up until last month the Swiss Government resisted the idea of a Holocaust compensation fund, arguing that it constituted an admission of guilt in the face of what officials depicted as a broad conspiracy by the United States, Jewish organizations and the news media.
Even in early January, the Swiss said they were prepared to use only dormant accounts left by Holocaust victims to set up a fund, an idea that outraged many Jewish groups and which only served to increase demands for a boycott of Swiss banks.
Then, on Jan. 23, after a security guard discovered officials shredding archives at the Union Bank of Switzerland, the Government announced it would take the lead in setting up a Holocaust compensation fund.
Swiss banking officials said the announcement today reflected the frustration of some senior commercial bankers at the Government's fumbling of a crisis that directly threatened their ability to do business and expand in the United States. However, the officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity, the creation of the fund had been agreed only after one bank -- the Union Bank of Switzerland -- dropped objections to the idea.

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1134 words

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
In Evolution of Clinton, A Few Echoes Survive

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Four years ago, in his first major address to Congress at the beginning of his first term, President Clinton announced a plan that, among even more audacious initiatives, would make the Head Start education and nutrition program available to "every eligible child."
On Tuesday night, in one of his many applause lines in his State of Union Message, Mr. Clinton announced a plan that "expands Head Start to one million children by 2002." What he failed to mention is that those one million amount to only half of the children who are eligible. 
 On Tuesday, Mr. Clinton urged the nation to "rise to the decisive moment," much as four years ago he warned that "nations must decide whether they are prepared to rise to the occasions history presents them."
But while much of the same language -- about offering opportunity, demanding responsibility, and preparing for the 21st century -- echoes through those two speeches, as through scores of others he gave in between, what the words add up to has changed dramatically.
Indeed, the two speeches show the evolution of Mr. Clinton as well as the influence of his master strategist, Dick Morris. Like points on a chart, they help plot the arc of the Clinton Administration from the first term to the second, revealing often consistent ends but diminished means and illustrating what has changed -- and what has not.
"I am asking the United States Congress to pass a real campaign finance reform bill this year," Mr. Clinton said in 1993, when his hair was shaggy and iron gray, not sleek and silver.
On Tuesday night, the President tried to convey a sense of decisive and coherent action, but without proposing any ambitious new Federal programs. Four years ago, he communicated the same sense. But then he called for radical changes in health care, significant increases in taxes, and $30 billion for highways and summer jobs.
Much happened in the last four years besides the arrival and departure of Mr. Morris. Asked what had changed between the speeches, one senior adviser to Mr. Clinton snorted. "How about the world?" he asked.
The sluggish economy that helped elect Mr. Clinton sped up and steadied for four years, helping sweep him back into office and allowing him to declare on Tuesday night: "We have won back the basic strength of our economy."
Four years ago, the man seated behind Mr. Clinton was a Democratic Speaker, Tom Foley, not Newt Gingrich, who in 1993 sat frowning in the audience as Mr. Clinton joked: "It is nice to have a fresh excuse for giving a long speech."
Mr. Clinton has come to recognize the limits imposed by the fiscal discipline that he has pushed, the adviser said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
"It's painting with not as big and bold strokes," he said of Tuesday's address. "We're all shaped by events and the life we live, and he knows a lot more now than he did four years ago. It's reality-based speech."
The change in Congress forced Mr. Clinton to switch to a more rhetorical, as opposed to programmatic, approach. He began issuing "challenges" to the American people.
Further, Mr. Clinton changed the content of his message simply because he has made progress toward some of his goals, including cutting the deficit. Four years ago, he asked for passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement; Tuesday night, he asked that such agreements be expanded.
But some of the specific proposals announced on Tuesday, including Mr. Clinton's call for character education and school uniforms, appeared prominently in the State of the Union address a year ago, promoted partly by Mr. Morris and thoroughly poll-tested to insure that they would buff Mr. Clinton's hoped-for image as a "good father" for the country.
Mr. Morris's influence may also be glimpsed in the way Mr. Clinton presented himself. Four years ago, to prepare his listeners for radical change in their health care, Mr. Clinton described the existing system in near-apocalyptic terms.
"Our families will never be secure; our businesses will never be strong and our government will never again be fully solvent until we tackle the health-care crisis," Mr. Clinton said then. "We must do it this year." (On Tuesday, Mr. Clinton said that the country must continue to increase access to health care, but only "step by step.")
Mr. Morris recounts in his recent book, "Behind the Oval Office," that he discovered it was a mistake for Mr. Clinton to mention bad economic news. "By omitting the bad news we usually gained an average of 20 points," he writes, describing how parts of Mr. Clinton's speeches were received in polls.
On Tuesday night, Mr. Clinton omitted the bad news throughout his speech. Even when he summoned the country to address what he called "my number one priority for the next four years" -- fixing the education system -- he did not describe a system in crisis. The closest he came to painting a grim picture was to say that with "record numbers of school buildings falling into disrepair, this has now become a serious national concern."
His aides were at pains all day to emphasize that Mr. Clinton did not see a crisis in education.
"I don't think he feels it's a crisis," Erskine B. Bowles, Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, said in briefing reporters about the address on Tuesday afternoon. "I think he feels we have a lot of opportunity."
Instead of dwelling on classrooms that are falling apart or children who cannot read or add, Mr. Clinton in his speech resurrected sunny language from his campaign to conjure images of a bright future: "Every 8-year-old must be able to read, every 12-year-old must be able to log on to the Internet, every 18-year-old must be able to go to college, and every adult American must be able to keep on learning for a lifetime."
To some observers of the Clinton Administration, Mr. Morris's role was to reinforce Mr. Clinton's own centrist impulses.
"There has always been a centrist tendency in Bill Clinton," said William E. Leuchtenburg, a historian at the University of North Carolina, "and I think what he has been saying -- what he said during the 1996 campaign and what he's been saying since then -- is congruent with that way of looking at the world. The departure was the health care plan."
Indeed, for all the emphasis in the last year on Mr. Morris's influence over Mr. Clinton, some of the themes in Tuesday's speech dovetailed with those four years ago.
But President has honed his language over time.
In 1993, he called for "a commitment to opportunity, to individual responsibility, to community." By the campaign, and again Tuesday night, that challenge had become this familiar refrain: "We must be committed to the pursuit of opportunity for all Americans, responsibility from all Americans in a community of all Americans."

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
3 Swiss Banks to Create Fund for Holocaust Victims
Credit Suisse, Swiss Bank Corporation and Union Bank of Switzerland, the three largest Swiss banks, announced that they would set up a fund for Holocaust victims and put $70 million into it. A1
 
Russia to Sell Reactors to India
Russia's nuclear establishment is planning to sell two reactors to India. The United States has objected to the multibillion-dollar sale, saying it violates a ban on sales of nuclear equipment to India, which is thought to possess atomic capabilities. Russian officials insist that they need export revenue to maintain their own nuclear program, in which engineers often go unpaid. A3
 
Russian Nerve Gas at Issue
The Clinton Administration, which is seeking Senate ratification of a chemical weapons ban, has asked the Russian Government to stop producing a lethal nerve gas. Some opponents of the treaty say that the gas's existence demonstrates that any ban on such weapons would be ineffective. Moscow, like Washington, has signed but not ratified the 1993 Chemical Weapons Convention, which prohibits the production of poison gas. A7
 
Mexican Rebels Speak Out
Hiding in a safe house near Mexico City, military leaders of the Popular Revolutionary Army said they believed their movement was gaining support all across Mexico, especially in rural areas where corruption is rife. The rebels said they planned a longterm armed resistance against the Mexican Government, which they see as corrupt. The rebels made several dramatic appearances last year, but seemed to fade away when pursued by the army. A10
 
Israelis Ponder Buffer Zone
Israelis mourned the 73 soldiers who died in a helicopter collision while en route to southern Lebanon, and faced hard questions about Israel's military occupation of a 9-mile-wide buffer zone there. In the last three years, 70 Israeli soldiers have died in the zone. But Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ruled out any change in policy. A11
 
Zaire's Neighbors Are Warned
The State Department has warned Zaire's eastern neighbors, Uganda, Rwanda and Burundi, to stay out of the civil war being waged between Zaire's Government and Tutsi rebels in the eastern part of the country. The conflict has flared as a Government counteroffensive has apparently stalled. A9
 
Protest in Ecuador
Hundreds of thousands of Ecuadoreans took to the streets in the first day of a two-day general strike intended to force President Abdala Bucaram out of office. Congress called a special session to consider whether Mr. Bucaram should be impeached, but it was suspended until Thursday. Mr. Bucaram ran for office as a populist but has since tried to push through austere economic policies. A10
 
NATIONAL A14-22, B8-11
 
Republicans Begin Attack On Many Clinton Proposals
Republicans went on the offensive to attack many of the proposals President Clinton made in his State of the Union Message. The attacks showed that while the President has moved toward the political center since taking office, a steep divide remains between him and Republicans. A1
 
Using oratory reminiscent of the New Deal, Mr. Clinton went to Augusta State University in Georgia and invoked the spirit of Franklin D. Roosevelt and the programs that Roosevelt used to help the region in the 1930's as reasons to support his own plans for education. B8
 
Clinton Prepares His Budget
President Clinton will give Congress his detailed proposals for balancing the Federal budget by 2002, including tax and spending cuts that Administration officials say will yield a surplus in five years. B8
 
A New Chapter for Simpson
The wrongful death lawsuit against O. J. Simpson by the families of his former wife and her friend went back to court to consider punitive damages. B10
 
Responses to the Simpson jury's verdict were expressed in ways that have come to be predictable. But regardless of their opinions, many people were just glad to see the drawn-out affair coming to an end. A1
 
15 Hurt in Amtrak Crash
An Amtrak passenger train on its way from Miami to New York with 187 passengers and 16 crew members struck a tractor-trailer, causing three passenger cars to derail and injuring 15 people. The Silver Meteor was about 13 miles north of Jacksonville, Fla., when the accident occurred about 5 P.M. Those injured were 5 crew members and 10 passengers. (AP)
 
Delays on Nuclear Waste
In 1973, the Federal Government agreed with utilities using nuclear reactors that it would dispose of the highly contaminated nuclear waste from the reactors. Fourteen years later, the Energy Department says that not only will it be unable to meet its deadline of Jan. 31, 1998, but it is unlikely to be ready to begin handling the waste before 2010. A14
 
AIDS Doctors Help Suicides
Many doctors treating people with AIDS in the San Francisco region have had patients who wanted to end their lives, and 53 percent told researchers for an article in The New England Journal of Medicine that they had helped at least one patient commit suicide. A18
 
New Abortion Fight Looms
A leading abortion opponent in Congress said he had the votes for the House to bar groups that support abortion overseas from receiving Federal money. The ban would apply even if the groups spend only private funds on their overseas activities. But the House outcome could be meaningless because the Senate seems unlikely to go along. A22
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-7
 
Police Captain Is Shot During a Weapons Raid
A city police captain leading a weapons raid was shot in the face and critically wounded after discovering a small arsenal of guns and explosives in a transit worker's Bronx apartment. The police were trying to learn if the worker fired the shots. B1
 
Race Concerns Crown Hts. Jury
Jurors in the Crown Heights case showed their sensitivity to the case's racial implications even before their deliberations started. The first juror chosen became forewoman by tradition, but because she is Jewish, they asked the judge whether that job should go to any Jewish or black juror. The judge told them not to worry about "public perception." B3
 
Workers Cited in Derailment
Ten months before a train derailed at a Hackensack River bridge, Amtrak employees knew that a steel part connecting rails on the bridge was cracked, officials said. The employees, who now face dismissal, made repairs instead of replacing the part. B7
 
CUNY to Help Immigrants
The City University of New York, which has long offered classes designed for immigrants, will give them some more practical aid. Starting this month, CUNY plans to train students, faculty and staff advocates on each campus to help immigrants apply for citizenship. B1

The New York City Opera said its 1997-98 season, the first to be entirely planned by Paul Kellogg, its general and artistic director for the last year, would include eight new productions. C18

HEADLINE: Nothing Says a Global Economy Is Inevitable;
In Boston or Hanoi

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re Thomas L. Friedman's Feb. 2 column: Globalization is inevitable, just as is the need for safety nets. Our domestic economy is absorbing people into the two- and three-job work force as the most draconian efforts of the "let-them-eat-cakers" become law. As we continue to sponsor corporate welfare, we must sponsor meaningful efforts for the safety net. 
 The missing ingredient in Mr. Friedman's continuum is a lifting of the poor and working poor to middle-class status. Becoming more competitive is admirable. Doing so by stripping all benefits from the wage earner to sate investors is temporary and false.
If these are the only jobs left to the semiskilled, someone needs to make Nike and McDonald's deliver wages a family can live on, be it in South Boston or Hanoi.
 
JIM FINCH
Sacramento, Calif., Feb. 3, 1997

HEADLINE: Clinton Tax Credit Plan Won't End Welfare Cycle;
New and Improved

 BODY:
To the Editor:
By linking outdated criticisms of an expired tax credit program to an initiative from President Clinton, your Jan. 30 editorial almost ignores a year and a half of bipartisan effort in Congress to create a public-private tax credit program, the Work Opportunities Tax Credit, which is just getting under way. 
 Although millions were helped by the Targeted Jobs Tax Credit program, its critics charged that many employers were rewarded yet welfare eligibility was not considered when the hiring decision was made.
The new program addresses that criticism by requiring employers to screen for eligibility during the job application process and by tightening the criteria to insure that the credit is available only for those who have a history of dependence on public assistance programs.
Employers have become comfortable with hiring credits because it provides them with the resources they need to engage welfare recipients in on-the-job training. The hiring tax credit helps to offset at least a portion of the higher costs associated with employing the hard-core unemployed.
 
(Rep.) AMO HOUGHTON
(Rep.) CHARLES J. RANGEL
Washington, Jan. 31, 1997

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
Pioneer in Sociology, Persevering Fighter for Civil Rights

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
For generations of black scholars, journalists and advocates of black causes, W. E. B. Du Bois stood as teacher, model, inspiration. If he is not so well remembered now, tonight's elegantly produced two-hour tribute may be a corrective. It celebrates his accomplishments -- and, some viewers may add, missteps -- between his birth in Massachusetts in 1868, when black Americans were barely emerging from slavery, to his death in Ghana in 1963, a day before the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s March on Washington.
"W. E. B. Du Bois: A Biography in Four Voices" divides his astoundingly productive life into manageable portions, written and narrated in turn by Wesley Brown, Thulani Davis, Toni Cade Bambara and Amiri Baraka. This being a testimonial of sorts, all are unrelievedly worshipful. Du Bois's courage and vision could have withstood more stringent analysis. 
 Before the turn of the century, William Edward Burghardt Du Bois became the first black student to receive a doctorate from Harvard University; his dissertation was on the African slave trade. He went on to pioneer empirical sociology with "The Philadelphia Negro," based on thousands of interviews he conducted. Some say that was the beginning of American sociology, but a few years later he went from academe to journalism, as editor of The Crisis, the N.A.A.C.P. magazine that quickly became the most influential black publication of its time. Along the way he wrote such enduring works as "The Souls of Black Folk" and "Black Reconstruction in America."
Relatives, acquaintances and historians, particularly his biographer David Levering Lewis, are put to good service explaining the clash with Booker T. Washington, who championed manual training as the most hopeful path for black youths; with Marcus Garvey, the black nationalist, whom Du Bois called "a lunatic or a traitor," and with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People as he moved steadily to the left and away from his longtime mainstream allies.
Deftly handled by Louis Massiah, the producer, the zesty pictures and music catch the spirit of the times. The photographs of Du Bois in his prime show a sportily garbed gent, and his recorded reminiscences give hints of boyhood elocution lessons.
These two hours leave no doubt of Du Bois's perseverance in the battle for civil rights and economic reform in the United States and self-rule for the peoples of Africa. The founding of the United Nations and the movement toward independence in the former colonial world seemed to promise the realization of causes he had long fought for, but with the coming of the cold war he was hounded for his associations with left-wing organizations and movements. Acclaiming even Du Bois's years as an ornament of groups devoted to the interests of the Soviet Union, Mr. Baraka shows a talent for agitprop pamphleteering, but the Government's campaign against Du Bois was cruel.
In the last isolated years of his life, possibly as a gesture of defiance, Du Bois applied for membership in the American Communist Party and then fled from an America to which he had contributed so much. A sad ending, perhaps for him, certainly for his country.
 
W.E.B. DU BOIS
A Biography in Four Voices
 
PBS, tonight
(Channel 13, New York, at 9:30)
 
Directed and produced by Louis Massiah; W. E. B. Du Bois Film Project/Scribe Video Center, producer. Monica Henriquez, editor. A presentation of the National Black Programming Consortium with WHYY, Philadelphia, and WQED, Pittsburgh. Narrated by Wesley Brown, Thulani Davis, Toni Cade Bambara and Amiri Baraka.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: On Benefits, Just Do It

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Greenspan Urges Action to Curb Cost-of-Living Rises in Benefits" (front page, Jan. 31): The Clinton Administration says that it will consider changing the Consumer Price Index if there is a consensus among economists as to how to do it. But consensus could only come from a biased set of experts. This ritual would be an obvious fib, decreasing confidence in government and adding (to unemployment and poverty rates, for example) still another manipulated statistic. 
 If Mr. Greenspan and company want to cut Social Security benefits, why not just admit it? Take off, say, 1 percent from the existing C.P.I. and just accept the political consequences.
 
NORBERT WILEY
Monterey, Calif., Feb. 3, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
German Fashion Art as Serious Art

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
GIVEN the current crazes for fashion-related art and photo-based art, the growing interest in one of their intersections, fashion photography, comes as no surprise. The latest indication is "Zeitgeist Becomes Form: German Fashion Photography, 1945-1995," an ambitious if uneven survey organized by F. C. Gundlach, a former fashion photographer and writer, at Pat Hearn and Morris-Healy, neighboring galleries in Chelsea. Sponsored by the German Government as part of a series titled "Photography in Germany From 1850 Until Today," it is one of several exhibitions of German photography in the downtown area right now.
As a relatively new esthetic cross-over, fashion photography follows a number of other marginal art forms, like furniture design or ceramics, that have come in from the cold of commerce and function to be taken more seriously as art. It may have the advantage of being a subset of photography, already taken plenty seriously, but its history has only recently begun to be examined with any thoroughness. "Zeitgeist Becomes Form," which includes the work of 35 artists from several generations, is one of the first exhibitions to focus exclusively on German fashion photography. 
 How German is German fashion photography? Many of the nearly 160 images here have been published in non-German magazines; some of the photographers were born elsewhere, while others born in Germany now live in Paris and New York. Still, the exhibition's answer is clear: German enough.
One of the show's salient characteristics is a strong sense of the national Zeitgeist of German history and even German art (Expressionism, Neue Sachlichkeit, Neo-Expressionism). It is overly inclusive and thus indiscriminate, especially in its middle section; it lacks a high frequency of truly resolved, breathtaking images, and offers plenty of reminders of how pretentious, gimmicky and vacant bad fashion photography can be. But it also says as much about Germany as about fashion or photography, thoroughly living up to its title (which rather cheekily echoes that of a groundbreaking exhibition of Conceptual art, "Live in Your Head: When Attitude Becomes Form," held in Bern in 1969). Along the way the show also offers a reasonable explanation for the current fascination with fashion photography, which simply, almost dumbly, touches on a fairly long list of overheated art issues: the body, clothing, gender, theater, not to mention style, beauty and, of course, sex.
The exhibition begins in the late 1940's, in the early years of Germany's economic recovery, when Christian Dior's "New Look" was all the rage and German photographers, like their colleagues in New York and Paris, took models out of the studio and into the street, contrasting their hothouse beauty with real-life backdrops. Some, like Willy Maywald, who worked for Dior and Jacques Fath in Paris, achieved a sharp-edged, ethereal elegance similar to Richard Avedon's.
In Germany, however, the backdrops often, possibly deliberately, conjured up the war's devastation, or the country's economic recovery. Herbert Tobias places a model in a lavish evening dress in front of the ruined arches of an imposing building in Berlin. Norbert Leonard positions his subject, wearing a day suit, in an automobile factory. More ambiguously, Hubs Floter places a sleek gowned model in the wooden bleachers of a stadium with a flock of blond schoolchildren grouped behind her.
Years later, in 1979, Helmut Newton continues the theme, placing a blond model wearing a black lace camisole in front of the Berlin wall, with the neglected Brandenburg Gate looming in the background. A darker cousin of the innocent tourist snapshot, it also summons something of Marlene Dietrich's "Blue Angel" and the grim satire of Grosz and Dix. Peter Lindbergh evokes his country's Nazi past, and fascism in general, when he places models in uniformlike suits by Comme des Garcons amid the monumental forms of a bridge that is, as it happens, in France. (More of his efforts are on view in a solo show at the James Danziger Gallery in SoHo.) A more esthetic backward glance is cast by Jurgen Teller's 1991 photographs of the stylist and model Anna Pawlowski for Comme des Garcons, especially one in which Ms. Pawlowski, wearing a cone-shaped skirt, clings to a tilting chimney like an escapee from "Dr. Caligari's Cabinet."
In recent years, the style of fashion photography has become both more international and more individual, a vehicle of personal expression that disregards clothes in favor of the mundane, the narrative or the overall effects of the image. Mr. Gundlach himself, whose images are remarkable for their seeming casualness and their stark graphic quality, may have contributed to this trend. (His fashion work from the 1950's and 60's is the subject of a show at American Fine Arts in SoHo.)
These tendencies give this exhibition a strong finish, especially in the "slacker" images of Wolfgang Tillmans, the sexually charged scenes of Ellen Unwerth, the isolating portraitlike treatments of Ulrike Schamoni and Rainer Leitzgen's luminous, almost painterly portrayals of Issey Miyake's designs in which the garments all but consume their wearers. In the end, this exhibition convinces one above all of fashion photography's unusual malleability, its continual oscillation between art and cinema, history and fantasy, reportage and seduction.
Still, when confronted with Ute Mahler's recent photographs -- especially one in which a black model in an overcoat runs across an old courtyard clutching banged-up suitcases in either hand -- a slight chill is unavoidable. Germany's past is always lurking just beneath the surface, ready to be exploited by the photographer or read into the image by the viewer.
Another exhibition that attests to the strength of German photography is a display of Karl Blossfeldt's elegant turn-of-the-century close-ups of plants, "First Forms of Art," at the Friedrich Petzel Gallery in SoHo.
Less direct corroboration is offered by "Someone Else With My Fingerprints," at David Zwirner, also in SoHo. An eclectic exhibition organized by Wilhelm Schurmann, a German collector and dealer, it offers images by numerous German photographers but also ranges throughout the world, from artists' works to film stills, with an encyclopedic fervor that is in some ways yet another expression of Germanness.
"Zeitgeist Becomes Form: German Fashion Photography, 1945-1995" remains at the Pat Hearn and Morris-Healy galleries, 530 West 22d Street, Chelsea, through Feb. 22.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A photograph taken by Helmut Newton in 1979 at the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin, at the Pat Hearn Gallery. (Helmut Newton)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Leap in German Joblessness Helps Buoy the Dollar's Value

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday, bolstered by a report showing record unemployment in Germany.
And newly released minutes of the Federal Reserve's rate-setting committee meeting in December helped the dollar, as well. Although the Fed took no action to raise interest rates then or at its two-day meeting that ended on Wednesday, the minutes showed that members were biased toward a rate increase. 
 Higher interest rates would bolster the dollar's attractiveness at a time when rates in Germany and Japan have been at longtime lows for several months.
Although uncertainty about the Labor Department's January unemployment report today contributed to some profit taking as the day progressed, the dollar settled in New York broadly higher, and traders said it was likely to keep rising.
"The dollar is undervalued, and there are significant problems in Germany and Japan," said Robert Nelson, managing director for foreign-exchange sales at Westdeutsche Landesbank in New York. "At the end of the day people ask: 'Where do I want my money? I don't want it in Japan, and I don't know what's going to happen in Europe, so that leaves the dollar.' "
After passing 123 yen for the first time in four years on Wednesday, the dollar reached an intraday high yesterday of 123.99 yen, then ended at 123.54 yen, up from 123.25 late Wednesday and up 6.6 percent in the first five weeks of 1997.
Against the German mark, the dollar reached an intraday high of 1.6547, the strongest since June 1994, before settling in New York at 1.6504 marks, up from 1.6454 and up 7.1 percent in the first five weeks of the year. The British pound slipped to $1.6359 from $1.6396.
The dollar rose on a German Government report showing an unexpectedly large surge of jobless people last month, bringing the total number out of work to a postwar high of 4.658 million. The national unemployment rate rose to 12.2 percent from 10.8 percent. The new figure was not seasonally adjusted.
Although the Bundesbank took no action on interest rates at a meeting yesterday, traders sold marks on the assumption that the central bank would have to ease rates further to help stimulate the German economy.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 BUDGET: THE PROSPECTS;
Even With Agreement, A Goal Remains Elusive

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The most important words about the budget today were probably ones unsaid.
President Clinton did not revive proposals like a sweeping health-care plan or a tax increase on the wealthy that Republicans would be bound to dismiss out of hand. 
 And the Republicans in control of Congress did not declare the President's budget "dead on arrival" as they did in 1995 and 1996 and as the Democrats did all those years when they ran Congress and Republicans were in the White House.
What this means is that both sides are starting the year with the attitude that they can strike a deal to bring the Federal budget into balance by 2002 and are treating the President's submission today as his opening bid.
The prevailing view in the capital is that the negotiations will succeed. But that does not mean the budget will ever be balanced. With the best intentions, Presidents and Congresses have been promising and then reneging on balancing the budget for 20 years.
Three strong pieces of evidence embedded in the President's budget lead to the view that this is not a document that would actually lead to a balanced budget:
*Mr. Clinton never concedes that balancing the budget requires anyone in particular to give up anything specifically.
*More than three-quarters of the deficit reduction he is proposing would come in the years 2001 and 2002, when he is no longer in office.
*The President's figures showing a budget surplus in 2002 are predicated on the questionable assumption that no recession will occur in the next five years.
In broad terms, the two sides are not all that far apart this year. Both want substantial tax reductions, with tax credits for families with children as the centerpiece and new tax breaks for capital gains and retirement accounts. Both propose savings in Medicare and Medicaid. Both say they favor limits on spending for domestic programs.
Even more important, the strong economy resulted in a deficit of only $107 billion in the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30. That is $40 billion less than what was anticipated just a year ago, making the task of reaching balance much easier.
Furthermore, as a political matter, the Democratic President and the Republican Congress seem to agree that it is in their interest to reach an agreement. Their standing with the public rose last summer after they put aside a year and a half of bickering and began enacting some legislation like the welfare bill and a health insurance measure.
But promising that the budget will be balanced, as a deal between the President and Congress would do, is much easier than actually doing it. The best evidence is the reluctance of the President and Congress to say who would bear the pain.
Starting in 1978, when legislation was adopted stating that spending "shall not exceed" receipts, the politicians have enacted one measure after another promising a balanced budget. Every one eventually foundered on the point that the only way to reach the goal was to raise taxes, cut spending or both.
That would have required actual families and companies and interest groups to sacrifice something. But every time people have been threatened with having to give up Government services, the politicians have abandoned the goal of putting the budget in balance.
Mr. Clinton told reporters today that his budget contained "detailed, difficult cuts in hundreds of Government programs."
But in the thousands of pages and hours of briefings that accompanied the release of his budget, there is no list of what those programs are. Some spending cuts, tax increases and new fees do appear in the fine print. But it would be hard for any specific voters to discern that they would have to relinquish Federal benefits or services they now enjoy.
When the President's budget director, Franklin D. Raines, was asked about this today, he ducked the question. "It's all boring," Mr. Raines said of the specific budget cuts. "They're all boring."
Republicans have hardly been more forthcoming about the dislocations their proposals might cause. They spent the entire election year, for example, arguing that they did not propose to cut Medicare, just slow the rate of growth, never once conceding that retirees might be faced with substantially reduced medical services.
On the matter of backloading the spending cuts, consider this: Over five years, the President proposes $252.1 billion worth of deficit reduction. Of that, $190 billion, or 75.3 percent, is scheduled for the last two years. In the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, tax cuts would actually exceed spending reductions, making the deficit more than $1 billion higher than it would be if no changes in policy were made.
For the programs other than the military that receive annual appropriations from Congress -- called domestic discretionary programs -- the budget envisions saving $58 billion over five years. Only $600 million would come in the first year, the only year for which the cuts must be specifically identified.
Administration officials argue, rightly, that the savings in later years appear greater in part because of annual compounding. But according to Robert D. Reischauer, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office, a steady pace of cuts would result in 62 percent of the savings occurring in the last two years, not 75 percent.
Perhaps, come the turn of the century, the promised spending cuts will be enacted, but hardly anyone who has followed the last 20 years of budget politics would bet on it.
As for the state of the economy, maybe business cycles are passe, and maybe the country can go another five years without a recession. But if that happens, this would be the longest economic expansion since economists started keeping records on such matters around the turn of the 20th century.
If the economy were to falter, tax revenues would drop, and balancing the budget under the prescriptions Mr. Clinton and Congress are considering would be out of the question.
In the view of some economists and politicians, this is why a constitutional amendment is needed to require a balanced budget. But many others say that focusing on whether the budget is actually balanced misses the point. What is most important, they say, is that the President and Congress seem to be committed to keeping the deficit from growing out of control the way it did in the 1980's.
Mr. Reischauer, for one, is in this camp. He thinks the President's budget and the impending negotiations with Congress are a strong signal that the politicians are on the right course.
"We shouldn't sacrifice the good for the best," he said.
