HEADLINE: Gore and Chernomyrdin Meet; Agenda Includes a Wider NATO

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore sat down today for two days of talks here with the Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, hoping to inject movement into an American-Russian relationship that has been stagnant for six months because of President Boris N. Yeltsin's infirmity.
Mr. Chernomyrdin told reporters a summit meeting between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin would be held in March as scheduled, in the second half of the month; American officials cautioned that a date was not yet fixed. While it is Mr. Yeltsin's turn to come to Washington, American officials have offered to meet in Moscow or elsewhere in Europe. 
 The Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission meets every six months and incorporates Cabinet-level committees on scientific, technological and economic issues. But with Mr. Yeltsin ill, the meetings have become the main formal channel for high-level bilateral discussions.
Asked today about Mr. Yeltsin, who turned 66 on Saturday, a senior American official said: "He is running the show and is on top of his brief. We are encouraged by what we're hearing."
But other officials said they had no independent confirmation of Mr. Yeltsin's health and stressed, as they often do, that American relations are "with Russia and its Government, not with any one individual."
The officials also emphasized that Mr. Chernomyrdin has a broad brief, able to talk authoritatively about security issues like NATO enlargement. Until Mr. Yeltsin's heart operation last autumn, when Aleksandr M. Lebed was dismissed as head of the National Security Council, Mr. Chernomyrdin's purview was almost purely domestic.
But it is still Mr. Yeltsin who is likely to call the shots on big decisions.
Mr. Chernomyrdin today called the March summit meeting "very important," and no American officials, frustrated with ambiguous and negative signals from Moscow on issues like NATO's enlargement and the ratification of an arms reduction treaty, would disagree.
A NATO summit meeting is set for early July, when a few new members are to be named. By that time, Washington wants to have a parallel understanding between NATO and Russia on security in Europe.
American officials say those negotiations could go down to the wire, even dominating the summit meeting of major industrialized nations in Denver in late June, to which Mr. Yeltsin is invited. But they said that in meetings with Mr. Gore and with President Clinton on Friday, Mr. Chernomyrdin has the authority to talk seriously about security issues. In an interview with The Washington Post last week, Mr. Chernomyrdin said Moscow wanted "a binding treaty, with verification" between Russia and NATO. Washington rejects a "binding treaty" but wants "a political commitment," like the Helsinki Accords, to provide venues for discussion and cooperation on security.
Washington also offers talks to update the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, to assuage Russian concerns about troop movements in new NATO members and concerns about any Russian troop movements from countries that will be left out of the first round of NATO expansion, like Ukraine and the Baltic nations.
Ambassadors of the 29-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development also agreed today in Paris to begin a process leading to Russian membership of the group, which coordinates economic policies. Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic are already members. Full Russian membership will require accords on capital movement, financial transactions and other issues.

HEADLINE: German Unemployment Soars, Worsening Choices for Kohl

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The number of jobless German workers soared by nearly half a million last month, to 4.66 million, an unexpectedly steep rise in what had already been Germany's highest unemployment since World War II, according to Government data released today.
The new figures startled economists and posed new problems for Chancellor Helmut Kohl, whose popularity has slumped to new lows in recent months and whose Cabinet ministers have plunged into open warfare with one another. 
 The overall unemployment rate in Germany climbed to 12.2 percent from 10.8 percent in December, and it was nearly 19 percent in the formerly Communist eastern region. Neither those figures nor the total number of jobless workers, which was up from 4.15 million in December, reflected seasonal adjustments. But even after accounting for seasonal factors, the increase in the number unemployed -- 160,000 -- surprised analysts because it was three times the rate of increase in the last four months and was three times higher than expected.
The data raised new doubts about rigidities built into the German economy, Europe's largest, and its ability to shake off several years of stagnant growth. Germany, like some other European nations, is in the midst of an anxious debate over how to modify its social-benefit system and whether to emulate the American model of growth with insecurity. And, like the other European nations, Germany faces pressure to maintain fiscal discipline as the planned introduction of a single currency gets nearer.
Though the Government said that the sharp increase in unemployment last month had been caused in part by cold weather, which shut down construction sites, it was also a symptom of the steps that German companies are taking to slim down in hope of regaining competitiveness. Industrial giants like Daimler-Benz and Hoechst have aggressively cut costs.
The revamping of German industry has helped keep the stock market at record levels, and the markets apparently took the news of higher unemployment in stride, reaching new highs today.
The economy is also getting a lift from a surge in exports, thanks in part to an increase in the value of the American dollar against the mark, which makes German products cheaper in the United States.
Germany's central bank decided not to give economic growth a further stimulus in the form of lower interest rates, leaving them unchanged at a regular meeting today. Most economists expect growth to increase from a paltry 1.4 percent in 1996 to more than 2 percent this year.
All that is cold comfort to German workers who have been put out of work. "This provides a shining example of how economic growth does not necessarily translate into new jobs," said Holger Schmiedling, senior economist at Merrill Lynch here. "We are beginning to see German business restructuring and regaining the competitiveness that it lost in the early 1990's, but it still has a long ways to catch up."
This sharply higher unemployment is likely to place Chancellor Kohl in a fiscal and political straitjacket. It will force the Government to pay billions of extra marks in unemployment costs, at a time Mr. Kohl is trying to slash billions in pension and health care programs to meet the fiscal requirements for taking part in the European currency planned in 1999.
An extra 160,000 jobless workers translates to about $5 billion in Government costs, or two-tenths of 1 percent of Germany's gross domestic product, according to Mr. Schmiedling. To qualify for the European monetary union, a priority for Mr. Kohl, Germany must keep its budget deficit to less than 3 percent of the G.D.P. this year. In 1996, the deficit reached 3.9 percent of output, largely from continuing huge expenditures to integrate eastern Germany into the broad economy. The Government says it can cut the deficit to 2.9 percent, but most independent economists were skeptical of that even before today's news.
"It is quite a problem for Kohl, because his popularity is extremely low right now," said Michael Lewis, senior economist at Deutsche Morgen Grenfell. But he noted that the Chancellor's party, the conservative Christian Democratic Union, is still more popular than the main opposition, the Social Democratic Party.
In recent weeks, Mr. Kohl and members of his Cabinet have been pilloried by critics, and have appeared in increasing internal disarray, as they tried to push through measures to cut social spending and change a byzantine tax system.
Members of the center-right governing coalition are fighting on a wide range of fronts. The Free Democratic Party, a centrist group that is the junior coalition partner, has repeatedly attacked what its members described as feeble-hearted attempts at tax reform. Now, two of Mr. Kohl's Cabinet members, Labor Minister Norbert Blum and Finance Minister Theo Waigel, are quarreling over Mr. Blum's proposal to overhaul the nation's underfinanced pension system. Mr. Blum proposed reducing a number of benefits and raising new money through an increase in the value-added tax, a kind of steep sales tax on each stage of production and distribution.
Free Democrats angrily assailed the proposed tax increase, while Mr. Waigel insisted that the Government start taxing some pension benefits.
Amid this rising pressure and open disarray, politicians and business executives have begun speculating that the Kohl coalition could falter or that Mr. Kohl might be pushed aside as leader in favor of others in the Christian Democratic Union.
The one big bright area in the German economy is exports. For all the complaints about the high costs and inflexibility of doing business here, the demand for German goods abroad grew rapidly last year and the country continued to enjoy a huge trade surplus.
Economists expect that trend to accelerate in 1997, thanks to the rise of the American dollar in relation to the mark. That rise is expected to be discussed at a meeting in Berlin this weekend of the Group of Seven leading industrial nations, as officials of several nations have questioned whether the dollar's value has increased too steeply.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Increased 5.8% in January

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
The sales increases that retailers were counting on for Christmas came too little and too late for many of the nation's stores.
From swanky department stores to deep discount chains, merchants reported strong sales increases for January for items ranging from women's apparel to household furnishings. 
 But January is considered one of the least important months of the year for retailers, and any comparison with sales figures reported last January must take into account the dreadful weather that hit much of the nation that month.
The Goldman, Sachs retail composite index, which tracks same-store sales ---- or sales from stores open at least a year -- increased 5.8 percent in January. That is well above the combined 2.9 percent gain in December for the nearly 60 retail companies in the index and a sharp climb from the 1.1 percent increase in January a year ago.
"It is actually the best single month since January of 1995, when the same-store sales composite rose 7.2 percent," Richard N. Baum, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said.
That said, January sales are typically increased by markdowns of merchandise that did not sell in the holiday season, and sales for that month only represent about 5 percent of most retailers' overall sales for the year.
Even so, some analysts said the sales gains portend strong retail sales this year.
"We continue to believe the luxury goods category remains the strongest in retailing," Jeffrey M. Feiner, an analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc., said. "In addition, consumer demand for apparel remains relatively favorable, as better fabrics, more exciting colors and fashions more reflective of an aging baby-boom generation have made this sector more appealing."
The improved numbers showed up across industry segments. Saks Holdings Inc. of New York, the parent company of Saks Fifth Avenue, had a 14.3 percent increase in January same-store sales, while the Charlotte, N.C., deep-discount chain Family Dollar Stores Inc., reported a 23.3 percent gain. Pier 1 Imports Inc. of Fort Worth reported a hefty 19.6 percent gain, while sales for the Limited Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, rose 17 percent.
Over all, retailers benefited because sales for the holiday season a year ago were so dismal and from deep markdowns of merchandise that did not sell during the recent holidays, according to Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard Retail Marketing Report, a forecasting firm in Scotch Plains, N.J. The mild weather in much of the country last month was also a factor, as was a sustained high consumer confidence level and a continued upbeat economy.
And in New York City, several retailers attributed higher sales last month to increased business generated by a program that suspended sales tax for a week in January on clothing selling for less than $500. The state and city agreed to drop their respective sales taxes on apparel for a week as part of an experiment to determine whether consumers would shift their spending to the city rather than shop in New Jersey and other nearby areas with little or no tax on clothing.
"Our January sales results were particularly strong, in part, because our New York retail operations benefited from the weeklong sales tax exemption," said Allen Questrom, chairman and chief executive of Federated Department Stores Inc., the parent of Bloomingdale's, Macy's and Stern's. He said half of Federated's 9.4 percent comparable-store sales gain for the month can be attributed to the tax exemption.
The real losers among retailers last month were home electronics companies. Best Buy Company, the Minneapolis electronics retailer, reported that its January sales plummeted 15 percent compared with a 4 percent gain in the same month a year earlier. Its competitor, Circuit City Stores Inc. of Richmond did not fare any better with an 11 percent drop compared with a 2 percent gain in the same period a year ago.
Lack of new products, price cuts and lower personal computer sales hurt electronics retailers, said Jack D. Seibald, a retail analyst with Blackford Securities.
Other winners included the Hills Stores Company of Canton, Mass., which reported an 11.4 percent increase and the J. C. Penney Company of Plano, Tex., which reported that its numbers were up 19 percent.
Some retailers, though, reported only minimal gains. The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation of New York reported just a 2.5 percent increase, while Builders Square, the troubled home-improvement retailing unit that the Kmart Corporation is in the process of unloading, had flat results with a three-tenths of a percent gain.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 BUDGET: INCOME TAXES;
Clinton and G.O.P. Are Distant on Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Although both sides say they are optimistic about reaching a compromise, President Clinton's proposal today to cut taxes by nearly $100 billion over the next five years is distant, both in size and composition, from the tax-cutting demands of Congressional Republicans.
The President's plan renews his calls to provide tax relief to middle-class families, make college more affordable and stimulate savings through an expansion of the Individual Retirement Account. 
 Although Mr. Clinton said his proposals would save taxpayers $98 billion, they are paid for in large part by other tax measures, including the closing of loopholes and the extensions of expiring taxes.
Republicans contend that those revenue-raising measures, which total $76 billion over five years, are simply tax increases, and that they therefore view the President's net tax cut as being only $22 billion. And Republicans noted that the Administration's plan would cancel its tax cuts after 2000 if the economy did not perform as well as it expects.
"The budget offers the American people what may be temporary tax relief, combined with permanent tax hikes, adding up to an excessive tax burden," said Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.
Republicans also characterized the Administration's plan to impose $10.9 billion in new "user fees" as tax increases by another name. The fees cover activities ranging from meat, poultry and egg inspections to mining on public land to applying for permits to dredge wetlands. The Administration is also proposing to charge airlines $300 million in new user fees next year, and to replace the current system of airline excise taxes with user fees in 1999.
By contrast, Senate Republicans have already called for $193 billion in tax cuts over five years. They have not yet specified what offsetting revenue increases they would seek, but senior Republican aides said they were aiming for a net tax cut over five years of at least $125 billion.
Moreover, the two sides are going into budget negotiations with a deep philosophical divide over what types of tax cuts to enact. Republicans have made a broad-based reduction in the capital gains tax one of their top priorities, arguing that lower taxes on the sale of stocks and bonds, real estate, small businesses and other assets would spur more investment and create more jobs.
The latest Republican plan calls for halving the current top 28 percent rate on capital gains. The Administration's plan only nibbles at the capital gains tax, allowing the exclusion of profits up to $500,000 on the sale of a home.
"While I am pleased that President Clinton addressed the issue of capital gains relief, I think we should go much further," said Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee.
Administration officials, recognizing that they will not get a budget deal without some compromise on capital gains, have made it clear that they consider the issue negotiable.
Some Administration officials have suggested they might be willing to trade concessions on capital gains for Republican acceptance of the President's plan to give tax breaks for college tuition.
The White House is also at odds with Republicans over the shape of income tax cuts. Republicans have taken a firm position that taxes should be lower across the board, while the Administration has kept its tax proposals focused on specific groups -- in this case middle-income families and families sending children to college.
Specifically, Mr. Clinton's plan offers families with incomes under $60,000 and children under the age of 13 a $300-per-child credit. The credit would be phased out for families whose incomes range from $60,000 to $75,000. In the year 2000, the credit would rise to $500 per child. The Republican proposal would offer a $500 credit starting next year for children under 18 for families with incomes up to $75,000. The credit would be phased out for families with incomes from $75,000 to $110,000.
The President's plan would also provide a $1,500 per-student tax credit for the first two years of college. Or families could deduct up to $5,000 for college tuition and job training expenses, with the maximum deduction rising to $10,000 per family in 1999. The deduction would be fully available for families filing joint returns with incomes of up to $80,000 ($50,000 for single filers), and would phase out for those with incomes up to $100,000 ($70,00 for single filers).
Another hurdle to an agreement is the difference in the economic assumptions being used by the White House and Congress to determine how large a tax cut the Government can afford. The White House uses slightly more optimistic assumptions, but has agreed to rescind some tax cuts and call for an additional 2.25 percent across-the-board cut in all spending except Social Security after 2000 if the economy does not perform as well as expected.

HEADLINE: Car-Loan Crisis Forces Jayhawk Into Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The Jayhawk Acceptance Company said today that its bankers had cut off access to new money, forcing it to file for bankruptcy, the latest in a series of financial crises in the auto-loan industry.
Fleet Financial Group told Jayhawk that it was in default and ordered it to pay back its loans, leading Jayhawk to file for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Jayhawk, based in Dallas, assured Wall Street last week that it expected to work out problems with its bankers, so news of the bankruptcy stunned analysts. 
 "Last week, they told us Fleet would work with them," said Tim McMennamy, an analyst at Stephens Inc. in Atlanta.
Jayhawk's bankruptcy comes as the business of making car loans to people with poor credit crumbles. The Mercury Finance Company has been on the brink of bankruptcy -- defaulting on $61 million in debt payments -- since revealing last week that it overstated earnings for four years.
In an effort to save $13.3 million, Mercury today eliminated its quarterly dividend, which would have been paid on March 3. Meanwhile, state regulators in Missouri have moved to restrict Mercury's control of its insurance subsidiary, the Lyndon Life Insurance Company, based in St. Louis. Missouri officials instructed Lyndon Life to inform regulators if Mercury, based in Lake Forest, Ill., requested any unusual money transfers.
And another company in the auto-loan industry, First Enterprise Financial Inc., based in Evanston, Ill., was forced today to delay releasing earnings because of unexpected charges for bad loans.
"With Mercury and Jayhawk back to back, that was enough to scare the industry," said Henry Coffey, an analyst at J. C. Bradford & Company in Nashville.
The bankruptcy of Jayhawk comes a week after the company took a $15.5 million charge for bad auto loans, resulting in a fourth-quarter loss. Jayhawk warned its investors last week that the charge put it in violation of its agreement with Fleet Financial .
The two incidents have driven down shares of other finance companies that make auto loans to customers with poor or no credit records.
Trading in Jayhawk's shares was halted after falling 12.5 cents, to $4. Shares of Mercury fell 37.5 cents today, to $2.25, down about 85 percent since its problems were revealed. First Enterprise Financial shares fell $3.375 today, to $8.875, a drop of 27.6 percent.
"The events at Jayhawk reflect a classic case of management who thought they knew what they were doing and obviously did not," said Dennis Telzrow, an analyst with Principal Financial Securities in Dallas.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Are Steady Ahead of Jobless Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were almost unchanged yesterday as traders waited for the release this morning of the employment report for January.
The 30-year bond slipped 1/32 to a price of 96 24/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, remained at 6.75 percent. 
 Early yesterday, a report of a decrease in new claims for unemployment benefits caused prices to fall slightly. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that claims fell by 12,000, to 325,000, last week.
The decrease in claims could signal a tightening labor market, which might cause inflation to pick up, eroding the value of bonds. But yesterday's report is less significant than the monthly report.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, described the market as taking a break after the Federal Open Market Committee decided earlier this week not to raise interest rates. "While the F.O.M.C. undoubtedly kept its bias toward tightening," he said, "the economic evidence pointing toward accelerating inflation simply wasn't compelling enough to persuade it to lift the Federal funds rate." That rate is what banks charge each other for overnight loans.
Mr. Fine said that in the employment report, the market would pay particular attention to data on average hourly earnings, in light of recent sharp jumps. The number of jobs added to payrolls, which is usually the most closely watched figure in the report, may overstate the strength of the labor market for last month, he said, in part because the blizzard in the Northeast last January caused the payroll figure to be skewed downward. The Labor Department has also made changes in the process it uses to adjust for seasonal variations.
As a result, Mr. Fine said, economists' forecasts for the increase in nonfarm payrolls have varied far more widely than usual, from 115,000 to 400,000. Though there is clearly no consensus, the average prediction is for a gain of about 232,000, he said, though it is unclear how the bond market would respond to such a figure. "Needless to say, any overestimate in January will likely be revised in February, and because of the seasonal adjustment difficulties both the January and February payroll figures should be viewed together in order to better ascertain the trend," he said.
Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York, said that bond prices were close to a peak, but with some room left for gains.
Because the payroll number could be affected by special factors, it is possible that the market will largely disregard it, he said, especially because there will be one more report on the job market before the Fed meets again on March 25 to decide on interest rates.
"Also," Mr. Palash said, "we are expecting some of the other components within the report to be market friendly."
He said he expected average hourly earnings to be unchanged and the average work week to decline, both of which would be noninflationary indicators. Mr. Palash said he expected the overall jobless rate to fall to 5.2 percent from 5.3.

HEADLINE: TRACK AND FIELD;
Determination Keeps Kostadinova Atop High Jump Field

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
For a decade now, the high jump bar has not nudged higher than 6 feet 10 1/4 inches for women, just short of a landmark for the metrically challenged. Javier Sotomayor of Cuba has reached 8 feet in the men's competition, but the world, at least that part of it that measures in feet and inches, is still waiting for the first woman to jump 7.
"For some woman it is possible," said Stefka Kostadinova, 31, the Olympic champion from Bulgaria who holds the world outdoor record. . 
 "Is it possible for you?" she was asked yesterday.
Kostadinova (pronounced costa-DEEN-ova) looked at her coach and husband, Nikolai Petrov, who was translating.
"She didn't say yes," Petrov said with a laugh.
"She can do it," Charles Austin, the men's Olympic champion from San Marcos, Tex., said later. "I've seen her jump 6-8 and 6-9 with plenty of room. Seven feet is all in her head."
The likelihood of a 7-foot jump is extremely remote at tonight's Chase Millrose Games, with Madison Square Garden arranged in its tiny, noisy track configuration. But the women's meet record of 6-5 1/2 is in peril. Surpassing it would give Kostadinova no small satisfaction, considering that the woman who holds it, Louise Ritter of Dallas, defeated the favored Bulgarian for a gold medal at the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea.
Kostadinova will be one of six 1996 Olympic gold medalists competing at Millrose, joining Austin, the 110-meter hurdles champion Allen Johnson, the 400-meter hurdles champion Derrick Adkins, the 4x100 relay member Gwen Torrence and the pole vault champion Jean Galfione of France.
The mile events feature the baby boomers Marcus O'Sullivan of Ireland, who has broken the 4-minute mark 47 times indoors, and Mary Slaney, who at 38 is trying to break her 15-year-old indoor American record of 4:20.50.
An offer yesterday by the Mobil Corporation to pay the combined $35,000 appearance fee of Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Gail Devers was declined by the athletes because of previous commitments and training conflicts. But even with the tarnish of their withdrawal, the 90th Millrose Games retains considerable Olympic luster.
Perhaps no track-and-field athlete, except Sergei Bubka, the Ukrainian pole-vaulter, has been as dominant as the 6-foot-1-inch Kostadinova, who owns the outdoor world record and 20 of the top 25 women's high jumps, thanks to an explosive liftoff and flawless technique. Her best leap indoors, 6-9, is half an inch off the world record.
"She is very confident," said Austin, a friend of Kostadinova and Petrov, her husband. "She approaches the bar as aggressively as the men. I wish my technique was as sound as hers."
Kostadinova's determination has equaled her confidence. She prevailed at last summer's Olympics in Atlanta after bitter disappointment in 1988; the fall of Communism and her state-supported training system; repeated injury; the birth of a son, Nikolai, two years ago, and continued upheaval in the Bulgarian economy. Now there is another distraction. Recently, Austin said, her father was involved in a serious automobile accident.
"I was very happy to win the gold medal," Kostadinova said. "I waited eight years."
She set the current outdoor record of 6-10 1/4 in 1987, and by the Seoul Olympics a year later, Kostadinova had 11 of the top 12 jumps in history and had won 73 of her previous 77 competitions. But Ritter had defeated her twice; more important, Ritter had Olympic experience and Kostadinova did not. In Seoul, both jumpers missed all three attempts at 6-8 and went to a jump-off. Ritter cleared 6-8 on her fourth attempt in sudden death, while Kostadinova missed, producing one of the biggest upsets of the Games.
"One comment she made was that she felt I was lucky," Ritter said in a telephone interview from Dallas. "That was an indication of her confidence at the time."
However, her explosive liftoff was to be grounded by a knee injury and a broken bone in her foot. At the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, the best Kostadinova could accomplish was fourth place with a mediocre jump of 6-4 1/4. She essentially took an 18-month maternity leave in 1994 and '95 and returned to competition in July 1995. After only two preparatory meets, she won the world championship in Goteborg, Sweden. Last year, at her third Olympics, Kostadinova finally won a gold medal, breaking Ritter's Olympic record with a leap of 6-8 3/4.
"She's extremely competitive," Ritter said. "She doesn't like to lose. After a personal defeat like Seoul, it didn't surprise me that she won in Atlanta."
Upon returning home with her gold medal, Kostadinova was given a $25,000 reward by the Bulgarian Government. But state support has largely gone the way of Communism in the Eastern bloc. A two-week training trip in Italy now costs $4,000, Petrov said, without the Government to pick up the tab. There is only one hall for indoor training, and the track is in poor condition, Petrov said.
An economic crisis in Bulgaria has led to mass protests, bread lines, spiraling inflation and an agreement by the Socialist government to hold general elections by April 20. Kostadinova's money is protected from inflation, Petrov said, asking for discretion about her finances for fear that "very bad people" could make trouble for them. Asked whether anyone had tried to extort money from Kostadinova, he said, "We have friends that protect us."
"For Stefka, food, training, it is no problem," Petrov said, adding that she is now sponsored by Nike. "For others, the economic crisis is bad. People cannot buy medicine. The old people have enough money to buy bread for one day. Everybody is looking for change, for a nice new day."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stefka Kostadinova, clearing the bar on the way to a gold medal, will be one of six 1996 Olympic champions at the Millrose Games tonight. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Ultimate Fighter For Ultimate Fighting;
Seasoned Lobbyist Gave No Quarter In Quest to Legitimize Bloody Sport

BYLINE: BY DAN BARRY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 6

 BODY:
A clue to the power of the lobbyist for ultimate fighting, James D. Featherstonhaugh, can be found on his sleeves. There, clasping the cuffs of a crisp shirt, are silver links embossed with the state seal.
Mr. Featherstonhaugh says the cuff links symbolize only admiration for his home state. But given his success in influencing the public debate to benefit his clients, the fashion statement also reflects the lobbyist's stature in the halls of the State Legislature. In the parlance of politics, he is "connected": once a strategist for former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, he is friendly with top Republican leaders and is a business partner of Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader. 
 Ultimate fighting -- the melange of kickboxing, wrestling and free-form brawling that is also called extreme fighting -- continues to draw fire. Although the Legislature sanctioned the sport a few months ago, a Federal judge today refused to stop the State Athletic Commission from imposing strict regulations on it. Rather than hold a bout scheduled for Friday in Niagara Falls, where they said the essence of the sport would be diluted, the promoters have moved the event to Alabama.
But the fact that the ultimate fighting debate reached even this level of legitimacy in public discourse is a measure of Mr. Featherstonhaugh's political skills. Just ask state Senator Roy M. Goodman, who last year proposed a bill to ban the sport he calls "human cockfighting," but wound up sponsoring the bill that eventually sanctioned it through regulation.
The reason, he says, is one word: "Lobbying." And the Senator makes clear he is referring to that man of slight build and bald pate, that man called Feathers.
Mr. Featherstonhaugh, 52, attributes his overall success to the 28 years he spent in the halls and courts of Albany. His firm was recently ranked third in fees collected by the State Lobbying Commission; its 41 clients last year included the bottling and beverage industries, AT&T, and several insurance companies.
But the relatively insignificant matter of ultimate fighting posed a rare challenge, he says. It had virtually no political charm, and therefore required him to draw heavily on the lobbyist's arsenal of timing, psychology and perseverance. "This would make a case study for how to lobby on a piece of legislation," he said. And, he noted with a hint of pride, "I don't think we bought anyone so much as a lunch."
To appreciate Mr. Featherstonhaugh's primer on lobbying, one must understand who he is. First, that name: Featherstonhaugh is an English surname (pronounced FAN-shaw in England but FEATHER-stun-ah here). He grew up in nearby Duanesburg. His father was an Albany newspaper reporter who died when his son was 8; his mother worked in a bookstore.
After graduating from Albany Law School in 1969, he got a job with a law firm that had an extensive lobbying practice; his major client was the Civil Service Employees Association. By 1982, he was a partner in his own law firm and had emerged as a prominent Republican. Nevertheless, a Queens Democrat named Mario Cuomo asked him to be the upstate coordinator for his gubernatorial campaign.
"He was the attorney for the C.S.E.A., and the C.S.E.A. was the first union to endorse me," Mr. Cuomo recalled. "It was a natural segue for him to go from the C.S.E.A. to the campaign."
Mr. Cuomo won, and the political capital of Mr. Featherstonhaugh rose, as did his wealth. Now a millionaire, he vacations every July with his family in a summer house in Nantucket -- after the end of the legislative session.
His rise has not been without controversy. In 1990, he joined the First Grafton Corporation, a real-estate company started years earlier by Mr. Bruno, a Republican Senator from Rensselaer County who is now the majority leader. Several years ago the company began to clear some rural land it owned for a subdivision, but was stopped by the state for disturbing wetlands; the matter has been in court ever since.
Mr. Featherstonhaugh said he never considered the propriety of a lobbyist being in business with a legislator. "It was probably a mistake not to think about it," he said.
For his part, Mr. Bruno said that after the ethical considerations were pointed out to him, he went to the Legislative Ethics Committee for advice and at its suggestion, placed his interest in First Grafton in a blind trust.
Mr. Feathestonhaugh made headlines again in 1995 when he gave a $100,000-a-year consulting job to Ralph Marino, shortly after Mr. Marino's ouster as Senate majority leader. Mr. Featherstonhaugh said at the time that Mr. Marino would strengthen his firm's representation of the bottling industry. But he now acknowledges that the hire probably made life easier for Mr. Marino's successor, Mr. Bruno.
"I don't know if I would categorize it as a favor," he said. "But I think the majority leader was pleased that Senator Marino left. Of course I was aware of that. To which I say, so what?"
The so-what, of course, is that these episodes provide a glimpse into the closeness between Mr. Featherstonhaugh and the state's decision makers. "What I do requires me to get my clients a fair hearing," he said. "And my relationship with all these people helps me to do that."
Blair Horner, a lobbyist for the New York Public Interest Research Group, said he would place Mr. Featherstonhaugh in the "800-pound gorilla category" of lobbyists. "He's one of the longtime lobbyists here, with extensive contacts deep into the Democrats and Republicans," Mr. Horner said. "But you don't see Feathers that much. He tends to fly under the public radar screen."
In late 1995, that reputation for access and effectiveness earned Mr. Featherstonhaugh another client: Semaphore Entertainment Group, producers of ultimate fighting.
Semaphore's president, Robert B. Meyrowitz, needed help. A recent attempt by another producer to stage a contest in Brooklyn had enraged city and state leaders, and they chased the promoter out of the city. Mr. Meyrowitz believed that ultimate fighting was much safer than its bloodsport reputation, and he wanted to counter plans by the Pataki administration and Senator Goodman to ban the sport in New York.
In a Dec. 5, 1995, letter to Semaphore, Mr. Featherstonhaugh laid out a strategy "to derail such an effort." He wrote that he would arrange meetings with key legislators; first on his list was his business partner, Senator Bruno. Then he would develop "our own legislation requiring regulation" -- which is what eventually happened.
Here is the psychological approach, as explained by Mr. Featherstonhaugh: "We thought that the way to deflect this ban was to allow them to regulate it. We wanted to give people a vehicle, a place to go other than a ban."
But first things first. The lobbyist and his staff put together an informational packet that included a videotape of an ultimate fighting match. Then they targeted several legislators, including Joseph T. Pillittere, then the chairman of the Assembly's tourism and sports development committee.
Mr. Pillittere recalled this week that he and his daughter, a professional wrestling fan, watched the videotape, and they both found the event boring. "But since they allowed certain kicking in the groin," he said, "I asked them if they would accept legislation that would put them under the auspices of the Athletic Commission."
Of course, came the answer. "Pillittere is where we got our first success," Mr. Featherstonhaugh said.
As the lobbyist continued to work the issue, he emphasized the economic benefit of offering ultimate fighting events to the distressed cities of upstate New York. The argument was blunt: "You could set off a bomb in your downtown at 11 o'clock at night, and no one would be hurt."
Meanwhile, Mr. Featherstonhaugh worried that Gov. George E. Pataki, who supported a ban, might reach the Republican Senate leadership before he did. He arranged a meeting between Semaphore's president and Senator Bruno, who saw no need for a ban. "He indicated that we were the first people to raise it," the lobbyist said, "which is what I wanted."
In fact, for the first two months of the 1996 legislative session, Mr. Featherstonhaugh lobbied virtually without opposition. Senator Goodman submitted his bill to ban the sport on Jan. 30, 1996, but his investigations committee did not hold a hearing on the matter until April 18.
"Often, if you get to make your case first and it's persuasive, you win," Mr. Featherstonhaugh said.
His early work weakened Senator Goodman's lobbying position. "Several senators mentioned that he had spoken to them," the Senator said. As a result, he added, "I was encountering resistance from senators and from leadership."
After three decades in the Senate, Mr. Goodman did not need a lobbyist to explain the political landscape. In June he proposed that the Athletic Commission oversee ultimate fighting; regulation, he reasoned, was better than to allow the sport to continue unchecked. By July, both houses had passed a bill that Mr. Featherstonhaugh says included some language that he had drafted.
"After it passed, we worked on the Governor," the lobbyist said. Letters of support rained on Mr. Pataki's office. But Mr. Featherstonhaugh said his most persuasive tool was the argument that if the bill were vetoed, "It was clear we could do these events without any regulation."
The Governor reluctantly signed the bill in October. Mr. Featherstonhaugh's work appeared to be done.
Since then, however, the Athletic Commission approved regulations that are anathema to the true ultimate fighter, like a prohibition against head kicks. And Governor Pataki, Senator Goodman and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver all support a ban. Mr. Featherstonhaugh attributed the move to the outcry brought on by sudden media attention and vowed to continue the fight for the ultimate fight.
And to those who might portray him as one of those cigar-chomping power brokers who make decisions in back rooms, he has a sly reply. "We represent the cigar manufacturers," he said. "So we applaud cigar chomping."

HEADLINE: A Gesture From Swiss Bankers

 BODY:
Self-interest rather than a humanitarian impulse has led three Swiss banks to establish a $70 million fund for the victims of the Holocaust, but the action is still a promising move. The motive in this case is less important than the signal that the Swiss banking industry belatedly recognizes it cannot brush off claims that it mishandled the accounts of Jews who died in the Holocaust.
Until the opening of the special fund this week, Swiss bankers had rudely resisted assertions that money, gold and other valuables placed in Swiss vaults in the 1930's by Jews had been looted or diverted by the banks after the war. The Swiss Government seemed equally intransigent, even entertaining the crude notion that organizations like the World Jewish Congress were engaged in a conspiracy to undermine Switzerland's economy. 
 The Jewish organizations are seeking something much simpler. They would like a complete and honest accounting of the old deposits and repayment to people who can establish legitimate claims. The best mechanism for auditing the accounts is in place, under the direction of Paul Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. If the bankers give the Volcker commission full cooperation, bank ledgers can be examined and accounts traced and in some cases probably recovered. Mr. Volcker should promptly and publicly complain if the bankers balk. The potential loss of American banking business is a powerful incentive for the Swiss to cooperate.
No one knows the precise number or value of accounts opened by Jews hoping to safeguard their assets as the Nazi threat developed. The sum could easily run into hundreds of millions of dollars. The $70 million fund, which is expected to grow with additional contributions from the Swiss Government and the Swiss central bank, is intended to help satisfy old claims, but the Swiss have not settled on exactly how it will be administered.
To insure that some money is available to cover old deposits, the United States, Britain and France agreed earlier this week to freeze the distribution of $68 million in gold bars, some in storage in Manhattan, that were stolen by the Nazis from European central banks. However, competing national claims and legal tangles make it uncertain that this gold can be used to compensate Holocaust victims.
The larger issue confronting Switzerland is its overall conduct during the Nazi era. Though the country was ostensibly neutral and not a combatant in the war, there is a growing documentary record showing that Switzerland served as Germany's banker and financial outlet to the world. Overcoming the myths of national identity is not easy for any country, and it will not happen overnight in Switzerland. But squarely facing the question of the Jewish claims is the place to begin.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Making the Budget Bearable

 BODY:
The basic outlines of President Clinton's budget for 1998 were largely set the moment he made election-year concessions to the Republicans to balance the budget by the year 2002, cut taxes and ax welfare spending. But now that he must live within these tight confines, Mr. Clinton has mostly made sound, compassionate decisions to mitigate the worst harshness.
His budget plan would remove the cruelest parts of the welfare law by reinstating the right of childless adults to collect food stamps if they are unemployed and unable to find work. The plan would also allow legal immigrants who become disabled after they arrive in the United States to collect cash assistance and Medicaid coverage. It would provide health coverage for many uninsured children and extend health insurance for millions of workers between jobs. 
 In education, the area he highlighted in his State of the Union address, Mr. Clinton would raise spending by a hefty $50 billion over five years. The budget would put one million children by 2002 into Head Start, the effective preschool program for low-income families. That needed move would still leave another million eligible children out of the program. Unfortunately, the bulk of Mr. Clinton's education spending would be doled out indiscriminately to families in tuition tax credits totaling about $35 billion. These will not boost college enrollment very much, and will not even leave money in the pockets of middle-class families once universities react, as they almost certainly will, by raising tuition.
By contrast, Mr. Clinton would spend less than $2 billion next year in additional funding for Pell grants, the proven way to help poor families send young people to college who could not otherwise attend. Now that the election is behind it, the Administration should not resist if some in Congress want to skip the tuition tax cuts and apply the money to tuition grants.
The President offers an important reform of Medicaid, proposing to control future spending by placing a cap on the amount of Federal spending per enrollee and allowing states to place enrollees in managed care without going through the frustrating process of begging for Washington's approval. But if Mr. Clinton's fiscal record is measured largely on the basis of what he does on Medicare, he risks a failing grade. He has proposed no long-term solution, rejecting an emerging consensus for turning Medicare into a competitive system like the one that provides a choice of health plans for every Federal employee.
Mr. Clinton's five-year plan concentrates about two-thirds of its spending cuts in the last two years, thus ducking difficult decisions. But for next year he has made mostly sensible calls. His budget would pay some of the money that the United States owes the United Nations and the World Bank for assistance to poor countries, boost money for lending institutions in urban ghettos and maintain spending on scientific research. These and other proposals look like a politically realistic basis for compromise with Congress in the year after budget parameters were set by a foolish competition to promise both a quick end to deficits and broad-scale tax cuts.

HEADLINE: Even Before Their Completion, Plans for Lilco Are Opposed

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 6

 BODY:
Even before state officials have completed their plan to cut Long Island's high electricity bills, opposition emerged today from an unusual coalition of business organizations, environmentalists and civic groups.
The critics said they feared that the plan being negotiated by the Long Island Power Authority would not make big enough cuts in electric rates, which are the highest in the continental United States. 
 The critics also doubted that the plan would foster the entry of competing energy suppliers, and they said the proposed merger of the Long Island Lighting Company with Brooklyn Union Gas would create a bigger monopoly.
And they objected to a public refinancing of the abandoned $4.5 billion Shoreham nuclear plant, calling it a bailout of Lilco stockholders. The refinancing, using tax-exempt bonds, would be the biggest factor in cutting electric rates, enabling a drop of about 12 percent. The critics contend that Lilco should absorb more of Shoreham's cost.
"We smell a rat" in the state's plan, said Gregory A. Palast, an economist advising the Hauppauge Industrial Association, representing 1,300 companies with 55,000 employees. He said his group opposed significant parts of the plan.
Another speaker, Ernie Fazio of Long Island Mid-Suffolk Business Action, said the plan "would be the biggest scam perpetrated against the people."
In reply, the Power Authority's executive director, Seth D. Hulkower, said his agency "is dedicated to promoting competition on Long Island as the way to lower rates long term."
"We are working to negotiate a good deal for ratepayers to achieve a significant rate reduction immediately," he said.
Coalition leaders left open the possibility of endorsing the final plan and said they were developing a strategy to mobilize public opinion and pressure the Power Authority, Public Service Commission and state and local legislators.
The coalition, called the Initiative for Competitive Energy, has 21 member groups. They include the New York Public Interest Research Group, a consumer group; the Nassau-Suffolk Hospital Council; Action Long Island, representing businesses with 200,000 employees; the Long Island Neighborhood Network, and the Energy Rate Reduction Council, representing 275 stores.
Richard M. Kessel, a Democratic minority member on the Power Authority, said of the coalition: "We're going to listen to their ideas and all the other interest groups and accommodate them where we can. Our goal is to get these rates down, and get them down now. I continue to believe that a LIPA takeover and Brooklyn Union merger are the best way to get the rates down."

HEADLINE: Bull Market Worried Fed In December

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers were unusually concerned about stock prices during their December meeting, about two weeks after Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, questioned whether "irrational exuberance" had inflated valuations.
Though members of the Federal Open Market Committee voted unanimously on Dec. 17 to keep interest rates steady -- a course they continued this week at their most recent meeting -- minutes of the December meeting showed that the deliberations had been made more difficult by the long boom in stock prices to levels they called "extraordinary." 
 The meeting took place 12 days after Mr. Greenspan's comments, which touched off a sharp but fleeting skid in the stock market on the fear they were a precursor to higher interest rates.
"The behavior of the stock market," the minutes stated, "injected an additional note of uncertainty into the forecast for consumer spending and the economy more generally. The rise over recent years had been extraordinary and had brought market valuations to fairly high levels relative to earnings and dividends."
As a result, "members recognized the need to monitor with special care price movements in the stock market and asset markets more generally for their implications for consumer and other spending."
Not only was this the most extensive discussion of the stock market by the Fed since the crash of October 1987, analysts said, but it also represented a new, sustained focus on it.
"This is the first time you really get a specific sense there's a monitoring process" in place, one inclined to regard the stock market as a source of economic stimulus, said William V. Sullivan, chief money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds.
The Fed also sought to account for a lack of a consumer spending spree driven by stock-market profits. It cited rising debt burdens, tighter lending standards and insecurity over jobs as possible reasons.
But Mr. Sullivan said the Fed's focus on stock prices indicated concern that the market gains could fuel spending to the point that inflation would increase, requiring the Fed to raise interest rates.
After the minutes were released at 2 P.M. today, stock prices briefly sagged, but they then recovered, and the Dow Jones industrial average finished the day with a moderate advance.
The Open Market Committee has kept the Federal funds rate, the rate on overnight loans among banks, unchanged since it cut it one-quarter point, to 5.25 percent, in January 1996 to head off a possible business downturn.
In August, after rapid economic growth during the second quarter of the year, the panel adopted a policy that leans toward credit restraint but that has not so far led to a tighter policy of higher interest rates. This week's meeting ended with no announcement of policy change, and economists and market operators assume that the bias toward tightening remains, given the increase in wages, continued low unemployment and the strong economic growth of the final months of 1996.
"Some members emphasized that it would be especially important for the committee to act promptly to counter any tendency for price inflation to rise and for higher inflation expectations to become embedded in financial markets and economic decision-making more generally," the minutes said.
Beginning today, minutes of Fed meetings are being published at 2 P.M. two days after the subsequent meeting, an interval of about six weeks. Publication had been three days after the next meeting at 4:30 P.M., or after most American markets had closed, usually for the week.
The Fed said the change was an attempt to be more forthcoming and to give American investors the chance to respond first. Previously, because of differences in local time, some overseas investors could act first. One analyst also suggested that the Fed might be seeking to make the markets more aware of its closer focus on them.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
40-Year Variable Mortgage Returns, in Strong Market

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
In another signal of the growing strength of the New York region's housing market, lenders are resurrecting the 40-year adjustable rate mortgages that were popular among first-time home buyers during the mid-80's.
Since it began offering such loans last month, the Greater New York Savings Bank in Manhattan said the 40-year loans represented 11 percent of its loan applications. Executives of other banks also reported increased interest in recent months from borrowers seeking such long-term mortgages. 
 Bank officials said the increase has been largely driven by the rising prices in the city's housing market that have made it harder for young people to buy. At the same time, rents have risen, encouraging more people to buy.
"The last time the 40-year mortgage was popular was at the height of the real estate market in the mid-80's," said Jeanne Lutfy, senior vice president at the Greater New York Savings Bank. "The reasons people used it then are the same as why they use it today. The longer term lowers the monthly mortgage payments and extends their purchasing power."
The 40-year mortgage "gets relegated to a dusty back shelf or pulled to the forefront, depending on certain market conditions," said Keith T. Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, which tracks mortgage activity. "They include high-priced home areas or times of increasing home prices or high personal debt loads, or a combination of both. Some of those conditions are being seen today."
Longer-term loans "are just one more variable some banks have chosen to offer," said Margaret S. Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services Inc., a mortgage brokerage in Manhattan. Ms. Scott said such loans are not offered by all banks, but they fill a niche "for those borrowers looking to reduce their monthly cash flow."
Ms. Lutfy said a person taking out a $200,000, 30-year fixed-rate mortgage at the current rate of 8.81 percent would carry a monthly payment of $1,484. With a 30-year adjustable-rate mortgage at 6.875 percent, a rate that would be recalculated after three years and every year thereafter, the monthly cost would be $1,314. That type of loan with a 40-year term would have monthly payments of $1,224.
The rate for adjustable loans starts out lower, but it fluctuates later. Banks are offering the 40-year term on mortgages that adjust annually by two to three percentage points after 1, 3, 5, 7 and 10 years, with 3 or 5 years the most popular. There is usually a 5 to 6 percent cap above that initial rate over the life of the loan. Some banks also offer more liberal income qualifying ratios.
"Combine all those factors with the extended term of these mortgages and the average borrower can get into a house sooner rather than later or buy more house," said Richard S. Kemp, regional vice president of the mortgage division of the Long Island Savings Bank in Melville, L.I.
Thirteen percent of the loans given in December by its Queens branch, which serves Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, were for 40-year adjustable rate mortgages, Mr. Kemp said. Like the other bank officers interviewed, he would not disclose the number of such loans, giving only the percentages of total mortgages.
Mr. Kemp of the Long Island Savings Bank said he knew of a couple in their late 20's with a combined annual income of $85,000 who wanted to buy a $300,000 home with 10 percent down in Kew Gardens Queens. He said with a 30-year fixed rate mortgage at 7.75 percent, the couple -- he is a lawyer, she works in the marketing department at a corporation -- could only qualify for a $225,000 loan.
But he said they were able to buy the house with a three-year adjustable rate loan because of the lower initial interest rate of 6.625 percent, the 40-year term and the more liberal income qualifying requirements.
Mr. Kemp said the couple were the kind who would seek such mortgages: "generally young, just starting out in their careers and they anticipate their salaries will go up." Others include corporate transferees, who do not plan to stay long, and the affluent, who are not as concerned with the fluctuations in the interest rate.
But such loans have drawbacks. With any adjustable loan, the borrowers must be diligent rate watchers, Mr. Gumbinger said. Also, the longer a loan, the greater the total payment and the longer it takes to build up equity.
"The bottom line," Mr. Gumbinger said, "is that a 40-year mortgage is a good way to get into a house, but unless borrowers are careful it could come back and bite them."

HEADLINE: THE 1998 BUDGET: FOREIGN AID;
$1.3 Billion Rise Would Halt Decline in Spending Abroad

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The budget proposed today by President Clinton would stop the steady decline in spending on diplomacy and foreign aid in his first term. It included an increase in aid to the independent nations of the former Soviet Union and a plan to repay the United States' debts to the United Nations and other international bodies.
The President's budget would spend nearly $19.5 billion on foreign affairs, an increase of nearly 7 percent over the $18.2 billion authorized by Congress this year. The new budget, however, represented only a modest increase over Mr. Clinton's request last year, which withered under resistance from Republicans. 
 Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that even with the proposed increase, spending on foreign affairs still fell short of the peaks of more than $21 billion in the early 1990's. In a news conference, Ms. Albright said the United States had to stop the decline in foreign affairs spending if it intended to preserve its international influence, a theme she has repeated often since assuming office last month. The budget, she said, would pay for "not the extravagant, but the essential."
In sharp contrast to the situation last year, the proposals received a relatively warm reception on Capitol Hill. Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, the Republican from upstate New York who heads the International Relations Committee, said it would be the basis for "a bipartisan consensus."
Part of the proposal, however, could face opposition. The President proposed repaying slightly more than $1 billion in back dues to the United Nations, $100 million in the coming fiscal year and $921 million the next year on the condition that the United Nations take still unspecified steps toward restructuring. He also proposed repaying over the next three years $860 million in back dues to other international organizations, including the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Some Republican lawmakers have resisted paying back dues without concrete steps by the United Nations to cut its budget and bureaucracy.
Most of the proposed $1.3 billion increase was for foreign aid, including $900 million for nations of the former Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Geography and Class In 2 Simpson Verdicts

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Stand on the infamous corner where the beatings and burnings of the 1992 Los Angeles riots began and ask Carl Wilson, a 27-year-old plumber who readily acknowledges that he joined the melee, why he is not moved by the verdict against O. J. Simpson.
"He's really not part of our community," Mr. Wilson responded, pausing at the intersection of Florence and Normandie Avenues in South-Central Los Angeles. After four white policemen were acquitted in the videotaped beating Rodney G. King, the city erupted, Mr. Wilson said, but this time, when another verdict went against a black man, "nobody really cares." 
 A few blocks away, at a Ralph's supermarket that was looted in the riots, Shirley Sims, a 41-year-old cashier, offered a geographical view. "This is where we live -- this is the ghetto," Ms. Sims said. "He lives in Bel Air and Brentwood, where it's all beautiful. The lawyers, those are his people. Not us."
Mr. Simpson's tribulations are seen by many across the nation as a classic "L.A. Story" of celebrity, money and race, so deeply associated with Southern Californian life that Gov. Pete Wilson declared after the verdict on Tuesday that he was "sick of California being known for little other than one Simpson trial or another." But the reaction here, after the verdict in the wrongful-death civil lawsuit against Mr. Simpson, highlights the topographical truth that his world consisted of only one corner of Los Angeles: the wealthier swath nearer the Pacific known as the West Side.
Though the racial divide over Mr. Simpson remains strong here, with blacks evincing more sympathy for him than whites, there is an additional gap at play, one that splits the second-largest American city based on class. It is the yawning distance between the West Side, where Mr. Simpson lives on charming streets where loafered lawyers lunch, and what some call the "other L.A.," where the vast majority of the metropolitan area's nine million residents spend their lives working much harder than they play.
Many compare the concentration of wealth of the West Side to the relative affluence of much of Manhattan. But the sprawl of Los Angeles isolates it even more, with some West Side residents never, ever venturing eastward into the rest of the city, especially since the riots.
"The geographical separation makes L.A. radically different from New York," said Jon Wiener, a professor of American history at the University of California at Irvine.
"The gap between the West Side and the other side of town is immense: the West Side really has no idea what the other millions of people in L.A. do every day, and O. J. is in many ways a quintessential West Sider. He lives on a fancy street in Brentwood and hangs out at the upscale restaurants and plays golf at the upscale clubs, and the only thing that is different about him is that he's a black man."
Rodney King, by contrast, has been seen by many minority groups as an Everyman victimized by the Los Angeles police. The support for Mr. Simpson after his courtroom defeat appears correspondingly tepid, and the tactical alert called by the Santa Monica police when the verdict was expected came across looking a little silly, given the low-key crowd of mountain-bikers, joggers, passers-by and a few protesters at the courthouse. The West Side does not riot.
"The one thing I've heard over and over from people in my community is, 'Let's get on with our lives," said John Mack, the president of the Los Angeles Urban League . "Given the daily survival issues that the average black person on the streets of South-Central has to contend with, this two-and-a-half-year obsession of most white Americans and many in the media is not shared by the average welfare mother whose check has been reduced and who will soon be booted off the rolls."
The demographic difference between the West Side and the rest of Los Angeles appears to have played a role in the contradictory outcomes of Mr. Simpson's two trials. In his criminal trial, the proceedings were held in downtown Los Angeles, where the mainly black jury was drawn from a heavily minority population.
But the civil trial was held in Santa Monica, among mostly white and better-heeled West Siders. The contrast between the two venues and two juries was among the starkest that could have been found in Los Angeles County, which is only 10 percent black and only 36 percent white; and neither reflected the region's demographic reality: which is predominantly middle class, 40 percent Hispanic and 11 percent Asian.
The Santa Monica jury, almost entirely white, found Mr. Simpson liable in the deaths of his former wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald L. Goldman.
"The geography of the two trials dramatized the gap, the gulf," between regions and races, Mr. Wiener said. "I can understand why black people would say, 'Well, what do you expect of a trial in Santa Monica?' "
In the verdict's aftermath, again, the particular demographics of the West Side come into play. Home to a large Jewish population and known as a center of liberalism and feminism, it has been the West Side where people have seemed to applaud the verdict against Mr. Simpson most loudly.
"It was a West Side issue, and the people most excited about this I've run into are women and Jews on the West Side," said Joel Kotkin, a fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. "Ron Goldman was like your brother. In a way it's just like Rodney King was like a brother for many African-Americans."
Mr. Kotkin, a researcher on urban economic issues, defined the West Side as encompassing nearly two million people on a swatch of land running from Malibu in the north to Torrance in the south. Statistics show that it is among the most educated and privileged pockets in the country, he said, and has been rebounding much faster from the latest recession than the rest of the region.
Others define the West Side more narrowly as the parts of Los Angeles proper that are west of Interstate 405. It is far from homogeneous and contains pockets of poverty as well as great chunks of middle-class neighborhoods, but there is little dispute about its overall status in a city where status is supreme.
Mr. Simpson's Bentley and his $3.5 million house, his plane-hopping and confessed bed-hopping all fit the image that Angelenos see as West Side, especially north of Sunset Boulevard, and that the rest of the country sees as Los Angeles, as Hollywood.
Some try to bridge the gap between West Side wealth and the rest of Los Angeles, like Michele Prichard, the director of the Liberty Hill Foundation, a Santa Monica-based group that finances community efforts to fight poverty and racial tension mainly in the inner city. But Ms. Prichard and many others say they believe that the Simpson case has deepened the very gaps it brought to light, in relations between the races, between men and women, and between the rich and the poor.
"I think it has been a polarizing course of events" in a city already polarized, she said, adding: "I don't think we're learned any positive lessons out of this in Los Angeles as a whole. This city is already very segregated, And it's been one more thing to drive a wedge between people."

Shirley Sims, right, said she and others in the neighborhood had little in common with Mr. Simpson. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: North Korea Agrees to Take Taiwan Atom Waste for Cash

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Facing famine and desperate for hard currency, North Korea has agreed to accept up to 200,000 barrels of nuclear waste from Taiwan, in exchange for tens of millions of dollars.
The deal has enraged South Korea, which is less than 40 miles from the reported disposal site in North Korea. As a result, the arrangement is adding new hostility to the tensions between North and South Korea. 
 South Koreans have traveled to Taiwan to protest the shipments, and a group staged a demonstration in South Korean waters on Wednesday to protest the shipping of the waste.
The idea of exporting nuclear waste has surfaced before. Japan and other countries currently send spent fuel from nuclear reactors to Europe for reprocessing, mainly to separate out the plutonium, which Japan can then try to use as a new energy source. But this is quite different from an outright export of nuclear waste.
Taiwan and North Korea do not belong to international treaties governing the disposal of nuclear waste, but experts say that if the Taiwan deal goes through as planned, then it could pave the way for other countries seeking refuge sites for their nuclear waste. "This might be a precedent for the practice of international exporting of waste," said Junizaburo Takagi, a nuclear chemist and executive director at Citizen's Nuclear Information Center.
Japan has reportedly considered the possibility of paying the Marshall Islands, in the Pacific, in exchange for storing waste there. Some residents of the Marshall Islands objected, and Japan quickly dropped the idea. The waste reportedly is mostly low-level garbage, like old gloves or clothing that have been used in the presence of radioactive material.
The United States has said that since the waste material contains no uranium or plutonium, the deal does not seem to raise any concerns about proliferation.
Still, the South Korean Government has been playing diplomatic hardball on the issue, threatening to refuse Taiwan the recognition it seeks in international organizations. And South Korea has also suggested that it will be less likely to arrange aid for North Korea if the North goes ahead with the deal.
The main concern of South Korean officials seem to be safety. They assert that North Korea does not have the proper installations to store the nuclear waste safely. The nuclear wastes, which would apparently be disposed of in an area with old coal mines close to the demilitarized zone that separates the North and the South, could leach into the ground water and harm the environment in South Korea as well.
Some officials quietly add that North Korea may collapse soon, and then South Korea will inherit responsibility for a nuclear garbage heap.
In any case, Seoul argues, Taiwan's move threatens to break an international practice of disposing of one's own nuclear waste at home.
"It could have a great environmental effect on the Korean Peninsula," said Lee Kyu Hyung, the South Korean Foreign Ministry spokesman. "This is like dumping waste. And dumping waste is prohibited by international practice."
According to reports in Taiwan about the deal, which was signed with North Korea by Taiwan's state-run power utility, the island is expected to begin shipments of low-level radioactive waste within a month. In exchange, it will reportedly pay about $1,135 per barrel, with an initial shipment of 60,000 barrels.
Taiwan then apparently has an option to turn over another 140,000 barrels of waste, which would amount to a total cash payment of about $227 million to North Korea.
Foreign Ministry officials in Taiwan would not comment on details of the transaction. North Korea officials were not available for comment.
In fact, the current deal solves pressing problems in both countries. North Korea is desperately in need of cash. Its economy is in shambles, and repeated bad harvests have left the nation's 23 million people on the verge of starvation, by some accounts.
Likewise, in Taiwan, a bitter debate has been growing over where to dispose of nuclear waste. Taiwan Power Company, the state-run utility, has run into opposition from communities near its proposed disposal sites.
Several months ago, North Korean officials approached Taiwan officials to discuss the possibility of selling access to disposal sites in North Korea, according to Taiwan news reports.
