HEADLINE: THE 1998 BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Presents '98 Budget, and a Goal

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton today proposed a $1.69 trillion budget for 1998 that he said would cut taxes on the middle class, increase spending on education and health care and lead to an end to deficits by 2002 -- and for almost 20 years after that.
The Administration said it would achieve its deficit-reduction goals over the next five years with a $350 billion bundle of program cuts and tax increases, including slowing the growth of Medicare and extending some taxes, like those on airline tickets, that are set to expire. 
 Indicating that he was ready to compromise even as he unveiled his proposal, Mr. Clinton argued that the progress of his Administration and Congress in cutting the deficit so far, together with the politics of the hour, presented "the best chance in a generation" to balance the budget.
"Some of the differences we have are truly principled differences," the President said at a midday briefing with reporters, "and we'll have to work hard to have an honorable compromise. But I believe that we can do it as long as the Republicans and the Democrats agree that we have to achieve this goal."
Citing its economic projections, the Administration held out the prospect of balanced budgets until the year 2020.
"We believe we can keep this budget in balance for a good long time," Mr. Clinton said.
But there is no guarantee that today's deficit-cutting zeal will extend to future administrations or Congresses -- or even endure the current ones. In a sign of how politically sensitive even small budget cuts can be, Administration officials today were at pains to avoid talking much about what Mr. Clinton called his budget's "detailed, difficult cuts in hundreds of Government programs."
The most important words about the budget were probably ones unsaid, with both the Administration and the Republicans starting the year with the attitude that they can strike a deal on balancing the budget. [News analysis, page A24.]
Republican Congressional leaders reacted frostily to the proposal, the formal start of a months-long negotiating process. But they did not dismiss it out of hand, as in years past.
"I suppose that you could say it's alive, but it's definitely not kicking," said Senator Trent Lott, the Mississippi Republican who is majority leader. Still, he said, negotiations could produce a balanced-budget agreement "within six weeks or so."
Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who heads the Budget Committee, called the proposal "a very good starting point."
But some derided the proposal almost instantly. Representative Tom DeLay, the Texas Republican who is the majority whip, said: "The Administration has embarked on a journey to Shangri-La, a mythical place where spending goes up, where the future is of no consequence, where the world is at peace and where budgets magically balance with a wave of the hand."
It is true that Franklin D. Raines, Mr. Clinton's budget director, wore a tie today that showed rabbits leaping out of hats, but Mr. Raines said he chose it only because it was red.
In fact, the two sides have already taken significant steps toward each other. The stark differences between them of two years ago -- like whether the Departments of Education and Commerce should exist -- boiled away after the two Government shutdowns over budget negotiations in 1995 and 1996. Mr. Clinton turned those fights to his advantage last year in his campaign by presenting himself as a bulwark against proposed Republican cuts in Medicare and other popular programs.
For his part, by declaring in December of 1995 that he would seek a balanced budget by 2002, Mr. Clinton was able to inoculate himself against accusations of being a big spender. But he also committed himself to achieving what was originally a Republican goal.
Still, much distance remains between Mr. Clinton and the Republican Congress. For example, Republicans have long sought a deep cut in the capital gains rate, the tax on profits from investments. Mr. Clinton's budget proposal does contain such a cut -- but one that is narrowly drawn, affecting only the profit from the sale of homes.
While the Administration projected a $17 billion surplus in 2002 with its plan, Republican Congressmen predicted a $50 billion deficit. In all, the budget proposal for 1998 amounts to a 3.5 percent increase over this year's projected Federal spending of $1.63 trillion.
Administration officials defended their projections as conservative, pointing out that they underestimated their progress against the deficit throughout Mr. Clinton's first term.
The budget proposal assumes steady economic growth over the next five years. Mr. Raines acknowledged that a recession would force the Administration, or its successor, to push back the deadline for balancing the budget. But if deficits loom, the Administration has incorporated a provision to automatically phase out $22 billion in tax cuts and to apply an across-the-board reduction in spending of 2.25 percent, excepting only Social Security.
Administration officials repeatedly stressed today that, as Mr. Raines put it, "we have already done much of the hard work necessary to balance the budget by 2002," pointing to the drop in the deficit from $290 billion in 1992 to $107 billion in 1996.
Still, whoever succeeds Mr. Clinton, if his plan is enacted, would have to grapple with the effects of deep reductions in Federal spending, compared with today. More than three-quarters of the deficit reduction the President is proposing would bite in the years 2001 and 2002, after his term. Some of his proposed programs, such as to provide money to help renovate schools, would simply cease to exist in 2002.
And to balance the budget in 2002, the Clinton Administration is counting quite literally on pennies from heaven, $22 billion that year alone from the auction of rights to broadcast frequencies whose value is hard to predict today.
One politician who hopes to occupy the White House then, Vice President Al Gore, was standing expressionless behind Mr. Clinton's right shoulder as he made his presentation today. Compared with Mr. Clinton's more conversational remarks, Mr. Gore followed with what sounded like a stump speech.
"We all know that the Government of yesterday cannot meet the challenges of tomorrow," he declared. Mr. Gore detailed the Administration's efforts to reduce the size of the bureaucracy without explicitly noting that he led them, saying, "We can balance the budget by 2002 because we're creating a Government that is fit for the new century."
Most of the proposals in the four-volume budget released today were sketched out by Mr. Clinton in the campaign, and again in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night. But in many cases he had not attached price tags to them.
Mr. Clinton is asking Congress for $21 billion over five years to restore benefits for legal immigrants, to reverse cuts in the food stamp program and to create jobs for welfare recipients. He is also requesting $2.8 billion next year, and $18 billion by 2002, to provide care to half of the 10 million American children who have no health insurance, and to finance medical care for several million people between jobs.
The President also hopes to spend nearly $19.5 billion next year on foreign affairs, a nearly 7 percent rise over the $18.2 billion authorized by Congress this year. He proposed to start paying off slightly more than $1 billion the United States owes the United Nations, starting with a $100 million payment in 1998.
Among his more expensive proposals, Mr. Clinton is seeking a 20 percent increase in spending on education and training, to $51 billion. He is proposing a combination of tax credits and deductions to help pay college tuitions.
Mr. Clinton hopes to cut taxes by $98 billion over the next five years. But his cuts are mostly paid for with $76 billion in new tax measures. He is seeking to raise $10.9 billion through "user fees" for everything from meat inspections to applying for permits to dredge wetlands. And he hopes to close certain loopholes benefiting corporations and investors.
But Administration officials caviled at the suggestion that such changes represented tax increases. "I don't know if I would call them a tax increase," said Robert E. Rubin, the Secretary of the Treasury. "What I would call them is an elimination of loopholes and unwarranted subsidies."

HEADLINE: THE 1998 BUDGET: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Urges Moratorium On Revenge

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Confessing that the partisan slights and squabbles of Washington had sometimes made his heart "a little harder," President Clinton urged politicians at a prayer breakfast today to "rid ourselves of this toxic atmosphere of cynicism," forswear efforts to "get even" and instead work together for the common good.
"We're in a world of hurt, we need help, we are in the breach, we are in the hole here," Mr. Clinton told several thousand politicians and community leaders at the annual National Prayer Breakfast at the Washington Hilton. Later, speaking to the same group, his wife, Hillary, lamented her own shortcomings and reflected, "We have, in our country, spent a lot of time in the last several years demonizing people with whom we do not agree politically." 
 Since taking office, Mr. Clinton has used the occasion of the breakfast, sponsored by Congressional prayer groups, to condemn hateful speech, call for more humility in politics and reflect on man's flawed place in a fallen world. Today, he took as his text a passage from Isaiah that he first cited in his inaugural address last month, exhorting the faithful to be "repairers of the breach" and asking the bipartisan group, which included Speaker Newt Gingrich, to help educate the poor, find jobs for welfare recipients and aid the needy in strife-torn countries.
But the President, whose speeches often echo a preacher's cadences, saved his harshest comments for himself, other politicians and the reporters who cover them.
"This town is gripped with people who are self-righteous, sanctimonious and hypocritical," he said. "All of us are that way sometimes. I plead guilty from time to time."
Indeed, Mr. Clinton has often been accused of just such vices, and for four years, he and Mrs. Clinton have been the targets not only of intense political and policy criticism but also of several investigations into their personal and political finances. They would be prominent beneficiaries of any moratorium on blame and revenge in the capital.
Later today, Mrs. Clinton picked up the theme, recounting a parable of a man, whom she did not identify, who approached her on Wednesday night at a dinner sponsored by the prayer group.
"I had a man say to me, 'Mrs. Clinton, I want your forgiveness because for the last four years I have worked very hard to destroy you,' " Mrs. Clinton said. "And I said to him, 'You know, I very much appreciate your saying this, and I certainly will remember forever that you have, and, of course, I forgive you.' "
Mrs. Clinton added that only when she got home did the man's full meaning sink in.
She said, "What I should have said is, 'I don't know you and I don't know anything about you, but I want you to forgive me also, because I am sure that in my moments of frustration and anger I have said terrible things about people like you -- and I have thought even worse."
In his own remarks, Mr. Clinton at one point talked in terms that at first seemed self-pitying but soon turned self-critical, recalling how, early in his term, he got "so mad at our friends in Congress and the Republican Party because they were real mean to me over something."
Later, he said, an old Washingtonian had told him it was "payback time" for years of acrimonious dealings between Republican Presidents and Democratic Congresses.
"Pretty soon, I was behaving that way," Mr. Clinton said. "I'd wake up in the morning and my heart was getting a little harder: Now, who can I get even with? This happens to you, doesn't it? Who can I get even with? And sometimes, you can't get even with the person that really did it to you, so you just go find somebody else, because you've got to get even with somebody. Pretty soon, everybody's involved in this great act."
Mr. Clinton said politicians had "now become just as cynical about the press" as he said the press was about them. He said, "Cynicism and all this negative stuff is just sort of a cheap excuse for not doing your best with your life, and it's not a very pleasant way to live, frankly -- not even any fun.
"I try to tell everybody around the White House all the time, I have concluded a few things in my life," Mr. Clinton added. "And one of them is that you don't ever get even. The harder you try, the more frustrated you're going to be, because nobody ever gets even."
Since his re-election, Mr. Clinton has called over and over for a spirit of renewed cooperation and bipartisanship, interpreting that as the will of a divided electorate that gave Democrats the White House and Republicans control of Congress. Today he thanked Mr. Gingrich for cooperating on a fiscal rescue package for Mexico two years ago.
Later, the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, was asked how Mr. Clinton thought the Republicans had been "mean" to him, and Mr. McCurry replied, "He was talking about a period in which there was a fair amount of partisan rancor," for example, when Mr. Clinton won no Republican votes in 1993 for his economic plan.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 BUDGET: CORPORATE TAXES;
Encore for a '96 Proposal To Raise Business Taxes

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is looking to Wall Street and corporate America to help underwrite its proposals to cut middle-class taxes and finance higher education, a strategy that met with little success last year.
Undeterred by failures to enact many of the same provisions, the Administration issued today a lengthy list of changes in tax and accounting law intended to raise $34.3 billion over five years and to end what the Administration called abuses of the tax code by business and wealthy individuals. 
 The proposal would increase taxes on multinational corporations, end the favored tax treatment of extra-long-term bonds and raise capital-gains taxes by changing the rules for computing the cost basis of securities when they are sold at a profit.
In soak-the-rich language seen nowhere else in the otherwise conciliatory budget submission, the Administration said the plan to increase taxes "cuts unwarranted corporate-tax subsidies, closes tax loopholes, improves tax compliance and adopts other revenue measures."
Wall Street revolted over those proposals last year, and the Republican chairmen of the tax-writing committees in Congress sided with their corporate constituents. The proposals never went to a vote.
This year, however, the Administration apparently hopes that Mr. Clinton's stronger political position and a new, if temporary, bipartisanship will allow the provisions to be considered on their merits.
The tax law now "costs the Federal Treasury revenue and makes the economy less efficient," a senior Treasury Department official who insisted on anonymity said today. The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, said in an interview that he would carefully review the proposed increases. "When we feel there is abuse, we will take action," Mr. Roth said.
The largest of 36 proposals, and the only major one not carried over from last year, would change the taxation of foreign sales of multinational corporations. The law now allows American companies that do business overseas to assume for tax purposes that half their income from foreign sales is generated overseas, even if the products are wholly made in the United States. That lets companies take advantage of tax differences between the United States and other countries.
The Administration proposes to tax foreign sales based on the site of activity, which in most cases would increase exporters' United States taxes. The Administration said it expected to to generate an additional $7.9 billion in corporate taxes from the change over the next five years.
Industry is expected to fight the change, as it did when it was proposed in the tax package of 1986, said Harvey B. Morgenson, an international tax specialist at the accounting firm Ernst & Young.
"This is the sacred cow that was spared in 1986," Mr. Morgenson said. "It's very easy to attack from a technical point of view, but it's very important to U.S. multinationals and exporters. It'll be down and dirty in the trenches when it comes to enacting it."
The Administration also proposed, as it did last year, to force taxpayers to use the average purchase price of a bundle of stocks bought at different times when computing capital gains. Current law allows taxpayers to choose among three methods to compute the cost basis of stocks, in many cases lowering taxes. Officials estimated that the change would bring in an additional $600 million a year.
The budget also attacks several maneuvers intended to delay or avoid taxes on the sales of securities like "short sales against the box" and various asset swaps.
Although unknown to most Americans, they are popular with corporate treasurers and wealthy individuals. None are projected to yield big dividends for the Treasury.
The proposed ban on certain short sales, for instance, would generate $300 million from 1998 to 2002.
The budget plan also tries to clarify a long-standing dispute over the distinction between debt and equity, which the tax code treats differently but which have become increasingly blurred with the large volumes of bonds with maturities of more than 40 years and zero-coupon convertible debt. If the proposals are adopted, the law would treat those products as equities, rather than bonds, eliminating favorable tax treatment.
The proposal would also limit the deductibility of loan interest in direct proportion to a company's holdings of tax-free municipal securities.
The executive vice president of the Bond Market Trade Association, Micah S. Green, said, "They will simply increase the cost of capital to corporations around the country and make it more expensive for local governments to raise money."

INTERNATIONAL A3-19

North Korea to Take Taiwan's Nuclear Waste
North Korea agreed to accept nuclear waste from Taiwan in exchange for much-needed hard currency. South Korea was outraged, because of the safety risks and because it wants to avoid inheriting liability for the waste in the event of North Korea's collapse. A1
 
Sotheby Executives Accused
Sotheby's, the world's oldest and best known auction house, suspended several senior executives amid charges that they readily offered their services to smuggle a protected work of art out of Italy. Sotheby's denied that such abuses were systematic and said the journalism used in the investigation constituted entrapment. A9
 
Ecuador Chief Loses a Vote
Ecuador's Congress voted to remove President Abdala Bucaram for "mental incapacity." Lawmakers said they were exasperated by his six months in office, during which the President sang and pulled political stunts while Ecuador fell into economic crisis. Mr. Bucaram, a showman who cheerfully referred to himself as "El Loco," called the vote a "coup by Congress" and said he would not recognize it. A5
 
Riots in South Africa
Mixed-race South Africans, known as coloreds under apartheid laws, held a violent protest in Johannesburg. It erupted as part of a demonstration against local utility rates they said were higher than those in nearby black areas of Soweto. But it also reflected fears of many mixed-race people that they are being left out of the new South Africa. A15
 
Gore Meets Chernomyrdin
Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin of Russia said that a summit meeting between Presidents Clinton and Boris Yeltsin would be held in late March, as scheduled. Mr. Chernomyrdin was in Washington for two days of talks with Vice President Al Gore. Progress on crucial matters between the two countries, like the question of NATO enlargement and other security issues, has been immobilized for the last six months by Mr. Yeltsin's illness. A19
 
No Progress in Peru Crisis
Two hours of negotiations between leftist rebels in Peru and a commission chosen to represent the Government produced little if any progress towards the release of 72 hostages held inside the Japanese Ambassador's residence for more than seven weeks. The rebels denied that they were willing to discuss safe passage to a third country and sought to disparage a recent diplomatic tour by President Alberto Fujimori. A7
 
Opposition Struggles in Serbia 
Although President Slobodan Milosevic has recommended the restoration of opposition victories in 14 of Serbia's largest cities, the opposition may have a tough time governing: departing officials of Mr. Milosevic's Socialist party have left municipal coffers bare and are organizing resistance to the new administrations. HEADLINE: THE 1998 BUDGET: HEALTH CARE;
President Moves to Protect Half of Uninsured Children

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton moved today to provide health care coverage to half of the 10 million American children who have no health insurance, and proposed a new program to finance medical care for several million people between jobs.
Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said these initiatives would cost $2.8 billion next year and $18.4 billion over the five-year period from 1998 through 2002. 
 Mr. Clinton would cover half of the cost by curbing the growth of Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for the poor. Over strenuous objections by governors of both parties, he proposes to set firm annual limits on Federal Medicaid spending, which is not subject to any such limit now.
"Even though the growth in Medicaid spending has fallen in recent years," Mr. Clinton said, "aggregate Medicaid spending still will grow at an average annual rate of 7.2 percent from 1997 to 2002. To insure that Medicaid's explosive growth of the 1980's and early 1990's does not resume, the budget would set a per-capita cap on Medicaid spending."
The President would not set any limits on state Medicaid spending, and governors fear that they wouldhave to pay costs incurred after the Federal Government reaches its limit, which would be tied to the nation's economic output.
In contrast to his 1993 plan to redesign the nation's health care system from top to bottom, Mr. Clinton now proposes a series of incremental changes to expand health insurance coverage step by step.
The President's proposals do not go as far as some members of Congress want. Under separate proposals offered by the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, and Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, the Federal Government would help pay health insurance premiums for working families with low and moderate incomes above the official poverty level (now $12,517 a year for a family of three).
Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, said tonight: "The President's proposal is a step in the right direction. But it still leaves millions of children without health insurance, particularly in working families." Mrs. Edelman said she hoped that Congress would build on the proposal and pass bipartisan legislation to cover all 10 million uninsured children.
Mr. Clinton said one million children could receive insurance coverage under his proposal to give Federal grants to the states for "innovative programs," to be designed by state officials working with health care providers and employers. The grants would total $750 million next year and $3.8 billion from then through 2002.
Mr. Clinton also wants states to make aggressive efforts to locate some of the three million children who are already eligible for Medicaid but are not yet enrolled. The Administration estimates that such efforts will find about half the eligible children, providing Medicaid to 1.6 million.
Under another proposal, Mr. Clinton would allow states to guarantee Medicaid coverage to children for one year at a time, rather than requiring them to re-certify eligibility every six months. This proposal would reduce paperwork and encourage health maintenance organizations to invest in children, knowing that the children would be enrolled at least a year.
The President said this proposal would help one million children keep Medicaid coverage that they might otherwise lose because of fluctuations in family income.
In addition to all these steps, Mr. Clinton estimated that one million children would become eligible for Medicaid over the next five years under provisions of current law.
Mr. Clinton said his proposal for workers between jobs would finance as much as six months of coverage for them. It would assist 3.2 million families, including 700,000 children, at a cost of $1.7 billion next year. The cost is estimated at $9.8 billion for the period from 1998 through 2002.
The President announced his major proposals on Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, two weeks ago, and he provided additional details today. The proposals are intended to save $100 billion over five years, mainly by curbing payments to hospitals, doctors and H.M.O.'s.
Under Mr. Clinton's proposals, the Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills would remain solvent through 2007. Under current law, the trust fund will run out of money in 2001 if Congress takes no action.
As for H.M.O.'s, Mr. Clinton said there was "substantial evidence that Medicare pays too much for managed care plans and, in fact, loses money" whenever beneficiaries enroll in such plans. Since H.M.O. enrollment is increasing rapidly, these losses may become a major expense for Medicare, even though many experts see managed care as a way to control the program's costs in the long run.
Medicare now pays H.M.O.'s 95 percent of the average cost that it pays for beneficiaries in the standard fee-for-service program. But Federal officials say elderly people who voluntarily enroll in H.M.O.'s are on average healthier than those in the standard program. Were these healthier people in the fee-for-service program, officials say, they would be costing the Government less than they do now. Mr. Clinton would pay H.M.O.'s only 90 percent of the standard program's average cost.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 BUDGET: THE NEGOTIATIONS;
Between Budget Line Items, Horse Trades in Invisible Ink

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Long before the Clinton Administration sent its budget tables, its pie charts and its five-year projections to the printers, it was already hinting at answers to the one question that dominates budget debates in Washington: where is the deal?
The first part of any deal, Mr. Clinton's budget aides told Congressional Democrats earlier this week, probably lies in the one concession Republicans say they want most in life: a cut in capital gains taxes, presumably one that could benefit the millions who have reaped big paper profits in the stock market. 
 "They have already told us to be ready to have a capital gains proposal or to respond to one," Senator Daniel P. Moynihan of New York, the ranking Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee, said today. "That should tell you something."
Part two of any meaningful deal, both Democrats and Republicans say, is finding a way to change the Government's calculation of inflation, which would greatly slow increases in the Government's Social Security payments and other entitlements linked to inflation.
But unlike most budget problems, that is not a battle between parties. Instead, it is a problem, as one of Mr. Clinton's top advisers said recently, "of finding a way to do this that allows everyone to deny paternity" for the idea, which already has Social Security recipients and other powerful interest groups screaming.
Solving those two problems, of course, is hardly the end of the battle. Mr. Clinton's chief budget negotiators -- the White House chief of staff Erskine B. Bowles, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the budget director, Franklin D. Raines -- will spend the next few months wrangling over the Administration's proposal to restore money for welfare programs and commit new funds to rebuilding schools. There are still major arguments ahead over how to reduce the costs of Medicare, the health care program for the elderly, and over Mr. Clinton's insistence that discretionary spending must rise and that military spending, at least in the short term, must shrink.
But those are increasingly arguments around the margins. What is perhaps most striking about the statistics this year is not how much the Republicans and Democrats disagree, but on how much they agree.
Consider this: the budget the Democrats say would be balanced in 2002 is the same budget that the Republicans, using different economic assumptions, say would run a $60 billion deficit. Sixty billion dollars, of course, is a lot of money by anyone's measure, and no politician can risk sounding cavalier about it. But it is also roughly 3 percent of the Federal budget that year, and one half of 1 percent of the overall economy.
And the number itself could be a total fiction: the Congressional Budget Office, in estimates published just 14 months ago, predicted the fiscal 1996 budget deficit would be $173 billion. In reality, it came in at only $107 billion -- $66 billion less than estimated -- because of a surge of unpredicted revenue.
"We are down to the point where we are arguing over insignificant figures that no one could accurately project a year ahead, much less five years ahead," said Stanley E. Collender, the managing director of Burson-Marsteller's Federal Budget Consulting Group.
In fact, some economists say there is reason to wonder whether the whole argument about balancing the budget is still worth the enormous expenditure of political energy on all sides. They point out that this year, the United States has the lowest budget deficit, as a percentage of gross national product, of any of the world's seven largest industrialized nations -- lower than Japan's, lower than Germany's. Yet only in Washington is it a subject of daily preoccupation.
"Balancing the budget, the actual precision of reaching balance, has become as much an issue of public trust as it has one of economics," acknowledged Gene Sperling, the new chairman of the National Economic Council. Indeed, in budget politics, symbolism is often more important than the numbers. And that is certainly true when it comes to fashioning a compromise.
So in the selling of the fiscal 1998 budget, capital gains taxes are the first symbol. Mr. Clinton made the first move, at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, when he proposed eliminating virtually all capital gains taxes on the sale of a home.
"That opens the door for us to talk about it," Representative Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said the other day. Today Senator Pete Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, added: "I think we just have to start with the proposition that this is the time to change the capital gains permanently, not just for houses but for assets held for business purposes and equities."
The Republicans have something grander in mind, however, than do the Democrats. They have called for halving the 28 percent tax on capital gains, which hits most investors when they sell winning stocks and mutual funds. It is highly unlikely such a sharp cut would happen, but there are occasional hints that the tax rate could eventually fall to, say, 20 percent or 21 percent.
On the record, Clinton Administration officials say this is bad economics, and they would not trade a capital gains cut for winning new funds for education, one of Mr. Clinton's big new priorities. Speaking not for attribution, however, they say that a capital gains cut is an issue they have to take seriously.
Recalculating the consumer price index is a different kind of problem altogether. Both sides concede it must be done, both because they believe inflation rates are significantly overstated, and because they know that correcting the statistics would save billions of dollars in Social Security payments and in other programs in which benefits are guaranteed to all who meet eligibility criteria. "This is where the real money is," a leading Democrat said the other day.
But neither side can figure out how to cast this change as a statistical fix, rather than a midnight maneuver to balance the budget on the backs of the elderly.
Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the budget master of the House Republicans, said today that the inflation measure "ought to be changed," adding, "But we can't go and change it on our own because the President -- we risk the possibility that our political enemies will not only not change it, but then they'll scare people again."
Those are problems of spin, not differences of ideology. But that may be what the next six months of budget arguments are chiefly about. The two sides have almost reached a statistical middle ground; now the question, as one Senator said, "is whether we can give each other the political cover to stand there."

HEADLINE: THE 1998 BUDGET;
Clinton's Budget Holds Few Clues on Exactly How to Lower Spending

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton plans to lower Government spending over the next five years by $252 billion, even as he increases spending -- sometimes dramatically -- on some of Government's most popular programs, from welfare to education to the environment to tax relief.
So how does he do that? 
 The budget Mr. Clinton released today offers some answers but not with great clarity. Sometimes it postpones a reply for years.
The White House would get some of its savings by reining in Medicare, the second-biggest Federal benefit after Social Security, shaving $100 billion over five years. But some of that is illusory; Medicare is cut in part by shifting some expenses to the general treasury.
The budget also saves $22 billion by applying a new spending formula to Medicaid, the health-care program for the poor. But $13 billion of that savings would be reapplied to other programs like health care for children, leaving $9 billion for deficit reduction. Military spending would fall by almost $80 billion from current projections, perhaps the single biggest cut, barring any new wars or peacekeeping duties.
But the handful of larger, highly visible cuts do not begin to offset the costs of expanded programs and wiping out the deficit. Mr. Clinton appears to get the rest from increases in Federal fees, better management, one-time sales of Government assets like the broadcast spectrum and unnamed cuts years from now.
And so, in the bowels of the 2,000 and more pages of tables and numbers handed out today, the White House says it would raise $700 million next year by auctioning off the rights to toll-free "888" telephone numbers, and $118 million by "increased attention to integrity activities in state unemployment insurance operations," in other words, cutting waste, fraud and abuse.
It would collect $350 million over the next five years by raising the fee companies pay when they submit merger proposals to antitrust experts for Federal approval. And it would scrape up $13 million, in $3-and-$4 million-a-year increments, with a "test employment strategy for the disabled" at the Social Security Administration.
The savings and profits in those and other "mandatory" programs -- benefits like Medicare, and other activities whose spending is determined mostly by fixed formulas -- total almost $159 billion. Mr. Clinton would spend $37.5 billion of that on new mandatory programs like child health care, leaving about $121 billion for deficit-cutting.
The remainder comes from changes in military spending and the other so-called discretionary programs, like roads and schools, whose budgets are set each year by Congress. And it is there that the Administration's intentions are least clear.
The budget trumpets its new programs. With contracts about to expire for 1.8 million housing units for the poor, elderly and disabled, Mr. Clinton seeks $24.8 billion next year for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, an increase of almost 30 percent.
Education and job-training spending would jump by almost 12 percent in 1998 alone, to $36.2 billion. The Environmental Protection Agency would reap a 12 percent increase over the shrunken budget that the Republican Congress approved for this year. Energy conservation spending would rise by one-quarter. Spending on Indian health and housing programs would rise by 6 percent.
And the Justice Department, whose budget has already swelled by 69 percent under Mr. Clinton, would get another 5 percent increase next year, to $19.3 billion. Much of that would go to programs to reduce juvenile crime.
All of those increases, and billions of dollars worth of others, must be balanced by cuts elsewhere in the budget for domestic discretionary spending, which is walled off from the military and mandatory budgets. But spending cuts are harder to find.
Mr. Clinton plans to shave his previously planned spending on nonmilitary discretionary programs by $58 billion. Of those cuts, about $600 million -- or about 1 percent -- would be made in the fiscal 1998 budget submitted today. Barely 6 percent would occur in fiscal 1999.
The new budget only hints at those proposed cuts in the 1,000-page book that outlines the 1998 spending plan. The remaining 93 percent of domestic spending reductions are left to future Congresses, and in some cases a future President.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Easing Food Stamp Rules

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The State Department of Human Services will ask for a waiver of job requirements for some food stamp recipients in an effort to help people living in places with high unemployment rates, officials said yesterday. The new Federal welfare law requires people who apply for food stamps to have held a job or been enrolled in a training program for at least three months of the three previous years. In November, the state received a waiver of the work requirement for 15,000 food-stamp recipients living in 24 areas where unemployment exceeded 10 percent. If the new waiver is approved, an additional 5,000 people would benefit, John McKeegan, a department spokesman, said.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Rise on Release of Jobs Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Investors who have kept to the sidelines of the bond market this week returned en masse yesterday after the Labor Department released employment figures that indicated that growth in wages was slow.
The 30-year Treasury bond gained 20/32 , to a price of 9712/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, slipped to 6.70 percent, from 6.75 percent on Thursday. For investors, the gain was about $6 for each bond with a face value of $1,000. 
 While last month's gain of 271,000 new jobs exceeded most analyst forecasts and was higher than last year's average monthly gain of about 214,000 jobs, Labor Department officials cautioned that the gain in new jobs might have been partly exaggerated by seasonal statistical adjustments.
The report suggested that the Federal Reserve would keep interest rates steady, as it did this week when the Fed's Open Market Committee, which sets interest-rate policy, met in its first session of the year.
"Given that the size of the seasonal-factor handicap was so large," Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said, "the credit market was truly amazed to see how close the number came in relative to the consensus figures of approximately 256,000.
"Moreover, this is the first time in a long time that we have received an employment report that provided such a uniform and consistent message of growth moderation," Mr. Chan said.
Mr. Chan said that this message had been confirmed by the big declines in workweeks in the economy as a whole and in the manufacturing sector particularly, as well as by the meager increase in the average hourly-earnings data and by a slight increase in the unemployment rate.
Mr. Chan said that the data released yesterday would please Federal Reserve policy makers. The unemployment rate rose a notch, to 5.4 percent in January from 5.3 percent in December, the Labor Department said, and average hourly pay for non-supervisory workers rose just 1 cent, to $12.06, compared with a 15-cent gain during the previous two months.
"The smaller-than-expected monthly rise in wages does add more support for Mr. Greenspan's moderate stance on policy," Mr. Chan said, "and should further enhance stature among any of the other F.O.M.C. members that may have hoped for an immediate hike in rates."
Based on all the economic data available from January, Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, predicted that overall real growth in the first quarter's gross domestic product should slow to about half the 4.7 percent pace in the fourth quarter of 1996.
Yesterday's run-up in prices was momentarily interrupted in the afternoon following comments by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. Speaking at a news conference in advance of the meeting today of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven major industrial nations, Mr. Rubin said: "We believe we should have a strong dollar. And we've had a strong dollar for some time now."
When pressed to elaborate on whether that suggested a policy change, Mr. Rubin said he would not elaborate further.
Mr. Chan thought that investors sold bonds on the belief that Mr. Rubin's endorsement of the dollar ahead of the Group of Seven meeting was somewhat less robust than his prior statements. The comments, Mr. Chan said, also gave the impression that Mr. Rubin's stance could change if pressed by representatives of the other member nations. A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more valuable to foreign investors.
Next week, the Treasury's quarterly refunding gets under way, with the sale of nearly $40 billion in new 3-year and 10-year notes and a new 30-year bond. In when-issued trading ahead of the auctions, the 3-year issue was offered at a price to yield 5.98 percent; the 10-year at a price to yield 6.36 percent, and the 30-year bond, 6.64 percent.

HEADLINE: Stocks Close Higher as Dow Gains 82.74

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
A fickle stock market soared, sputtered, and then soared again yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average ending sharply higher. The session showed once again how jittery the market can be in reaction to a news headline.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 82.74 points, or 1.22 percent, to close at 6,855.80, just 28 points shy of the closing high it set on Jan. 21. For the week, the Dow was up 42.71 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent. 
 Broader market indexes fared even better. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 9.41 points, to 789.56, a new high. And the Nasdaq composite index was up 11.31 points, to 1,357.71, after technology issues rebounded from a weeklong decline.
 "If there's one word I'd use to describe this market it's resilience," said Andrew M. Brooks, vice president in charge of equity trading at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. "It's really tough to push this market down," he added, noting that strong cash flow and a benign bond market have helped bolster equities.
 While the January increase of 271,000 jobs in nonfarm payrolls was a little more than expected, the fact that average hourly wages rose by only one-tenth of 1 percent was taken by investors as a sign that inflationary pressures remain under control.
 In the afternoon, though, news that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin may have eased his support of the dollar on the eve of today's Group of Seven meeting in Berlin caused the dollar to fall. That, in turn, fed downturns in the bond and stock markets.
 Though the dollar has risen nearly 14 percent against the Japanese yen in the last six months and 12.6 percent against the German mark, analysts said that a declining dollar could drive some foreign investors out of the bond market.
"Over the past year, foreign participation has had a tremendous impact on the bond market," said Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "That has helped to keep yields at this level. If that currency dynamic were to shift, you'd see tremendous selling."
 The markets turned downward yesterday, after Mr. Rubin's remarks, but stocks and bonds quickly recovered. The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond fell 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.70 percent.
In stocks, blue-chip issues again fueled the rally. Of the Dow 30 component stocks, 14 gained at least one point, led by American Express, I.B.M., Boeing and Procter & Gamble.
 American Express rose 3 3/8 a share, to 65 3/8. I.B.M., after a five-day decline, gained 2 3/4, to 148 3/4. Boeing was up 3, to 109 1/2, and P.& G. rose 2 5/8, to 122 1/4.
 Technology stocks shrugged off a weeklong decline with a strong finish. Intel, Microsoft, Dell Computer, Gateway 2000 and other computer stocks soared. Intel was up 3 7/16 a share, to 156 3/8; Microsoft gained 3 1/4, to 100 3/8; Dell rose 2 5/8, to 65 3/4, and Gateway advanced 3 1/2, to 60 3/4.
 Advancing issues outpaced decliners, 1,643 to 944, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. But some analysts said that the rallies were still powered by a small group of blue chips.
 "It seems every time you see a rally, fewer and fewer players participate," said Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. "Your big, high-priced stocks are making your big moves here. It's a one-sided advance."

HEADLINE: Other Carriers Preparing for A Strike Threat At American

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
A strike by the pilots of American Airlines threatened to begin next Saturday is by no means a sure thing. Still, airlines, passengers, cruise ships and other industries heavily dependent on air travel are not taking any chances.
Some passengers appear to be booking flights on more than one airline, airlines and travel agents said. And cruise ships have already moved thousands of passengers from American to other carriers. 
 In an effort to minimize double-booking, two days ago Delta Air Lines took the rare step of making its expensive full-fare tickets nonrefundable and requiring that customers pay for them within 24 hours of making reservations, rather than at the airport just before takeoff.
So far Delta's restriction is limited to travel from Feb. 15 through Feb. 18, the busy Washington's Birthday holiday weekend, which includes the start of the threatened strike. It is also limited to 13 cities where Delta competes heavily with American, including New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Dallas/Fort Worth and flights to and from San Juan, P.R., and St. Thomas and St. Croix in the Virgin Islands.
The AMR Corporation, American's parent, said that in the event of a strike it would shut down both American and American Eagle, its commuter carrier. American recently calculated that the economic cost to the nation of a 60-day strike ran to nearly $5 billion. American itself could lose as much as $50 million a day in revenue.
"A lot of people are concerned about the strike," said Norman Sherlock, executive director of the National Business Travel Association, "and many of them are already booking away from American."
Northwest Airlines, which competes with American on only a small percentage of its routes, said it had seen a surge in bookings between the Midwest and Florida from what appear to be American passengers.
Rosenbluth International, the worldwide travel agency that specializes in business clients, has been getting in touch with customers to discuss available options, and is changing travel plans for those who request it. In addition, "Agents down on our reservations floor are starting to get questions and requests from travelers to look at alternatives," said Liz Joseph, a spokeswoman at Rosenbluth's headquarters in Philadelphia.
Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines has already changed bookings for more than 8,000 passengers who had been scheduled to fly American to or from its home port in Miami next weekend, and Princess Cruises, a unit of the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, has switched more than 5,000 passengers.
"We have seen some erosion, but it's not a large number," said Tim Smith, an American Airlines spokesman. "We've seen more double-booking than booking away from us."
Helping to minimize defections, apparently, is the fact that this has been a busier than usual first five weeks of the year, according to the Air Transport Association, with the percentage of seats occupied by paying passengers as much as 12 percentage points higher than the usual January and February numbers.
While double-booking is perfectly legal, the practice is uniformly detested by airlines because it often results in large numbers of no-shows -- that is, seats that fly empty.
"We decided to put the restrictions on when we saw an unusually high volume of walk-up fares for February," said Bill Berry, a spokesman for Delta. "We knew then we had to do something to protect us from the speculative passengers who might be a no-show or who would pre-empt our loyal business travelers."
Normally, only discounted tickets, used by the vast majority of leisure travelers, require advance purchase and are nonrefundable.
Because of its improved capability to monitor and detect unusual booking patterns across its entire system, Delta has identified many potential "questionable" passengers, from double-bookers to passengers who may have never flown with Delta or who have never flown at full fare.
It can also identify travel agents or large groups that suddenly show up in its computers, or travel agents who are booking Delta flights for the first time.
The carrier is already getting in touch with many such passengers to inquire diplomatically about their travel plans -- and to suggest that they would be doing other passengers a big favor if they would relinquish any extra bookings.
While airlines can require such passengers to buy tickets within a certain time or risk cancellation, that approach requires a balance of toughness and tact because fair-weather fliers are also potential frequent fliers.
Representatives of other airlines said that they were considering following suit. One even said that if an unusual surge in potential double-booked flights was detected, it would likely impose similar restrictions. That carrier, though, declined to be identified, because it did not want to scare off customers.
Trans World Airlines has not imposed restrictions on full fares, but a spokesman said that it was considering using "flight firming" -- that is, getting in touch with passengers who are booked on high-occupancy routes also flown by American and asking if they still planned to take that flight.
Continental Airlines, on the other hand, has decided not to impose restrictions on full fares, because, a spokesman said, "we didn't want to risk penalizing our loyal customers."

HEADLINE: Lott Calls for a Truce in the Budget Wrangle

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
It was Trent Lott the bad cop who went first today, as Congressional Republicans laid down some rhetorical markers before the start of negotiations with President Clinton on balancing the budget.
"I must tell you, I am gravely depressed about what I have seen," Mr. Lott, the Senate majority leader, said of the budget plan submitted by the White House on Thursday. The Administration's proposals, he said, were "disappointing," lacking in leadership and courage and loaded with "optimistic assumptions and shell games." 
 Then it was Trent Lott the good cop, assessing the outlook for the negotiations scheduled to begin on Tuesday on Capitol Hill.
"The idea there will be to just sit down and roll up our sleeves, forget what's been said, forget the campaign, and see if we can begin to actually get down to work," he said. "I'm going to urge that we not waste time talking about what we disagree on. Let's see where we can find some commonality, where we can begin to come up with agreements that will help the quality of life of all Americans."
Senator Lott's partisan criticism, juxtaposed with his call for a truce, suggests just how fine a line Republican leaders are walking as they position themselves for the budget talks.
Mr. Lott and his counterparts in the House dearly want to achieve a budget deal to erase the electorate's memories of the legislative deadlock of the past two years. To speed the process, nearly all the Republican leaders are willing to accept the President's budget proposals as a starting point, without submitting a budget of their own.
But to complete a deal they will have to control the considerable animosity within their party toward Mr. Clinton and his tax and spending policies.
So Mr. Lott, a Mississippi Republican, and other leaders of his party spent today pivoting from one audience to another, assuring their own hard-liners that they view the Administration's opening gambit with deepest skepticism, but also encouraging Mr. Clinton to come to the table prepared to deal seriously. Rather than risk poisoning the atmosphere, Mr. Lott issued orders to Republicans this week to keep their mouths closed, or at least to temper their statements, and to let him and his top lieutenants do the talking.
Because all of the House Republicans left Washington on Thursday for a two-day retreat in Williamsburg, Va., he has largely succeeded.
Among those silenced by absence from Washington today was Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee. Mr. Kasich, a harsh critic of the Administration's plan, has been resisting Mr. Lott's call to forgo presenting a Republican budget alternative.
Senator Lott said, "I've been very careful to try to set up the atmosphere, as far as rhetoric goes, to try to move us toward the possibility that we could come to a budget agreement this year."
Indeed, the majority leader went so far today as to say what the White House perhaps most wanted to hear: that the Administration's education proposals, the heart of Mr. Clinton's second-term agenda, contain "a lot of good ideas."
The President, in turn, said he was encouraged by the response of House and Senate leaders, Mr. Lott's criticisms notwithstanding.
"We are just beginning this process, and I took no offense about what he said today," Mr. Clinton said. "I think he thinks maybe there's a bigger difference between us and we'll have to work harder, but we always knew we would have to work hard to reconcile the differences between us. We can do this."
But neither Mr. Lott nor his colleagues shied away from listing the substantive problems they said they have with the Administration's budget, starting with its call for $60 billion in new spending in the next five years on health care benefits for children and the unemployed, the expansion of certain Medicare and Medicaid benefits, food stamps and other welfare benefits, and school construction.
"I don't believe we can spend our way into a balanced budget," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Budget Committee. "The Administration, as I see it, is stepping on the accelerator when we should be stepping very hard on the brakes."
The Administration started its effort to protect its budget priorities on Capitol Hill today with an appearance before the Senate Budget Committee by Franklin D. Raines, the White House budget chief.
Mr. Raines called the Administration's proposals a "starting point" for negotiations, and added, "We want to get your reactions to our budget, and we want to hear your ideas."
Mostly what he heard was that the Administration was ducking tough choices on spending and not supporting nearly enough in tax cuts to get a deal with Republicans. The Administration wants to slow the growth of Medicare by $100 billion over five years, trim domestic programs slightly and defer increases in military spending. It has proposed $98 billion in tax cuts for individuals, largely offset by $76 billion in new and extended taxes on corporations, investors and airline travelers.
But even those Republicans who gave Mr. Raines a chilly reception hewed to the leadership line that they had to negotiate a compromise.
"We don't have any choice but to work together," said Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma. "A repeat of last year is not acceptable to anybody."

HEADLINE: Payrolls Swell by 271,000, But Inflation Stays in Check

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
A buoyant economy created more jobs last month than economists had expected, but growth in labor costs slowed, calming Wall Street's jitters about inflation.
Labor Department figures showed today that strong demand for workers swelled payrolls by 271,000 last month, although analysts said the increase did not imply additional pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. 
 The report also showed that the proportion of Americans with jobs rose to a record in January.
"Pinch me because this just seems too good to be true," said Joel L. Naroff, chief bank economist for First Union in Philadelphia. "The economy keeps adding jobs like crazy, but the labor markets manage to absorb the demands without any major problems."
One sign of job equilibrium was that the unemployment rate edged up one-tenth of a point, to 5.4 percent, as a large number of people -- 509,000 -- entered the job market and all but 75,000 of them found jobs.
The employment report -- the first broad look at the economy's performance this year -- showed steady growth with low inflation, a combination that heartened investors. Both stocks and bonds surged on the report. The rally was interrupted by a drop in the dollar that was prompted by comments by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, but both stock and bond prices ended higher.
The moderation in labor costs in particular cheered investors, suggesting that the Fed could keep short-term interest rates steady. Average hourly earnings inched up just 1 cent, to $12.06, last month after increases totaling 15 cents in November and December that unnerved inflation-watchers.
The report also showed a growing confidence in the job market. The number of people who left jobs voluntarily -- presumably believing they could readily find a better one -- jumped to 890,000, or 12.3 percent of the jobless ranks compared with 11.7 percent in December.
And both the proportion of the population with jobs and the proportion who either have jobs or are actively looking for them edged up to new heights, surpassing peaks of late 1996.
These were said by officials to be the highest percentages since the two related statistical series were begun in 1943, though they cautioned that periodic changes in methodology prevented exact comparisons.
This, said Isabel Sawhill, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, reflected the combination of the long-established trend of more women working outside the home and an economy that has been expanding without significant interruption for nearly six years.
"You always get an uptick in the participation rate in the upswing of a business cycle," Ms. Sawhill said, dismissing suggestions that tighter restrictions on welfare had forced enough recipients into the job market to have had a noticeable effect on the statistics.
The participation rate was 67.2 percent last month, up from 67 percent in December. The rate jumped about three points in both the 1970's and 1980's to average 66.5 percent for 1990.
In another economic report today, the Federal Reserve cited further slowing in the growth of consumer credit, a trend that supported Government and private expectations that the economy was cooling off and would expand in coming months considerably more slowly than the 4.7 percent pace that prevailed in the fourth quarter of 1996.
Credit outstanding grew at a 4.9 percent clip in December to cut the quarterly average to 5.7 percent, scarcely half the pace of the first three months of the year. Revolving credit, mainly credit cards, grew at a 6.2 percent pace compared with 10.6 percent in November.
Though highly reassuring to the markets, today's employment report was complicated by extreme weather conditions that made the figures "harder to read than usual," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber.
Heavy snows that cut employment in January 1996 distorted the seasonal adjustment process for last month, Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
But while this had the effect of exaggerating job growth in various industries, bad weather this January dampened the job market as did what she called "unusual movements" around the holiday season in several industries. The net effect on payrolls, she said, was "small."
Much of the 271,000 growth was in the category of help-supply, mostly temporary workers, where the increase was magnified by the weather-related factors, such as jobs shoveling snow. But health services added 43,000 jobs last month, nearly double the average monthly gain last year, and manufacturing added jobs, albeit a modest 18,000, for the fourth consecutive month.
Employment in the apparel industry, however, lost 8,000 jobs and has now lost 200,000, or one-fifth of its work force, over the last five years.
The length of the workweek fell sharply, the report also showed, but this as well as a skid in factory overtime was attributed to unusually harsh weather.
Regionally, however, the jobless rate climbed three-tenths of a point in the Northeast, to 5.8 percent, while the rate eased in the South, Midwest and West.
"Today's report contained something for everyone," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for the Chase Manhattan Regional Bank. But even strong growth, he added, "is not a problem as long as it's not accompanied by inflation pressure."

HEADLINE: Swiss Begin to Question Image of Heroism in War

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: SCHAFFHAUSEN, Switzerland, Feb. 3

 BODY:
This land has nurtured a wartime vision of itself as an Alpine redoubt whose young men girded to fight Hitler's armies, even as geography and neutrality left them encircled and obliged to deal with the hated Nazi enemy.
But in recent months the notion of wily heroism -- central to a generation's self-image and to the way history is viewed here -- has come under assault. For the first time, older Swiss are facing an agonizing question: did they buy their wartime survival with guile or something much worse, collaboration with Hitler? 
 Peering into this unfamiliar mirror of their wartime history, some Swiss have responded with anger at the American politicians and Jewish organizations who have in recent months forced Switzerland, its banks and its Government to reassess the past. Others feel the Swiss should no longer be captives of their wartime myths.
"It is not Jews who are our enemy," said Thomas Borer, a 42-year-old diplomat charged with defusing the crisis. "It is not Americans who are our enemy. It is the way we look at our own history that is our enemy."
And, as if the historical reappraisal were not enough, the questioning has come at a time when this land apart from both the European Union and the United Nations is laboring under six years of economic stagnation, replacing a sense of smug, postwar prosperity with that of an embattled malaise.
Suddenly, people like Kurt Bachtold, a 79-year-old Swiss Army veteran, find themselves confronting an outcry that their land not only traded in looted Nazi gold but also turned back Jewish refugees at their border and, in the postwar era, offered only a bureaucratic stonewall to family members seeking to locate money and items of wealth deposited in Switzerland by Holocaust victims.
Their response, in part, has been bewildered incomprehension.
"We did not realize that we would bring these accusations of guilt upon ourselves," said Hermann Wanner, an 83-year-old veteran and former high defense official who led a horse-drawn transport unit during the war.
But what is missing from the current debate, both men said in separate conversations, is an understanding of precisely where Switzerland stood and how its people responded to the war around them.
"In those days," Mr. Bachtold, a retired journalist and politician, said, "there was no point for the Swiss in trying to play the lion. We had to play the fox."
Back in 1940, Mr. Bachtold said, German troops were in the Black Forest across the border, Hitler's armies were on the move, and Switzerland was critically dependent on trade with Germany for its economic survival. Like other young men, he said, he was called to military service, guarding a ridge just across the Rhine from the home he lives in today.
With his light machine gun at the ready and insufficient ammunition in his foxhole, he said, he knew Germany would have no real problem overrunning the approaches to the Alps, the jagged, icy mountains that then, as now, provided the last refuge of Swiss strategic thinking.
"Every day we said, 'The Germans are coming,' " he recalled during an afternoon conversation. "We knew we might die. But we said to each other, 'When we go, we'll take five of them to the grave with each of us.' "
Even then, he acknowledged, there were signs of accommodation.
A nearby Swiss factory, Mr. Bachtold said, was producing steel for Germany to build those same tanks and artillery pieces kept across the border. In the center of this Swiss town, German railroad officials openly operated a part of the network of tracks that formed Nazi Germany's vital link straight across Switzerland to Italy, its Axis ally.
But Mr. Bachtold insists that a German invasion would have met stiff resistance. "The idea was to make the entrance fee to Switzerland so high that the Germans would not wish to pay it."
The historical record is complex and, many Swiss say, it has been distorted in the barrage against them. Certainly, historians argue, Switzerland did suggest to Nazi Germany in 1938 that the letter J, meaning Jude, or Jew, be stamped in German Jewish passports to facilitate recognition by the Swiss border police.
But many Swiss recall that Switzerland also offered sanctuary, under very ambiguous terms, to more than 20,000 Jews among the 200,000 wartime refugees it sheltered. Moreover, the Swiss role as a neutral power and financial center, many Swiss argue, was as valuable to the United States and its allies as to Nazi Germany.
Only last December, Jean-Pierre Roth, the head of the Swiss National Bank, pointedly remarked that the Swiss had bought almost as much gold from the United States as it had from Nazi Germany. American spies, the Swiss argue, operated freely from here. And in December 1944, when the war was almost won, Winston Churchill called the Swiss "the only decent neutrals in the world."
For many younger Swiss, including left-wing historians who have been challenging the nation's mythology for the last decade without much resonance, the reality is simply this: the reason Hitler's army did not invade was simply that Switzerland was worth far more as a financial clearinghouse and source of hard currency than as an occupied land.
"If the Germans had overrun Switzerland, they would have gained a few square miles of territory, but they would have lost the Swiss franc," said Gian Trepp, an author of several books about Switzerland's banks.
By this account, the tales of people like Mr. Bachtold in his foxhole on the frontier are part of a heroic mythology that was woven into Switzerland's postwar self-image to disguise the fact that its financiers and officials cooperated all too willingly with the Third Reich.
"The Swiss convinced themselves that they were without guilt in the Second World War, and that's not the case," said Jurg Schoch, a reporter covering the affair for Tages Anzeiger, the Zurich daily newspaper. "To accept the other reality is very difficult for the older generation."
That seemed clear enough as Mr. Wanner spread maps and diagrams showing just how strategically vulnerable Schaffhausen was and how advanced Nazi invasion plans were in 1940.
"It was not a myth. The decision to fight had been made," he said. The Swiss, he said, held two trump cards for deterring the German Army: the rail tunnel through the Alps that carried war materials between Germany and Italy, and Switzerland's military plan to concentrate its forces in the Alps.
"It would have been a mountain war, and Hitler was frightened of that," he said. "And on top of that the Germans knew that the transit tunnels would be blown up if they invaded."
This heroic image of Switzerland's wartime resolve underlies Swiss officials' recent reluctance to cast the crisis over Nazi gold in moral terms. It explains, in part, why the Swiss have preferred to lay the blame on other factors, like the purported willful misreading of historical realities in the United States or a conspiracy by Jewish organizations, politicians and the news media.
One diplomat, who lost his job for saying so, called it a war. Another diplomatic report helped persuade the outgoing President, Jean-Pascal Delamuraz, to depict Switzerland public as a target of "blackmail and extortion."
Last month, after long delay, the Government in Bern agreed to take the lead in establishing a Holocaust memorial fund, along with the Swiss National Bank, commercial banks and insurance companies -- all institutions that did business with Nazi Germany. Still, the Government and the National Bank shied away from making firm financial commitments.
[On Wednesday, the country's three largest banks, impatient with what they saw as politicians' ineptitude and keen to salvage business interests facing the threat of a boycott, said they had put up $71 million as the basis for the fund.]
For some older Swiss, the slow process of disclosure has gradually produced finer shadings of memory.
From the beginning, Mr. Bachtold said, people like him knew the Swiss position was conditioned by his country's need to trade with Nazi Germany, trading Swiss steel and war material for German coal.
But only later did he and his men learn that the German units across the border had been deployed as no more than a feint to distract from the planned invasion of Belgium and France.
In the late 1950's, the story of Switzerland's decision in 1942 to turn back at least 30,000 Jewish refugees began to emerge and convinced him that "this was the worst chapter in Swiss history."
But for decades after, the question of dormant accounts and trade in gold with Nazi Germany was simply not an issue. "The matter was closed for us," he said.
These days, he said, he has arrived at a different conclusion. "A lot of what is said now is just. In this dark chapter with the banks, the Government reacted slowly, and we found that the Swiss banks did not behave very nicely."
As for the war years, he said, it seems now that Hitler was held at bay by a variety of factors, both economic and strategic, not just the army on the border.
