HEADLINE: As Rebels Gain in Zaire, Army Morale Is Declining

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 7

 BODY:
For months after rebels invaded the border towns of eastern Zaire in October, their insurrection was confined to a long but narrow strip of land 1,000 miles from the capital. This country's vastness seemed to offer the Government here a kind of protection that its woeful army could not.
But in recent weeks, Zaire's rebels have enjoyed a stunning string of successes that have turned the tables on the Government and drastically changed the nature of the war. 
 Operating with what Western diplomats describe as strong support from Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi, the rebels have advanced on widely separated fronts, stretching the Government's fragile defenses to the breaking point just as a counteroffensive led by foreign mercenaries struggles to get under way.
Suddenly, instead of merely controlling a slender buffer zone between Zaire and its eastern neighbors, diplomats, relief workers and Zairian officials say the rebels have a strong foothold in 4 of the country's 11 provinces.
They now appear poised to threaten the country's second- and third-largest cities in what could mark an outright bid to topple the longtime dictator, President Mobutu Sese Seko, and seize power.
The rebel advance raises the serious prospect of the violent disintegration of Zaire, which by virtue of its size, population and mineral wealth is one of Africa's most important countries.
Although Zaire, which is one-third the size of the United States, has never been stable, the catastrophic breakup of the country would be deeply troubling to many of the country's nine neighbors.
Western alarm at this threat has been somewhat tempered by the fact that the rebel moves have strengthened the stability of Rwanda, Burundi and Uganda -- all of which have suffered in the past from insurrections based in Zaire and so have an interest in aiding the rebel forces.
In two simultaneous advances west and south, the rebels are moving toward the major cities of Kisangani and Lubumbashi. They are led by a longtime foe of Mr. Mobutu's, Laurent Desire Kabila, with considerable help from Zaire's eastern neighbors. Asked how Mr. Kabila's forces have managed to achieve so much in so little time, one Western diplomat here responded tersely: "Rwanda and Uganda."
"That's where they are getting their weapons, their transportation, their communications, their new uniforms, even some of their men," the diplomat added.
But others say that as important as the aid from outside the country has been for the rebels, the recent successes in pushing west and in swelling their ranks suggest that Mr. Kabila's forces are taking root.
While Mr. Kabila proudly reviewed a parade of 5,000 new recruits who marched through the streets of Goma, near the border with Rwanda, on Thursday, the Government's recruitment efforts have been met with little enthusiasm. Army enlistment offices in Kinshasa have remained empty in the week since a call was made for young men 15 to 18 years old to join the war effort.
Zaire's soldiers are paid as little as $1 a month, and like many citizens who are disaffected with a Government that has driven this country into poverty, they seem to see no reason to fight.
By almost all accounts, the rebels' advances have been aided by the sympathetic reception that they have often received from local populations, who are happy to see the army, which has engaged in widespread looting, chased away.
Foreign witnesses who saw the rebels arrive in the eastern town of Shabunda the other day say they were greeted with courtesy, if not fanfare, by the residents as they marched in orderly formation through the area.
The recent combat has only reinforced the impression that the Government of the gravely ill Mr. Mobutu lacks the kind of international support that it will need to prevail.
Today, Mr. Mobutu returned to his native village after a stay in France for cancer treatment and denied that he had used a stopover in Morocco to plead for military support from that country. Zairian journalists immediately speculated that it was less embarrassing to deny having asked for help than to admit that a request for support had been turned down.
In recent days, other African countries from Togo to Egypt that have aided Mr. Mobutu during past crises have publicly said they would not get involved in the current fighting, apparently because they are unwilling to risk their troops for a weak and increasingly unpopular leader.
Even people close to Mr. Mobutu have acknowledged discouragement in the ranks of the 300 or so foreign mercenaries recently flown into Kisangani. The mercenaries have complained that they lack the means to fight a surprisingly well-organized enemy in unfamiliar jungle terrain.
"The Belgian officers say that the Serbian soldiers just want to give up on this," one person close to the presidential entourage said. "Their men are getting sick in this climate, they don't speak the right language and they have never been in a war like this."
Several mercenaries have already been killed, while others have complained that they have been paid with counterfeit currency, diplomats say.
In their latest advances, the rebels have taken towns like Walikale, Shabunda and Punia, marking the beginning of a strong westward push from the eastern border region toward Kisangani -- known in colonial times as Stanleyville -- which is Zaire's second-largest city and the strategic capital of the north.
Simultaneously, the rebel troops have thrust far to the south of their de facto capital in Goma, taking the port city of Kalemie on Lake Tanganyika.
The seizure of Kalemie, at the northern terminus of an extensive network of railways, deprives the Government of a means of resupply and reinforcement for any attempt to retake the east.
Now, from Kalemie, just within the borders of the historically restive southern province of Shaba, diplomats say the rebels could march on Kamina, or alternatively on the country's third-largest city, Lubumbashi, the provincial capital.
The logistical nightmare that the Government faces, with its limited airlift capacity and shortage of men and hardware, is perhaps best illustrated by its attempts to protect Kisangani, the main operational base for the Zairian defense effort.
Flying dozens of Serbian mercenaries to the small town of Muhulu last week to hold a bridge spanning the Oso River, the Zairian military managed to stop the advance of the rebels toward Kisangani from the recently captured city of Walikale.
Undaunted, the rebels swept southwest to take the city of Punia and are now threatening the city of Lubutu, well behind the mercenary lines.
The Government announced today that it had scored several successes against the rebels in the last 24 hours, notably in the towns of Walikale and Watsa, which Defense Ministry officials say were recaptured.
But independent observers could only confirm that these towns had just been subjected to intense aerial bombing.
Unrest near Lubutu, where Government forces have reportedly been distributing weapons among members of Rwanda's defeated former army, forced international relief agencies to pull out of that town today. The move has sown panic among many of the 140,000 Rwandan and Burundian refugees of the Hutu ethnic group who have gathered in the area in recent months and vastly complicated relief efforts.
Commenting on a similar rebel movement toward Kisangani from the north, one international relief official said: "This looks like a replay of just the same kind of pincer movement they used to such great effect near Goma at the start of the war. Given the way they have been moving, you have to wonder how long it will be before Kisangani falls too."
Tension is already mounting sharply in Kisangani, according to reports reaching the capital from that city. Anti-army sentiment is said to be strong after recent bouts of looting by soldiers, and the shooting of a pregnant woman by a soldier on Thursday sparked a large protest march through the city today.
From the very start of the country's independent history in 1960, Zaire has almost continually experienced powerful centrifugal tensions, including repeated attempts at secession. Time after time, Mr. Mobutu, who has governed since 1965, was able to call on Western friends to save him.
Mr. Mobutu could do this because Zaire under his rule had repeatedly proven an essential ally in the cold-war struggle against Communism on the African continent.
The last major rebellions were in 1977 and 1978, in the copper-rich province of Shaba -- known earlier as Katanga -- which inflicted embarrassing defeats on the Zairian Army. The first revolt was eventually put down by Moroccan troops airlifted with American assistance. The second was defeated by the French Foreign Legion.
Today, Zaire lacks the cold-war strategic importance that it once enjoyed. And diplomats say its army, never a reliable fighting force, has been on a steady decline for as long as 15 years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Some 5,000 new recruits to the Zairian rebel cause marched in the city of Goma on Thursday. The rebels are advancing against a demoralized army. (Reuters)(pg. 6)
 
Chart: "AT A GLANCE: A Troubled Nation"
 
HISTORY
Called Congo until 1971, Zaire was under Belgian control from 1885 to June 1960. A period of instability followed independence until November 1965, when Mobutu Sese Seko seized power in a bloodless coup. He has ruled as an autocrat ever since.
 
ECONOMY
While meaningful economic figures are difficult to come by, Zaire's hyperinflation, chronic large Government deficits, and plunging mineral production have made the country one of the world's poorest. Most formal transactions are conducted in hard currency as indigenous bank notes have lost almost all value, and a barter economy now flourishes in all but the largest cities. The estimated per capita gross national product in 1994 was $440.
 
PEOPLE
Over 44 million (1995 estimate) people are divided among over 200 African ethnic groups with the largest tribes being the Kongo, Mongo, Luba, and the Mangbetu-Azande. The languages include French, Lingala, Swahili, Kingwana, Kikongo and Tshhiluba. The literacy rate (age 15 and over) is 72 percent and the life expectance at birth is 47.5 years (1995 estimate).
 
GEOGRAPHY
The third-largest country in Africa, Zaire is about one-quarter the size of the United States. With vast forests and plenty of rainfall, Zaire has huge agricultural, logging and hydroelectric potential. (Source: The World Factbook)(pg. 6)
 
Map of Zaire: The rebel forces, pushing westward from the eastern border region toward Kisangani, Zaire's second-largest city and the strategic capital of the north, have taken Walikale, Shabunda and Punia and other towns. At the same time the rebels, have thrust far to the south of their de-facto capital in Goma, taking the port city of Kalemie on Lake Tanganyika. (pg. 1)

HEADLINE: Secretary of State Sells Foreign Policy at Home

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Madeleine K. Albright took her first trip as Secretary of State today, traveling not to some foreign capital, not even to some state capital, but rather to Texas, determined, she said, to take America's foreign policy straight to the people.
"Usually passport offices don't get this kind of attention," one woman declared as Ms. Albright waded through the Leland Federal Building in downtown Houston, becoming the first Secretary of State in recent memory to attend to one of the more pedestrian offices of the Department of State. 
 And as if she needed to do any more to distinguish herself from her predecessors, including the courtly, highly reserved Warren Christopher, Ms. Albright went on to visit a high school and delivered on her promise to speak plainly about matters of international affairs.
"Not only can foreign policy be cool," the Secretary of State told a group of earnest high school students, "but it can be awesome."
For Ms. Albright, only two weeks into the job, it was a trip short of substance but larded with symbols, almost all of them self-conscious. "It's a perfect schedule," one aide said proudly, describing her two-day visit here. "It's got everything."
In addition to the stop at the passport office (a symbol of her commitment to the State Department's workers), she met with Mexico's Foreign Minister, Jose Angel Gurria (a symbol, she declared, of the importance of its relations with the United States).
She also delivered a speech at Rice University at the institute named after one of her predecessors, James A. Baker 3d (a symbol of her desire for a bipartisan foreign policy). And as if to make sure the last point sticks, she plans to have breakfast on Saturday with former President Bush.
"As Secretary, I will do my best to talk about foreign policy not in abstract terms, but in human terms and in bipartisan terms," she told the students, professors and others at Rice. "I consider this vital because in our democracy, we cannot pursue policies abroad that are not understood and supported here at home."
In her speech at Rice, where she was introduced by Mr. Baker, Ms. Albright returned to the theme of bipartisanship, echoing President Clinton's calls for an end to partisanship on everything from the budget to foreign affairs.
She also called on Congress to approve a convention that would ban chemical weapons, which has faced opposition from some Republicans even though it was negotiated and signed under President Bush, and to approve Mr. Clinton's plan to repay the United States' back dues to the United Nations.
A day after Mr. Clinton presented a budget that included a modest increase in spending on foreign aid, she also argued that after four years of a declining foreign-affairs budget, the United States was "steadily and unilaterally disarming ourselves."
Ms. Albright's maiden voyage -- "It's a little hard to be a maiden at this age," the 59-year-old Secretary told reporters on the flight here -- precedes by a week her first trip abroad. On that trip she will circle the globe, making stops in Rome, Paris, London, Brussels, Bonn, Moscow, Tokyo, Seoul and Beijing.
But Ms. Albright herself wanted to make her first trip a domestic one, hoping to convince people of the importance of a vigilant, aggressive foreign policy to their lives. And she chose Houston -- after aides originally considered Chicago -- evidently to wrap herself in as many symbols as possible.
During her confirmation hearing before the Senate, Ms. Albright promised to spend more time articulating and defending foreign policy. While it remains to be seen whether she will have any more success than her predecessors in selling the importance of foreign policy to the public, her reception here was certainly warm enough.
As she gladhanded her way through the waiting crowd at the passport office, one man even asked her to sign a $5 bill. She declined, signing an envelope instead.
At Lamar Senior High School, Ms. Albright made her case against an isolationist foreign policy to 50 or so students studying international affairs. Ms. Albright, a professor for many years at Georgetown University, deftly fielded questions on topics from illegal immigration to human rights in China. Sitting in front of a world map, she offered as inspiration that she had failed geography as a girl. "I've tried very hard to make up for that," she said.
After the speech at Rice, Ms. Albright also made the case for increased spending on foreign affairs in a private meeting with executives from major corporations. For their part, one official said, the executives made a case against unilateral American sanctions to punish other nations for violations of human rights.
Among the companies represented was Unocal, which last month announced a gas exploration and pipeline project in Myanmar even as the United States considers new sanctions against the Burmese Government there.
Asked by one of the students at Lamar, Oneil Crosby, about the line in foreign policy between economic and humanitarian principles, Ms. Albright replied: "What we have to be careful about in foreign policy is not to make false choices. The truth is you can focus on both issues."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Madeleine K. Albright at a meeting yesterday with high school students in Houston. (Associated Press)

INTERNATIONAL 3-6
 
Confusion Rules in Ecuador As Three Claim Presidency
Three people claimed to be the President of Ecuador after the incumbent, Abdala Bucaram, was voted out of office by Congress. They were Mr. Bucaram, who rejected the decision and hunkered down in the presidential palace; the president of Congress, who won a congressional vote naming him interim president, and the Vice President, who said she was Mr. Bucaram's legal successor until a vote could be called. The army's intentions were not clear. 1
 
Rebels Gain Ground in Zaire
Rebels in eastern Zaire, pushing westward on several fronts from their de facto capital in Goma, appeared to be on the verge of taking the country's second- and third-largest cities. 1
 
A Populist Trip for Albright
Madeleine K. Albright made her first trip as Secretary of State -- to Houston, seeking to fulfill her promise to take America's foreign policy to the people. She took it to a passport office, a high school and a university. She also met with Mexico's Foreign Minister. 6
 
U.S.-Russia Summit Dates Set
President Clinton agreed to shift his summit meeting with the ailing Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, from Washington to Helsinki, Finland. The meetings are to take place on March 20 and 21. Russia's Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, reiterated Moscow's opposition to NATO enlargement during a visit to Washington but said further discussions could mollify Russian wariness about it. 6
 
Strike Extended in France
A strike by public transportation drivers stretched into a second day in many French cities, and unions in some cities voted to extend their strikes until Monday. The union members want the retirement age cut to 55 and a shorter working week with no pay cut. They say the measures would help reduce record unemployment. (Reuters)
 
Military Crackdown in Nigeria
Violence broke out in Kano, a northern Nigerian city, when about 400 Shiite Muslims converged on a prayer ground, waving swords and other weapons and chanting slogans protesting against the military Government. The police opened fire after marchers attacked them with stones and other weapons. Witnesses said five people had been killed; the police reported one death and arrested at least two Shiite leaders. (AP)
 
Rebels Attack Colombian Town
Hundreds of leftist guerrillas attacked a town in eastern Colombia, destroying the police headquarters and killing eight people, including three civilians. The police believed the National Liberation Army, which has a strong presence in the region, to be responsible for the attack in Cubara, 215 miles northeast of Bogota. They said that three rebels had been killed and that at least two officers were missing. (AP)
 
NATIONAL 7-10
 
Illegal Immigration to U.S. Continues, at Lower Level
In the last four years, the number of immigrants living in the United States illegally increased by more than a million to a total of 5 million, the Government said. It said the number of people overstaying their visas had declined slightly. 9
 
Jury Urged to Punish Simpson
Lawyers for the families of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman urged jurors in the O. J. Simpson wrongful death suit to use their decision on punitive damages to punish him. But his lawyers countered that their client had been punished enough by the jury's award of $8.5 million in compensatory damages. 9
 
Lake Settles Stock Case
President Clinton's nominee to be Director of Central Intelligence, Anthony Lake, agreed to pay $5,000 to settle a Justice Department inquiry into stock dealings while he was the national security adviser. 10
 
Tense Episode in Philadelphia
Armed Philadelphia police officers stood outside a check-cashing agency for more than three hours and kept 121 people inside, fearing they had been taken hostage by robbers. But a gunman had already fled and the plot had already started to unravel. 7
 
Deal on Partners' Benefits
San Francisco reached tentative agreements with United Airlines and the city's Roman Catholic archbishop. The deals were steps toward fulfilling the city's quest to require all of its contractors to offer health and other benefits to the unmarried partners of their employees. 8
 
Drug Use Cited in Du Pont Case
Several wrestlers testified that John du Pont had been seen snorting cocaine at least once and often emerged from his library with white powder under his runny nose. Prosecutors have asserted that Mr. du Pont's delusions in the years leading up to his fatal shooting of the wrestler David Schultz were caused by drugs, not mental illness. (AP)

Police Judge Recommends Dismissal of an Officer
Officer Francis X. Livoti used an illegal, and ultimately lethal, choke hold while arresting a man on a Bronx street corner in 1994, a police administrative judge ruled. The judge said Officer Livoti should be dismissed and denied his pension benefits. 1
 
Air Force Suspends Flights
The Air Force suspended all operations in the areas off the East Coast that are reserved for military use so its pilots could review the rules on keeping away from civilian planes. 1
 
New Haven Police Chief Quits
The New Haven Police Chief, Nicholas Pastore, resigned after the revelation that he had fathered a child with a convicted prostitute. Chief Pastore had built a national reputation for transforming an iron-fisted Police Department into a friendly force. 23
 
Pataki's Speeches Under Fire
A New York-based magazine company paid Governor Pataki $30,000 to deliver two speeches in Boca Raton, Fla., at a conference of the company's key advertisers, the cosmetics industry. A few months later, the Pataki administration made a regulatory decision favorable to cosmetics manufacturers. There is no evidence that the decision and the speaking fees were connected, but government watchdogs said the case underscored the need to bar public officials from giving paid speeches. 23

HEADLINE: Clinton's Focus on Schools Hits Home

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
In outlining his ambitious agenda for education this week, President Clinton tapped into a deep national yearning to improve the nation's schools, even if it might mean accepting the revolutionary notion of national standards and perhaps even national tests to compare students, schools and states.
But Mr. Clinton's plan to spend $51 billion on everything from recruiting reading tutors to repairing tumbledown school buildings runs counter to two other currents: the traditional belief that education is essentially a local rather than a national concern, and the budgetary strictures and anti-tax sentiments that will make it extraordinarily difficult to increase Federal spending. 
 So for all the surface appeal of Mr. Clinton's dramatic educational call to arms, how much will eventually go into effect, how much is sound policy and how much is affordable remain very much in question.
"He's a master communicator," said Representative Bill Goodling, the chairman of the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, "but as people sort all of this out, I think they'll have a different opinion of his plan than they do now.
"There's no question that education is the sexiest thing out there right now, and the President knows that. But I think people have to ask how much of this is new and how much is just more of the same."
The education plan, which was the centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's State of the Union address on Tuesday, was most revealing in reflecting how far the nation had come toward accepting the importance of national standards. It may have been most vulnerable in its call for increased college financial aid and its notion of volunteerism as a cornerstone of literacy.
But experts say that if one of Mr. Clinton's goals was putting education at the top of the national agenda and forcefully identifying himself with it, the speech was a major step in that direction.
After fighting off Republican efforts in the last Congress to cut Federal spending on education, he called for a record $51 billion for education in his budget proposal on Thursday.
The plan seeks to raise standards, improve the quality of the nation's teachers, improve reading, enhance early learning and offer more choices -- particularly largely autonomous charter schools -- in the context of public education.
The President also called for more character education, $5 billion to repair and rebuild crumbling school buildings, more financial aid to college students, improved adult education and a plan to connect all schools to the Internet by the year 2000.
The proposals drew their strongest support from mainstream educational groups, teachers unions and other professional educators.
"It was a home run," said Bella Rosenberg, assistant to the president of the American Federation of Teachers. "It was a coherent package of high standards for achievement and high standards of conduct."
By identifying himself so strongly with the critical importance of education and by melding diverse ideas, Mr. Clinton left most critics praising his commitment to educational innovation, though arguing over the specifcs of his plan.
"He said it was his number one priority," said Jeanne Allen, president of the Center for Education Reform, which advocates choice options like vouchers and charter schools. "I think there is a fundamental misconception about what makes schools good and what makes children learn, but I think it's really important that the President spoke about education."
Many experts say the most significant aspect of Mr. Clinton's program is its enthusiastic embrace of national standards and even national tests for some grades. That reflects the degree to which a national presence -- but not a Federal one -- in standards and assessments has become perhaps the most important wave of educational change.
"What Bill Clinton has done has gone way beyond where the country was even at the Education Summit at Palisades last year," said Marc Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy and co-director of New Standards, which has drawn up proposed voluntary standards for the nation's schools. "He's saying that not only do we need standards, we need national standards. That would have been almost unthinkable even a year ago."
The road to national standards will be long and bumpy. Some critics on the left think standardized tests are often biased and inaccurate, and many on the right chafe at a larger national role in education.
But for many analysts on both sides, Mr. Clinton's call for national standards -- and a test of the nation's fourth graders in reading and eighth graders in math -- had more potential than anything else in his proposal to improve education.
"I graded the different parts of the program, and the grades ranged from A to F, but the part I liked best was perhaps the most controversial one, which was the test," said Chester Finn, a prominent conservative critic of education and a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute.
Mr. Finn said that at the opposite extreme was the President's proposed program of tax credits for education. Many skeptics, on the left and the right, say financial incentives to make a 13th and 14th year of education as common as high school is now could lead to grade inflation and cause schools such as junior colleges to use the new Federal money for their own needs rather than pass the savings on to students. Such incentives would help those who go to school already, they say, not open the door wider for those who do not.
"The poor are going to be largely unaffected by this," said Arthur Levine, president of Teachers College at Columbia University. "It won't improve access one iota."
Republicans in Congress question the price tag of Mr. Clinton's proposal and the addition of new programs to the 760 they say exist now in 39 Federal agencies at a cost of $120 billion.
And many people are skeptical of parts of the plan with the most surface appeal, like the idea of recruiting one million tutors into a national Reading Corps. "He seems to have this screwy idea that because two and a half million teachers who are paid to do this stuff are not very good at it, that sending a million amateurs into the classroom is going to make a difference," Mr. Finn said.
Still, if the details of the plan will face withering scrutiny, many educators say Mr. Clinton artfully caught the public's mood on education and did a real service in focusing attention on it.
"He's picked an issue that's very clearly at the top of the public's mind, and he's played the specifics pretty much off the polling data that's available," said Paul Houston, executive director of the American Association of School Administrators. "He's going to have a tremendous amount of public support, at least initially."

HEADLINE: RUBIN HINTS AT END TO LONG U.S. PUSH OF STRONG DOLLAR

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, taking a little air out of the rapidly rising dollar, suggested today that the Administration had ended its two-year-long effort to drive up the dollar against the world's other major currencies.
Mr. Rubin has said repeatedly over that time that "a strong dollar is in the interest of the United States." Today, in a subtly worded change of policy, he said at a meeting with reporters that while a strong dollar was still in America's interest, "we have had a strong dollar for some time now," a phrase he used three more times. 
 The midday comments by Mr. Rubin, the former investment banker who has emerged as perhaps the most influential member of President Clinton's Cabinet, set off a torrent of activity on financial markets. The dollar, which had been rising sharply on strong United States jobs data, tumbled more than 3 Japanese yen, before recovering somewhat.
A rise in the dollar tends to make American goods more expensive abroad and make foreign goods a better bargain in the United States. That puts added competitive pressure on American manufacturers to keep prices low, and it can cut into their profit margins overseas. But a stronger dollar also helps hold down inflation and makes it less expensive for Americans to travel abroad.
In recent months, the Administration has received many complaints from Detroit, where American auto makers and unions contend that a weak yen is allowing Japan, with its cheaper prices, to gain a larger share of the American market.
Mr. Rubin's phrasing was calculatedly vague and might have been intended to keep speculators in the currency market at bay. "We think about these statements pretty carefully before we make them," he said today, deflecting reporters who were probing for more.
He spoke only a day before senior finance officials from the United States and the six other largest industrial economies are scheduled to meet in Germany. "The G-7 countries have expressed concern about recent declines in their currencies," Mr. Rubin said. "We look forward to discussing these issues in Berlin."
But it is unclear whether Mr. Rubin and the finance ministers of the other countries will be able to stem the rapid run-up in the dollar's value, a trend that reflects such fundamental forces as a healthy American economy, continued stagnation in Japan and increased nervousness about a unified European currency.
Today's remarks, however, sent players in the trillion-dollar-a-day currency markets scrambling. They sought the answer to a two-sided question: Was Mr. Rubin signaling a sharp turn in American currency policy? Or, as seems more likely, was he simply trying to avoid a steep, and hard-to-reverse, further rise in the dollar's value, which could worsen the trade deficit?
Mr. Rubin clearly does not want to overreach and send the dollar into a tailspin as his predecessor, Lloyd Bentsen, did in early 1993 with the flip comment: "I'd like to see a stronger yen." Traders immediately interpreted that as a license to sell the dollar against the yen.
Unlike Mr. Bentsen, a lifelong politician with a populist tinge in favor of low interest rates and a competitive currency rate, Mr. Rubin made his mark on Wall Street, where he rose through the ranks of Goldman, Sachs as a highly successful trader. If his past actions are a reliable guide, his comments today were simply an attempt to sow uncertainty among global money managers, making them fearful of betting on a further rapid rise of the dollar.
Mr. Rubin made clear two years ago that he knows how to burn speculators. In early 1995 he tried to talk the dollar up, but the markets paid no attention, bidding up the yen until it nearly touched 79 to the dollar.
Then, after a long silence, Mr. Rubin intervened in the markets -- buying dollars at unexpected times, often in coordination with the central banks of other countries -- and the speculators who had bet on a weaker dollar lost fortunes.
Mr. Rubin has not discussed that move publicly, though once, when asked about it, he smiled and said, "I'm told that's what happened."
He does not seem likely to intervene anytime soon to cool the dollar off. For one, there is hardly the unanimity among the seven allies there was in 1985, when the Plaza Accord -- reached at a meeting at the Plaza Hotel in New York -- led to a coordinated effort to devalue the high-flying dollar. American officials are not particularly upset at the dollar's current level, either, as long as it does not go much higher.
"It's not the level they have in mind, it's the pace," said David Gilmore, partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, a consulting firm in Essex, Conn. "I think they are worried that the markets could overshoot, and they figure that if they make noises now, there is less risk of that."
Indeed, if finance ministers in Berlin issue a communique -- and there was some doubt today that they would -- it will probably refer only to the need for stability in the markets. The step beyond that would be calling for an end to the "orderly reversal" of currency values, the phrase that finance ministers started using in 1995.
If America's trading partners seem of mixed minds, that is because a strong dollar may help their export performance but tarnishes their image politically. Japan's international companies are more profitable when the yen is weaker. But the dollar has been so strong lately that investors are fleeing the sagging Tokyo stock market, and Japanese officials fret out loud that the weak yen is becoming a symbol of a weak Japan.
In Europe, the rise of the dollar has given a welcome lift to exports, too. But there are anxious rumblings, including the fear that the poor performance of several European economies could make it harder to introduce the Euro, the common currency planned for 1999.
In the United States, the loudest complaints have come from Detroit. "One would probably be naive not to look at the yen valuation as a huge opportunity for them," G. Richard Wagoner Jr., the president of General Motors' North American operations, said on Wednesday.
For the day, the dollar ended trading in New York at 122.60 yen, down from 123.54 yen on Thursday and at 1.6568 German marks, up slightly from 1.6504 marks.

HEADLINE: Capital's Police Union Chief Asks U.S. Takeover of Force

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Describing the streets of the nation's capital as a war zone where residents should fear for their safety, the head of the District of Columbia police union called on the Federal Government today to take over the Police Department and provide hundreds of millions of dollars to improve it.
Although neither step is likely any time soon, as the Government moves toward balancing its budget by 2002, Ron Robertson, president of the local chapter of the Fraternal Order of Police, cited a series of recent violent crimes in the city, and warned: "We're in a war here, but what's happening is, we don't have a battle plan. Nothing's getting done." 
 Later in the day, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. summoned reporters to Police Headquarters to denounce Mr. Robertson's appeal, saying there was no need "for any Government takeover of any part of this problem."
Mr. Barry said he had urged the Federal Government to provide the city new money for the police as a supplement to the Clinton Administration's proposal for municipal assistance that would include taking over the District's prison system and increasing the Federal share of Medicaid payments.
"I argued that our officers need raises and additional help for new equipment," Mr. Barry said, putting the cost at about $10 million, far less than the $700 million that Mr. Robertson said the department needed over the next five years.
Calls by the District's police officers for Federal intervention are nothing new. Since the city's economy began spiraling downward in the early 1990's, increasing the pressure on the police budget, officers have frequently looked to Capitol Hill for help.
But their pleas gained a new urgency after a uniformed officer was shot to death early Wednesday morning as he sat in his patrol car waiting for a traffic light to change. The police later arrested a 23-year-old man and charged him with killing the officer, Brian T. Gibson, by repeatedly firing a semiautomatic weapon at his head through the car window.
That incident followed several others of note so far this year. In one, a 12-year-old boy was kidnapped as he walked home from school and was shot to death by a group of teen-agers. Last Sunday a 78-year-old woman walking home from church in the middle of the afternoon was killed by a stray bullet. Although arrests have been made in the case involving the 12-year-old, there have been none in the other.
While the homicide rate is falling in many American cities, it is increasing in Washington, where the police have recorded 45 killings already this year, 2 more than for the same period last year, which ended with 393 killings. That was a 3 percent increase over the total for 1995.
Detective Renee Holden said fear among officers had grown so palpable that if she were to stop a car at night for a traffic violation, she would approach it only with her gun drawn.
"It's getting significantly worse out there," Detective Holden said. "When you walk out your door in the morning, you look at your kids and think, 'I may not be home tonight.' It makes you think about any situation you might get involved in."
Officers generally attribute the rising crime rate to what they describe as the city's lack of financial support for the Police Department. Once a force of 5,100 uniformed officers, the department now has about 3,600, and illness or administrative matters keep as many as 200 from working on any given day.
The control board that oversees the city's finances approved a Police Department budget of $236.3 million for the current fiscal year. Because of the city's efforts to reach a balanced budget, that sum is expected to increase only marginally, if at all, next year.
The Police Chief, Larry Soulsby, said in a radio interview today that the department was currently authorized to have 3,800 officers and that he was in the process of hiring recruits every month. But he contended that no number of additional officers could have prevented a gunman from approaching a patrol car and suddenly opening fire at the driver.
"As long as we have people in society willing to do that," he said, "it's going to be very difficult for the Police Department to deal with it."
Mr. Robertson, the union leader, disagreed. He argued that additional financing would, among other things, enable commanders to send out two officers in each patrol car at night, rather than one, a difference that he said might have saved Officer Gibson's life. He also said the police needed more cars, better radios and station-house roofs that do not leak.
"We have a third-rate Police Department operating in what has become a third-world city," Mr. Robertson said. "Safety is a problem, and it's a hazard for us. But more important, it's not safe here for citizens."
Mr. Robertson said the department needed a huge infusion of money, far beyond what Mr. Barry suggested, just to modernize equipment and bring pay to levels comparable with those of adjacent jurisdictions in Maryland and Virginia. He said the starting annual salary of District officers, $30,000 to $32,000, was about $2,000 less than elsewhere in the region.
But no matter how high the crime rate climbs, turning the Police Department over to the Federal Government appears to be an unlikely solution for now. When asked his position today, Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, said, "Drastic problems call for drastic action." But he stopped well short of advocating a Federal takeover, instead calling on President Clinton and municipal leaders to meet and "have a serious discussion about what we can do to help."
Mr. Robertson said that in the absence of a Federal takeover, he would support the creation of an oversight panel to run the department, much like the one recently appointed by the city's control board to run the dilapidated public school system.
Mr. Barry said no such panel was necessary.
"We have the power and the brainpower," the Mayor said, "to tackle these problems ourselves."

HEADLINE: 3 Ecuadoreans Laying Claims To Presidency

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: QUITO, Ecuador, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The morning after their President was ousted on the ground of mental incompetence, Ecuadoreans awoke to a more dizzying spectacle: three people claiming to be President.
Today the ousted President, Abdala Bucaram, remained hunkered down in the heavily fortified presidential palace, clinging to the office he won in August and deploring the congressional decision to depose him as unconstitutional. 
 In a vote that swiftly followed the decision on Mr. Bucaram, the legislators chose Fabian Alarcon, the conservative president of Congress, to serve as Interim President.
At the same time, Vice President Rosalia Arteaga, saying she was the legal successor, appealed for a plebiscite so voters, not Congress, could choose their President.
Tension grew today as all three declared their determination to protect the Constitution and democracy, while contradictory voices from the military left people uncertain about the army's intentions.
The unabashed jockeying for control of the country had one Western diplomat quoting a song from "Evita," the musical about the life of Eva Peron: "Dice are rolling, the knives are out, would-be presidents are all about."
By late afternoon, Mr, Bucaram was again addressing the nation, declaring that Congress had no medical examination or other grounds for labeling him mentally unstable, and arguing that if the Congress did not agree with his handling of the presidency, it should hold a political trial to determine his fitness.
But tonight he flew to Guayaquil, his home city, leaving behind a challenge to Mr. Alarcon to meet him there on Saturday for talks.
Mr. Bucaram, a populist candidate who won a record-breaking 20 of Ecuador's 21 provinces to become President last August, is showing this Andean nation the most precipitous political decline of any President in its unconventional history.
During his flamboyant campaign, Mr. Bucaram would croon with an Uruguayan rock band at rallies, and once elected, El Loco, as he called himself, recorded a rock song called "A Madman in Love." Last fall he met with Lorena Bobbitt, the Ecuadorean-American who had cut off her husband's penis, and hailed her as a woman who "knows how to defend her principles and values."
Soon after taking office, Mr. Bucaram, whose candidacy resounded with stinging attacks on the ruling classes, made an about-face. He adopted economic measures to reduce the protective role of the state by privatizing public companies, reducing subsidies and dismantling laws that made dismissing workers almost impossible.
The most immediate effects of his new policies -- painful increases in the cost of telephone service, cooking gas, gasoline and electricity -- were made worse by his administration's reputation for rampant corruption and nepotism.
In his numerous speeches this week, before and after the congressional vote, Mr. Bucaram responded to those charges, accepting the resignation of four of his most highly criticized Cabinet members, including his brother, Adolfo Bucaram.
He lowered the prices on gasoline, cooking fuel and electricity, which had skyrocketed during his administration. All complaints, he said, could be addressed. "The only thing that is not open for discussion is that there is a constitutional President of Ecuador, elected by popular vote." The measures did not help.
"If he was really serious about any of these steps, he would have done them before now," said Virgilio Hernandez, who led a 10-day occupation of the Metropolitan Cathedral here that effectively set off the waves of protest that swept the country. "It's just to buy time."
A 48-hour general strike led up to the special session of Congress on Thursday night. In some areas where the protests have been most overwhelming, the graffiti repeated the mocking word, "Ablablabla."
In Carondelet, the presidential palace, Mr. Bucaram reinforced a military cordon in the streets, and makeshift barricades of logs connected with barbed wire appeared by the palace entrances alongside piles of sandbags and new revolving doors that locked with each turn.
Outside, crowds that marched with congressional leaders to the presidential palace in the late afternoon chanted "Bucaram out!" Police officers threw tear gas, forcing the congressional leaders and other political figures to duck into a nearby church.
An 18-year-old student, Patricio Uyumbillo, was killed today in the streets around the palace, and as evening fell the area was covered with clouds of tear gas.
While a number of Ecuadoreans said on Wednesday that they believed the Congress should name the Vice President as the natural successor to Mr. Bucaram, Mrs. Arteaga appeared to have scuttled her chances by accusing Mr. Alarcon and other congressmen of plotting a coup d'etat, and raising the prospect of their arrest.
Mr. Hernandez, in an interview inside the cathedral shortly before his group of 60 protesters left the building, said Mrs. Arteaga had not taken steps to distance herself from the President until it was too late.
Indeed, Mr. Bucaram's presidential portrait still hangs in the Vice President's entrance to the presidential palace. In an interview, Mrs. Arteaga said she had simply overlooked the picture because events had happened so quickly.
She also said she believed that part of the reason she had not been named President automatically was that she was a woman. "I believe machismo is very strong in this society," she said, adding that in the past, male Vice Presidents had assumed the presidency as a matter of course.
With another general strike and protest scheduled for Saturday, the stand of the military -- an important factor in any political crisis in South America -- remained unclear. Early in the day, the Defense Minister, Victor Manuel Bayas, a retired general who appeared in military fatigues, read a statement declaring a state of emergency signed by Mr. Bucaram, suspending civil liberties and other constitutional protections.
But the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Paco Moncayo, said the military would not be the country's political arbiter and would limit its role to protecting the safety and security of the country's borders, officials, buildings and citizens -- a position hailed by Washington.
Though bemused by the one-upmanship among their leaders, people returned to work, buses ran and shops opened after the two-day strike.
"Everything's working fine without them," a diplomat said. "What does that tell you about the Government?"

HEADLINE: Vallone Describes Vision Of Floating Casino Fleet

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Peter F. Vallone, the generally cautious Speaker of the City Council, is hardly the riverboat gambler type, rarely even submitting a piece of legislation unless he knows he has the votes to pass it. Yesterday, however, he instantly became New York's most prominent supporter of floating casinos, urging the city to approve a virtual flotilla of the boats while keeping a substantial portion of the pot for the municipal treasury.
Though his plans are likely to be dampened by a far more skeptical Giuliani administration, Mr. Vallone sketched out a scenario under which gambling boats could leave from waterfronts in all five boroughs, carrying passengers past the three-mile limit of state jurisdiction to spin roulette wheels, play blackjack and pull slot machine levers. 
 "There's no reason why we shouldn't consider big boats going out beyond the three-mile line and having the city franchise it out," he said in an interview. "We have the natural resources, so why not use it? People are going to gamble anyway."
One such boat recently began operating from Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn, and another leaves Manhattan in the summer months. Mr. Vallone said he saw no reason to stop there, predicting that the city could make hundreds of millions in tax dollars from city gamblers who now travel to Atlantic City or American Indian casinos. He even raised the possibility of the city's operating the boats, though he did not elaborate.
Inspired by the Sheepshead Bay enterprise, a group of business leaders in the Rockaways section of Queens is already trying to lure a casino-boat operation there, hoping to inject some economic life into the depressed area.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been circumspect about the growth of ocean gambling in the city, expressing anger in December when the operators of the Sheepshead Bay boat began offering gambling cruises with no warning. After the operators agreed to pay city taxes and submit employees to background checks, the administration allowed the cruises to continue, but submitted legislation to set up a commission to regulate future ventures.
Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, said yesterday that the commission would have to review each application for a boat carefully to determine the impact on surrounding areas, the background of the operators, and the overall effect on the city.
Asked if the administration shares Mr. Vallone's enthusiasm for a fleet of gambling boats, Mr. Mastro declined to comment. But he said the commission would be empowered to limit the overall number of boats. He also expressed skepticism about the money-making potential of the boats, noting that the state of New Jersey collects only $300 million a year from all the casinos in Atlantic City.
"While we are exploring all of these options, we believe that it is unrealistic to expect that kind of tax revenue from any of these gambling boats," he said. "We have consistently said that the city should proceed with caution and prudence in this area."
Casino gambling has been banned in New York City since the 1840's, but no regulations apply once boats are three miles from shore. The Sheepshead Bay yacht, known as the Liberty I, takes about 30 minutes to reach the limit, and has proven popular with gamblers. But its neighbors are less pleased, citing concerns about traffic and crowding.
Mr. Vallone said the Council would move quickly on the bill submitted by the Mayor, and said he supported the same kind of strict regulation that Mr. Giuliani favors. With the failure of a bill to allow casinos in some areas of the state, he said, he expects that other jurisdictions will authorize offshore gambling as an alternative. New York City, he said, must move quickly to beat the rush.
"I think it's a real money-making venture," he said, "and we have to get on board before the ship sails."
The Rockaways plan, initiated by the Chamber of Commerce last week, is still just an optimistic idea at this point, but has won the backing of the development committee of the local Community Board. "We think it will be a shot in the arm for the Rockaways," said Bill Hanson, co-chairman of the committee.
While some Rockaways residents interviewed yesterday expressed reservations about the proposal, many were enthusiastic. Kerriann Daly, who owns Connolly's Bar in Rockaway Beach, said she had been on the Sheepshead Bay boat and would love to see a similar venture in her neighborhood. "Anything that will bring people to Rockaway Beach is a good thing," she said, adding, "I wish we had done it first."

HEADLINE: THE CAPITALIST;
Royal Scam

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis 

 BODY:
A FEW WEEKS AGO THE FORMER Duchess of York, Sarah Ferguson, became the official spokeswoman for Weight Watchers, a subsidiary of the H. J. Heinz Company, the ketchup maker. She will be paid $1 million -- with a bonus if she keeps the fat off -- for appearing several times during the coming year on behalf of Weight Watchers. The world has become so numbed to celebrity endorsements that the arrangement attracted only passing notice: If Bob Dole can hawk Visa cards, why can't Sarah Ferguson peddle diets? But the Duchess's deal is new and a bit different, a footnote to the final chapter of the epochal struggle between aristocratic values and market values.
Today only two classes of citizens in developed countries retain any trace of the old-fashioned snobbish hostility to the market. The first is the Artist. The romantic notion most clearly put by the poet William Blake that "where any view of Money exists Art cannot be carried on" is still in the air in lower Manhattan, though less intoxicating every day to people who actually have to sell what they write, paint, sculpt and compose. You're most likely to hear the sentiment expressed by the lounge lizards and cling-ons of the art world, who want to sound as if they understand art. 
 The other class of antimarket snob is the European Aristocrat. And the European Aristocrats most prone to the snobbery, at least in modern times, have been the English. England is the last place on earth, for instance, where the American bond trader who wants to talk about money is made to feel slightly second-rate; and the higher up in English society he climbs the more second-rate he is made to feel for wearing his money on his sleeve. The trick in England has long been to have money without being seen to make it. Obviously, this aristocratic pose is a shrewd and ugly strategy to demoralize energetic newcomers and to preserve one's own unearned position.
At its most extreme, which it no longer is, the conceit was both obnoxious and counterproductive, one of the reasons Britain became an economic failure. (When Margaret Thatcher set out to kick-start the British economy she first raised the prestige of enterprise by doling out aristocratic honorifics to leading businessmen: Lord Hanson of Hanson Trust, Lord Weinstock of British General Electric.) But buried beneath the pose is at least a shred of genuine moral concern about the small self-abasements and petty deceptions often required to succeed in the marketplace.
 ENTER THE WEIGHT-WATCHING Duchess. In the past, it is true, the royal family has granted British companies the right to use the royal seal on their products. But no member of the royal family, or former member of the royal family, has ever hawked products for hard cash. The Duchess is the first. (And the second. In addition to Weight Watchers, she has signed up to promote Ocean Spray cranberry juice.)
In taking the million dollars from Weight Watchers, the Duchess is selling something that doesn't belong to her: the prestige of the British royal family. (Just as Dole is selling the prestige of the U.S. Senate in taking his money from Visa.) She had nothing to do with building that prestige, though she has had a little to do with destroying it.
About this the buyers could care less, however. According to someone close to the Duchess's affairs, the market response to her deal has been to inundate her with offers to do more of the same. "We've never seen this kind of response before," says this person. "Everyone wants to use her."
No one can say whether the Duchess feels she has abased herself. But her deal with Heinz is perfectly consistent with current market standards of honesty. She hadn't ever tried the current Weight Watchers program until a couple of weeks before the deal was inked. By the time Weight Watchers got to her she had already, on her own, shed the fat that inspired British tabloids to dub her the Duchess of Pork. Weight Watchers cannot honestly imply that it helped a Duchess to lose weight, though of course the company will. Even to claim that its diet keeps a Duchess trim would be not quite true, precisely because the Duchess is taking money to stay trim.
There is only one lesson to be gleaned from the sight of the svelte Duchess stumping for customers: if you are lucky enough to sign a million-dollar deal laced with financial incentives to avoid cream cakes, you will avoid cream cakes. (Or you'll never see another penny.)
There was a time when antimarket snobbery was widely shared by the people at the top of society, to the point where even big businessmen would have been nervous about taking a Duchess to market. But now something like the reverse seems to be true: the Duchess is nervous about not having the businessmen around.
The Queen of England herself recently had to fight public opinion to get her new yacht built with taxpayers' money. As reported in The New York Times on Jan. 23, "the Queen had been concerned that a yacht not paid for by the Government would end up with commercial logos on its funnels, 'out of keeping with the ambiance of the royal yacht.' " The Queen's argument for preserving her ambiance, however, was not that a Queen deserves a yacht simply because she is a Queen. It was that she had cut $3 billion in trade deals on her old yacht. When the Queen of England resorts to the market defense, you know that the jig is up.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
CHANGING ENEMIES: The Defeat and Regeneration of Germany, by Noel Annan. (Norton, $27.50.) Lord Annan's gift for anecdote, portraiture and aphorism is well displayed in this memoir of his service in British intelligence in World War II and in a conquered Germany.
 
THE CREATION OF DR. B: A Biography of Bruno Bettelheim, by Richard Pollak. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) Mr. Pollak's rendition of Bettelheim's life is startling: he was a liar, a fraud, an anti-Semite and a rat.
 
DEWEY DEFEATS TRUMAN, by Thomas Mallon. (Pantheon, $24.) Amorous configurations and public events are tightly linked in this novel, persuasively located in Dewey's Michigan hometown as the election of 1948 draws near.
 
LE DIVORCE, by Diane Johnson. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $23.95.) A wise, humane comic novel in which a freewheeling Californienne collides with French social and cultural values.
 
DO THE WINDOWS OPEN? by Julie Hecht. (Random House, $21.) A first collection of short stories by a brilliant comic writer whose single narrator links all the stories, sharing her daily harvest of terror, pessimism and misadventure.
 
EVERYTHING FOR SALE: The Virtues and Limits of Markets, by Robert Kuttner. (20th Century Fund/Knopf, $27.50.) A contrarian argument by a well-armed economics journalist who longs to demolish the view that government can do nothing right and markets nothing wrong.
 
FATHER, SOLDIER, SON: Memoir of a Platoon Leader in Vietnam, by Nathaniel Tripp. (Steerforth, $26.) A close-up examination of terrible things and of the author's efforts to work out his manhood in love and family.
 
GUIDED TOURS OF HELL: Novellas, by Francine Prose. (Metropolitan/Holt, $23.) Two irresistible tales about Americans abroad in pressurized environments that both speed and aggravate the purgation of their inner problems.
 
HINTS OF HIS MORTALITY, by David Borofka. (University of Iowa, $22.95.) An impressive short-story collection, chiefly inhabited by men who have somehow failed to make the grade.
 
PATCHES OF FIRE: A Story of War and Redemption, by Albert French. (Anchor/ Doubleday, $22.95.) An unflinching meditation on his own service in Vietnam and failure in business by a black novelist whose grim past, he believes, has driven his creative present.
 
RACE AND HUMAN EVOLUTION, by Milford Wolpoff and Rachel Caspari. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A husband-and-wife team of anthropologists argues for the (currently) minority thesis that modern humans evolved from prehuman stocks in more places than one.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 44; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1416 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Lost in Space on Philadelphia's Independence Mall

BYLINE: By Thomas Hine; Thomas Hine is the author of two books about design and popular culture, "Populuxe" and "The Total Package."

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
THIS CITY'S HISTORIC SHRINES are targets for drive-by patriotism -- parking and getting a peek at the Liberty Bell, and a tour of Independence Hall too if you're ambitious. Then, before the meter runs out, you're on your way to Amish country or Atlantic City.
For Independence National Historical Park, this behavior results in expensive facilities that are underused. For the city, it means hit-and-run tourists who don't stay long enough to spend any money. Both park and city are puzzling over how to present the story of the nation's creation to a jaded and impatient public, and it's not easy. 
 A few years ago, when Disney proposed a patriotic theme park near the Civil War battlefield of Manassas in Virginia, the issues seemed clear enough. An ersatz Hollywood version of the American past was threatening a real piece of it.
But suppose you have the real thing: Independence Hall, the Liberty Bell and hundreds of public buildings and houses that date from Revolutionary days. How do you present all this authenticity to a public used to having its tourist destinations packaged as entertainment, with theme-park-level maintenance and security? Can the merely real compete with -- or even learn from -- the memorably mock?
Obviously, neither the problems nor their solutions are entirely about design. What Americans learn in school plays a role. As Karen Butler, executive director of Historic Philadelphia Inc. and Mayor Edward G. Rendell's chief adviser on historical tourism puts it, "We have more and more people coming here who know less and less." And no matter how cute you make Benjamin Franklin look, he's no Mickey Mouse.
Still, creating a place where people feel good, even moved, is important. Last month, the National Park Service began a search for a design team for Independence Mall, the largely empty esplanade of three superblocks that stretches nearly half a mile north from Independence Hall to the base of the Benjamin Franklin Bridge.
The specifications call for a site plan and design guidelines for several new buildings and public spaces that may be built there: a new pavilion for the Liberty Bell, a visitor center, a National Constitution Center and a replacement for an underground garage. But the real task is to create a transition zone that takes visitors out of their cars and gets them interested in all the real stuff the park and the city have to offer.
The plan is urgent because, after many years of neglect, money is beginning to flow into the park. The Pew Charitable Trusts is committed to providing most of the money for a visitor center that will serve both the park and the region. The garage operated by the Philadelphia Parking Authority beneath one block of the mall is to be rebuilt. The city has earmarked $1 million to design a new pavilion for the city-owned Liberty Bell, off the street and closer to Independence Hall. And the National Constitution Center, a private group chartered by Congress, is raising money for a substantial new museum filled with interactive exhibits that it is promoting as "America's project for the millennium."
All this activity has produced several generations of designs. Nearly two years ago, the National Constitution Center presented one in which its high-tech entertaining museum would take up most of the second block of the mall, with the Liberty Bell as its climax. This vision contrasted with the park service's own mall proposal, which would have changed hardly anything.
Last summer, Denise Scott Brown of Venturi Scott Brown & Associates, working for Pew, proposed a massive visitor center that would close the vista at the end of the first block, with the Liberty Bell at its core. (The third block, a little-used tree-filled square designed by Dan Kiley, is to be left alone for now.)
There are good reasons those building on the mall want to grab the Liberty Bell. It's where most tourists want to start, even though its story, a symbol of the antislavery movement during the second third of the 19th century, is chronologically the last of the stories the park attempts to tell.
Philadelphians will tell you that the current home of the Liberty Bell, an elegant though hardly monumental glass pavilion on Market Street, a block north of Independence Hall, is the historic area's biggest problem. It is not, but moving the bell will be a popular, and perhaps necessary, step.
The biggest problem is the mall itself. It offers plenty of room for the arrival and orientation of visitors without compromising any historic buildings. In fact, dozens and dozens of 19th-century buildings that would now be considered historic were razed to create it, but that all happened 40 years ago. It's hard to look at the mall, though, without concluding that it should not have happened.
The mall makes Independence Hall -- in its day one of the largest and most imposing buildings in North America -- look like a toy, an anticlimax of a baroque vista. And it is surrounded by a wall of huge, mostly undistinguished blocky institutional buildings of the 1960's and 70's.
This second-rate patch of Washington at its most inflated and imperial is wildly inappropriate as a setting to commemorate a small group of men coming together in a modest-size room who rashly and brilliantly invented a nation. The room's most precious artifact is an inkwell. But how are visitors to focus on something so small after they've been lost in space on the mall?
The plan proposed by Scott Brown last July sought to deal with the mistake of the mall largely by undoing it. Its approach was to use the visitor center to stop the vista down the mall after only one block. It also intended to relocate the only historic building left on the mall, a late 18th-century Quaker meeting house, to a site diagonally across from Independence Hall. The north side of the visitor center was to be a facade of neon and supergraphics recalling Robert Venturi's unbuilt billboard-based design of 1964 for the College Football Hall of Fame.
ALONG WITH THIS preferred design, Scott Brown proposed a second choice, with the visitor center going on the second block while the Liberty Bell stayed on the first. This formed the basis of the current Park Service plan, which the new designers are being asked to elaborate.
James Pickman, Pew's consultant on the mall, says Scott Brown's design accomplished what it was intended to do, to change the park designers' thinking and get people focused on the implications of the visitor center and the character of the mall. He said the foundation had not yet begun to select an architect for the visitor center.
Clearly, though, the desire to unmake the mall is more a polemic than a possibility. Independence Hall is what gives the mall its mystique. In theme park terms, it's the real, republican equivalent of Disneyland's fantastic royal castle. "The 'Monday Night Football' image -- the Liberty Bell with Independence Hall behind -- is really important," says Ernest Leonardo, director of comprehensive planning for the City Planning Commission, which has pressed the park to rethink the mall.
It is believed that if people can't see Independence Hall from the visitor center, they won't stop. But if a vista down a grand axis is out, will a glimpse from a second-story window be enough? And that's not the only feat the planners will be asked to perform. They are to find ways to connect the mall with the city as a whole, even though the mall is isolated by wide streets and huge structures. Will a view of an 18th-century spire from the bus drop-off do the trick?
How can the mall, an implicitly classical place, become asymmetrical, informal yet dignified, filled with tourists following their own interests yet going to all the places the park and the city want them to visit?
And assuming all these conundrums can be resolved, one large one will remain. However much visitors might want the mall to be like a theme park, it can never be one. It is a public place, one that must accommodate both Presidential speeches and the demonstrators who think the President is wrong. Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell may serve most of the time as backgrounds for photo ops, but they embody democracy, the rule of law and freedom.
The problem of Independence Mall is how to remake an embodiment of cold-war megalomania into a place where a sense of shared civic values is as real as the red brick of the buildings where America was invented.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Liberty Bell Pavilion and, behind it, the spire of Independence Hall--In its day the largest and most imposing building in North America, it now looks like a toy. (Bill Cramer for The New York Times)

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: February 9, 1997

SECTION: Section 2; Page 4; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1544 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
The Starry 'Three Sisters' Cast Reveals a Trend

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
ANTON CHEKHOV'S "THREE SISTERS" is a kind of New York perennial, popping up regularly in limited runs (a Russian production, in Russian, appeared at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater on Broadway in November) and in Off Broadway experiments (Richard Schechner's version last month, with each of the four acts set in a different time, will play an encore at La Mama from Feb. 26 through March 9). But rarely is it given a Tony-eligible staging, the kind of full-scale, conventionally interpreted treatment meant to withstand the scrutiny of Broadway audiences and critics.
That is the first thing to note about the Roundabout Theater Company production that opens at the Criterion Center on Thursday. But even more remarkable is its cast, a glamorous ensemble of performers -- including Amy Irving as Olga, Jeanne Tripplehorn as Masha and Lili Taylor as Irina, in addition to Billy Crudup, Calista Flockhart, Paul Giamatti, David Marshall Grant, Jerry Stiller, Eric Stoltz and David Strathairn. Many of them have passed up considerably more lucrative Hollywood projects to appear in Chekhov's melancholy, comic masterpiece about how lives go on in one place uneventfully while life goes on somewhere else. 
 Indeed, the production is perhaps the clearest signal yet of a mounting trend: the return, in appreciable numbers, of screen actors to the New York stage. For years, New York theater producers have lamented the loss of talented actors to film and television in Los Angeles. It was where the action, the notoriety, the money were: Have you seen Lily Tomlin, Swoosie Kurtz, Joan Allen, Jason Alexander, Adam Arkin, Scott Bakula, Annette Bening or Kevin Spacey, all Tony nominees in the late 1980's and early 90's, on a New York stage recently?
But now, just as Chekhov's troubled sisters yearn from a distance for the Moscow that once sustained them, so too do many actors, it appears, for New York. And not just the megastars like Al Pacino, who swoop in to great fanfare, do their thing and disappear. Or the coterie of well-known Broadway performers who supplement their livelihoods in film and television, people like Philip Bosco, Bernadette Peters, Nathan Lane, Frank Langella, Bebe Neuwirth, James Naughton and Tony Roberts.
Rather, there is a whole new group of younger actors -- among them Kevin Bacon, Kyra Sedgwick, Sarah Jessica Parker, Matthew Broderick, Anthony LaPaglia and Marisa Tomei, in addition to much of the cast of "Three Sisters" -- who are renewing the primacy of New York theater in the performers' firmament.
"There's a buzz," said Alan Eisenberg, executive secretary of Actors Equity, the actors' union. "I'm definitely hearing it from the membership. There's renewed interest in Broadway, and in playing in New York, which is not just Broadway." It's a difficult trend to document, though a list of crossover actors compiled by the union, "Famous Performers on Broadway, 1994-1997," runs to six single-spaced pages. "The ball is bouncing up," Mr. Eisenberg said, "and hasn't yet reached its apogee."
David Marshall Grant, who portrays Kulygin, the dullard married to Masha in "Three Sisters," said, "There's just a tremendous number of people living in actor cyberspace right now, that nonexistent, airplane-shaped place between L.A. and New York." Mr. Grant has played dozens of character roles in films and on television, but is nonetheless best known for his stage work, particularly for his role as Roy Cohn's reluctant protege in "Angels in America," for which he received a Tony nomination.
Why this is happening is also a matter of conjecture. Mr. Grant said that the ease of air travel -- "basically going from New York to L.A. is dinner and a movie" -- has had an impact. A number of performers said in interviews that a perceived revival of New York itself, combined with a perceived decline of Los Angeles, is a factor. Others cited the upsurge in film and television production in New York, the bull market on Wall Street, which has stimulated investment in theater productions, and the rise of independent film making in general.
Among Hollywood actors, "there's always been an interest," said Michael David of Dodger Productions, which produced "The King and I," starring the film actor Lou Diamond Phillips, and "Once Upon a Mattress" with Ms. Parker, both now on Broadway. The problem, Mr. David said, is that the long-term career cost of acting on stage had become untenable, "not just in terms of the money you don't make," but in the necessary time commitment.
Still, in persuading actors to come to Broadway, he said, "we found two things are compelling. One is the recent example of people who have come back and done it; not only did they feel good being here, but it turned out to be good for them to be here. The other is in creating an economic model that allows us to get our money out in a shorter period of time; that induces an actor to say yes."
The economic model almost invariably includes a nonexorbitant salary for the star; the Dodgers were able to bring "Hamlet," with Ralph Fiennes, to Broadway for 14 weeks two years ago largely because Mr. Fiennes took a salary Mr. David described as "wonderfully small."
"It's like, 'If I can do this and not give my life up entirely, why not?' " Mr. David said. "No disrespect, but if you were in the movie business, wouldn't you be looking for something else to do, at least for a little while?"
For many actors, film acting -- with the camera as the audience, scenes filmed out of sequence, hurry-up-and-wait work days and the finished product in the hands of a director and editor -- can be frustrating.
"In the theater, everything you do is about acting," Ms. Parker said. "In the movies, it's about a fifth, or an eighth."
Lanford Wilson, the playwright whose translation of "Three Sisters" is being used in the current production, added: "Actors are interested in acting, and there isn't a lot of acting going on in the stuff being made in Los Angeles."
Frustration is not limited to the set; the roles many actors are being offered in Hollywood do not provide much artistic sustenance. "You don't bother saying it anymore because everyone is saying it," Ms. Parker said, referring to the paucity of good parts in Hollywood movies. "And it's not even about being a woman any more. The choices I have are just not that satisfying."
For Mr. Stoltz, 35, whose screen work has included such films as "Mask," "Singles" and "Pulp Fiction," "Three Sisters" is his second New York play in a row. He said he turned down more lucrative film work to make $1,000 a week at the Roundabout (and considerably less in the Irish Repertory Theater's Off Broadway production of "The Importance of Being Earnest" last fall).
"It depends on how you define success," said Mr. Stoltz, an ordinarily debonair actor who plays the Baron, Irina's homely, doomed suitor, one of several actors whom the director, Scott Elliott, has cast against type. (Amy Irving as a spinster!) "Doing something like this is more enriching than doing a film. Ideally, we'd be getting $20 million to do Chekhov and people in silly movies would be getting B scale."
Mr. Stoltz was one of several in the "Three Sisters" cast who mentioned Chekhov as a compelling reason for signing on. Another is the ensemble nature of the play. "For me, the great joy is the rehearsal period," Ms. Irving said. "The interchange with the director and the other actors, the chance to come up with something you couldn't come up with by yourself. You don't get that in film. You can do a film and never meet your colleagues, and you're at the opening and it's 'Hey, nice to meet you.' "
Mr. Elliott, who was directing Off Off Broadway just a year ago, is now also represented on Broadway by "Present Laughter," and his fast-rising star proved to be part of the attraction. (He is himself testament to the new fluidity between New York and Hollywood; after "Three Sisters," he begins work on a film adaptation of Jane Hamilton's novel "A Map of the World," the first installment of his three-picture deal for Disney.)
The director said he was amazed at the ease with which he cast the play; everyone said yes right away, he said, and only one person pulled out. When Frances McDormand, who was originally cast as Masha, withdrew, she was replaced with a single phone call to Ms. Tripplehorn, who said it was equal parts Chekhov and Elliott that convinced her.
EVEN THE YOUNG STARS with burgeoning Hollywood careers -- like the 27-year-old Mr. Crudup (who plays Solyony, the eccentric soldier in love with Irina) and Ms. Flockhart (Natasha, the shrewish sister-in-law), who made a verbal, not contractual, commitment to the play six months ago -- stayed put. Ms. Flockhart, who is not yet 30, landed her first featured role last year, a plum, as the young fiancee in Mike Nichols's hit film "The Bird Cage." She has not auditioned for any potentially conflicting film since she accepted the role of Natasha in September.
But hypothetically?
"If I were offered a great commercial movie, I'd have to decide," she said, a little nervously. "But I'd have to say I'd pick this and hope the movies would still come around. Theater pays you back, not in cash but in a lot of other ways."
