HEADLINE: Plan to Cut Rates At Lilco Nearing Decision on Debt

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
FOR years it has been no secret that one way to cut Lilco rates would be to refinance the staggering debt for the Shoreham nuclear power plant with low-interest tax-exempt state bonds that customers would pay off.
Now, as the Long Island Power Authority, the state agency that can issue the bonds, moves closer to announcing a rate-cutting plan that would most likely have debt refinancing as a cornerstone, critics are attacking the approach as ill advised, anticompetitive, premature or simply wrong. 
 At issue is whether the State Public Service Commission, which is not directly involved in the power authority negotiations, could do more to lower electric rates on Long Island.
For many months, the power authority has been working to carry out Gov. George E. Pataki's pledge to cut electric rates on the Island by at least 10 percent. The Public Service Commission has played a secondary role during this period. The commission chairman, John F. O'Mara, said last week that the agency would await the outcome of the L.I.P.A. plan before taking action on Lilco rates.
Any L.I.P.A. agreement would need the approval of the Governor, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Brooklyn, and the Senate Majority Leader, Joseph L. Bruno, Republican of Rensselaer.
Critics of the P.S.C, said the regulatory agency had failed to take steps to reduce significantly or eliminate the more than $4 billion that Lilco is owed under an agreement in 1989 to close the $5.5 billion plant. Some critics said that when interest was included, the payment under the agreement would be $7 billion.
"The Public Service Commission can order Lilco to write off its stranded asset, the Shoreham nuclear power plant, tomorrow morning, and the rates can drop by one-third," a utility economist, Gregory A. Palast of Southold, said. "They control this company. They have absolute power over it."
Mr. Palast and others said the 1989 pact was binding for just three years. A crucial part of the accord, which the P.S.C. adopted, created a regulatory asset representing the investment of the Long Island Lighting Company in Shoreham that allowed the utility to recover those costs in rates that are the highest in the country except for Hawaii.
Last week the chairman of the commission, Mr. O'Mara, said he believed that the 1989 agreement, with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, remained binding and could not be altered without exposing the state to a successful legal challenge.
"I have been outspoken in the past about how disastrous I think the Shoreham settlement was for the people of Long Island," said Mr. O'Mara, whom Gov. George E. Pataki appointed as chairman. "They are now paying about 24 percent of the rates to pay for that settlement," and would continue to pay for 30 or more years.
"However," Mr. O'Mara said, "the advice I got from our legal staff and my own conclusion is that nothing could be done short of creating liability for the state."
An expert on utility finances, Charles M. Studness, said the commission could alter rates without directly addressing the agreement, adding, "The P.S.C. has extraordinary flexibility."
Others said the commission had less latitude. "Given the legal constraints under which the commission is operating, it could not do significantly more than it has done," said Matthew T. Crosson, president of the Long Island Association. Mr. Crosson said the business group would withhold comments on a plan by the Long Island Power Authority until after it had been proposed and analyzed. "What we don't want to see happen is that everyone on Long Island is surprised by the consequences of a deal," he said.
Some business interests reportedly have misgivings about a plan that would involve bonds that the authority would repay through electric rates. Such an approach could create a situation in which the authority would oppose new forms of competition because of the need to pay off the bonds.
The cost of the bonds would also be reflected in the cost of electricity, adding to the cost that entrepreneurs could import. The chairman of the power authority, Frank G. Zarb, has said the plan will be announced by next month.
Last week Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said that Mr. Zarb would deliver the best plan possible to cut rates and that it was not credible that Mr. Zarb and others, including a trustee of the authority, Richard M. Kessel, would be involved with a rate reduction that ignored an opportunity for customers to save.
"I don't blame people for being concerned," Mr. D'Amato said. "I certainly want the highest possible rate reduction. I am for whatever plan will do that."
He added: "We are limited" by the 1989 agreement, which "does not permit what some of these people are advocating." He said he had been told by officials in the Pataki administration that the plan of the power authority could save customers up to $300 million a year.
A former Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein, said the expected authority plan dwarfed considerations of whether the P.S.C. had done enough to lower rates.
Mr. Klein, Mr. Kessel and a number of business leaders joined Lilco in September to oppose a 5 percent rate cut that the commission was considering. They said the cuts would harm electric service and reliability. The commission postponed a vote and has not rescheduled one.
"The reality is that the rate proceedings have been totally subsumed by the prospective humongous complicated combination of the merger and some kind of a deal by the power authority," Mr. Klein said. "It's like two bugs struggling over a crumb when they are about to be run over by a steamroller."
The Energy Rate Reduction Council, a new coalition of 13 large Long Island retailers and the Association for a Better Long Island, a developers' group, took a different position.
Harry Davitian, president of Entek Power Services of Setauket and a spokesman for the council, told a State Assembly committee last month that any sale of state bonds to finance a plan by the power authority should be carried out only after the P.S.C. had taken steps to lower rates, if at all.
"The commission has let this important effort fade into oblivion," Mr. Davitian said. "We are deeply troubled by the seeming unwillingness of the commission to carry through with this process it began with so much promise."
Mr. Davitian said the commission "should establish a long-term rate plan with price caps that lower Lilco's rates to levels that reflect market prices over a reasonable period of time. There is nothing sacrosanct about the 1988-1989 Shoreham settlement."
In an interview, Mr. O'Mara also dismissed a widely heard view that Mr. Pataki had directed the commission to suspend proceedings to lower Lilco rates while the power authority negotiated with Lilco.
"Because the discussions have been going forward between the Long Island Power Authority, Lilco and Brooklyn Union," Mr. O'Mara said, "it seemed to me to be just a matter of common sense that we not act precipitously to interfere with what I think reasonably holds out the promise for double-digit rate decreases on Long Island. We have not been asked to hold our proceeding in abeyance by the Governor."
Other critics contend that Mr. Pataki and Mr. D'Amato, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, prefer a rate reduction that would include a bond sale because that would be lucrative for their supporters on Wall Street.
"If you deliver to Wall Street $200,000 to $300,000 in various kinds of fees, certainly this is going to come back to them in nice amounts," Mr. Studness said. "That is the driving force behind this. That is why D'Amato and Pataki prefer L.I.P.A over the P.S.C."
Mr. D'Amato said that was absurd, adding: "It's horrible. It doesn't deserve comment."
Mr. D'Amato confirmed a widely held belief that he had been promoting an authority plan to cut rates. "Am I encouraging it?" he said. "You'd better believe it."
Another issue before the P.S.C. is the proposed merger between Lilco and Brooklyn Union Gas. The utilities, which announced a plan on Dec. 28, said a merger would save $1 billion over 10 years.
Mr. O'Mara said last week that "any plan that holds out double-digit rate relief" deserved consideration. He said that the merger, as he understood it, was "the first step in a process which will then have the merged companies negotiating with the Long Island Power Authority to complete the other action."
Critics said the merger, which many of them oppose, and the power authority's assumption of the Shoreham debt would weigh against electric and gas competition on Long Island far into the future, denying the region lower prices that competition could bring.
Wayne Prospect, a former Suffolk County Legislator who is an adviser to the Hauppauge Industrial Association, said his group was "opposing the proposed merger, because it is contingent on Lilco's ratepayers paying monopoly prices for electricity."
The association is a member of another new coalition of business, civic and environmental groups that opposes the merger and refinancing of the Shoreham debt.
"The best way to deal with the Shoreham debt is for Albany to force Lilco to write it off as a bad debt," Mr. Prospect said. "Don't transform it into a public debt."

HEADLINE: PERSPETIVES;
The New Approach in Arverne: Incrementalism

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
HOW do you give a two-family New York City house a "beachy" look?
That is one of the problems the architects face in designing houses for the Rockaway peninsula in Queens, where the Briarwood Organization, a development company based in Bayside, has won the city's designation to develop 161 unsubsidized two-family houses -- a total of 322 housing units -- on 15 acres of vacant land. 
 It will be the first time in the 35-year history of the 302-acre Arverne urban renewal site that a market-rate development has been built -- that is, one in which no public funds will be used to reduce rents or sales prices to a level affordable to an income-targeted population. At the Briarwood development there will be no governmentally prescribed limitations on the income of buyers.
Briarwood's architect, Fakler/Eliason & Associates of Fresh Meadows, Queens, would like to satisfy the Department of Housing Preservation and Development's wish to see a house that reflects the near-the-waterfront location of the property. Complicating its task is the fact that Briarwood is a masonry-wall and concrete-plank builder, and the facade touches that might be considered beachy are harder to produce in that construction form, the architect says, than they are in wood-frame houses.
Design is in its early stages now that Briarwood has the contract to produce houses on empty land between Beach 74th Street and Beach 72d Street, as well as various infill sites between Beach 61st Street and Beach 59th Street. The houses are expected to go on the market for about $210,000 to $225,000 each, for earliest occcupancy next spring. The developer expects home prices to rise over time, perhaps to $245,000 to $250,000 during a sales period that will likely run until mid-1999.
"We'll probably have balconies on the buildings that are three stories," said Edward C. Eliason, the architect, "but we're still trying to decide what 'beachy' means." The builder has the idea that color will help. The brick on the facade is expected to be a light gray instead of dark red, and the roof shingles and building trim will probably be done in light blue.
There will also be a private road network within the enormous block -- the site runs 880 feet on 73d Street and 900 feet of 74th Street, so that the outdoor parking can be on-site -- within the block -- rather than on the street, with half the homes in clusters of separate buildings facing inward, and the rest facing the street, something like dominos placed at right angles to each other.
Complementing the housing development will be 75,000 square feet of new stores on land between Beach 73d Street, Rockaway Beach Boulevard and Beach 69th Street, a 200,000-square-foot site, with offstreet parking. Jobco Inc. of Great Neck, L.I., and Halmar Construction Corporation in Mount Vernon are the designated developers.
ALL of this represents the new shift to incrementalism in developing the largely barren Arverne urban renewal tract. In the late 80's during the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, developers were invited to submit proposals for building out the entire site over many years, providing a minimum of 7,000 housing units, or as many as 10,000, and handling the infrastructure development costs themselves. A team headed by Forest City Enterprises, based in Cleveland, bid $90 million for the land and was selected as the developer. Its plan envisioned an eventual 7,500 new housing units.
Interestingly, the Briarwood Organization itself was part of a different development team that lost out with a bid of $60 million. "We were lucky we didn't get it," said Vincent L. Riso, president of Briarwood. Forest City Enterprises is said to have spent over $2 million in developing plans for the site, which were never used because the bottom dropped out of the real estate market in the early 90's.
Now the planning for future development has started over, with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens announcing the appointment of the consulting firm of Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Alschuler, of Manhattan, to do a six-month market study to figure out what form of development should be undertaken.
On that score, local residents have already made known their preferences through the urban renewal committee of Community Board 14. It has called for a maximum of 400 two-family houses (800 units) on the west end of the urban renewal site (from Beach 73d Street to Beach 59th Street), and no housing at all on the east end (Beach 59th Street to Beach 32d Street).
Instead, the committee wants to see diversified economic-development projects -- such as a resort hotel and conference center, or an ocean museum and learning center, or an indoor amusement center. "There is a feeling that a good portion needs to be kept in its natural state," said Delores Orr, head of the committee.
Historically, there has been an enormous public investment in clearing the urban renewal land for new development. It happened mainly in the 60's and 70's. Even the earlier extension of the subway system to the Rockaways was predicated on the idea that the peninsula should undergo major development. Much public housing or otherwise government-assisted high-rise housing was also built, much of it outside the urban renewal area. But the days of public subsidies with which to build new high-rise housing exclusively for occupancy by people who cannot afford market rents or prices is past.
Apart from lengthy controversy over what form new development in Arverne should take, there was the question in the 70's and beyond of how the high cost of infrastructure development would be borne. The strong real-estate market of the 80's seemed to hold the answer -- private developers would pay. But by the time the city got around to implementing that policy, the market opportunity had passed.
THE plan was to get a development team to take on the burden of the estimated $200 million that was needed for storm and sanitary sewers, a sanitary sewer pumping station, a 48-inch-wide water main and pipes, a six-lane boulevard, 45 acres of new public parkland, a firehouse and two 600-seat elementary schools. The Forest City team planned to develop condominium housing over many years and sell at prices that would justify its investment.
Even in the 80's many builders doubted the feasibility of the city's plan, despite generally encouraging market conditions. But on the sites that have been awarded by the Giuliani administration, the infrastructure investment needed is relatively modest. And Briarwood is paying $5,000 per house (or $2,500 per housing unit) for the land.
From the public sector will come $7 million for sewer and water connections, streets and curbs for the new residences and stores. Half the money is coming from city funds and the other half from discretionary funds available to the Queens Borough President.
Her contribution calls attention to what has been a growing role by Borough Presidents outside Manhattan to use discretionary funds to boost housing production. According the the office of City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden allocated $6 million for housing over the three-year 1995-1997 period, and Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer allocated $5.1 million.
Ms. Shulman also said she was using $1.75 million of her funds to help advance relocation and property acquisition for new houses that are eventually to be built under the New York Housing Partnership program on 134 acres in the Edgemere section of Rockaway Peninsula, with sales restricted to households earning roughly $25,000 to $70,000 a year.
The site is just north of the eastern section of Arverne, between Beach 30th and Beach 50th Streets. There are to be 800 housing units in 400 owner-occupied two-family homes, mainly on infill land amid already existing housing. The plan is expected to be ready for public land-use review, following preliminary examination by the Department of City Planning, within the next month.

HEADLINE: Skepticism Over School Pledge

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
WHAT appears at first glance to be good news from Albany for the schools -- increased state aid, assurances of no cuts to districts and reduced property taxes -- has been met with cautious enthusiasm and some skepticism from Westchester superintendents.
"It sounds like we're getting all this money, but I'm still trying to understand it,"said Dr. Marjorie E. Castro, Superintendent of the Croton-Harmon School District. "Probably we're not getting more money. Districts have been getting less state aid in the last few years. We're dealing with certioraris, and our tax base is shrinking. We're going to have a difficult year, and as we prepare our budget, we're going to talk about realities and what we think we're going to get." 
 Dr. Frank Tota, Superintendent of the Dobbs Ferry School District, said, "The Governor's overall state approach is excellent, but it may not do any good for Westchester."
Among Gov. George E. Pataki's proposalsannounced last month was a provision to reduce property taxes in the next four years and increase state aid to districts to help make up the difference. State aid to schools, currently at $10.2 billion, would be increased by $302 million under the Governor's plan.
The Governor's $1.7 billion school property tax cut would be mirrored by an additional $1.7 billion in state aid, which would be phased in during the next four years. Under this proposal, Mr. Pataki called for annual school tax increases of no more than 4 percent, or the rate of inflation, whichever would be lower. There would be exceptions to that regulation in the case of enrollment increases, a two-thirds district vote and additional first-time revenue from new taxable construction.
Some superintendents are skeptical of what they perceive as a political gambit in negotiations between the Legislature and the Governor's office. "The Governor is trying to control educational costs, and thinks he is doing everybody a favor,"said Dr. Stanley Toll, Superintendent of the Ardsley School District. "Taking a number like 4 percent is ridiculous. It's a number out of thin air. My costs for health care are going to go up, and I can't control inflation."
Dr. Ronald Valenti, Superintendent of the Harrison School District, said: "I endorse any effort to reduce the burden on the local taxpayer. But much of the tax-rate increases today were caused by state aid cuts in 1990. I'd like to see the state restore us to the aid level we were receiving in 1990. The problem was caused by Albany."
To many superintendents, the package appears appealing, but most of them say they would like to see more concrete figures to justify the Governor's plan. Many districts still face the burden of repaying certiorari claims against them by corporations and local businesses and are not expecting compensatory revenue increases.
"We're pleased to see the Governor is focusing on support for education from Albany," said Dr. Donald Kusel, Superintendent in the district serving Tarrytown and Sleepy Hollow. "I'm curious to see how he is going to be able to increase aid to education, reduce property taxes and give a tax cut on the state income tax."
Some superintendents are worried that residents, especially older ones, are receiving an unclear and incomplete message about the budget's perceived benefits. "The Governor is proposing a huge tax relief in general, not Rye Neck in particular," said Peter Mustich, Superintendent of the Rye Neck schools. "It's not a big windfall for Rye Neck. I'm also concerned about the difficulty we may face in presenting the budget if the Governor keeps telling senior citizens they will be seeing tax cuts."
Given the burdensome nature of the seasonal budget ritual, with such uncertainties about final state aid numbers from Albany, it might seem as if districts would be tempted to look at their nonprofit school foundations as auxiliary partners in the budget process.
Despite the increasing prevalence of the foundations, which have been established in the last few years to help provide amenities not usually included in the basic school budget, superintendents are clear about the function these foundations serve.
"We have an explicit mission statement not to substitute for money in our operating budget,"said Dr. John A. Chambers, Superintendent of the Bronxville schools. "Our foundation offers opportunities to strengthen curriculum and to act as a catalyst for new programs."
Most of the time, the line between district expenses and foundation support is clear. In Rye Neck, for example, school officials and members of the Parent-Teacher Association are not members of the foundation board. "We've been very cautious," said Mr. Mustich, who as Superintendent visits the foundation twice a year to discuss the district's goals. "None of our community-fund people have overlapping roles. We tried to get diverse community members, so the foundation would develop programs for the community at large."
Dr. Valenti said: "At no time did we suggest that our foundation assume any of the responsibilities of the district. If a district is not clear on that point from the beginning, it can be slippery. The role of our foundation is to provide seed money for projects and to complement our regular budget. The foundation will supplement what the voters provide, not supplant it."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
New Canaan Acts to Condemn Rental Complex Site

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
IN almost five years of bickering between New Canaan and Avalon Properties over the developer's proposal to build a mixed-use project on Elm Street, the state's courts have consistently ruled against the town.
Nevertheless, the town has appropriated $5 million to buy the property through its power of eminent domain and condemn it for use as a municipal parking lot. 
 While condemnation itself is not unusual, both Jay Sandak, Avalon's lawyer, and Robert W. Reeves, the lawyer representing the town, agree that this is the first time that any municipality in the state has attempted to take property that the courts have previously ruled must be allowed to be developed as planned.
Condemnation was approved in a nonbinding referendum last December by a 2 to 1 vote of some 3,600 townspeople out of a total population of 18,150.
But at a hearing last Monday in Superior Court in Stamford before Judge William B. Lewis in which Avalon sought a temporary injunction to halt the town's action, Avalon agreed not to start construction and the town agreed not to proceed with condemnation pending the results of a lawsuit by Avalon scheduled to start in April.
The suit will challenge New Canaan's effort to condemn and its ability to do so under Connecticut law requiring the exercise of good faith in condemnation proceedings. "I think this is a proper course to follow," said Mr. Sandak.
Avalon, which is based in Wilton, optioned the New Canaan site in 1991, and in the next two years it filed five proposals for rental apartments, stores and offices, each time complying with new suggestions or mandates by New Canaan's Planning and Zoning Commission.
In 1992 the commission unanimously approved a zoning change for the project but subsequently denied applications for site plan approval, based on density, height, setbacks, unsuitability to the neighborhood and other complaints.
Twenty-one of the 104 apartments in the project were to be priced about $1,000 below the market rate of around $2,000 to $2,500 in accordance with the state's affordable housing law of 1989. The law gives developers offering a fifth of their total units to buyers whose incomes do not exceed 80 percent of the area's median (in this case, the median is $74,000) a density bonus of 20 percent.
In addition, the law shifts the burden of proof in denying such applications to the municipality. The developer formerly had to show compliance with regulations and provide assurance that no harm would come to the community. Now the towns must prove that the development is detrimental to the community in order to deny an application.
In 1993 Avalon filed an appeal in Superior Court in Hartford. In 1994 the commission agreed to a compromise negotiated as a result of a stipulated judgment by the court, but soon withdrew its approval. In 1995 Judge A. William Mottolese overturned the commission's action, ruling that "the record fails to reveal any evidence of the nature or extent of any claimed detrimental effect on neighboring properties" and "the commission has failed to sustain the burden of proof that its decision is necessary to protect substantial public interest in health, safety or other zoning matters."
The town appealed, but the Appellate Court affirmed the lower court ruling in 1996, and the State Supreme Court refused to hear the case when approached by the town that same year.
Avalon plans to take whatever additional legal action is necessary to eventually build 104 rental apartments and 15,000 square feet of stores and offices in the project it calls Town Close. "New Canaan started out believing that they would wear us down," said Charles Berman, president and chief executive of Avalon, "but they won't."
"New Canaan is not atypical," said Timothy Hollister, Avalon's Hartford lawyer. "Being told by the state that they have to provide affordable housing has generated wrath in many towns."
HE said that an informal survey under way by lawyers, developers and municipal consultants showed that only 120 units had been completed under the law, due in part to the recession of the early 90's. But 650 units have been approved and are seeking financing, he added, and 600 more are in litigation.
"We don't think this is a case about affordable housing," said Mr. Reeves of Cummings & Lockwood in Stamford, the town's lawyer. "If the town has been slow to condemn this most important piece of property to solve its parking problems, no town is anxious to spend a lot of money to condemn someone's property."
According to Peter Murphy, New Canaan's administrative officer, more than $50,000 has been spent on legal fees, and $5.25 million has been appropriated to buy the site and develop a parking lot. "If a higher purchase price is set by the courts," he said, "the town is committed to pay it." Avalon's costs for land acquisition, architectural, legal and engineering fees have exceeded $6 million.
Opposition to the New Canaan project has been led by Citizens for New Canaan, described as a charitable trust by its founding member, Dudley C. Phillips, a local lawyer.
"I could see from the beginning that Avalon wanted to pack the property with as much as possible, not consistent with anything else in town," he said. "We raised $15,000 to pay for petitions soliciting the referendum and the campaign to persuade voters to overturn the Town Council's original vote not to condemn the property."
After the referendum the Town Council reversed itself and voted 11 to 1 in favor of condemnation. "In a democracy," said John Heatherington, a Council member who switched his vote to approve condemnation, "there's always a certain tension between the duty to exercise independent judgment and the duty to carry out what your constituents expect you to do."
Said Richard Bond, the First Selectman: "Parking is the only issue in this matter as far as I'm concerned." Referring to a 1972 study, he noted that "the town then needed 700 parking spaces."
"In 1986 the town business plan suggested that the town acquire the Elm Street property for parking," he said. "With growth in population we need 800 spaces. The Elm Street lot would give us 370."
AVALON offered to make 170 spaces available to commuters out of 309 underground spaces planned in its project; the town offered Avalon $5 million for the site. Both offers were refused.
"Those spaces would only be available if Avalon's tenants weren't using them," explained Mr. Bond.
"We are paying taxes on $6 million and a completed development would be worth millions more," said Mr. Berman of Avalon's rejection of the town's offer.
James Bennett, a lawyer and a 10-year member of the Planning and Zoning Commission, most recently as its chairman, was not reappointed at the end of his three-year term in December. "I was the only one scratched," he said. Considered a moderate voice on the commission, he said, "I don't have an answer to why a development looking so much like the rest of town was rejected."
"Parking is not the problem, there are vacant lots," said Carl Kuehner, a developer of high-end homes who grew up in New Canaan. "A number of my peers have moved away because they can't afford it. The town itself hasn't sat down and come up with a compromise. It can write large checks for appeals." During a 15-year history of the site, Earl Smith, the former owner, tried unsuccessfully to sell it to the town. His efforts to develop an office building failed to attract financing during the recent recession, and he completed a sale to Avalon in 1995 for $4.35 million, after Avalon had obtained a favorable court ruling.
Leo E. Karl 3d, whose family has owned the Karl Chevrolet dealership on Elm Street since 1927, is concerned with the rights of the private property owner. "If I put an extension on my house and the neighbors didn't like it," he asked, "could they go to the town and have my house condemned and take it?"
